Hello Folks!

 The next World Science Fiction convention , commonly called Worldcon , 
is coming to San Francisco on the Labor Day weekend . The name of this 
year's Worldcon is ConFrancisco. I've been trying to arrange a special 
birds-of-a-feather meeting with the ConFrancisco committee , and it 
looks like my efforts have succeeded!

 My meeting is set for Sept. 3rd , Friday afternoon, from 3PM to 5PM. 
The meeting is meant for people who are both "fen"  and ravers! ( The 
term "fen" means fans of science fiction and fantasy ). I want it be an 
opportunity for folks from all over the world to compare the experiences 
of raving and SF&F fandom . " Can fen dance to techno/house ? Can ravers 
read anything more complex than party flyers ? "

 I am also arranging for sound system support , and I'll probably be 
able to play music from cassettes and CDs , to give the attendees an 
idea of the type of music that our local DJs put out.

 => Where I need help from my fellow SFRavers - I would like to show 
videotapes and slides of local raves , and would appreciate the loan of 
same from anybody on the mail list. I already have the Connection II and 
the FMR videotapes - are there any available from the Richmond Civic 
Center events ? Also , for completeness sake , Toon Town or Cyberfest?



					Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

 Southbay SFR Lunch Reminder
 
 
 Just a quick reminder to let everyone know about
 today's SFR Lunch ...
 
 When: Thursday, Aug. 5th   
 Time: 12.00 noon
 Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto
 
 Directions:
 
 * From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
 
 * Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
   (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)
 
 * Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (past apartment complexes on right)
   
 * You will see the park on your right hand side. Park in the first
   carpark to your right.
 
 * We'll meet on the grassy knoll, under the trees behind the backstop.
 
 Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!
 
 				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com    )

greetings, all.

speaking of music . . . just talked to my rep at Formula in New York a couple
days ago:  she's sent me two new releases -- the new Orbital and an ffrr (full
frequency range recordings) compilation tape (we're rockin' the Wired warehouse
with 'em even as i write).

also, Orbital is just winding up a UK tour called "Midi-Circus," and are
planning a similar tour in the US with other artists within the same
ambient/house circles.  keep your eyes and ears peeled; the Midi-Circus ship
should be landing on our continent sometime in the second or third week of
august.

also, before i sign off, a "heads up" on a few more releases soon to be out: 
U96, "Replugged" -- September; VapourSpace, "Gravitational Arch of 10" --
September; One Dove, (not sure of the title yet) -- October.

don't know if we'll be able to break away from impending deadlines long enough
to check YSH tonight, but do some raving for us in case we can't make it.  (if
we do show up, i'll be the one with long dark purple hair and really short
bangs.)  L8R!

peace,
=:)
kristin spence
assistant editor
wired magazine





From sfraves-owner  Thu Aug  5 12:10:12 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA13617; Thu, 5 Aug 93 12:10:12 PDT
Received: from mindvox.phantom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA13610; Thu, 5 Aug 93 12:10:07 PDT
Received: by mindvox.phantom.com (Smail3.1.28.1 #5)
	id m0oOAlb-0009FLC; Thu, 5 Aug 93 15:14 EDT
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Cc: ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu
Subject: Home Again
From: inhuman@mindvox.phantom.com (Inhuman)
Comments: Feed Your Head
Message-Id: <HXPT8B2w165w@mindvox.phantom.com>
Date: Thu, 05 Aug 93 15:13:40 EDT
Organization: [Phantom Access] / the MindVox system
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Well I'm finally home again after my west coast excursion.  Just wanted to
say thanks to all the sfravers for their friendliness and hospitality
(esp. Leah & Cindy for lodging).  You all have a terrific scene out there
and a terrific city in general.  Don't take it for granted!  :)

Just a brief review of all the events I went to so you can see an
east-coaster's perspective on things:

Ben & Dan met me, Kreig, and Jason at the airport in LA and we drove
straight to SF,hoping to catch some of Unity.  It took us a hell of a
long time (11 hours), because we were in the overloaded Wundervan which
couldn't seem to get above 50-55 mph.  We finally got to Unity around
6am.  It was worth it!  We danced for an hour or so until it ended.  I
wish we could have gotten there earlier, but getting in for free was also
nice.

Next was Tilt-A-Whirl on Monday night.  This was a fiasco from the
beginning.  We parked in the vague vicinity of the address hoping to find
it by foot.  We immediately ran into another group of people also trying
to find it.  Someone from the group came up to us and said "I'm tripping
hardcore man, but I think I know where it is.  Follow me!"  With a
reasonable amount of trepidation, we followed behind him.  He lead us all
over the place and finally to the club where Tilt-A-Whirl was.  It turned
out it was two blocks from our car and we had gone in this big U-shaped
path.  :)  When we finally did get inside there were only like ten people
there, maybe two of which were dancing.  Damn.  The DJ was playing some
mediocre house music.  One of the two people dancing was this guy who
looked like the lead singer of the Spin Doctors doing the I'm-on-acid
shuffle.  We danced for a little bit and then the second DJ came on.  The
BPM dropped by about 20 as he put on some real old school electro Beat
Street Electric Avenue type music.  This completely cleared the
dancefloor except for the Spin Doctors guy.  Then about five minutes into
the set the Spin Doctors guy GOES CRAZY!  He starts break-dancing,
spinning on his shoulders and stuff.  It was hilarious and incredible,
because he was the last guy there who anyone would expect to start
breakdancing.  We eventually left when it was clear that this wasn't where
it was at that night.

We spent the next couple of days and nights exploring San Francisco and
Berkeley.  Finally on Thursday night we headed to Your Sister's House.  I
was really looking forward to this because I'd heard so much about it.  We
got there around 9:30, in time for some of the discussion.  I like the
concept of having a round-table discussion before raving, but this just
sort of exceeded my hokeyness-meter.  People were taking themselves a
*little* too seriously.  One woman said "What were doing right here, we
could be executed for it!  It's treason!  The government is violently
afraid of this kind of discussion!"  Nevertheless, it was interesting and
any kind of discussion is a step in the right direction.  Once the music
got going and more people came, the party got moving.  It was a lot of fun
and the music was great.  It just goes to show you don't need to be Jeno
or Garth to totally move a crowd.  The last DJ spun a really good hard
acid set, too!  I was entirely surprised.  I had left my love for that
kind of music on the east coast, thinking I wouldn't need it in SF.  But
everyone was digging it (including me).  The night would have been perfect
had things not ended so badly for us: The Wundervan got broken into.  They
took Dan's banjo & traveller's checks & his vinyl 70's-style jacket.  It
was such a weird thief.  He didn't even take my backpack or the camera
which was right next to the traveller's checks.

On Saturday we headed to Basics.  When we first got there, things felt
real strange.  I couldn't really get into it.  I kept wandering around
from place to place, feeling like Carlos Casteneda trying to find "his
spot."  Finally after the place started to clear out a bit, I got into
Markie's set a bit and started moving.  When Tony came on, he set me into
a frenzy.  After maybe ten minutes of Tony's set, I started getting this
sharp pain in my toes.  I stopped dancing and set down and took off my
shoes to see what it was.  I had these two big blisters, one on each of my
middle toes.  And they had already popped.  Ouch.  I was really upset
because I really wanted to dance to Tony's incredible set.  I wandered
around and eventually found some gaffer's tape and bound up my toes.  It
felt much better and I kept on dancing.  Yay!  After that, I didn't want
to rest even though the outdoor chill space was way cool.  We finally left
sometime in the morning.  It was cool how they gave away free fruit in the
morning, too.  A fun party, once things got going.

I slept most of the day Sunday, in preparation for the FMR, our last night
in San Francisco.  First was Leah's lovely barbeque, though.  After that,
with the Wundervan loaded to capacity, we headed up to the FMR site.  It
was a beautiful drive.  We finally got there around 3:00, I think.  You
know the rest of the story with that site.  It was still an incredibly
beautiful site and just being there with all these other people was fun
enough, even if there wasn't any music.  We got lost on the way back to
Berkeley and didn't get to the Marina until 8:30 (a three hour drive).
Once things finally got moving, we danced and danced.  Markie spun a long
long set.  Three hours.  Wow.  It had its ups and downs, but we were all
happy when Garth finally came on.  We left around 2pm, but the party was
still going strong, with joggers occaisionally wandering by to dance.  It
was a fun last day in SF.

The 12 hour drive back down to LA was awful.  It was hot as hell and the
Wundervan's heating was broken so we couldn't shut off the heat.  Ugh!  We
finally made it to Joachim's around 3.  (Thanks Joachim!)

All in all, it was a very fun trip.  Thanks to all those who made it so.
I think my next ticket will be one-way.  Give me a couple years...

Michael                 |  groovin' in the chocolate city!
(inhuman@phantom.com)   |  <PGP Key Available Upon Request>

Hi everybody!

Tonight again, Your Sisters' House is the main attraction.  I'm not
sure about Friday, maybe Mission Rock is your best bet again.  
Corduroy City is new, don't know how it went last week.  I think
Francesco on KZSU Tuesday said there would be a Gathering on Friday,
but there's no message on the Gathering line (415.267.4800).

Saturday, Groove Kitchen returns with a strong lineup of underrated
DJs, the Fridge opens at Big Heart City, and Where the Wild Things Are
could be fun too, but avoid it if it's at 16th & Harrison :) ...

debatable, but they were advertised by fliers and the music could be
good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their 
appropriateness in being on the list, let me know....

Hi Kyle,

Well, looks like this has evolved and mutated into FreeVibe!!! :-) It's
free, lot's of people in the community will contributing their time and
energy.  This will be a dress rehearsal for the next FMR. I've done up the
flyers and we're gonna do it Saturday, Aug. 7.   The info line is 726-8077.
We're in the process of setting up the logistics.  So far, we have Pete
Ashdown, Donald Glaude (aka Dominator aka Steve Austin), Brad Shaw,
Dervish, on the DJ line up.  If you want to spin or know anyone else let me
know.  

Tigger

I cross posted to sfraves cuz I thought that you sfravers might be
interested in seeing what kind of trouble Pete's getting himself into up
here in the great north west!  :-)   Peace y'all!!  Also, hi and hugz to
Wigli Boy (Greg), Renee, and Pat Lui, who are all in the Bay Area!!! 
Tig

From: Kyle Farrell on Thu, Aug 5, 1993 12:07 PM
Subject: city ordinances
To: Glenn Fajardo,USA

I'm not a lawyer (although i play one on tv), but seattle cops have never
really liked the "rave" scene as you probably know.  The city would
probably do anything they can to stop us once they saw a soundsystem being
set up with a bunch of people around.
Like it or not, this is going to be a renegade party like the last one! 
The best we can do is look for a spot where cops won't find us & neighbors
won't complain. btw- where is the Garcia concert?  IMHO, i don't think
there will be tons of people in the parking lot ready to dance around to
some tunes.
If your willing to drive about 20 minutes east of Seattle, I know of a
spot that would work pretty good- it was one we were considering for the
fmr a month and a half ago.  what day is this scheduled for?  
hope this turns out good!
kyle

From sfraves-owner  Thu Aug  5 13:56:41 1993

Subject: CII tapes -- high bias?

	From looking at the media of the tapes (nice music,so far, as
I'm listening to it right now..) I noticed that it's black, thus it's
not a normal bias tape. But the case doesn't have the indicator on it
so a deck which auto-detects high bias based on the indicator (such as
the one it's playing on right now) will assume the tape is normal bias
and sound quality apparently suffers. (I haven't had time to compare
with a manual-switch deck, as I just picked upthe tapes today.)
	While this doesn't really matter to *me* as my own deck
doesn't auto-detect, (my own deck really sucks and doesn't even do
dolby decoding or bias adjustment.) is it possible to make the holes
with human tools? I've never tried it.. (for obvious reasons..) Maybe
someone knows how?
	(Nice tapes, even still.)

	Peace,

Date: Thu, 5 Aug 93 15:26:16 PDT
From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
To: zane@genesis.mcs.com
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: Sameer Parekh's message of Thu, 5 Aug 1993 17:09:35 -0500 (CDT) <m0oODVA-000ZCjC@genesis.mcs.com>
Subject: CII tapes -- high bias?
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


they are BASF Chrome + (cobalt) tape.  they are professionally
duplicated.  as is the case with many high quality pro-dup tapes,
(starting with "The Police -- Synchronicity" way back in the mid 80s,
the first major release on chrome tape) the tape is specially
formulated to playback as normal bias.  I.E. the lack of tape type
keyholes on the top is 100% correct.  (recording over storebought
tapes is always dumb, they aren't meant to be recorded on home
equipment, regardless of setting.)

for future reference, there are a few very dark type I tapes out
there, notably some Fuji and Denon formulations... so that's not a
reliable indicator generally.

imho and from my experience selling the tapes, the sound quality
should be very high, if not, you've probably got dirty heads on the
deck.  clean and demagnetize the deck before you go punching holes in
the tape shells :-)

Bob

Beyond the ultraworld of SCRUTON@joyce.dnet.hac.com:
> 
> On the synth side, the all-time bargain has to be the Kawai series of Midi
>   boxes (also available with keyboards)
> 
> You can get a box with tons of sounds (orchestra, synth, percussion) for 
>   about $250.

On the sampler synth side, the all-time bargain has to be the Gravis Ultrasound
PC soundcard... I'm currently writing a program that will run on an XT and over
with just a floppy (no monitor, no keyboard, just a Gravis) (total cost about
200$) and will make the XT+GUS run like a 32 channel sampler synth with full
sysex control. It will be comparable to an EPS-16+ with no effects (except
for reverb, chorus, flanger and echo) and will emulate the MT-32, SCC1, will
be General Midi and will accept new patches (with new samples) thru floppy or
thru sysex up to the 1Mb the GUS has. The program will be around 40$.

Subject: Re: Visuals
Message-Id: <93Aug6.013020pdt.14319-1@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Fri, 6 Aug 1993 01:30:20 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



Some of the new console machines coming out this fall will have a
quantum leap in the rendering capability available in the sub-$1000
gear market.  I can't say much about the others, but the 3DO (plug,
plug) will be a great low-end machine for trippy visuals.  It's a
prime machine for video-audio linked color organ effects because
the DSP lets you sample the audio waveform continuously. I'm
already hacking up a math functions module that phases zonked
patterns, and it would be extremely easy to master audio tracks on
CD with this kind of display software matched to it.

Look forward to true VJ's (not MTV mannequins), pixel jocks scratching
trance visuals to match the mix the DJ is laying down.  Better yet,
be one.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Aug  6 03:46:33 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17299; Fri, 6 Aug 93 03:46:33 PDT

	id AA17283; Fri, 6 Aug 93 03:46:18 PDT
Received: from piaget.harlequin.co.uk by holly.harlequin.co.uk; Fri, 6 Aug 1993 11:47:27 +0100
Received: from wundt.harlequin.co.uk by piaget.harlequin.co.uk; Fri, 6 Aug 93 11:47:16 BST
From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Fri, 6 Aug 93 11:47:13 BST
Message-Id: <12251.9308061047@wundt.harlequin.co.uk>
To: zane@genesis.mcs.com
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: Sameer Parekh's message of Thu, 5 Aug 1993 17:09:35 -0500 (CDT) <m0oODVA-000ZCjC@genesis.mcs.com>
Subject: Re: CII tapes -- high bias?
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>>>>> On Thu, 5 Aug 1993 17:09:35 -0500 (CDT), zane@genesis.mcs.com (Sameer Parekh) said:

  Sameer> I noticed that it's black, thus it's not a normal bias tape.

Correct, because it's a pseudochrome (Type II).

  Sameer> But the case doesn't have the indicator on it.

Correct, because it was recorded with 120us equalization, as used on
Ferric tapes.

  Sameer> deck which auto-detects high bias based on the indicator (such as
  Sameer> the one it's playing on right now) will assume the tape is
  Sameer> normal bias [...]

Correct, but it doesn't matter, because *bias* is only used when
you're recording...

  Sameer> and sound quality apparently suffers. 

NO!  Because the deck will correctly play back at 120us equaliztaion.
Equaliztion essentially selects the frequency-response curve, which
should be the same for record and playback.  You should play the tape
back as an ordinary (type I) tape.  If you play it back as a Type II,
you'll select 70us bias, and lose high-frequency response.


  Sameer> is it possible to make the holes with human tools?


NO! NO! NO! NO! NO! NO! NO! NO! NO! NO! NO! NO! NO! NO! NO! NO! 

Don't do this to your C2 tapes!  (Unless you intend to record over them!)




	Cosmic Roy

 ----------
 Literary Freeware -- Not for Commercial Use

 Speeches by William Gibson and Bruce Sterling
 National Academy of Sciences
 Convocation on Technology and Education
 Washington D. C.,  May 10, 1993

 BRUCE STERLING:

      Hello ladies and gentlemen.  Thank you for having the
 two of us here  and giving us a license to dream in public.

      The future is unwritten.  There are best-case
 scenarios.  There are worst-case scenarios.  Both of them
 are great fun to write about if you're a science fiction
 novelist, but neither of them ever happen in the real world.
 What happens in the real world is always a sideways-case
 scenario.

      World-changing marvels to us, are only wallpaper to our
 children.

      Cyberspace is the funhouse mirror of our own society.
 Cyberspace reflects our values and our faults, sometimes in
 terrifying exaggeration.  Cyberspace is a mirror you can
 edit.  It's a mirror you can fold into packets and send
 across continents  at the speed of light.   It's a mirror
 you can share with other people, a place where you can
 discover community.   But it's also a mirror in the classic sense
 of smoke-and-mirrors -- a place where you might be robbed
 or cheated or decieved, a place where you can be promised
 a rainbow but given a mouthful of ashes.

      I know something important about cyberspace.  It
 doesn't matter who you are today -- if you don't show up in
 that mirror in the next century, you're just not going to
 matter very much.  Our kids matter.  They matter a lot.  Our
 kids have to show up in the mirror.

      Today, we have certain primitive media for kids.
 Movies, television, videos.  In terms of their sensory
 intensity, these are like roller-coaster rides.  Kids love
 roller coasters, for natural reasons.  But roller coasters
 only go around and around in circles.  Kids need media that
 they can go places with.  They need the virtual equivalent
 of a kid's bicycle.  Training wheels for cyberspace.
 Simple, easy machines.  Self-propelled.  And free.   Kids
 need places where they can talk to each other, talk back and
 forth naturally.  They need media that they can fingerpaint
 with, where they can jump up and down and breathe hard,
 where they don't have to worry about Mr. Science showing up
 in his mandarin white labcoat to scold them for doing things
 not in the rulebook.  Kids need  a medium of their own.  A
 medium that does not involve a determined attempt by cynical
 adult merchandisers to wrench the last nickel and quarter
 from their small vulnerable hands.


      That would be a lovely scenario.   I don't really
 expect that, though.   On the contrary, in the future I
 expect the commercial sector to target little children with
 their full enormous range of on-line demographic databases
 and privacy-shattering customer-service profiles.  These
 people will be armed and ready and lavishly financed and
 there every day, peering at our children through a
 cyberspace one-way mirror.    Am I naive to expect better
 from the networks in our schools?  I hope not.  I trust not.
 Because schools are supposed to be educating our children,
 civilizing our children, not auctioning them off to the
 highest bidder.

      We need to make some conscious decisions to  reinvent
 our information technology as if the future mattered.  As if
 our children were human beings, human citizens, not raw
 blobs of potential revenue-generating machinery.   We have
 an opportunity to create media that would match the splendid
 ambitions of Franklin with his public libraries and his mail
 system, and Jefferson  and Madison with their determination
 to arm democracy with the power knowledge gives.  We could
 offer children, yes even poor children in poor districts, a
 real  opportunity to control the screen, for once.

      You don't have to worry much about the hardware.  The
 hardware is ephemeral.  The glass boxes should no longer
 impress you.  We've shipped our images inside glass boxes
 for fifty years, but that's a historical accident, a relic.
 The glass boxes that we recognize as computers won't last
 much longer.  Already the boxes are becoming flat screens.
 In the future, computers will mutate beyond recognition.
 Computers won't be intimidating, wire-festooned, high-rise
 bit-factories swallowing your entire desk.  They will tuck
 under your arm, into your valise, into your kid's backpack.
 After that, they'll fit onto your face, plug into your ear.
 And after that --  they'll simply melt.  They'll become
 fabric.  What does a computer really need?  Not glass boxes
 - -- it needs thread -- power wiring, glass fiber-optic,
 cellular antennas, microcircuitry.  These are woven things.
 Fabric and air and electrons and light.   Magic
 handkerchiefs with instant global access.   You'll wear them
 around your neck.  You'll make tents from them if you want.
 They will be everywhere, throwaway.  Like denim.  Like
 paper.  Like a child's kite.

      This is coming a lot faster than anyone realizes.
 There's a revolution in global telephony coming that will
 have such brutal, industry-crushing speed and power that it
 will make even the computer industry blanch.  Analog
 is dying everywhere. Everyone with wire and antenna is going
 into the business of moving bits.


      You are the schools.  You too need to move bits, but
 you need to move them to your own purposes.  You need to
 look deep into the mirror of cyberspace, and you need to
 recognize your own face there.   Not the face you're told
 that you need.   Your own face.  Your undistorted face.  You
 can't out-tech the techies.  You can't  out-glamorize
 Hollywood.  That's not your life, that's not
 your values, that's not your purpose.  You're not supposed
 to pump colored images against the eyeballs of our children,
 or download data into their skulls.  You are supposed to
 pass the torch of culture to the coming generation.   If you
 don't do that, who will?  If you don't prevail for the sake
 of our children, who will?

       It can be done!   It can be done if you keep your wits
 about you and you're not hypnotized by smoke and mirrors.
 The computer revolution, the media revolution, is not going
 to stop during the lifetime of anyone in this room.   There
 are innovations coming, and coming *fast,* that will make
 the hottest tech exposition you see here seem as quaint as
 gaslamps and Victorian magic-lanterns.   Every machine you
 see here will be trucked out and buried in a landfill, and
 never spoken of again, within a dozen years.  That so-called
 cutting-edge hardware here will crumble just the way old fax-
 paper crumbles.  The values are what matters.  The values
 are the only things that last, the only things that *can*
 last.  Hack the hardware, not the Constitution.   Hold on
 tight to what matters, and just hack the rest.

      I used to think that cyberspace was fifty years away.
 What I thought was fifty years away, was only ten years
 away.  And what I thought was ten years away -- it was
 already here.  I just wasn't aware of it yet.

      Let me give you a truly lovely, joyful example of the
 sideways-case scenario.

      The Internet.  The Internet we make so much of today --
 the global Internet which has helped scholars so much, where
 free speech is flourishing as never before in history -- the
 Internet was a Cold War military project.  It was designed
 for purposes of military communication in a United States
 devastated by a Soviet nuclear strike.  Originally, the
 Internet was a post-apocalypse command grid.

      And look at it now.  No one really planned it this way.
 Its users made the Internet that way, because they had the
 courage to use the network to support their own values, to
 bend the technology to their own purposes.  To serve their
 own liberty.  Their own convenience, their own amusement,
 even their own idle pleasure.  When I look at the Internet -
 - - that paragon of cyberspace today -- I see something
 astounding and delightful.  It's as if some grim fallout
 shelter had burst open and a full-scale Mardi Gras parade
 had come out.   Ladies and gentlemen, I take such enormous
 pleasure in this that it's hard to remain properly
 skeptical.  I hope that in some small way I can help you to
 share my deep joy and pleasure in the potential of networks,
 my  joy and pleasure in the fact that the future is
 unwritten.

 WILLIAM GIBSON:

      Mr. Sterling and I have been invited here to dream in
 public.  Dreaming in public is an important part of our job
 description, as science writers, but there are bad dreams as
 well as good dreams.  We're dreamers, you see, but we're
 also realists, of a sort.

      Realistically speaking, I look at the proposals being
 made here and I marvel.  A system that in some cases isn't
 able to teach basic evolution, a system bedevilled by the
 religious agendas of textbook censors, now proposes to throw
 itself open to a barrage of ultrahighbandwidth information
 from a world of Serbian race-hatred, Moslem fundamentalism,
 and Chinese Mao Zedong thought.  A system that has managed
 to remain largely unchanged since the 19th Century now
 proposes to jack in, bravely bringing itself on-line in an
 attempt to meet the challenges of the 21st.  I applaud your
 courage in this.   I see green shoots attempting to break
 through the sterilized earth.

      I believe that the national adventure you now propose
 is of quite extraordinary importance.  Historians of the
 future -- provided good dreams prevail -- will view this as
 having been far more crucial to the survival of democracy in
 the United States than rural electrification or the space
 program.

      But many of America's bad dreams, our sorriest future
 scenarios, stem from a single and terrible fact:  there
 currently exists in this nation a vast and disenfranchised
 underclass, drawn, most shamefully, along racial lines, and
 permanent feature of the American landscape.

      What you propose here, ladies and gentlemen, may well
 represent nothing less than this nation's last and best
 hope of providing something like a level socio-economic
 playing field for a true majority of its citizens.

      In that light, let me make three modest proposals.

      In my own best-case scenario, every elementary and high
 school teacher in the United States of America will have
 unlimited and absolutely cost-free professional access to
 long-distance telephone service.  The provision of this
 service could be made, by law, a basic operation requirement
 for all telephone companies.  Of course, this would also
 apply to cable television.

      By the same token, every teacher in everyy American
 public school will be provided, by the manufacturer, on
 demand, and at no cost, with copies of any piece of software
 whatever -- assuming that said software's manufacturer would
 wish their product to be commercially available in the
 United States.

      What would this really cost us, as a society?  Nothing.
 It would only mean a so-called loss of potential revenue for
 some of the planet's fattest and best-fed corporations.  In
 bringing computer and network literacy to the teachers of
 our children, it would pay for itself in wonderful and
 wonderfully unimaginable ways.  Where is the R&D support for
 teaching?  Where is the tech support for our children's
 teachers?  Why shouldn't we give our teachers a license to
 obtain software, all software, any software, for nothing?

      Does anyone demand a licensing fee, each time a child
 is taught the alphabet?

      Any corporation that genuinely wishes to invest in this
 country's future should step forward now and offer services
 and software.  Having thrived under democracy, in a free
 market, the time has come for these corporations to
 demonstrate an enlightened self-interest, by acting to
 assure the survival of democracy and the free market -- and
 incidentally, by assuring that virtually the entire populace
 of the United States will become computer-literate potential
 consumers within a single generation.

      Stop devouring your children's future in order to meet
 your next quarterly report.

      My third and final proposal has to do more directly
 with the levelling of that playing field.  I propose that
 neither of my two previous proposals should apply in any way
 to private education.

      Thank you.


 -------------------------

From sfraves-owner  Fri Aug  6 10:49:28 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA19283; Fri, 6 Aug 93 10:49:28 PDT
Received: from pilot.njin.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA19276; Fri, 6 Aug 93 10:49:25 PDT
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA14566; Fri, 6 Aug 93 13:49:23 EDT
Date: Fri, 6 Aug 93 13:49:23 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9308061749.AA14566@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: YSH
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

So like after some sporadic dancing, see, I find a nice spot for
chilling, and this cat jumps right into my lap like he owns it,
stretches luxuriously, and looks at me with the expression: "Well?"

What can I say? I'm a mortal man. I pet the cat.

Susie drops by, and then we're really chillin', oozing through the
floor, just soaking up the good vibes, humans and cat, vibe and purr,
all going well.

There must be some law of nature that says the minute a cat falls
asleep in your lap, some disruptive force must come along that makes
you get up, spoiling the moment. In this case, that disruptive force
was Jan Cooley.

She started spinning this really high energy house set, which got
better and better. Before you know it, toes were tapping and heads
were nodding. Susie and I looked each other and I think we shared the
same thought: Sitting here during this music is criminal.

Wow! The dance floor was really moving. People were hopping and
jumping and jamming and grooving. What a vibe!

And then she played THE SONG. I heard it about 6 weeks ago during a
rave, and it's been going off and on in my head ever since. I've been
wanting to dance to it so badly! (I'll sing it for you sometime, maybe
you can tell me what it is.)

She played it! And I went off like a rocket, pushing the throttles to
the wall and jamming as hard as my body could go (I think I scared
Susie, party on :)). And everyone else was going wild too! Oh wow that
was so much fun.

And it didn't end there, Jan just kept on jammin with more and more
energy. She nearly killed me. I was begging for mercy :). What a set!
I had to take my shirt off or suffer a complete meltdown.

It was a good night. I got lots of smiles from people I didn't even
know, there was a great vibe, and of course you were there.

YSH has been and continues to be my favorite night of the week. For $5
one gets a really friendly event, a great vibe, and a chance to hear
women DJs spin a good variety of music.

I get up at 7:30am, work a 9 hour day, drive from Sacramento to SF, go
to YSH, drive back to Davis, get two hours sleep, and go back to work.
And every Friday morning I wonder to myself "Am I crazy?......" for
maybe 2 seconds :). Crazy is sitting at home wondering how much fun I
would've had if I'd gone.

"Well, son, a funny thing about regret is..."

Sean


PS - Nice meeting you S... S... the guy whose name I can't pronounce
right :). Hope to see you at the next event!

------- Blind-Carbon-Copy

To: funky-music@athena.mit.edu
Subject: Racist Sen. Jesse Helms sings "Dixie" to a black Senator...
Date: Fri, 06 Aug 93 10:57:54 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom2>


Just in case any of you have forgotten what a complete asshole Sen.
Jesse Helms is, let me repost the following from 8/5/93 SF examiner
(actually an AP story) of an exchange between Sen. Carol Moseley-Braun
and Sen. Jesse Helms.

"When Helms stepped into the elevator, she [Moseley-Braun] said "he saw
me standing there, and he started to sing 'I wish I was in the land of
cotton ...'  And he looked at Senator Hatch and said, "I'm going to
make her cry. I'm going to sing 'Dixie' until she cries."

"And I looked at him and said, "Sentator Helms, your singing would make
me cry if you sang 'Rock of Ages,'" said Moseley-Braun, an Illinois
Democrat and the Senate's only black.

 ...

Helms' press aide Eric Lundgren said, "It was a good natured
exchange... they all got a good chuckle out of it"....

 ...

Paul Smith, Hatch's press secretary, said the senator heard the
exchange and added, "They were kidding each other. it wasn't mean." The
aide acknowledged that singing "Dixie" to a black person could be
considered offensive, "unless you know Helms."

 ...

Last month Moseley-Braun succesfully led a fight on the Senate floor to
defeat an amendment to renew the United Daughters of the Confederacy's
patent on the Confederate flag insignia.

(I wish that shit-fer-brains Helms would just die, I really do!)

A few nights ago I was hanging out at a friend of mine's house.. a woman
who recently moved here from New York.We started talking about music and she
mentioned to me that her sister sings house music .. little did I know..

She put on a tape of her,
and I was absolutely amazed to hear the most
incredible voice..
This girl's 24 year old sister was incredible.. a wailing diva type with
a voice much like (and on a similar talent level to..) Lady Miss Kier of
Deelite.
I was floored..Although I'm not an expert on music..I know a good voice when 
I hear it..I couldn't beleive it when my friend said that her sister hasn't
ever been
successful in getting herself on plastic..(Evidently she's been approaching 
major record labels...not small independents..) So my thought in posting to
the music experts here on the list..was to ask if anyone knew any small record
labels which publish the classic house style of music..(beautiful female
vocals.. voice used as an instrument..) Maybye 
she just isn't sending her demo to the right kind of people..
Any ideas pop into mind?

Subject: Medical News & Views
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

This is kind of personal, but you're all my friends, and my
experience might be of some benefit to others.

Over the last couple of weeks, I've developed quite a large
rash on my back and shoulders.  I went to the Doctor, and it turned
out to be a fungus, like athlete's foot, most likely resulting
from:

- spending too much time in sweaty shirts. (the heat wave didn't help)
- not showering immediately after sweating all night. (crashing instead)
- Depressed immune system. (lot's of work-related stress lately)
- Significant amount of body hair (nuff said)

It's no big deal and not terribly contagious (my wife Janie with whom
I've been in occasional physical contact with doesn't have it), but I'd 
be more comfortable if people refrained from hugging me this week.

The cure?  Soaking myself in Selsen Blue Shampoo has already been 
helping, but my doctor has prescribed a quicker cure.  What I'm 
supposed to do is eat a couple of pills and then within one 
hour, engage in some kind of strenuous sweat-inducing activity and *not* 
take a shower for at least 8 hours.  I assured her that I was capable
of doing this.  The medication is supposed to kill the fungus through 
my sweat.  If necessary, I have to repeat this in one week.

So basically, it looks like I am under doctor's orders to rave hard 
this weekend!  

As an aside, I got to meet my primary care physician for the first 
time yesterday.  She's with the Bayfair Women's Medical group in
SF.  What a place; entirely run by women, the doctors, receptionists -
with a truly warm and caring vibe - it was like the Medical Office 
version of Your Sister's House!  If only they could do something
about that waiting room music.

Also, my doctor views MDMA usage as a "lifestyle" choice and has 
patients who have used it over a long period of time.  Some of them
developed cases of depression due to fried serotonin receptors,
but her current view was that the stuff was no worse than doing 
alchohol or tobacco.

- leg of eel

To: inhuman@mindvox.phantom.com

In-Reply-To: Inhuman's message of Fri, 06 Aug 93 00:10:43 EDT <kseu8B6w165w@mindvox.phantom.com>
Subject: C/U tapes
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


well, I produced the C2 tapes, and didn't produce the C/U tapes, so
that's obviously why they are inferior :-)

but seriously folks, the C/U tapes are on normal bias tape, so they
don't have as wide of a frequency range.  i also find that they
especially don't have a good bottom (bass) --- probably due to
aesthetic judgements made in the mastering process.  (also, i suspect
a compressor / limiter was somewhere in the signal path before the
recording equipment.)

C/U was recorded live to 8 track digital, with 2 tracks used for mics
and 2 tracks from the mixer line out.  in production, some of the
crowd noise was intentionally mixed in with the music.  i think it's a
pretty cool effect, lots of energy on the tape, but i personally
prefer straight mixing board tapes.

just a few notes to explain why they are what they are.  i try to make
it clear to people that the C/U tapes don't sound as good as the C2
tapes, but it's kind of hard to do that without coming off sounding
pompous.

Bob

Bring me your defective tapes, and if I can verify that there's a
problem, I'll exchange it for a new one.  (If I'm out, I can get you a
new one within a few days / at the next South Bay lunch or YSH.)

I've listened to one set all the way through, and it didn't have any
dropouts, and I've also listened to the DAT cassette production
masters, and they are fine.  It sounds to me like the duplication
house might have hit a bad spool of tape.

re: "C2 process" well, every tape I do is on chrome tape, and every
bin loop and DAT production master is verified by me before the tapes
are duplicated.  Chrome = better sound and verification = less chance
of quality problems.  "Better tapes --- you have my word on it!"  (sez
spokesperson Bob...)

Bob


From sfraves-owner  Fri Aug  6 15:04:24 1993

	id AA02370; Fri, 6 Aug 93 15:01:21 -0800
Date: Fri, 6 Aug 93 15:01:21 -0800
From: Robert Jesse <rjesse@us.oracle.com>
Message-Id: <9308062301.AA02370@lila.us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Medical News & Views
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>>Also, my doctor views MDMA usage as a "lifestyle" choice and has 
>>patients who have used it over a long period of time.  Some of them
>>developed cases of depression due to fried serotonin receptors,
>>but her current view was that the stuff was no worse than doing 
>>alchohol or tobacco.

>there's a pretty wide range of opinion out there in the
>medical/scientific community though... i know a neurological
>specialist who thinks the stuff is the Kiss Of Death and wouldn't even
>try one hit recreationally just for the hell of it...

>Jon Drukman

there is a prescription anorexic called fenfluramine taken by millions
of people around the world.  i've read that the same animal study 
methodology that shows mdma to be neurotoxic at "high" doses (higher
than moderate human recreational doses, adjusted for body weight) also
shows fenfluramine to be *more* neurotoxic on a dose equivalent basis,
and by [approx?] the same mechanism of action.  the same source says
there are no adverse neurological or behavioral effects reported to be
linked with human fenfluramine use as commonly prescribed.

one might conclude that fenfluramine, in its ordinarily prescribed
anorexic doses, is pretty safe, and that mdma, used in moderation, is
therefore at least as safe.

i would be very interested to hear if your neurologist friend has
contrary data on fenfluramine, or can explain how the conclusion above
might not be warranted by the evidence at hand.

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno

I went to YSH last night and I had a blast.

The DJs were good, all of them. Rebecca and Jane (Jan?) were especially
good, but all of them were outstanding last night. They spun hard, they
spun loud, they spun frenetic and kinetic, get up off your ass kinda music.
And the vibe never stopped.

I ran into a few people I met out there (Hi, Susie, Louis!) and a few I
didn't (Hi, Monica, Starchild!). Seems that YSH has become the default SFR
hangout now. Yeah!

For the five bucks, you get it all. Being an unemployed Starving College
Student (tm), five bucks means something, and the YSH experience squeezes
every drop of entertainment and warmth it can out of every penny.

A definite three thumbs up!


hazrat Gregor Mosheh

Until Aug. 31, 1993:
623 Radcliffe Drive   Davis, CA  95616-1011
(916) 758-5589

Until the Internet dies:
gmosheh@nyx.cs.du.edu
mosheh@cybernet.cse.fau.edu

"I don't trust the DJ with my body right now."
                -John Draper, Cap. Crunch
In reference to the DJ's rapid style changes.

Rave is forever. Party hard and party loud. Harm none, love all. And dance
'til dawn.

From: rudholm@aimla.com (Mark Rudholm)
Message-Id: <9308062214.AA03419@aimla.com>
To: sfraves@techno, socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Subject: Re: Visuals
Cc: mdiehr@ucsd.edu
Content-Length: 2579
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno

>From SFRaves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU Fri Aug  6 02:31:05 1993
>From: "William A. Baker" <wab@well.sf.ca.us>
>To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
>Subject: Re: Visuals
>Message-Id: <93Aug6.013020pdt.14319-1@well.sf.ca.us>
>Date: 	Fri, 6 Aug 1993 01:30:20 -0700
>Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU
>
>
>Some of the new console machines coming out this fall will have a
>quantum leap in the rendering capability available in the sub-$1000
>gear market.  I can't say much about the others, but the 3DO (plug,
>plug) will be a great low-end machine for trippy visuals.  It's a
>prime machine for video-audio linked color organ effects because
>the DSP lets you sample the audio waveform continuously. I'm
>already hacking up a math functions module that phases zonked
>patterns, and it would be extremely easy to master audio tracks on
>CD with this kind of display software matched to it.
>
>Look forward to true VJ's (not MTV mannequins), pixel jocks scratching
>trance visuals to match the mix the DJ is laying down.  Better yet,
>be one.

A friend of mine and I did just what you describe at an event last
weekend called "SHARE."  We had 3DO (development box), CD-I
(model 180, development box), PC (Y/C video out SVGA), and a
Powerlink Presenter equipped Duo210 (which has video out), and
Hi8 tape of stuff including old movies and such.  We mixed material
with a Panasonic mixer that has the wonderful capability to mix
non-genlocked sources.  One of my favorite effects is to make a
B/W movie very high contrast and then AND mix it with a pattern
(fractal, interference pattern, whatever) so that people in a scene
appear to be walking about wearing fractal clothes and have fractal
faces!  Quite neat.  We had two SHARP 400 video projectors that were
brilliant (literally and figuratively.)  We got many rave compliments
and some people wanted to hire us.  We did the show as a favor for
a friend and we had lots of fun.

I agree with William, the 3DO machine's "cell engine" is
wonderful.  Some people in attendance with an understanding of
computer graphics were incredulous when we told them that we were
calculating images in real-time.

-Mark

Disclaimer: this message describes my personal opinions and
activites, it has NOTHING AT ALL to do with my employer or employment.

From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: raves, parties, and videotape
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Before I start I wanted to say that I did not enjoi Basics too much.  There
were lots of people there but the whole scene was confused.  I did think
that Markie was especially great that eveneing (as always), Josh was good,
Tony was good,  Garth is Garth, Doran's set was a bit too uh...well I'll
leave it at that.

I was good seeing BB working the parking lot, with a smile and friendly
demeanor no less.

In any case I thought the DJ's were good, sound system bad, and the people?
 Well it's what I have come to expect from a massive.  I do predict one
thing about the upcoming Universe clown fest.  This will be confusion taken
to new heights.  If you thought Cyberfest was ugly, or that Basics was
clueless it will only be amplified ten-fold when that thing gets going. 
It's not a dis of their crew cuz I don't know 'em.  It's just a fact of
this area that's all.  I do think that they will make alot of money, and
some new people may be brought into the scene.  But that will not prevent
many lost and clueless souls from attending, and leaving even more confused
than when they entered.  I dunno if I'm going.  If I'm compe'd I'll go, if
not I'll report from the sidelines.

Ok, now that I've said all that...I have seen that many have mentioned
video tapes of the parties you have attended.  When these posts were goin
on I completely forgot that I have a few of those tapes here at home.  But
I cannot give out copies :(  BUT there is an alternative.  Nitty Gritty
Productions has just about EVERY party that has gone on in the Bay Area
since this scene began.  They have FMM (Full Moon Massives), Wicked,
Gathering, Basics, Toon Town, Sharon, Funky Techno, Vortex, Equinox, Let
Freedom Rave, ALL the New Years Parties, Let Freedom Rave, Get Down Get
Wicked, Wax, Groove Kitchen, Love American Style, the Sacramento Parties,
the Chico Parties and many others.  The music on the tapes are from the
parties themselves, as well as special soundtracks done by Garth, Josh,
Surge, and others.

The FMM's are NOT available yet.  He is still working out something with
the crew.  But all the others are avaialble on VHS tape.  If you are
interested (I will not give the number out on the net) please mail me and
I'll make the connection between you and Nitty Gritty.  BTW, I receive no
profit from this venture, hell I already have the tapes I wanted (since
they used my digitial mixer to make most of the tapes).  The tapes are of
the highest quality, and the tapes are in stereo (I beleive).  Let me know
if any of you are interested.  And they are priced right too!

Groove Kitchen looks like the party to go to tonight.  He has a great
lineup!  The King St. space is one of the better spaces in the city.  I
hope he can keep the security from roving around like streiod-thugs and
just have them man the doors.  There will be a good crowd there (400-600)
so it should be a good event (Preston has YET to throw a bad one).  It's
21+ :)  so bring your ID.

Peace over and out.

	On one of the Internet wierdness lists, they mention
	that the DEA is on sfraves... If this is indeed true,
	then I just want to extend this welcome to them!  I hope
	that by reading this list, you come to realize that raving
	and the raving life style is about much more than just the
	consumption of controlled substances.  Maybe you'll realize
	how important things like community, caring, love, honesty,
	freedom and liberty are to the participants of this group.

	Please realize in the coming months that maybe your "war on drugs"
	could be turning into a "war on consciousness".

From sfraves-owner  Sat Aug  7 12:19:18 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA25718; Sat, 7 Aug 93 12:19:18 PDT
Received: from ravel.udel.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA25711; Sat, 7 Aug 93 12:19:15 PDT

	(5.65c/IDA-1.2.8) id AA00862; Sat, 7 Aug 1993 15:16:03 -0400
Date: Sat, 7 Aug 1993 14:55:23 -0400 (EDT)
From: Alan Michael Parry <brit@ravel.udel.edu>
Subject: A few SF thoughts..
To: ne-raves <ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu>
Cc: sf-raves <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.07.9308071423.A150-b100000@ravel.udel.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Well, on my first day back east from an amazing trip that I hoped would
never end, here are a few reflections. Basically, inhuman summed it up
with "my next ticket to SanFran will be one way". What you people have
other there is amazing and it seems a lot of you take it for granted.
Though the scene is older than ours, it seemed, to me a least, so much
more fresh and alive than our own. Though many sf-ravers seemed
dissapointed with Basics, it was an incredible experience for myself. To
see 1500+ people dancing is not unheard of here, but to see that 1000+ of
those people still dancing, shouting, and screaming with enthusiasm at 7:30
the next morning is. Thoughts of the DC/Balt morning cross my mind - 80+
people in a huge warehouse with a few more lying comatose on the floor.
There was so much energy out there that at times I was just overwhelmed,
the FMR being a prime example of that. The location went out over the
phones arond 10 or so, then 4 hours later, around 1500 people had gathered
on a beach, 50 miles north of SanFrancisco - all this on a Sunday night!
then after being busted around 4:30, the party relocated to Berkeley
marina...another 50 mile drive. There the party went on and was still
going strong with 300+ people at 2pm Monday afternoon. It is truely a
beautiful place. 

Thanks for everyone who made this trip so special - brian, joachim, cindy,
leah, inhuman and the wundervan posse, and everybody else we came in touch
with.  

much love.

-F
  _

wow
feels wierd to be home
when i felt very much at home all of last week
while i was up in SF
for that i really thank brian and leah for giving me a place
to crash and tam for picking me up and tam and jo and ingrid and brian 
and whoever else for driving me around
thanks to YSH for a great party
and everyone else for making it greater by being able to meet you

to re-cap the week in the post FMR section
i slept and ate and laid around a lot
actually didnt eat that much so it was mostly sleeping and laying around

but seriously.. had tons of fun with leahx2 and jo and microwiz
and then leahx2 and jo and alpha
and then leah and jo
justwandering around telegraph or haight
and watching everyone log in everyday at leahs
played Dactyl Nightmares at Dwight Cafe with greg who quite toasted me
although i nailed him in the back mighty good
and many other things that were quite to much wonderful to try to compact
into one little whodingit

one notable thing of this week is how small the world felt
aside from meeting everyone who was out from the east coast
and all these people from sf (and im quite sorry i didnt
meet more people at YSH who i guess were there)
but also going into a piercing place and opening a magazine
to see the woman who has done my pierces being featured in there
to going into amoeba clothing and seeing all this jewelry
that looks really familiar adn it turns out a friend of mine made
to running into a friend from high school at YSH and to find out
that hes on sfraves and been reading my psots
to running into Brad Bakers (of B.B.'s X-FX) in LAX on the way home
to i dont know how many other things that just amde it seemed like
there realyl are only 547 people in the world and ive almost
met them all

well even if i dont meet teh rest, the ones who i ahve
seem quite wonderful enough to keep me ecstaticly happy for now

 ,
dana

Robert Jesse <rjesse@us.oracle.com> writes:

> there is a prescription anorexic called fenfluramine taken by millions
> of people around the world.  i've read that the same animal study 
> methodology that shows mdma to be neurotoxic at "high" doses (higher
> than moderate human recreational doses, adjusted for body weight) also
> shows fenfluramine to be *more* neurotoxic on a dose equivalent basis,
> and by [approx?] the same mechanism of action.  the same source says
> there are no adverse neurological or behavioral effects reported to be
> linked with human fenfluramine use as commonly prescribed.
> 
> one might conclude that fenfluramine, in its ordinarily prescribed
> anorexic doses, is pretty safe, and that mdma, used in moderation, is
> therefore at least as safe.

I, too, remember reading this is one of my big LEXIS/NEXUS searches on 
MDMA.  I can dig up the proper references if someone wants them; I know 
all the printouts are lying around my room somewhere...

Just to recap the madness:

-- Fenfluramine, legal, more nuerotoxic than MDMA
-- MDMA, illegal, less nuerotoxic than fenfluramine


Michael                 |  groovin' in the chocolate city!

From sfraves-owner  Sun Aug  8 00:28:13 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA28681; Sun, 8 Aug 93 00:28:13 PDT
Received: from nkosi.well.sf.ca.us by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA28674; Sun, 8 Aug 93 00:28:10 PDT
Received: from well.sf.ca.us (well.sf.ca.us [192.132.30.2]) by nkosi.well.sf.ca.us (8.5/8.5) with SMTP id AAA14371; Sun, 8 Aug 1993 00:28:09 -0700
Received: by well.sf.ca.us id <14229-2>; Sun, 8 Aug 1993 00:27:49 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: YSH!
Message-Id: <93Aug8.002749pdt.14229-2@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Sun, 8 Aug 1993 00:27:40 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Haven't had much time to get online since I returned from my California
trip to Portland.  I've been busy busy busy -- in Sacramento earlier
in the week, took the train back to Richmond Thursday evening, BARTed
to the City and dropped off my stuff at my friend's apartment, then
headed over to the Lost & Found Saloon in North Beach where I saw my
old friend Doug Jay playing blues harp with his band the Chevrolets!
I hadn't talked to Doug since 1979 when he was playing with a band
called the Allstars from Charlottesville, so that was really great.
If you like the blues, catch his band if you can but you'll have to
move quick since he's going to Austria in September for a couple of
months to join the premiere blues band there :)

I then headed over to YSH, which I haven't attended since the 24th St
Beach night (I'd be there every week if I could, believe me!).  It was
good to see Brian and Peace holding forth in the back entrance, and
I saw quite a few of the Penelope's krewe as the evening went on as
well.  Upstairs the TAZ space was set up in funky, comfortable disarray.
This rave felt like a *party*, or maybe this was a party that felt like
a *rave*!  It was busy but not overcrowded, and when I arrived the
floor had plenty of low-key dancing action.  

I wandered back to the chill area in front with this *classic* view
of Market St. below -- the Psychedelic Shop across the street in the
old Wells Fargo building (we moved literally a ton of bank record
boxes in the basement of that building for a birthday party I went to
there a while ago!), and the cop shop on the far corner.  

All of a sudden Jan Cooley came on laying down this phaaaaat phunky house
set and THINGS REALLY CLICKED!  I hadn't heard Jan spin before so this 
turned out to be a real pleasure -- she's got a great smooth style and
a way of giving some of the more popular mixes a more interesting setting
than they usually get.  The room suddenly seemed to *cohere* and for
about 20 minutes I had one of those really fine well-aligned resonating
'xperiences I associate with my best times in this scene.

Thursday nights definitely have mixed blessings.  On the one hand, the
crowd were very relaxed, not into the Friday Frenzy or the Over The
Edge Saturday Surge.  But there was also a relatively low level of
interactivity until later in the evening.  Yet I had the feeling that
this was one of those fabled moments where a lot of elements that
define the good side of the scene came together.  The lack of commercial
focus for YSH upholds the relaxed/intense feeling that I really like best.
And it holds those feelings for more than a few moments at a time. 
Like many others, I'm feeling quite annoyed by the commercial scene and
more inclined than ever to go with the smaller parties where the music
and dancing and socializing are the focus, not stylin' and the promoter-
security-DJ triangle that defines much of the mainstream (while giving
appropriate props to the GK and Boogie Buffet krewes and others who
do quite well in the more 'commercial' context).

The only drawback to Thursday night was the time factor.  I had a plane
to catch *early* in the morning, so I was weighing the prospect of an
early exit and a couple of hours sleep against the fine vibes of YSH.
Well, YSH and Jan Cooley won out, I'm happy to say.  I left around 4:15
and caught my flight with a bit of a perma-grin that maybe the other
passengers noted -- but how could I explain to them what the sources of
my contentments were?!

From: Jon Drukman <jdrukman@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: renegade review
Reply-To: jdrukman%dlsun87@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

it's noon on sunday and i've just woken up after returning from ethan
& co's renegade party down at 3rd & 24th.  i got there at 3.30 and
found the crowd disappointingly thin on the ground, but big smiles and
hugs to those who had the stamina to brave the chill ocean winds!

this is a nice space and looks like it could be home to some great
independent parties in the future.  i certainly enjoyed it more than
groove kitchen, which i thought was a crowded and sweaty vibeless
affair with subpar music (although i'm sure it improved after i left,
as rick preston and jon williams had yet to come on...)

anyway, good to see the familiar faces that made it down to the
water's edge.  with a little planning and some more advance notice,
i'm sure future events will be ten times as good.

and now, lunch.

Jon Drukman                                      jdrukman%dlsun87@us.oracle.com

Always note the sequencer - this will never let us down.

	Fenfluramine: Medical, thus accepted: legal.

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9308090122.AA11000@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject:  Groove Kitchen and NRG's Renegade
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Groove Kitchen

(Subjective review alert!) :) :) :)

I thought Groove Kitchen was way too crowded, and had really poor
ventilation. The smoke was the worst I've experienced in my
approximately 20 events. No ins-n-outs, and the only cool space was
being harassed by the security. I'll probably not visit that space
again.

The music was good, with pretty conventional house. The sound was too
loud for my tastes. If I'd have had my earplugs, I'd have put them in,
and parked right in front of the speakers. The vibe was pretty thick
(with the smoke, really thick, does everyone have to foul other
people's air?).

So it was a real relief to get back to...

The Renegade

At which Jon played some good funky house. By then though my body was
pretty much thrashed, but it felt good to be out there with you guys.

Let me know if you do it again :). My # is 916-757-1373. I have no
real computer access after business hours M-F.

Sean

dana...

You put it much better than i could ever have...
This past week was more than i could have ever hoped for- because of the 
people i've met, the friends ive made, the amazing time i had both at 
the berkeley  marina on monday & at YSH...

There is something about SF ravers that makes one feel naturally accepted and
welcomed - there is little if any attitude that ive encountered.
Everyone is there for the music, exuding a warm feeling of love and 
friendliness... it's like nothing ive ever encountered before or thought i 
could ever find in people.

I am overwhelmed with a sense of child-like wonder at how many 
different people i have met (from both coasts) & the fact that even my cynical
self has been won over...

i find myself infected with the same feeling of friendliness & happiness...

i especially want to thank brian b. for introducing me into this new world of
music, and thank leah for being so wonderful to me while i was staying there.

hello to everyone i've met recently & to all those i hope to meet in the near
future....


-jo

From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug  9 01:03:46 1993

From: hyland@netcom.com (Tim Hyland)
Message-Id: <9308090804.AA14585@netcom3.netcom.com>
Subject: Renegade Rhythm
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SF Raves List)
Date: Mon, 9 Aug 93 1:04:26 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hi gang, it's been a while since I've been to a rave (July FMR?), but
stopped by the 24th St. Renegade for a couple of hours on Saturday
night and had a fun time chatting and dancing around.  Definitely a
cool space.  I do love the outdoors sites.  In fact, I can't remember
the last time I went to an indoors rave.  Must have been something
last summer in the basement of the Fashion Center?  Definitely looking
forward to the planned (cross-yer-fingers) GGP rave in October and the
possible Renweal in Willets later this month.

After jookin' for a while at the renegade, headed over to Rhythm at
around 2:00, which was listed in the calendar but wasn't a rave.  It
was the opening night of a new gay dance club.  It was at 177
Townsend, which was cool to revisit.  Lots of memories of the big
Toontowns and Care*Free's early days.  Cool space.  There were a lot
of people, but as club openings go, I've been to better ones.  

Jon Williams was spinning when I got there (must have been right
before his set at Groove Kitchen) and his mix didn't do much for me.
It was a lot of mild, droning techno.  Not quite trance and not quite
house.  Just boring.  After an hour or so he must have started warming
up (or I warmed up to his mix) and danced for a while.  All in all, a
pleasant evening.

Share and Enjoy,

Tim

Went up to Mission Rock last Friday with some newbies (who
were much impressed with the place) and I thought Jon
Williams' set there was pretty good.  Interesting enough to
set the mood and get you moving, but not *too* interesting
(as in, "What the hell is he doing now?").

It seems funny to me that Mission Rock isn't more of an
sfraves hangout.  It's cheap, outdoors on the bay, the
music is good, and the mix of people is all right, but I
only got to say hello to Derek there (and I saw Jon Drukman
around, but somehow we kept missing each other).  

I guess it's annoying that it's 21+, but at least the people
on the door don't seem to be too obnoxious...

Anyway, I was wondering what happened with the Gathering
party at the Berkeley Marina that night.  Anybody make it
over there?  They were announcing on the phone message that
Nitrous wouldn't be tolerated.  How did that work out?

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)

Hi,  I think I'm the first casualty of the faschist regeme formed by the
piggishness of the club owners.   Let me explain...

I thought that me and my friend should check out "Where the wild things
are" at One Step Beyond.    A few of my friends then met me in the parking 
lot and told me that things weren't happening that made it worth the steep 
$20 admission,  and also reported that the usual faschist sceme of NO WATER 
ALLOWED,  unless you are willing to pay the steep pricees they charge,  
so we collectivly agreed to check out GK.

So we drive all the way into SF from Santa Clara to the King St club.
When we get there,  we had to wait in line for more than an hour to get
in,  while the goons were taking their time carding everyone.   Ha Ha!!
Even *I* got carded (And I'm 50 yrs old).

Once in,  I figured that I could find a place where I could escape from
the cigerett smoke.   After scouting around,  I was appalled to learn that
the chill out area was HOTTER than the dancing area.

In fact,   I worked up a sweat just WALKING through that area (Yukk!!).
But I did find a cooler area to chill out in the front hallway,   but
about 3 am or so,  the goons kicked out everyone and forced them back into
the main area which was very hot,  smokey and steamy.

I stayed by that doorway as much as possible,  but that big black goon
in the main entrance hallway must have had it in for me,   because everytime
I opened the door to stick my head into the hallway,   he threatoned to kick
me out if I did that again.

Eventually,  I found a stairway down into one of the other exit doors where
it was partially opened and I could get a gasp of fresh air.    But it opened
to the outside area,  and immediatly,  a goon from outside saw me as I stuck
my head out,   came in and then bolted the door shut so I could only get a
crack of fresh air.    It was better than nothing,   but I don't think it
was worth the effort to attend.

Eventually,  I started to feel whoozy and slightly sick,  and asked the goon
for permission to breath fresh air because of my nausia,  and he said "get
back in there,  or I'll kick you out"  (This was another goon).

After the party,  and the usual visit to the Boogie Buffet,  on the way back,
I really started to get sick,   and my rashes exploded to the point where I
have
to now visit the doctor and get more anti-tobacco medication.   This is going
to
cost me about $500 in medical expenses,  and a few days from my new job.

So,  I ask others that attended if they ALSO experienced any ill-effects of the
stuffyness caused by the goons of King st.  And if they did,  to please contact
me via phone (510) 745-0702 (Message only).   This is because I am
investigating
the possibilities of a class-action lawsuit charging in-humian treatment on the
part of the Kink St goons.   I will NOT name any of the promoters of the event,
as I KNOW it is NOT their fault.

I know Preston the promoter of the GK,   and it's NOT his fault,  and that he
had to go by their rules which he ALSO thinks they suck.   Preston is a great
guy,
and really had done a LOT to provide us with good raving.

I am not sure yet whether or not I will start this lawsuit,   but that depends
on
the rest of you raver folks,  and whether or not anyone else can claim any ill-
effects from being there and can DOCUMENT them to the point where the court
can accept them as legitimate medical problems.

So,  I ask the group... If you,  or your non-sfrave rave friend has experienced
any ill-effects to please contact me.    

Please remember,   I will ONLY do this if OTHERS have experienced any
ducumentable
ill-effects.    I SURE cam prove my problems...

Sean,  I also saw your posting about YOUR discomfort as well.   And I urge you
to
also consider joining me.    

Perhaps if I instigate this lawsuit,  and make a big media situation out of it,
then other club owners may get the idea that PEOPLE NEED WATER and AIR.   It is
a basic fundimental human need,   and NO club ownder should deprive one of
these
basic fundumental needs.

One more thing,   When I start talking to the media about how great raves are,
and all the GOOD things about raves,   I am certainly going to mention the
faschist
attitudes of certain club owners,  and if I'm allowed to name them,   I'll also
do that...

I remain...
Cap'n Crunch

OH!! One more thing,  I'm going to need the name of the King St owner and mailing
address so I can write them an official complaint letter on our behalf...

If anyone can provide me with that,   I would appreciate it..

CC

Hey, doom! Hey, all!

No, I didn't go to the Gathering renegade, but a friend of mine did. So,
this will be a vicarious report (take it with a grain o' salt?).

According to my friend- it got broken up; I don't know when.

Also, she said that two really negative incidents occured- one, 
a personal experience; the other, more general.

She accidently (physically) bumped into another woman at the party,
and said, "Oh, I'm sorry," smile 'n all...

To which the woman replied, "You better be sorry, bitch." (feel that vibe!)

Additionally, some sort of fight broke out; something like five 
men kicking and beating another man who was already down (curled into 
a ball on the ground). Apparently, nobody intervened due to fear and/or
numbers and/or the possibility of guns.

Me? I spent all weekend at work to meet a deadline tomorrow. The most
exciting thing that happened was when I accidently set off the alarm in
our office-
'twas the music for the weekend. And, yep, my renegade got busted :)

Back to the grind-

Jocelyn

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)

Subject: weekend rpt
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Mon, 9 Aug 93 10:49:00 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


We had great fun a Ethan's party Sat. nite.  Great music, great people;
it was like a family gathering, except that I was with people who I 
actually like.  Finally got to meet Sean, Giamma, Bryce, Ben & Jessica
Wing and some really friendly non-sfravers.  And of course it was fun 
to mix it up with the other sfravers who came.  We danced, we chilled, 
we talked, we ate - the Universe is now a better place then it was...

Stopped by Ethan's and Bob's renegade rave at the end of 24th later in 
the evening, which seemed to be gaining momentum.  It was a nice scene,
friendly people, good music, crisp sound, easily accessible outdoor 
site.  The 2 strobe lights were a nice effect. 

I was under doctors orders to sweat hard, so I went to The Fridge.  The
basement of Big Heart City is hot, although the 10 or so fans did help a
bit.  Ran into Steve Saede(sp?) dancing like a maniac.  The sound system
was mediocre, but adequete, and there was a lot of room to chill.  7$ 
seemed fair for this venue on a Sat. night.  In a pinch, this place
will do depending on how long you can last without oxygen.  I
basically stayed for Simon's set, who tore the place up with Carlos
cheerleading nearby. 

It looks like I'm cured of my Raver's Rash, thanks to the anti-fungal
weed-killer that surged from my pores that night.  Now I won't have to
explain to the people commenting on my weird dance moves for the last
few weeks that I was only trying to to scratch the itch in the middle
of my back.

After Simon, I figured that breathing would kind of fun, so I
woke Janie, picked her up, and shot back over to 24th St.  The crowd
had thinned out, but we hung out for a bit of Jon's set, which was excellent
BTW.  Big name DJs?  We don't need no big name DJs.  It was kinda chilly,
so we decided to call it a night, and then decided to see if we could
get in cheaply for the tail end of GK.  But Janie, who turned 35 this
week didn't have her ID, and the securty goons were adamant about it.  I was 
told that it didn't matter how old they thought she was, that their license
would be jeapordized if a cop found her inside without ID.  I guess this
means that my 66 yr old dad wouldn't  be allowed in without ID.  It is
a strange world that decides that a beuracratically sanctioned peice of
paper/plastic is more meaningful than the Truth.  Oh well.  I was too tired
to beat up the entire Groove Kitchen Security Force so we went went home.

- leg of eel

Subject: GK
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

well, Groove Kitchen was like most other Groove Kitchens that I had been to
in the past, in that the vibe was weak until about 4 am.  Until that point,
the place was extremely crowded and hot, and the DJs (Gavan and Mark Farina) 
being somewhat boring.  Mark Farina played Erotic City (unmixed!) by Prince at
one point  (hmm....).

Jon Williams came on and really tore it up.  He is such a great DJ, really.
All the reviews of his music that have been posted here are accurate.  Then
Rick preston came on.  For those of you who know Rick and see him frequently,
his set would've amazed you.  He came on after Jon Williams had finished up his

set with some really good acid house, and proceeded to play the most intense,
driving acid set I've ever heard.  He was jamming so hard, it was unbelievable!
Rick really is the most underrated DJ around, in my opinion.  He is always good,
and now has shown to have some of hte greatest high-energy acid music around.
I hope to catch him more at bigger events in the hopes of hearing that music again.  Mind blowing!

Kudos to the renegade for going off.  I would've gone over there but I really
wanted to hea rRick that night, since he had told us that we would probably be
"surprised" by his set.  More renegades!

Who's going to Festivahl?

Zak

> groove kitchen, which i thought was a crowded and sweaty vibeless
> affair with subpar music (although i'm sure it improved after i left,
> as rick preston and jon williams had yet to come on...)
I'll agree with you on that one.  The one thought that kept on running
through my head during my three hour stay at Groove Kitchen was: "Christ
it's hot in here.  Some fresh air would be nice..."  So Pete and I left
at 3 or so.

However, the weekend wasn't a total waste.  We ended up going to San Jose,
and we checked out a very cool after party held at a cafe/laundromatte
called Lattes & Laundry.  There were about 50 people there, and the DJs
were Tara, Wool and Spun.  (I had never heard Tara or Wool before.)  Tara
started out at 6:30 am.  With the exception of her opening song (the disco
classic "Copcabana") her set was pretty damn cool -- happy, funky, housy
stuff, which was perfect for the vibe that was going down.  Wool came on
at about 8:30 and failed to impress me.  We left at 9:00, and the party
was still going strong when we left.  (Spun had yet to play.)

Overall, a fun little party that blew Groove Kitchen away.

Here's the paltry beginnings of my list. Please help me flesh this out
by listing any spaces that have bad conditions, unreasonable
restrictions, or age limits.

This does not reflect upon the promoters of an event at these spaces.
It is intended to give people some advance information before they go.
If this list reaches some reliastic volume, I'll start printing it out
and leaving it at raves as a public service :).

I might build this up as a table, and list all sites that we hear of
so that we can list the good ones in a separate section.

Note that I am currently boycotting 174 King St. and One Step Beyond.


(Name?) 174 King St., SF
	21+. No ventilation. NO COOL AREAS. Very rude staff. No
	re-entry. Small.

One Step Beyond, (Address?), Santa Clara
	Age limit? NO WATER. NO BACKPACKS. Rude staff. No re-entry.

(Name?), 6th & Folsom, SF, current site of Boogie Buffet.
	Age limit? NO WATER.

Richmond Civic Center, (Address?), Richmond
	No re-entry. Continuous police presence.

Sean

PS - It seems that some of these measures are intended to prevent the
kinds of problems associated with drunken crowds. They don't apply to
raver crowds, who have different needs, specifically a cooldown area,
and plenty of water. I wonder if some spaceowner education might help?

Subject: Boogie Buffet (was Re: THE LIST: Spaces with gotchas. )

             <9308091907.AA05944@pilot.njin.net>

> <sean's boycott list>
>(Name?), 6th & Folsom, SF, current site of Boogie Buffet.
>	Age limit? NO WATER.

That's 1015 Folsom.

I went to B.B. yesterday (my first time). There were pitchers of water
and and paper cups available throughout the day. The bar is quite
expensive -- at one point I got charged $5.00 for an irish coffee, even
though I had paid $8.50 for both an irish coffee and a bloody mary
earlier in the morning. (No, I wasn't "drinking"... just buying the
occasional drink for myself and others.).

This was my first Boogie Buffet and I was impressed. I didn't
particularly like the crowd (a few too many "look at me" clubland
adonis/venus-types) but the vibe was pretty good nonetheless. The DJs
easily played some of the best  music I've heard in a long time. I
loved the slow/funky "disco/boogie/dub/ragga/funk" stuff being played
in the "sunlight" room, and they were tweaking good techno/trance in
the "dark" room. I was expecially impressed by the mixing in the
"sunlight" room -- this wasn't your usual
mix-in-a-song-play-it-for-a-while-and-then- mix-the-next-song. It was
much more of a "performance" with lots of quick mixing back and forth,
between beats and tunes, the laying on of effects, and  other cool
stuff.  I tend to know some of the older "rare groove" "reggae" "disco"
stuff that DJ's might play -- but not this time -- the music was as if
beamed in straight from Saturn.

Anybody know who the DJ's were? I suspect/heard it was Thomas in the
"sunlight" room, but i was unable to locate the "man behind the
curtain" because it was too crowded over by where the DJ was and
because I had passed beyond the doors of perception :-).

And the music in the "daylight" room was definitely "jazzy funky
boogie", not techno. This was actually a very nice change. I could
easily introduce some of my rock-n-roll/reggae/deadhead/anti-rave
friends to this kind of music and they'd feel right at home. 

The soundsystem in the "daylight" room was positively jurassic,
massive, large and in charge -- massive dinosaurs of bass rumbling
through the space. The music played there had a lot of horns in it and
they sounded great too (which is something a lot of disco sound systems
can't do properly). Easily one of the best soundsystems I've heard in a
long time.  It was loud, clean, and my ears did not ring afterwards,
even though I wasn't wearing earplugs. Combined w/ the excellent DJing,
the experience was nearly magical. Great stuff, I will return.

PS: I had planned on checking out Groove Kitchen, but ended up falling
asleep, waking up at 5:30AM, and heading over to Ethan's renegade. We
then proceeded to Boogie Buffet, arriving around 7AM, and we stayed
till closing. Given the reports on Groove Kitchen, I'm really glad I gave
it a miss.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
