EFFector Online Volume 5 No. 13       7/23/1993       editors@eff.org
A Publication of the Electronic Frontier Foundation   ISSN 1062-9424

                  -==--==--==-<>-==--==--==- 
                        In this issue:
             Online Congressional Hearings Postponed
             Summary of New Infrastructure Bill
             EFF Joins Telecommunications Policy Roundtable
                   -==--==--==-<>-==--==--==- 

[other items deleted]
*******************************************************
Telecommunications Infrastructure Act of 1993 (S. 1086)
*******************************************************

Introduced by Senators Danforth and Inouye on June 9, 1993
First hearing scheduled: July 14, 9:30 AM

A Summary by the Electronic Frontier Foundation

The Senate Communications Subcommittee is now in the process of 
considering legislation that would eliminate the legal monopoly that 
local telephone companies have on local phone service, allow any 
communications provider to offer local phone service, and allow local 
telephone companies to compete fully in the cable television market.  
The legislation's goal is to promote increased investment in the 
nation's telecommunications infrastructure.

The bill proposes many significant policy changes, chief among 
which is a very rapid move toward deregulating the local telephone 
companies' monopoly on local telephone service.  The policies proposed 
are laid out in broad concepts, leaving the Federal Communications 
Commission to wrestle with the actual implementation of the policies.

LOCAL EXCHANGE COMPETITION

One year after the bill is enacted, any company would be allowed 
to offer local telephone service.  Potential new entrants that would be 
allowed in the local exchange market under this bill include cable 
television companies, wireless service providers, and even Bell 
companies outside their current local exchange monopoly areas.  Any 
State laws that would preserve the current telephone company monopoly 
or limit the entry of competitors are pre-empted by the bill.

TELECOMMUNICATIONS CARRIER OBLIGATIONS

Any company that offers telecommunications service or is 
interconnected with the local exchange carrier's network has several 
obligations under this bill.  The definition of telecommunications 
service is somewhat vague, but it certainly includes voice telephone 
service, interactive data services used to carry information services, 
and possibly one-way video services such as those currently provided by 
cable television companies.  Carriers' obligations include:

1. Interconnection

All carriers that either provide telecommunications service or are 
interconnected with a carrier that provides telecommunications 
service must allow other carriers to interconnect with their network 
for the purpose of providing telecommunications or information services 
to users of either network.  Network operators must provide 
interconnection under nondiscriminatory terms, on an unbundled basis.  
Operators must also supply all necessary technical information to enable 
others to interconnect and interoperate from one network to another.

2. Universal Service

All providers of telecommunications service must contribute to the 
"preservation and advancement of universal service."  States, in 
cooperation with the FCC, are responsible to make regulations that 
establish the mechanism for supporting universal service in the newly 
competitive telephone market.  The bill does provide, however, that any 
universal service support should be given directly to "individuals and 
entities that cannot afford the cost" of telecommunications service.  
Subsidy for users' communications equipment is also allowed.

3. Number Portability

The FCC will establish regulations the provide for "portable" 
numbers from all carriers as soon as possible.  Thus, a customer could 
switch telecommunications providers without having to change telephone 
numbers.  The administration of the numbering system would be removed 
from Bellcore and placed with an "impartial entity."

INFRASTRUCTURE FOR RURAL AREAS AND NONCOMPETITIVE MARKETS

The bill recognizes that in a competitive market environment, 
rural and "noncompetitive markets" may not enjoy the level of investment 
necessary for providing advanced telecommunications services.  The 
minimum level of service desired in the bill is that which would 
"provide subscribers with sufficient network capacity to access to 
information services that provide a combination of voice, data, image, 
and video; and are available at nondiscriminatory rates that are based 
on the reasonably identifiable costs of providing such services."  It is 
not clear that such services would be interactive.  State regulators would 
be given the primary responsibility to ensure that carriers have an 
incentive to provide high-quality services to all areas.  If this 
approach fails, the FCC is empowered to take action to have necessary 
service delivered to these areas.

NETWORK STANDARDS AND PLANNING

All segments of the communications industry are encouraged to work 
together to set voluntary standards for interconnection and 
interoperability.  If the FCC determines that standards development is 
not succeeding or is proceeding too slowly, it may set incentives or 
deadlines for work to be completed.  The FCC may also impose mandatory 
standards if the voluntary process fails.  

The FCC and the States are required to ensure that advanced 
telecommunications services are designed to be accessible to people with 
disabilities.

TELEPHONE COMPANY ENTRY INTO CABLE TELEVISION MARKET

The current ban preventing local telephone companies from entering 
the cable television market is lifted, in part.  Local phone companies 
will be allowed, under the bill, to provide cable television service 
within their serving area, if the service is provided by a 
separate subsidiary and the phone company does not break any laws 
regarding improper cross-subsidization between phone service and cable 
services.  By the same token, cable companies that provide 
telecommunications service must do so through separate subsidiaries and 
obey laws regarding cross-subsidization.  Phone companies are still not 
allowed to purchase more than 5 percent interest in any cable system 
that provides services within the phone companies' service regions.

CHANGES IN LONG DISTANCE RESTRICTIONS

The restrictions on local phone companies against providing long 
distance (InterLATA) telecommunications service are lifted, in part, by 
the bill, to enable local phone companies to function more easily in the 
cable television and cellular phone markets.  Bell companies would be 
allowed to operate wireline and satellite links for the purposes of 
distributing cable television signals over long distances.  Some 
relaxation of the InterLATA restriction is also allowed to enable Bell 
companies to carry cellular phone calls from one region to another, and 
to hand off calls from one cellular system to another.  

INFORMATION SERVICES SAFEGUARDS

Bell companies that provide information services must do so 
through a separate subsidiary in order to prevent cross-subsidies that 
would be unfair to consumers of basic phone service and to information 
service competitors.  The separate subsidiary must maintain separate 
books and records, only engage in arms-length transactions with the Bell 
company, and follow other regulations that the FCC issues regarding 
accounting, tariffing, and business practices.

PRIVACY OF CUSTOMER TRANSACTION INFORMATION

Telecommunications carriers are prohibited from disclosing 
information about individual customers unless there is an affirmative, 
written request to do so by that customer.  Carriers must, however, make 
any information (Customer Proprietary Network Information) that is 
disclosed available equally to their affiliates and all competitors who 
request the information.  Customer Proprietary Network Information 
includes quantity, type, and technical characteristics of 
telecommunications service used by a customer, as well as information 
contained in bills received by the customer.

[A complete copy of S.1086 is available by anonymous ftp on ftp.eff.org.]
[Please direct any questions to eff@eff.org.]


----- End Included Message -----

From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug  9 15:03:31 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA21740; Mon, 9 Aug 93 15:03:31 PDT
Received: from netcom2.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA21733; Mon, 9 Aug 93 15:03:28 PDT
Received: by netcom2.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA03334; Mon, 9 Aug 93 15:04:21 -0700
Date: Mon, 9 Aug 93 15:04:21 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <9308092204.AA03334@netcom2.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Following sent to Lagal conference
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

To Legal Conf:

Hi,  I have a question about some possible legal violations that I think
are taking place.

First,  some background...  I like to go out dancing at raves and nightclubs
on weekends.   These clubs often practice faschist ideas like not allowing
us to bring in our OWN water.   For instance in "One Step Beyond" in Santa
Clara,
they don't allow us to bring in our own water,  thus forcing us to purchase
water they provide (At a very high price of $4 per bottle).    I cannot drink
Santa Clara Tap water because of the high bacteria content,  which causes
serious stomach problems for me.

Not only that,  I am allergic to tobacco smoke,  and often have to leave
and go outside for fresh air,   and most of these clubs don't allow us to 
leave.

One such place is 174 King St - Which s run by the most faschist group of
goons in the city.    Last weekend,  they wouldn't even allow me to stand
next to the door to get fresh air,  and I couldn't leave the place,  because
I had a ride there with a friend.

When I explained my medical problem,  the laughed and said "Just leave...",
and on the Nets,  everyone has been complaining about these practices of
depriving us of our most basic rights to water and air.

Most people go to these to dance,  and exert a lot of energy and all need
water,  and most cannot afford to purchase it at those inflated prices.
Not to mention some people on Extacey and Acid and other drugs which the
depravation of water can cause serious health problems.

We think there are certain laws that they are breaking by not providing us
with our basic needs,  or not allowing us to leave and to return.   If so,
we would be most interested in knowing if there are laws they are breaking,
and what we can do about it.   Are there any public health codes they are
breaking?  If so,  who do we file our complaints with?

Also,  I would like to take the responses and send them to our Raves group
on the Internet and ask those that respond for permission to re-post to that
mailing list as appropriate.

Thanx... On behalf of us folks that like to dance to Techno House music,
live peacefully,  and have a good time...

John D.

Just playing devil's advocate again...

> To Legal Conf:
> 
> Hi,  I have a question about some possible legal violations that I think
> are taking place.
> 
> First,  some background...  I like to go out dancing at raves and nightclubs
Avoid the word "rave".  Stick to "nightclub".  Remember the audience you're
addressing.

> Not only that,  I am allergic to tobacco smoke,  and often have to leave
> and go outside for fresh air,   and most of these clubs don't allow us to 
> leave.
They do allow you to leave.  They simply want to charge you to re-enter.
I don't see why this is against the law.

> One such place is 174 King St - Which s run by the most faschist group of
> goons in the city.    Last weekend,  they wouldn't even allow me to stand
> next to the door to get fresh air,  and I couldn't leave the place,  because
> I had a ride there with a friend.
No, you could leave.   Then you could have walked home or called a cab.  The
club is not legally obligated to let you back in just because your ride is 
still inside.

> Not to mention some people on Extacey and Acid and other drugs which the
> depravation of water can cause serious health problems.
Mentioning drugs is not going to go over well with the audience you're 
addressing.

I was gonna view the shower with some friends but now I too wonder if 
anything is going on that night.  Meteor showers are best viewed after
midnight because the earth's rotation is then rotating into the meteor
field head on so to speak.  I've been watching this shower for about
8 years now and it's never been that exciting.  I hope this year pays
off like it's supposed to.

If nothing is going on anyone is welcome to join us.  I was going to go
to the Berkeley or Oakland hills, which are dark enough believe it or not
but if it's overcast, I'll go to Briones or Diablo, both should be out of
the SF-Marin-Berkeley fog belt.

-Mark

Subject: This weekend
X-Sun-Charset: US-ASCII

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Ok, so nobody liked Groove Kitchen, but were you really surprised? I have never
been to 174 King St. when it wasn't really hot and crowded. And it is always
vibeless until well after 3:00 a.m. This is because the clubby crowds clued 
into it as a space where events were frequently held and it became a sort of
regular spot during a night of bar hopping. The only unpleasant surprise for
me that evening was the lack of ins and outs. That is usually the saving grace
of events held there. It surprises me to hear bitching about the things that 
are always true about that space. Not that they don't deserve to be bitched
about, but if you can't deal with that stuff, why did you go there?

On a brighter note, San Jose is becoming the center for a number of truly
happening events. Every other Monday, Rick Preston and Harry Who host a party
called Free Life at the F/X which is consistently cool and they've just
started a new party called Progress which is held every Tuesday night at a
place called Club Oz. Thursday nights there is Deep Space, which is consistently
wonderful and there is also an Acid Jazz night at the Ajax lounge which gets
going early enough that you can go to it before Deep Space. 

The afterparty for Where the Wild Things Are was a really cool little event.
Good music, which was well suited to the time, venue and crowd. The people
were happy and friendly. And there was an espresso bar (every afterparty
should have one). It was a fun place to hang out.

						Pete

Did anybody read the article "Cintra Wilson's Fantastic Space Odyssey"
in Sunday's SF Examiner Image section?  It's not real serious, but it
gives the impression that ravers are big believers in UFOs.  The only
link I had perceived before was the ToonTown "UFO's Are Real" rave over
a year ago.

But the writer talks to Ernie Munson (the DJ), Nick Philip (from
Anarchic Adjustment), Steve Mitchell (a raver), and Matt (a rave flyer
designer).  Each are portrayed as big believers in UFO's and aliens,
then they tie those beliefs to the sort of spacey/psychedelic/
spiritual weirdo beliefs about love and communication and energy that
we ravers have ;)  (Matt is portrayed as a bit paranoid, though).

It's too long for me to type in, but if you don't have Sunday's paper,
someone you know probably does (if you live around here).

One quick excerpt:

  	Ernie told me that there are a lot of souls that were 
	originally from another planet whose sole purpose of
  	reincarnating into human form on Earth is to spread
  	the message that the kingdom of heaven is within us,
  	and that we are all gods and goddesses linked together
  	in a fabulous expansion of the overall mind of goodness.
  	He said that I was probably one of these reincarnated
  	aliens, sent to expose this information through my 
  	writing.  I thought that sounded pretty bitching.


Someone should write a letter to the editor about luv phasers :) :)

-Derek

You have been misinformed.  The reason that they allow the parties to go
off there is that they are educated to the fact that they can make bank by
letting in 13+ into this space, charge bucks, and make out like bandits. 
They are quite aware about money, and how to make it.  As for problems, the
only probs. at Richmond are the hillbillies that tend to appear.  Czech it.

!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Ok Sean and others...that does it! 8-{ !
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

First I wanna say to whoever threw that so-called ug (underground) at 24 & 3rd:
weak (so weak I give it a small 'w').  That space is NOT at all new...the
first late train was thrown there WAAAAAAAY back.  Get original pleeeeze.

Next about boycotting spaces...whatever.  So far the only places to have
parties that will suit many of you will be outdoor freebies.  Good luck in
finding them, and good luck keeping them from getting busted.

As for the constant and annoying complaints about smoking...tough!  Look
you're in a CLUB, people smoke, always have!  If it's not cig's it's pot,
if it's not that it's the fog machine...sheesh...Here is the solution...If
you know it's gonna be in a club, DO NOT GO!  As a matter of fact if it's
going to be in SF DON'T GO!  This will help all of the minions with rashes,
sore achy eyes, and the breathing impaired.  No it's not that I'm
insensitive but I hate to hear people complain especially when they damn
well know what to expect!  Have ANY of you ever gone to a CLUB here in SF
that was smoke free??!!??  Didn't think so...as for the TAZ space, like
soooo many others, it will NOT last.  The one thing the cops know is when a
party is getting big, and YSH @ that loc is no exception!  Time will tell. 
And god help it if it moves into a club where, god forbid, SMOKERS of all
sorts will be there!

Yeah yeah yeah, I know that we ALL (I do NOT smoke) deserve to party in a
place with more ventilation (I wish they had more at the above spaces), but
at a rave, a true UG rave, a true warehouse rave, smoke whether by smoke
machine or pot, is used to make the effect.  My best times were spent here
in THIS city in sweaty warehouse's, sweaty clubs, with people going off! 
This is the REAL SF!  No room for the weak, timid, or environmentally
aware.  Either you're there to party and sweat, or you're there for
nothing.  Either you're there for the drugs, or you're there for nothing. 
Either your there for the infamous BASS that MAKES house HOUSE, or you're
there for nothing!  

I know that King St. is rather opressive, but it is because of underage
fucks, & non id carrying assholes getting into trouble that has caused that
place to become Stalag 19!  And this is true of many places, who at one
time were VERY COOL about people getting in, that must protect themselves
from a selfish few who only care about themselves and not others.  Look, I
know that there have been certain people in this group who are NOT 21
somehow sneaking into clubs (either under the guise of "working", or just
sticking around until the club opens) and just melding in.  This is self
centered and stupid since the place can easily get busted for such an
offense.  This ruins it for the people who are there legitimately!  There
are spaces for people who are 21-.  These are most clubs in SF before 2:30
a.m. , DV8 & the Stone.  Those are your choices.  So if you're 21-- either
go to those clubs(DV8 & Stone"d"), go to ones that allow you in until 2:30,
or wait for a massive that are usually all ages!  It's that simple.  Or you
can get politcially active, but seems to me that there has been more talk
than action of late.

Now about other clubs...Sean you bagged on Boogie Buffet.  I take personal
offense at this since P is a very good friend of mine, and has done one
helluva good job with that space.  It is a club for 21+ period.  Why?
(Besides zoning & licensing)  Well maybe the people who are 21+ do NOT want
to be around people 21--.  No reason needs to be given, but that seems to
have escaped many people's attention.  People go to Wicked, and don't go to
the Gathering for those reasons alone.  It's not right or wrong, everyone
has preferences.  The thing I love about most of P's gigs are the ONE thing
that most of these other parties everyone talks about lacks...DIVERSITY! Go
to a Gathering I am hard pressed to find Asian's (in numbers),
Latino's/Chicano's/La Raza (in numbers), and most glaringly
African-American's (in ANY numbers).  You go to a Boogie or a Groove and
you will see a multitude of colors, people's, and lifestyles!  Not just a
bunch of white kids waiting for the second coming of Jesus to appear on the
dancefloor!  Most of the 21+ clubs are like that.  Just a bit more diverse
than the average so-called "rave"!  Wicked is the same thing...I see a few
Brothers there (although the crowd has changed over the years from the
old-skool->new-school they still have a vibe thang going on...and as much
as I don't like the changes in Wicked, those dudes THROW DOWN (21+ sorry,
and you won't get the same vibe at Get Down)!

As for Richmond Center.  One of the only places 21-- can go all night,
smoke out and have a good time.  The presence remains outdoors..when there
is not a presence people get hurt.  This has been proven time and time
again.  Why, if the cops are being cool and staying outdoors is this a
problem I duuno.  I rahter they check outside than lurk inside.  Believe me
they have helped make situations better at parties at times, not worse
(besides if you have off duty cops, and you wax them your party won't get
busted).  I hardly ever worry about cops, I worry about the testosterone
laden rednecks that have been showing up to parties of late.  Those fucks
get drunk, and fight over their Daisy Dukes lookin' girlfriend just becuase
some guy said 'hello'.  Happens quite often at Gatherings...check it (as
well as the first benefit for Malachy! ohhh what a vibe :(    )!  

All of this talk about lawsuits (in an already too letiginous society), and
boycotts (how far the right wing has gotten), and bullshit about a club
being 21+ is doing one thing to the scene, KILLING IT!  Much like Gays have
pulled away from the "rave" scene because of the general unfriendly nature
of hillbilly het's, the same thing is happening here.  It is occuring along
age lines this time, and cultural lines, and who does whatever non-pc
thing-of-the-day line.  Pesonally I'm sick of it.  Instead of being more
inclusive many sound like the right winger's trying to make something their
exclusive domain, for their ideas and their kind.  Well that's fine...maybe
with enough filtering things will get back to normal...no more ug's, no
more parties, no more "raves".  Just a bunch of letiginous homogenous
hippies celebrating trees, and trying to save some fucking whale, while the
children of Hunter's Point, Potrero Hill, and the Mission District continue
thier cannibalism whilst you watch and wonder "why don't they dance?"!

So look, the UG has been here sooo strong that it never left.  Just like
the old days you gotta know someone to go!  This exclusivity I like!  Why? 
Becuase they're held in H.Point, The Mission, under the moon, with people
of MANY colors dancing and grooving to each other.  They are there to
party, crack on, joke around, and have a good time, no fighting or rednecks
allowed.  THAT is a RAVE.  Anything else is a mere imitation and pales in
comparison!  So sue away, stay away, gripe away, walk away....the party
WILL continue.  The choice is ALWAYS yours!  

My personal review:
GK- Seen better, Mark Farina fucked it up!
Boogie - Getting uglier with their exotic dancer preview, but many, many
fine points that make it THE afterhours in SF.
Fridge - Didn't go but heard good things.
Renegade - Many have asked "How'd they have it there with all those ---s in
the ---d?"  Heard some good things about it, way to go!  Hopefully onto a
more original venue, but ya gotta start somewhere!
Wild Things - Didn't go, haven't heard.


Disclaimer to Sean Casey:
Sean this was NOT a personal attack on you whatsoever.  Your's was just the
last straw in a string of staws I've seen posted since Sat.  You have been
generally objective in the past, but I had no other choice but to react
when I read "Boycott 'em all, and let god sort them out" rhetoric. 
Whatever...I ain't mad at you directly...sorry you have had such a bad time
at those clubs but they are what they are and they make no illusions about
it.  Know b4 you go!

providing one of the best spaces in SF for that community to have parties.

events that have been all inclusive of people regardless of their race,
creed, or sexual orientation (Toon-Town remains as one of the MOST
intergrated parties EVER here in SF).  A guy with a heart who has opened
the King ST. garage for all to enjoy.  Yeah, sue him...he deserves it after
all he's done!

>   The OWNER of King St.  Is a kind man who I think is bed ridden with an
>   illness.  He has given back to the community (primarily gay/lesbian) by
>   providing one of the best spaces in SF for that community to have parties. 
>   He has also been open to the Rave community (check Toon-Town) and other
>   events that have been all inclusive of people regardless of their race,
>   creed, or sexual orientation (Toon-Town remains as one of the MOST
>   intergrated parties EVER here in SF).  A guy with a heart who has opened
>   the King ST. garage for all to enjoy.

    That's interesting.
    Perhaps the owner needs to be informed of how some of his employees
    have been running the place.  I'm particularly thinking of the
    untimely shutdown of Aurgasm last month.  If the *owner* is bed-ridden
    then he didn't shut down that party, but somebody working for him did.
    That is a reasonable thing to complain about, I think.  Smoke is
    to be expected in a club, no ins-and-outs is at least something they
    tell you about when you come in, but shutting down the party at
    2:30 when it's supposed to go until dawn isn't right.  I was psyched
    for what Aurgasm was trying to do there, and wanted do it all night.
    Some folks took the train from the South Bay to that party,
    assuming that it would be running again by the time the party ended.

    I don't think suing anybody will solve anything, it will just make
    it harder for us to get spaces to have our parties in.

    Perhaps if somebody *knows* the owner of King Street, they should
    talk to him.
                        rave on
                                &andy

Subject: cool/uncool/whatever spaces
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


John and Crunch both have good points, but:
1) John will have a better time with promoters and security than most people
because he is in the promoter end of the scene and therefore knows a lot
of them and understands why security exists.  Since an above-ground business
must NOT deny entrance to people on any grounds but imminent danger (or
risk lawsuits), you get all kinds, many of which look for trouble.  If you're
going to make bucks, you need theirs too, so you're stuck underground
if you want to restrict your circle to a small known scene.
2) CC (and many others on the consumer side) will note that a lot of things
obviously suck.  (Liquor->age limit, curfew, high rent, public land that
isn't really public, AntiSomeDrug laws, etc.)  So obviously it's the fault
of the people putting on the event, or the people who own the space.

I find myself agreeing a bit more with John here (!) in that GK might have
been a crummy place that night, but a lawsuit?  Seems like the problems are
mostly due to archaic fire codes and crummy ventilation.  OK, I won't go
there.  Most of the problems on the list above are due to legal bullshit
and not promoters: if it was easier to throw events that were more like
a rave, we'd see more, and people would stop going to the crummy places.
We can either throw more renegades, or agitate for change.  Hey, in San
Jose no one can do anything after 2 AM.  And you think SF is rough...

Still, comments like "ins and outs if you know the promoter" don't help
the people who, as John noted, are paying for it, and annoying security
can be a problem.  Hey -- if I can't bring in water I turn around and
leave.

I'd love everything to be as great as PW was, but they lost a ton of money.
I hope events like that are more what we want so that next time something
similar happens it'll be able to happen again.  Maybe people all just
want beer and attitude: I hope not.

So what am I saying?  I dunno.  Do what you gotta do.  // g

It's funny that King street seems to be creating lots of bytes in the matrix...
In Montreal, King and Prince street have always been the center of heated
discussions here... There are 2 garages converted to "made for warehouse
parties". The guy who owns these places makes more money than most clubs,
charging 3000$ a night to promoters for renting the place... however, it has
never been busted except on new years day because they didn't have permits, and
even if the security is like a state pen, the parties (dont say the r word)
are always succesfull.

Anyway, just a little note... As for charging for water, and no going out, i'm
affraid it's universal... Please let the good old days return...

Ciao,

All right now, John.  I rarely get angry because I don't believe in
doing so without a good cause; but this message is just too much.
From your previous postings I've thought you a pretty cool guy and
wanted to meet you personally; but now I'm starting to wonder what
sort of fucked-up attitude trip you're on.  If you want to contribute
useful information and viewpoints, then I welcome your input
wholeheartedly; but if all you want to do is prove how much better
and more well connected you are than everyone else, then please go
away.

In article <9308100336.AA00359@netcom.netcom.com> you write:
|>
|>(Name?) 174 King St., SF
|>        21+. No ventilation. NO COOL AREAS. Very rude staff. No
|>        re-entry. Small.
|>
|
|You have been misinformed.  The whole space is cool. 21+ is VERY cool :)

I seriously don't understand the way you continually harp on how great
21+ is.  Get it into your head -- 21+ is an ARBITRARY division coming
out of a stupid legal system that likes to oversimplify things.  There
is no sudden jump in coolness that happens when someone turns 21.  There
are plenty of cool 17 year olds, and plenty of fucked-up 25 year olds.
Everyone goes at their own pace.

|
|>One Step Beyond, (Address?), Santa Clara
|>        Age limit? NO WATER. NO BACKPACKS. Rude staff. No re-entry.
|>
|
|You have been misinformed.  OSB has no age limit and there's no question
|about it.  Nice staff, & re-entry if you know the promoter. Check it.

You also mention below about "if you know the promoter".  Don't you
realize -- NOT EVERYONE KNOWS THE PROMOTER?  Why must everything be
so elitist?  Furthermore, this attitude is very hypocritical when
compared to the rest of your message:

1) Isn't "knowing the promoter" akin to getting around the law?  If
you're so keen on lambasting 21-- people for trying to get around the
silly 21+ laws, and others who might invite the wrath of the fire
marshals, shouldn't you flame yourself for getting around the no
ins/outs and no-free-water policies?   For that matter, shouldn't
you be reporting your underground parties to the police, since they're
obviously illegal?  Either rules are meant to be followed or they aren't;
you can't go both ways.

2) Furthermore, realize that your elitist "I'm in, you're not" attitude
is exactly akin to the old "I'm white, you're not."  Think about this
before ragging any more on white hets just because of their skin color
and sexual preference.

|You have been misinformed.  There is no question about the age limit it is
|21+ only.  They have plenty of water.  Free if you know the promoter. $0.50
					^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
|First I wanna say to whoever threw that so-called ug (underground) at 24 & 3rd:
|weak (so weak I give it a small 'w').  That space is NOT at all new...the
|first late train was thrown there WAAAAAAAY back.  Get original pleeeeze.

Man, what *is* your problem?  Besides the fact that not all of us have the
exquisite privilege of attending your cherished Late Trains, why is it
"weak with a small 'w'" to call a party "underground" merely because the
space was used before?  Nobody is denying that the space was used before;
YSH was there about 6 weeks ago.  (perhaps you didn't know that because
you're too "in" to go to YSH?)  If you're going to get so worked up about
not finding a totally unused space, then why are you going to such lengths
to defend the heavily used King St. space?

|going to be in SF DON'T GO!  This will help all of the minions with rashes,
|sore achy eyes, and the breathing impaired.  No it's not that I'm

Your criticism of John Draper for saying "big black goons" has no validity
at all if you start resorting to the same kind of mudslinging that he
did.

|I know that King St. is rather opressive, but it is because of underage
|fucks, & non id carrying assholes getting into trouble that has caused that
|place to become Stalag 19!  And this is true of many places, who at one
|time were VERY COOL about people getting in, that must protect themselves
|from a selfish few who only care about themselves and not others.

"selfish few who only care about themselves and not others" -- indeed so,
Mr. 21+ Elitist.

|There
|are spaces for people who are 21-.  These are most clubs in SF before 2:30
|a.m. , DV8 & the Stone.  Those are your choices.  So if you're 21-- either
|go to those clubs(DV8 & Stone"d"), go to ones that allow you in until 2:30,
|or wait for a massive that are usually all ages!  It's that simple.

I suppose if I'm under 21 then I better just go away and hide myself
under a rock until I "come of age" and cease to be the vermin I once was.

|(besides if you have off duty cops, and you wax them your party won't get
|busted)

Man, let me say this again.  If you're not gonna follow the law, then
you sure as hell better not complain about others who don't do so either.

|Instead of being more
|inclusive many sound like the right winger's trying to make something their
|exclusive domain, for their ideas and their kind.

Mr. "I'm inclusive of you [as long as you know the right people]" speaks
again.

|So look, the UG has been here sooo strong that it never left.  Just like
|the old days you gotta know someone to go!  This exclusivity I like!  Why? 
|Becuase they're held in H.Point, The Mission, under the moon, with people
|of MANY colors dancing and grooving to each other.

Answer me, is raving about inclusivity, friendliness and good vibes, or
is it about having the right suitably oppressed color of skin and holding
it in the right suitably oppressed part of town?  I think getting more
diversity is a very good thing to do, but there's something wrong when age,
skin color, sexual preference, etc.  becomes a politically correct litmus
test (sorry to throw these overused political terms into the discussion)
determining whether a party is good or not.  If racial diversity is your
sole or primary determinant of good vibe, then that's fine with me, but you
need to preface your remarks with a big IMHO rather than stating them as the
out-and-out word of God, esp. seeing as so many people on this list clearly
disagree with you.

Ben
(who, BTW, is not 21--)

In article <9308100437.AA08908@netcom.netcom.com> you write:
|GK- Seen better, Mark Farina fucked it up!
|(for all who take things too literally this IS a good thing.  Mark Farina
|Played a BRILLIANT set...just in case it was not clear!)

Have to agree with you here ...  I was about to leave Groove Kitchen at
about 3 or 3:30 when all of a sudden I noticed that the music was REAL
real good and the people were dancing hard, and I threw myself into the
dance!  I ended up staying till 5 or so.

My biggest complaints about G.K. were not the space (which I thought was
fine; the smoke and heat didn't bother me much and the humorless security
was more a minor annoyance than anything else) but the people ...  granted
there were a lot of real good looking people, which is always nice :),
but so many of them projected such negative energy ...  there were pockets
of good vibe here and there, esp. on the dance floor itself, but all the
negativity from the other people really dampened the overall atmosphere.

As it happens, all of the events I've been to with really good vibe have
been inclusive of under 21'ers.  Coincidence or not?  You make the call.

Ben

not sit by while many nice spaces are skewered by people for what I see as
ridiculous reasons.  21+!, I and MANY others like them (ever seen Wicked
not have a vibe or people not go because it's 21--. If so I ASSURE you that
THEY are in the minority).  The thing lacking here is perspective.  You and
others make these GRAND assumptions about spaces, and people.  You ASSUME
that becuase YOU want 21-- to mingle with 21+ that the 21+ want the same. 
Not a safe asumtion.  There is a REASON why many of the crowd that goes to
Wicked, GK, and other generally 21+ events stay away from all ages.  And
they have a right to do so without having to explain themselves.  So yeah,
21+ is great.  21-- going into a club for 21+ is a no-no and is
disingenuine with the concerns of others who are legitimately there.  If

are the one who is intolerant.  Check it.

and becuase I beleive in what they represent am more than willing to spend

certain priviledges with others who do the same.  Most of my firends do NOT
throw parties.  But I am more than happy to share my privs with others

het's I am now certain you cannot read.  I know my spelling needs help

black goon" is more in line with your train of thought.  Man, that pretty
much says it all about how you twist and distort the obvious for the sake
of some misguided ideal.  Diversity is great, anything less is a farce. No
more hillbilly parties with a bunch of okies unless there are plenty of
carmel bits & chocolate chips.  Check it.

been to a few of them but they occur on nights that I usually have to work.
 It is this "idea' that that space was sooooo cool and soooo new when it
has been broken in, and done before.  So much so the kops are well aware of
it.  Keep having stuff there and it will get busted, sound equip.
confiscated and other harsh shit.  Look, I beleive that UG's no matter what
are GREAT.  Could give a fuck who throws them, as long as they go off.  I
have gone to 2 FMM's, and don't like 'em.  But because they try ot have
them in diff locations and keep the party mobile I have little to say. 
They are doing more to keep the UG scene alive than anyone else.  In the
post I said NOTHING about the quality of the party, just that the space
itslef was weak, used, and done.  But becuase you are looking for a problem
you found one.  I am getting worked up about the only-way-is-our-way
attitude that you and others have.  You dislike the space, you dislike the
promoter, you dislike the culture, you dislike almost everything, Yet how
unwilling you are to spend thousands of your own dollars to make a diff. 
This is the hypocracy.

As for the constant bashing of my connections and me being a promoter. 
There are many on this board who are comped at parties while  YOU have to
spend $15-$20 to attend.  They don't talk about it.  I do.  Why?  Becuase I
don't beleive in secrets and other BS.  There are MANY facests to this
culture that you and others are unaware.  I am giving you my perspective as
a person who for most of the time has PAID to get into events, and STILL
PAY (yep, I may get comped, and have 3 on the list, but I will throw down
$45-$60 to get them in.  I am not rich by any means, but I ALWAYS pay.  One
way or another I pay!  When have YOU done that).  As for the "if you know
the promoter"  you're all cuaght up in making a point that you lost the
joke.  Not all that uncommon, but the thing is, read carefully now, "1015
has FREE water.  There is no 0.50 charge!"  (during Sunday morn) Maybe if
you went to events there you might have found this out.  Stop the hype.

Check it.

>
>|going to be in SF DON'T GO!  This will help all of the minions with rashes,
>|sore achy eyes, and the breathing impaired.  No it's not that I'm
>
>Your criticism of John Draper for saying "big black goons" has no validity
>at all if you start resorting to the same kind of mudslinging that he
>did.

You have been misinformed.  What mudslinging.  The fact is if you know
about the space and don't like it stay home.  Don't go if you know that its
gonna be smoked out etc.  In other words be RESPONSIBLE FOR YOUR OWN
ACTIONS.  How this is mudslinging escapes me.  Your constant hyperbole does
not however so I advise you to check it.

>
>|I know that King St. is rather opressive, but it is because of underage
>|fucks, & non id carrying assholes getting into trouble that has caused that
>|place to become Stalag 19!  And this is true of many places, who at one
>|time were VERY COOL about people getting in, that must protect themselves
>|from a selfish few who only care about themselves and not others.
>
>"selfish few who only care about themselves and not others" -- indeed so,
>Mr. 21+ Elitist.

You are misinformed.  The licensing says 21+.  The fact people go there is
due to them NOT wanting to mix with 21--.  This is wrong in your eyes.  In
mine it has always been ok for people to freely associtate with their
peers.  This is called FREEDOM.  Maybe if you understood the concept a bit
better you would have less complaints about people not attending 21--
events.  Oh yeah, there has been at LEAST 1 GK closed due to a 21-- being
present.  Wicked was closed becuase of overcrowding OUTSIDE and well as all
the hallways blocekd with people inside.  A fire hazard sir.  But you could
give a fuck about that and the people who are in such a fire trap.  That is
why that "black goon" told Mr. Draper to get in or get out.  For the safety
of many he denied 1 person an exclusive privvy.  Man  what a concept.
Breathe-in breathe-out, blink. Check it.

>
>|There
>|are spaces for people who are 21-.  These are most clubs in SF before 2:30
>|a.m. , DV8 & the Stone.  Those are your choices.  So if you're 21-- either
>|go to those clubs(DV8 & Stone"d"), go to ones that allow you in until 2:30,
>|or wait for a massive that are usually all ages!  It's that simple.

>I suppose if I'm under 21 then I better just go away and hide myself
>under a rock until I "come of age" and cease to be the vermin I once was.

You have been misinforme.  You can go to FMM or to the larger parties that
are usually all ages.  Is there something wrong with that?  Check it.

>|(besides if you have off duty cops, and you wax them your party won't get
>|busted)
>
>Man, let me say this again.  If you're not gonna follow the law, then
>you sure as hell better not complain about others who don't do so either.

You are engaging in more hype. Check it.


>|Instead of being more
>|inclusive many sound like the right winger's trying to make something their
>|exclusive domain, for their ideas and their kind.
>
>Mr. "I'm inclusive of you [as long as you know the right people]" speaks
>again.

You are misinformed.  All of you know the right people to get into a club. 
It is the person at the front who either sells you a ticket or not.  This
is they key togetting in ANY club.  Check it.

>
>|So look, the UG has been here sooo strong that it never left.  Just like
>|the old days you gotta know someone to go!  This exclusivity I like!  Why? 
>|Becuase they're held in H.Point, The Mission, under the moon, with people
>|of MANY colors dancing and grooving to each other.
>
>Answer me, is raving about inclusivity, friendliness and good vibes, or
>is it about having the right suitably oppressed color of skin and holding
>it in the right suitably oppressed part of town?  I think getting more
>diversity is a very good thing to do, but there's something wrong when age,
>skin color, sexual preference, etc.  becomes a politically correct litmus
>test (sorry to throw these overused political terms into the discussion)
>determining whether a party is good or not.  If racial diversity is your
>sole or primary determinant of good vibe, then that's fine with me, but you
>need to preface your remarks with a big IMHO rather than stating them as the
>out-and-out word of God, esp. seeing as so many people on this list clearly
>disagree with you.
>
>Ben
>(who, BTW, is not 21--)

You have been misinformed.  I said the one thing I like that other parties
lack is diversity.  But somehow in that hyped-up mind of your you have
twisted that around to make it seem as though THAT is a bad thing.  Well
let's lay it out.  What IS bad is the homogeneous nature of raves of late. 
I don't like it.  Moreso than smokers that shit burns me up.  I do not like
it that gays/lesbians who FOUNDED the fucking house scene have been going
to their own clubs becuase "raves" became the mecca of horny aggro het's. 
I like it when I see people of ALL backgrounds grooving together.  That is
MY criteria, and MANY share it.  But you don't.  As long as there is music
and your buddies there that's all you need.  Well ok, to each his own.  But
I respect that concept, whereas you do not.  If anyone can be called a pc
elitist it is you.  You have a very narrow view of what makes/breaks this
scene.  If the scene can accomodate the many interests and tastes of the
community then it will thrive.  That has NOT been happening.  The more
homogenoues it has gotten the quicker it has withered.  Diversity is
strength and fueling that diversity is a big job.  It just takes the right
people, the right vibe, the right 'tude to do it.  And I am all about that.

Maybe if you were not so concerned with the class schtick
(promoter/partier) you would understand that they are all the same.  People
who throw these gigs for you to enjoy have done so for many reasons, but
most of all the people who have been doing it for 2-3 years beleive in what
they do. We don't sit around and decide who is in or out, most of the
converstaion have been on raising the quality of parties and giving people
even MORE for their money.  You can't say that about LA.  Most of the
people who throw decent parties are the same people who used to pay to get
into parties.  They decided that they wanted something different so they
did it themselves.  And now you have the Gathering, Sharon, Basics,
Foundation, Vortex, Origin, YSH, Together, WIcked, FMM, and others.  You
have lost sight of this.  I am not an elitist pig or whatever
label-of-the-day you want to call me.  I could care less what you call me. 
People get compe'd for a variety of reasons.  Personally I think it's
funny, and NEVER take the shit seriously.  Thats why I say things like "if
you know the promoter"  becuase in essence that will have very little to do
with having a good time.  Either the party is good or it's bad.  All those
promoter privies are just that.  And they exist like any other support
mechanism and are there, for people who do a certain thing, to provide a
small break for them.  Hell if a person has spent $5000 putting on a show
why should they not get a little from a friend who has done the same thing
and understands the headache and joy that goes with doing a party.  So we
comp each other.  Is that so bad?  You mean if a friend of yours wanted a
favor from you you would not do it?  If an SFR needed help you would not
provide it?  I guess that I was mistaken in thinking that I could share
some things with you.  Oh well...stay myopic, it's easier that way. Check
it.

Crunch has not a leg to stand on...should'nt have gone.  And that shit
about a "big black goon" is still BS, but ben thinks this is ok so...

>>All right now, John.  I rarely get angry because I don't believe in
>>doing so without a good cause; but this message is just too much.
>>>From your previous postings I've thought you a pretty cool guy and
>>wanted to meet you personally; but now I'm starting to wonder what
>>sort of fucked-up attitude trip you're on.  If you want to contribute
>>useful information and viewpoints, then I welcome your input
>>wholeheartedly; but if all you want to do is prove how much better
>>and more well connected you are than everyone else, then please go

I decided this paragraph was especially insidious since it asks me to leave
so I'll reply. Look, I have many complaints about parties.  And many gripes
against promoters and others.  Do you know what I do?  TAKE ACTION (or in
my case INACTION).  I do NOT like massives.  I don't complain about them. 
I may comment on what I think they will be (usually correct), but that's
it.  Since I don't like them I STAY AWAY from them.  I don't go, after
stating I dislike them, then re-appear here to aire the obvious discontent
I have with my actions.  THIS IS THE HYPOCRACY.  I go to VERY few 21--
events, but I won't bag em.  I don't go to Sharon's or the Gatherings
(except for a few) because the crowd and vibe does not suit me.  But I
don't bag 'em.  And when I do go I know exactly what to expect, not becuase
I know the promoter or some "inside track".  Plain and simple I've been to
the party before and I know what to expect.  So when I see people complain,
and bitch, and complain, and bitch about things they have already made
apparent it pisses me off!  So since you have decided that the things I say
are of little use, tell me what is?  Tell me EXACTLY what you want to hear,
and how you want to hear it.  Of course I will not oblige BUT since you
only want certain kinds of info please STATE for the record what this info
is.  If I can't take it I will treat it like I treat parties, and stay
silent (aka stay away bka go away).  But please be sure to enforce it
equally lest you be given the title hypocrite.  But I DO want to know what
you, the god of the list with his own "inside track", deem acceptable and
not.  I am morbidly curious.  I am curious of why I can't say "diversity"
and Crunch can say "black goon", I am curious.  I am curious as to why I
can't say that I like or even love 21+ while others can state otherwise.  I
am curious why you can't read veiled sarcasm, yet read so clearly the words
of others. I am curios as to why others can debate and state their case yet
when I state mine I am labeled, stamped, filed, indexed, briefed,
de-breifed, and numbered.  Yes I am curious.  But like I said, if you lay
down the law (since you're the man in charge here), and I don't like it I
will bow out, no problem.  I await your answer. Until then...

	id AA26849; Tue, 10 Aug 93 10:00:04 PDT
Received: from orca.es.com (ES.COM) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA26827; Tue, 10 Aug 93 09:59:54 PDT
Received: from slack ([130.187.198.23]) by orca.es.com (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA08644; Tue, 10 Aug 93 10:59:51 MDT
Received: by slack (4.1/E&S_client-ver1.5/SMI-4.1)
	id AA00826; Tue, 10 Aug 93 10:58:31 MDT
From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Message-Id: <9308101658.AA00826@slack>
Subject: FreeVibe and more
To: nw-raves@wimsey.bc.ca (NW Raves), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SF Raves)
Date: Tue, 10 Aug 1993 10:58:29 -0600 (MDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL22]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 5234      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

First off, thanks to Glen, Rick, and Tim for pulling this thing together and
doing a great job.

I packed my Denon, my Biamp, and ~300 CDs in a large shipping box that was
BARELY under Delta's maximum weight (70 pounds).  I actually had to throw
about 100 CDs in my clothes bag in order to level things out.  Then when I got
to the airport, the ticket agent didn't even bother to weigh it.

Upon arrival in Seattle, I called Glen and Mike to see what the status was.  I
then went hiking in the Northern Cascades (great views, bad bugs) on Thursday
and Friday afternoon.  When I got back, I gave Glen another call and he was
very excited about the situation.  He'd contacted a local promoter about it,
and 10,000 watts of sound had been arranged along with a generator.  I had
brought up a small quantity of vinyl as well, and Glen stated there would be
turntables there.

When Gretchen and I arrived at the gate, there was one car waiting and nobody
else there.  The gate was locked.  Soon the sound van arrived and a bit of
discussion ensued.  Someone stated that maybe they were up at the site and
they'd come down periodically.  I volunteered to hike up there (about a mile
and a half) to find out.  I jumped the fence and started the trek.  About a
half mile in, I noticed lights coming up the road.  The gate had been opened
and everyone had been let in.

We arrived at the quarry to find nobody there.  It was a great spot, secluded,
large, interesting, with one catch.  Trespassing big-time.  It was government
property and the promoter had cut a lock and replaced it with his own to let
everyone in.  Despite this news, the sound guys started setting up and soon I
had patched in my mixer and CD player.  No turntables were in sight.

Things kicked off for a small crowd of 20 at the time.  I wondered how many
more people would show up during the night.  About after an hour of playing,
around 80 people had arrived and were gathered around a nearby campfire.  Only
a few people were dancing, about ten, but they were ripping it hard.  I had
the equipment on Gretchen's 4-Runner tailgate, with my back to the crowd.  It
was like flying blind, I periodically had to turn around to see what was going
on.

More than few people wandered up to see what was going on with the drastically
different setup.  A few people asked me about how the Denon worked and I
showed them, but more just gaped at the stacks of CDs I'd lugged 800 miles.
Some other DJs had turned up and they had brought a coffin with 1200's.  I
plugged them into one of my tape inputs and they were ready to be fired off.
Meanwhile they got blitzed out of their minds.  I talked to one who was really
friendly, I can't remember his name, but he stated his big claim to fame was
the fact that he had DJ'd for "Rave Called Sharon" (ugh).  At about 2:00 I
quit and slid things over to the other mixer.

Over the course of the night DJ's kept showing up in hoards.  What
disappointed me was the extreme attitude most of these guys carried.  Very few
of them danced, and most just hung around the tables in a circle.  There were
mixed talents, but there were two guys in particular who played really well.
Too bad I have no idea who they were.

People still didn't dance in force until about the middle of the third DJ.
This was about 3:30, and the only thing I can attribute it to was the hardcore
showing up later.  My set was all over the place and nothing really seemed to
spark any fires.  With the exception of one ambient/trance DJ, the other guys
just played fairly straightforward house.

At 6:00, Gretchen and I really needed to leave.  We had a full schedule
planned for Sunday, and sleeping through half of it really didn't facilitate
that fact.  My equipment was still being used, albeit just as a pass-through.
I managed to convince Tim that I could hot-swap the stuff off with just a
minimal break in sound.  We did so, but then I was informed that I couldn't
get out of the quarry.  The guy with the key had disappeared.  I didn't know
if I was being bullshitted, so I bullshitted right back.  I told them I needed
to be at the airport, ASAP.  It wasn't making me very happy that all of a
sudden this had turned into a lock-in early in the morning without warning.
Gretchen calmed me down and we agreed that we would stay until 8:00 when they
would unlock the gate.  I started to fall asleep in her truck until then.

Suddenly the call came to shut everything down.  I was mostly packed up, so we
closed the truck up and got out.  On the way out, we saw the police on the way
in.  I have no idea what happened to the promoters, but I feared for the
worst.  They were blatently trespassing, no bones about it.  If they managed
to pack everything up in time, I'd imagine they would have gotten out safely,
but the amount of time it took to unload made me realize that it was going to
take a while to pack up.

All in all, it was a good time.  Gretchen is a rave newbie and she danced hard
all night.  We took a short nap inside her truck and it was really weird to
wake up and see video being projected on a rock wall outside the truck.  I was
pleased to meet Arias, Glen, and Rick.  I wish you folks could be down here
this weekend for the desert show.

My response to John Lee's comments...

>I see, now we have a big black goon. Everywhere else he just calls them
>goons, but he had to make a point about this particular security agent
>being black.  What gives?  What is the purpose of this classification?  Are
>we to imagine Mike Tyson or some other "big black goon". Hmmm...so much for
>a color blind society. Check it.

I am only describing the particular individual,  don't care about color...
Didn't mean to implicate anything,  and sorry I came across that way.

>Have you ever thought that mutual respect for another person might have
>gotten you farther?  Maybe your understanding that he had a job to do; not
>let people congregate outside in the halls, which IS a fire hazard (the
>Fire Marshall checks there nightly).  Consider others.  Check it.

Then they should at least put in some fans to keep the place ventilated,
then nobody will ever HAVE to go into the hallways to get a gasp of fresh air.

>Now I do have sympathy, but you know about clubs.  They have smoke.  You
>know what smoke does to you, and you went.  Who IS responsible for YOUR
>actions.  Check it.

Smoke I can deal with as long as I can ocassionally go outside and breath 
deeply to flush out my lungs and inhale my medication.   Naturally I am
even deprived of THAT action.    

>Let's see...since you went into the club at your own recognizance, and
>since you knew about the environ (you have posted previously that you hated
>smoky clubs and complained once about GK before) then who is responsible
>for your illness.

This is NOT the point,  other people also have complained of ill-effects of
being cooped up in a smokey atmosphere.   I am not the ONLY one complaining.
For instance,  at the earlier Wickid raves held over at the Sound Factory
was completly acceptable for me, dispite the failure of the air conditioner,
because I coule always go into another part more ventilated.   Also the goons
were a lot more reasonable.

>The OWNER of King St.  Is a kind man who I think is bed ridden with an
>illness.  He has given back to the community (primarily gay/lesbian) by
>providing one of the best spaces in SF for that community to have parties. 

If THATS the case,  then perhaps someone who knows the owner should inform 
him of these conditions,  as I'm sure he is pashionate and would understand
and do something about it if he knew about it.   In that case,   I would NEVER
target someone like that.   

By the way,  I've been seeing a lot of duplicate mail messages.   Is there
something wrong with the Mailserve?

Sean says,  in response to the bad places list...:

>You are misinformed.  It most certainly does.
>Promoter choose spaces where there event can go off, better than getting
>busted.  By saying that the space sucks you doom a promoter bgecause of a
>logical choice he/she has made, and also the potential of damaging thier
>livelihood.  Check it.

Then sometimes the promoters don't know in advance how the club owners 
set up security or policy until the partys start.

>As for the constant and annoying complaints about smoking...tough!  Look
>you're in a CLUB, people smoke, always have!

I have no problem dealing with smoke,  I can always get away from it,  as long
as I can get some fresh air from outside or near a well ventilated fan.   Why
do you think there is so much anti-smoking attitude in other places besides
clubs?   It's because second hand smoke IS DEFINATELY HARMFUL.    I can so
a pretty good job of avoiding it,  as long as I'm not deprived of an
opportunity
to get away from it and fill my lungs with real air once in a while.   Again,
I expect smoke,  and DO know how to deal with it.

Geoff White says...

>As far as I'm concerned the lesson here should be ...
>THAT WE NEED TO GET OUR PARTIES OUT OF THE FUCKIN ALCOHOL RIDDEN,
>MAFIA RUN, POLICE PAYOFF CLUBS and back into nature or at least on
>private land where we can do these things right.

Right on dude...!!

Anyway,  I have replied to SOME but not all responses here,  and apologize
for all the disruptions I have caused and extra net bandwidth.   I am just
making a point that SOME club security folks have NO compassion for ones
health.   I hope that other people can agree with me on that subject.

I remain...  and still want to rave on...

Cheers
CC

Hi all,

For any of you who might be interested, synergy is now the proud borrower
of public airtime.  Our new bi-weekly show debuts this Wednesday at 6:00
p.m. and will be called synergy presents.  Format is still under
consideration, but will most likely involve local interviews and
commentary (not necessarily rave-related) mixed with trippy, drippy graphics.
Our first show, this Wednesday, is titled "abstract expression" and is a
completely ambient ride into the digital fluid.

I'd love to hear feedback.

Enjoy,

Tony

Hi Folx--
 
After several months of just virtually lurking
in the background, deleting 30 or 40 messages
at a time, reading some with great interest
(like the latest brouhaha over "faschist" club
owners), and chatting with but a few of you, here
I am again!
 
I've been planning for some time to tweak my
career a bit--and I've finally had the opportunity!
I've chosen to teach at an alternativehigh school
our district has, called The Ark, with 120 students
and six teachers.  I'm really excited about this,
but what does it have to do with raving, you ask.
Well, I've already gotten together with chris, the
sysop of our local cruzio! network with plans for
setting up email opportunities for young people,
telecommunicating between schools and newsgroups
out there.  Some parts of the country have more things
going in this area than we seem to (the latest WIRED
has a good article about schools doing this).  So--
if any of you out there are interested in helping in
any way--even tips and info--I'd gladly welcome it!
 
I saw some of you at the last rave I attended--the
July 4 Freedom in 3D with Tim Leary and virtual
reality machines; I saw some more folx at at South
Bay Luncha couple weeks later.  I'm planning on coming
up to YSHthis Thursday, so I hope to see even more!
My keyboarding is as bad as ever, but my dancin' feet
are eager to hit the floor!
 
World's Rip Van Winkle raver,
Will

--

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hi All,

Well,  hopefully I can provide a semi-lucid account of the events from my
end.  The site we picked was government public use land about a 1/2 mile
from an abandoned Nike missile base.  The base itself would have been ideal
save for the fact that there were residentials about 500 yards from it, so
we went to the rock and clay quarry further up the road.  

We got to the site about 11pm and had everyone involved set up.  Pete did
an EXCELLENT job with the music.  He was very conscientious about playing a
range of tunes and tried very hard to get the groove going.  I cannot
express my gratitude enough to Pete for being a part of this.  Very BIG
kudos to Timothy of Tuff productions who helped organize the sound and
almost everything else!   

Unfortunately, people had some difficulty adjusting to the surroundings as
it was very different from anything that has been seen and done up here. 
It did get better in time though.  :-)

I must reiterate the newness of the scene and the high degree of inbreeding
inherent in the Seattle scene. My whole purpose in initiating events like
FreeVibe is to break the old school patterns established and hopefully
stimulate the growth of a more open, freer vibe (pun totally intended :-) 
).  It wasn't very long ago that a majority of the dj's that played on
Saturday night would have laughed at the idea of doing a free show.  I
think that they're now beginning to see that non-profit cooperative efforts
are essential to their art and their livelihoods.  Yes, there were
definitely attitudes.  But I think that in time and by example, we can show
people that some of the best things in life are definitely free.

I think that the dj's Pete liked and referred to were Donald Glaude (heavy
set with dreads) and Hebegebe (also heavy set, brown hair, goatee). 
Without exception a couple of the most talented dj's here in the North
West, not to mention the coolest I've had the pleasure to work with. 
Special props go to Dervish (Nathan) who spun some really wicked tribal
trance mixes.

Kollaps of PlayDoh visuals brought some new video work worthy of a gallery
show.  It was all very trippy analog video feedback that was projected on
one of the quarry walls.  A friend of mine, Jeffrey, went up in front of
the projection and did a shadow dance to the music and visuals that had
people clapping and cheering.  It was very beautiful!

There were many memorable things that happened that night.  However, this
mail is getting too long already!  But the main thing for me, is that a
group of very dedicated people with GREAT hearts, threw their talents and
energy into an event that was free of charge and done for the love of the
vibe.  It WORKED people, and it ROCKED!!!  We've thrown a rock into the
pond the vibrations are just beginning to spread.  We had over a hundred
people grooving and vibing to 10K watts of butt pumping sound in nature's
glory from 12am to 7am!  

Thanks to a sentry system and some very nice park employees, we had plenty
of warning before the forces of Babylon came to impose their will.  I was
in one of the last cars out of the site as cruisers came speeding into the
area.  We just smiled and waved our goodbyes!  :-) 

Thanks again to EVERYONE who who contributed and to everyone who had
partaken of the event. Love to you all!
Peace!

Tigger



_______________________________________________________________________________
From: Pete Ashdown on Tue, Aug 10, 1993 10:07 AM
Subject: FreeVibe and more
To: Glenn Fajardo,USA

First off, thanks to Glen, Rick, and Tim for pulling this thing together
and
doing a great job.

I packed my Denon, my Biamp, and ~300 CDs in a large shipping box that was
BARELY under Delta's maximum weight (70 pounds).  I actually had to throw
about 100 CDs in my clothes bag in order to level things out.  Then when I
got
to the airport, the ticket agent didn't even bother to weigh it.

Upon arrival in Seattle, I called Glen and Mike to see what the status was.
 I
then went hiking in the Northern Cascades (great views, bad bugs) on
Thursday
and Friday afternoon.  When I got back, I gave Glen another call and he was
very excited about the situation.  He'd contacted a local promoter about
it,
and 10,000 watts of sound had been arranged along with a generator.  I had
brought up a small quantity of vinyl as well, and Glen stated there would
be
turntables there.

When Gretchen and I arrived at the gate, there was one car waiting and
nobody
else there.  The gate was locked.  Soon the sound van arrived and a bit of
discussion ensued.  Someone stated that maybe they were up at the site and
they'd come down periodically.  I volunteered to hike up there (about a
mile
and a half) to find out.  I jumped the fence and started the trek.  About a
half mile in, I noticed lights coming up the road.  The gate had been
opened
and everyone had been let in.

We arrived at the quarry to find nobody there.  It was a great spot,
secluded,
large, interesting, with one catch.  Trespassing big-time.  It was
government
property and the promoter had cut a lock and replaced it with his own to
let
everyone in.  Despite this news, the sound guys started setting up and soon
I
had patched in my mixer and CD player.  No turntables were in sight.

Things kicked off for a small crowd of 20 at the time.  I wondered how many
more people would show up during the night.  About after an hour of
playing,
around 80 people had arrived and were gathered around a nearby campfire. 
Only
a few people were dancing, about ten, but they were ripping it hard.  I had
the equipment on Gretchen's 4-Runner tailgate, with my back to the crowd. 
It
was like flying blind, I periodically had to turn around to see what was
going
on.

More than few people wandered up to see what was going on with the
drastically
different setup.  A few people asked me about how the Denon worked and I
showed them, but more just gaped at the stacks of CDs I'd lugged 800 miles.
Some other DJs had turned up and they had brought a coffin with 1200's.  I
plugged them into one of my tape inputs and they were ready to be fired
off.
Meanwhile they got blitzed out of their minds.  I talked to one who was
really
friendly, I can't remember his name, but he stated his big claim to fame
was
the fact that he had DJ'd for "Rave Called Sharon" (ugh).  At about 2:00 I
quit and slid things over to the other mixer.

Over the course of the night DJ's kept showing up in hoards.  What
disappointed me was the extreme attitude most of these guys carried.  Very
few
of them danced, and most just hung around the tables in a circle.  There
were
mixed talents, but there were two guys in particular who played really
well.
Too bad I have no idea who they were.

People still didn't dance in force until about the middle of the third DJ.
This was about 3:30, and the only thing I can attribute it to was the
hardcore
showing up later.  My set was all over the place and nothing really seemed
to
spark any fires.  With the exception of one ambient/trance DJ, the other
guys
just played fairly straightforward house.

At 6:00, Gretchen and I really needed to leave.  We had a full schedule
planned for Sunday, and sleeping through half of it really didn't
facilitate
that fact.  My equipment was still being used, albeit just as a
pass-through.
I managed to convince Tim that I could hot-swap the stuff off with just a
minimal break in sound.  We did so, but then I was informed that I couldn't
get out of the quarry.  The guy with the key had disappeared.  I didn't
know
if I was being bullshitted, so I bullshitted right back.  I told them I
needed
to be at the airport, ASAP.  It wasn't making me very happy that all of a
sudden this had turned into a lock-in early in the morning without warning.
Gretchen calmed me down and we agreed that we would stay until 8:00 when
they
would unlock the gate.  I started to fall asleep in her truck until then.

Suddenly the call came to shut everything down.  I was mostly packed up, so
we
closed the truck up and got out.  On the way out, we saw the police on the
way
in.  I have no idea what happened to the promoters, but I feared for the
worst.  They were blatently trespassing, no bones about it.  If they
managed
to pack everything up in time, I'd imagine they would have gotten out
safely,
but the amount of time it took to unload made me realize that it was going
to
take a while to pack up.

All in all, it was a good time.  Gretchen is a rave newbie and she danced
hard
all night.  We took a short nap inside her truck and it was really weird to
wake up and see video being projected on a rock wall outside the truck.  I
was
pleased to meet Arias, Glen, and Rick.  I wish you folks could be down here
this weekend for the desert show.

Yaaaawwwwnnnnnn, can we talk about raves rather than just getting into flame
wars? Every space has its plusses and minuses which is unique to the space.
Every promoter has their plusses and minuses which is unique to them. Every
raver has their own unique headspace on a particular night. Add it all up and
roll the dice and maybe the raver will enjoy themselves and maybe not.

90% of whether you enjoy yourselves or not is in your own head, so make it a
quest to discover that mental state where you always have fun. If you're at
a party and not enjoying yourself, leave. If it's too expensive to sample
parties that way, go to cheap or free ones. If you still can't enjoy yourself
stay home.

So, make your own fun. This mystical quality called "Vibe" which we are always
talking about as the ultimate standard of rave quality is entirely dependent
on the attendees of the party. It has little to do with space or promoters or
how good the music/sound/visuals are. If you go to a rave and just wait for it
to happen, it never will.

						Pete

Hullooo...
I just returned from a Fantastic Voyage to SF.  Since there have been many 
reviews of the events we (me Chris and Guy - Team Canada) attended, I won't get 
into details. A few standout memories tho: 

-Basics- the pictures of all the army Officers on the wall right when you walk 
 in (if they could talk!). 
-The Basics floor-gropers near the water booth.
-The drive to Point Reyes (thanks Rob - energyman!) and the long steam of 
 headlights (like the last scene in 'Field of Dreams').
-Passing out in Leah's bedroom during the BBQ (finally- sleep).
-Tam in th GeEK hat :) 
-the fmr: We're listening to a walkman?!?!!'
-krieg(sp?) and doug zim. in the parking lot, with the 2-fisting nitrous 
 raverette... one balloon for each hand! 
-that beautiful... utterly stunning site- full points to Brian! Dana summed 
 it up "a sight that will stick in my mind til a few years after im dead"
-and of course meeting so many net.ravers... i just get the warm fuzzies! 

extra special mahalos to cin (and jeno) for her hospitality. and for showing
me and Doug around SF, what a beautiful city... *sigh* 

I ended up in Concord Wed and I *sadly* didnt make it to YSH... but im currently
workin on a SF boondoggle in October for the seybold conference :)

Again, thanks to all for your hospitality. Chris, Guy and I had a great time
and please please please let me know if/when any of you have northwest 
travel plans.

pat

P L U
e o n
a v i
c e t
e   y

> 
> >  John> from a selfish few who only care about themselves and not
> >  John> others.  Look, I know that there have been certain people in
> >  John> this group who are NOT 21 somehow sneaking into clubs (either
> >  John> under the guise of "working", or just sticking around until
> >  John> the club opens) and just melding in.  This is self centered
> >  John> and stupid since the place can easily get busted for such an
> >  John> offense.
> >
> >Yeah, and (you may be surprized to hear) there are people in these
> >clubs taking DRUGS.  This, too, is illegal, and could get the club
> >shut down....  
> >
> >It just seems to me you're being a tad hypocritical in singling out
> >the particular offence of being in a space under-age...
> >
> >If you want to argue that we should all obey the law, regardless of
> >how stupid it is, that's one thing -- but you can't pick and choose
> >your laws....
> >
> >
> >        roy


Well I think an individual CAN pick and choose their laws, but they must
be willing to suffer the consequences of their actions.  Raves are evolving
from a gray market fringe activity (check out the "happenings" around
New York City in 1965.  The point is if you are trying to promote in a way
that you 
	
1) are not willing to wind up in Jail
2) wanting to have some sense of security at your parties.
3) Want to throw them in San Francisco and not some place like sonoma.

You have to play by the rules.  Even when I talk to the police at undergrounds,
It gives you alot more barganing power, if there aren't people swilling
beer, lighting up pipes, and filling nitrous baloons. If they don't see it,
then they can only cite you for the park being closed.   If i can
say to them, hey walk around, we have nothing to hide, then it escalates
up to wheather they are bust us cause we're dangerous or wheather to let it
go like "the current college prank" like streaking in the seventies.
A club is a bussiness, it has to make a profit or at least break even to be
even available for parties. They came down on 174 , well , let's just say
that I`ve been to some really grEAt parties there in my time. And the Door
was one of trhe coolest around.  They most likely got in trouble.
The bottom line is it's hard for a cop to go into a crowd and single people
out and force them to take a drug test, they can't do that... yet... So
they can't shut you down for "drug use" unless they see it going on or
they make a bust for the sale of a drug.  If they make a bust for the sale,
they can hassle the club about having adequate security to keep out the drug
dealers, no backpacks... they're loaded with ecstasy:), no wather bottles,
their loaded with Liquid LSD...

 THIS IS WHY WE GOTTA MOVE OUR PARTIES OUTTA THE CLUBS!!

> 
> You have been misinformed.  You are comparing apples to oranges.  Drugs are
> a LOW-PRIORITY item on SFPD list of no-no's.  Underage drinking, due to
> current hysteria, is on the A-list.  Facts of life.  So I deal within that
> realm. 21-- stay out of 21+ clubs.  What's the problem?  Oh yes I said
> nothing about obeying the law, just that others (like the cops) will
> enforce it.  John S. Lee or no.  Not much choice for now Roy. (BTW - in the
> past in SF you could go(21--) to 174 no problem, but things have changed
> since they have been busted before). Check it.

Yes It's true, if you want to dot your i"s and cross your t"s you should
not have underage people in your club, the cops can hassle you and give you
a fine, fines cost money.  It`s also in your best interest to discourage all
forms of consumption of controlled substances, because some stupid kid will
smuggle in a beer or sell a joint or a hit to an undercover cop and really
make some people upset. Oh and make sure that the girls are not allowed to 
use the men's room, she might "make" some fucking asshole rape her.

WE GOTTA HAVE PARTIES OUT OF THE CLUBS!

The creative freedom that the club environment provides is getting to limiting.
We need to cultivate relationships where we can set up a better quality
of Temporary Autonomous Zone the the club venu provides.  

Check it.

>   
>   Personally, i don't care what age the people i'm partying with are...
>   I think the rave scene over in SF must be pretty different from ours
>   if the 21+ crowd actually go out of their way to avoid all-ages
>   parties....  But then, over here, the rave scene is viewed primarily
>   as a young person's scene...

    It seems to draw from at least 2 generations out here.  I haven't
    really seen much of a division by age, except that imposed by the law
    where alcohol is served.  I'm a little confused on that point as well,
    as most of the concert venues serve beer, and they have no problem
    letting underage folks in, but they can't serve them alcohol.  Usually
    you have to get a wristband or get your hand stamped after they look
    at your ID.  Yet clubs don't even let you in the door if you are underage.
    What determines which set of rules apply to a venue?

>     John> You are misinformed.  The licensing says 21+.  The fact people
>     John> go there is due to them NOT wanting to mix with 21--.

    I think it's 'in spite of' rather than 'due to'.  As you said, there
    aren't many 21-- places to go to, so it's not too surprising that
    most of the 21+ go to 21+ places.

>   Of course, with the drinking age being 18 in the UK, there's no such
>   thing as a 21+ club here (at least not that i've ever heard of) so i
>   guess it's not surprizing that the idea seems pretty alien to me....

    This is a very Puritanical country, and that takes precedence over
    Constitutional rights such as freedom of religion and freedom to
    peacefully assemble.
