From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


JSL -- Ok, so you're continuing to run with you're capitalist schtick
of siding with those in positions of power/money/control -- that's your
choice. However, if you're gonna run with capitalism, then you better
do it right. One aspect of capitalism in the service/entertainment
industry is that THE CUSTOMER IS ALWAYS RIGHT. This seems to be a
forgotten aspect of "service" of late (whether the service is a
restaurant, theatre, concert venue, or rave).

Nowadays, instead of competition for the best value, service, or
whatever, we're  seeing the increasing attitude on the part of the
promoters -- "we're here, we're doing it, we're rich, so we must be
right, fuck off, and you can leave if you don't like it (and no, we're
not giving your money back you little worm!)." As if by their 
well-connected, know-it-all hipsterness, they become entitled to our
money.

Well, to those kinds of promoters, I proclaim a loud "fuck you" right
back at them. And better than that, I'll be happy to slander them (or
see them slandered) on public mailing lists, newspapers, magazines,
radio, or what have you. They DESERVE to lose money for their rudeness,
mistakes, bad business practices, and bad customer relations. They
don't deserve respect if they don't respect the customer. I couldn't
give a flying fuck if they lose money because we're boycotting --
that's the risk they take in running an enterprise. If they don't want
that risk (or the upside rewards), then they should go out and get a
real job. Or learn how to run their business properly.

The jist of my argument is that If you're going to play in a free
market, then people have the right to be informed of problems without
fear of censorship/flames/whatever. The CUSTOMER NEEDS TO REMEMBER THAT
THEY ARE ALWAYS RIGHT. The  promoter/venue/bouncers are there to serve,
and in the process of doing that, if they make some money, then more
power to them.

Some customers are sheep and will take whatever they get. However, the
people on sfraves are not sheep. We're here to learn, build community,
look out for each other, and inform each other.  So people should feel
free to discuss bad venues, asshole promoters, and any of the scam
artists that have become part of the scene. We have a right as
prospective customers to inform each other of problems so that we can
avoid getting ripped-off by greedy capitalist promoter-skum (tm). If
our "boycott" causes a promoter to lose business and $$$ then so be it
(earning money is no-one's god given right -- check it!).

But some promoters are acting like they're doing us some big favor by
charging us $15.00 to lock us in an unventilated room, with smegma-pit
bathrooms, idiot fascist (note spelling) bouncers, no water policy, no
fresh air policy, nothing. Fuck them. Smart people will take into
consideration a negative review of a promoter/venue/event and vote with
their feet.

So lets let the discussion continue without getting at each others
throats. These are all opinions after all! We all have a right to learn
and become wise. 

In conclusion,  I, for one, will never set foot in One Step Beyond, and
will resist attending any Wicked/Groove-Kitchen events at 174 King St.
I tell these opinions to all-and-sundry in the hope that promoters LOSE
when they choose those venues. Organize and revolt -- It's the only way
for the powerless to not get screwed by the greedy. If enough of us
follow suit, then our consumer-advocacy will have worked.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

I agree that San Jose is getting better for dancing. I have always 
enjoyed Fresh Fridays at FX, but I can now enjoy dancing during the 
week.  
Free Life on Monday nights is a great place to continue the weekend.

I am sad that I missed the party Saturday night at Latte and Laundry.  
I was there the Friday night before till 5 and it was really mellow, 
but the music was good.  I am going to go to Progress tonite and 
check that out. I agree it should be good to night with Julius Papp 
spinning.  I also recommend Thursday nights at AJAX for Acid Jazz 
with Harry Who.  You cannot really dance, but the music is great 
to listen to.  You could always go to Oasis on Thursday nights, but 
in my opinion it is only good every once in awhile. Wednesday at 
Toons used to be great however that has been over for awhile now. 
Does anyone else know of anything going on in SJ on Wednesdays?
 
There are finally alternatives to driving to San Francisco, we just 
have to get the 2am law lifted.  

See you at Progress tonite,


vivianm

From: rocky mullin <caliban@soda.berkeley.edu>
Message-Id: <9308110142.AA15953@soda.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: the weekend!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


	started out bypassing both long line and admission by
	just waltzing right into product.  i ahd never been to
	the 1015 folsom space and it was *amazing*.  i'm a gear-
	head and into lighting/effects/sound for buisness and
	pleasure at the setup in the main room there is one of 
	the best i have ever seen.  the music was great (nikki
	rivera was awesome) and the energy there was *so* intense.
	not so much as in the *vibe* sense as it was in the sheer
	energy sense, all these hot shirtless sweaty men (80%
	male i would guess) combined with tech mad it one hell
	of a good time.  'specially for free...

	we moved on to groove kitchen which was enjoyable (also
	bypassed the line easily) but the energy was not nearly 
	as high.  met some cool people, no one from the net though
	(i think.)  had more phun making out on the beanbags than
	dancing at that one.  and i think preston is blowing it
	by always leaving the intelligent lighting turned off when
	he throws his parties.  at 4.30 we moved on...

	where the wild things are, one step beyond.  i had been
	going to shows there for years and years.  it was very
	late, empty and free by that time.  pretty dull crowd,
	though we danced alot (until six when it was over.)  
	ernie munson and markie played a cool (albeit way hardcore
	for five thirty am!) set on four turntables.  

	my reccomendations:  hit the 1015 space sometime if you want
	to be amazed, and try not to pay anywhere you go.

calirock

	actually i just heard that his year's shower is going to
	be rather like most previous years- there was a miscalculation
	and the really spectacular shower will be next year.  as for 
	viewing (because it is *still* spectacular!) goes, i will 
	be at the bonny doon airport on empire grade in bonny doon
	(follow the road by bonny doon beach (it turns into pine flat
	road) up to empire grade and trun right.. it's within a mile on
	your right.)  there will be a gathering of people there to
	see the shower.  the conditions are ideal up there:  warm,
	clear, open and very dark.  telescopes will be available.

calirock

enthusiasm for the scene!  As for your other gripes, I still hold by my
word.  I do agree that MORE should be done in venues to make sure that air
circulates, and most importantly REPLENISHED!  But since this is not the
case I do beleive in let the buyer beware.  In any case....

>>Have you ever thought that mutual respect for another person might have

>deeply to flush out my lungs and inhale my medication.   Naturally I am

The problem John is that EVERYONE wants to do that.  And until the fire
codes are changed it is difficult for them to make any exceptions.  I DO
wish things were different, but for now they are not.  Clubs are for the
headstrong, sometimes brain stupid, sometimes workout-crazed!  In any case
once again, know the environ and let the buyer beware.  It IS not so
strange that the Sound Factory would have beeter ventialtion.  The King St.
garage is JUST that, a GARAGE (read TRUE HOUSE).  Sound Factory used to be
some type of indorr raquetball court, and  they seemed to have placed a
greater deal on ventilation as well.  If other clubs would follow suit then
EVERYONE would be a bit more comfortable.

>>Let's see...since you went into the club at your own recognizance, and

I disagree, but what else is new.  If you know about the environ then you
enter at your own risk!

>>The OWNER of King St.  Is a kind man who I think is bed ridden with an

>>You are misinformed.  It most certainly does.
>>Promoter choose spaces where there event can go off, better than getting

>>logical choice he/she has made, and also the potential of damaging thier
>>livelihood.  Check it.

>Then sometimes the promoters don't know in advance how the club owners 
>set up security or policy until the partys start.

You are misinformed.  YES THEY DO!  And the promoter is RESPONSIBLE for
making sure that security not only operates to keep the interest of the
club in mind, but the interest of the RENTER (read PROMOTER).  So I see it
as a promoters responsibility to talk to security ahead of time.  When we
had our gig at OSB we did talk to security.  They did not do their usual
(shining flashlight on girls asses, harassing people).  FOr OSB they were
LAX.  Yeah I know they didn't let people in with bags, but some did get in.
 It depended on the persons attitude who came to the door.  Plenty had
backpacks, plenty did not.  But they left people the hell alone when they
got there.  Why?  Because we talked to them and told them EXACTLY what we
wanted!  If more promoters did this instead of relegating THEIR
responsibility of providing people a safe, ggod time, then we would have
less complaints about security.  Check it.

>a pretty good job of avoiding it,  as long as I'm not deprived of an
>opportunity
>to get away from it and fill my lungs with real air once in a while.   Again,

vociferous manner.  There need not be sugar coating on things I STRONGLY
disagree with, and I wont do it.  If you slam a club when I know the
promoter has only the best intentions then I reserve my right to reply in
defense of my friend(s).  If others can state that so and so's suck, then I
should be able to do the same (read opposite).  It seems as though there is
a double standard and if THAT is what is required to get along here then I
will NOT post, or get along.  You have interpreted my actions as negative,
I have intepreted them as constructive.  We just differ in our ways and
means of communicating.  I know I come off strong but that is my manner.  I
am an individual and will remain such.  No need to check it though as you
are well aware of this fact ;)

style, and am looking forward to hearing her at YSH in the VERY near
future!  Your invitation is accepted, and THANK YOU!

>John and Crunch both have good points, but:
>1) John will have a better time with promoters and security than most people
>because he is in the promoter end of the scene and therefore knows a lot
>of them and understands why security exists.  Since an above-ground business
>must NOT deny entrance to people on any grounds but imminent danger (or
>risk lawsuits), you get all kinds, many of which look for trouble.  If you're
>going to make bucks, you need theirs too, so you're stuck underground
>if you want to restrict your circle to a small known scene.
>2) CC (and many others on the consumer side) will note that a lot of things
>obviously suck.  (Liquor->age limit, curfew, high rent, public land that
>isn't really public, AntiSomeDrug laws, etc.)  So obviously it's the fault
>of the people putting on the event, or the people who own the space.

Agreed.

>
>I find myself agreeing a bit more with John here (!) in that GK might have
>been a crummy place that night, but a lawsuit?  Seems like the problems are
>mostly due to archaic fire codes and crummy ventilation.  OK, I won't go
>there.  Most of the problems on the list above are due to legal bullshit
>and not promoters: if it was easier to throw events that were more like
>a rave, we'd see more, and people would stop going to the crummy places.
>We can either throw more renegades, or agitate for change.  Hey, in San
>Jose no one can do anything after 2 AM.  And you think SF is rough...
>
>Still, comments like "ins and outs if you know the promoter" don't help
>the people who, as John noted, are paying for it, and annoying security
>can be a problem.  Hey -- if I can't bring in water I turn around and
>leave.

That is a JOKE.  "ins and outs if you know the promoter" is the biggest
laugh!  Since during the party the promoter is usually busy making sure
that all is well.  S/he usually has little time to escort his/her many
friends in/out of the door.  So usually if there are no in's/out's only the
people actually "working" + the promoter get the privvy.  All others (even
yours truly) has a difficult time.  That is UNLESS I have worked with the
guard before and have at least echanged names with the person.  But at 174,
who gives a shit.  One time I went to my car to get some bud.  I told the
sec guard SABER that I'd be back.  She said "cool".  I tried to get back in
but she had changed posts.  I had to wait for her to get back so that they
would let me in.  In the meanwhile your "true insider" was outside, blocked
by some big overly handsome thug who stood right in front of me (the sucker
was tall, about 6'5"). But I had to wait, and was eventually let back in. 
I stayed in after that!  Even "insiders" get shit treatment at "174".  But
I do LOVE THAT SPACE! (this is no joke I really do!).

Maybe if many of you were not so emotional about my babbling on and just
spent some time thinking about the logic of the various situations that I
mentioned you would find the joke.  But you're soo caught up in being
"righteous" and "musketeerish" that you miss the obvious.  I must say
though that the end of the post where I said "that does it" was no laughing
matter and I stand by every word.  Musketeer or no. No need to check it. 
You have been informed (this is NOT directed at you SDTrap, just thought
I'd throw it in).

>
>I'd love everything to be as great as PW was, but they lost a ton of money.

>similar happens it'll be able to happen again.  Maybe people all just

>
>So what am I saying?  I dunno.  Do what you gotta do.  // g

(from afar) outdoor parties.  I think both, when done right have their
benefits.  I think outdoors is a bit of a problem though.  MOST "ravers"
leave tons of shit on the site.  It usually takes a coordinated effort to
make sure that people have a place to put their empty bottles, plastic bags
, and nitrous containers so that they leave the "mother" the way she was
before they got there.  I'm all about that.  Anything less is a farce.

except for a few.  It is always good to see fresh blood, new faces, and
most importantly new ideas spring forth from the community.  Plus some of
the women involved I know personally and they are really great people, and
that does LOTS for the vibe.

Here is some meteor shower info that I thought might be of interest.  From
what I understand predicting when and if the shower turns into a storm is
pretty uncertain and if it is real strong and hits a little late it would be 
a shame to miss it.

The most intense storms are supposed to "give you a sense of the earth's
motion through the solar system" which I thought was pretty rave related ;)

Dave

   CNN is going to try to televise it from the east coast 
__________________

 SKY & TELESCOPE NEWS BULLETIN -- AUGUST 7, 1993

 Skywatchers around the world are eagerly awaiting the night of August
 11-12, when they might witness one of the best meteor showers of the
 20th century. This week's spectacle will feature the Perseids, which
 occur every year around August 11th or 12th and last for several days.
 The Perseid shower usually produces up to one naked-eye meteor per
 minute if you're at a dark location far from city lights. But this year
 may be different. SKY & TELESCOPE magazine predicts that the shower
 could greatly intensify for an hour or so sometime late on August 11th
 or early on the 12th, to produce a meteor every few seconds. With luck,
 the shower could even turn into a "meteor storm" of several shooting
 stars per second. 

 Here's why: the Perseids are tiny, sand-grain- to pea-sized bits of
 rocky debris that were shed long ago by Comet Swift-Tuttle. Over the
 centuries, the comet's crumbly remains have spread debris all along its
 130-year-long orbit. The Earth plows through this meteor stream every
 August, and they strike our atmosphere at 37 miles per second.
 Astronomers believe the comet is accompanied by a dense ribbon of
 rubble within the larger, well-known stream. Indeed, in 1991 and 1992
 we apparently sliced through its leading portions, because the shower
 briefly got much more active. This year, Earth is most likely to go
 through the dense ribbon of meteoroids during late Wednesday afternoon
 North American time. If so, it will be daylight and we won't see
 anything. But at that time Europe and western Asia will be in darkness
 and facing the oncoming meteors, so expectations for a spectacular
 display are high in those parts of the world. But for all we know, it
 could happen at any time of night. 

 Meteor watching is easy! If the sky is clear, bring a comfortable,
 tilt-back lawn chair to a dark site that has an open view of the
 heavens in any direction. Lie back and give your eyes at least 15
 minutes to adapt to the dark. Faint meteors are tiny, quick streaks.
 Brighter ones may sail across the heavens for several seconds and leave
 a trail of glowing smoke. Don't forget, Perseids appear *anywhere in
 the sky.* But if you trace their direction of flight backward far
 enough across the stars, you cross the shower's radiant in the
 constellation Perseus. The radiant is near the north- northeast horizon
 right after dusk, higher in the northeast by midnight, and nearly
 overhead by the first light of dawn. 

 Some press reports have mistakenly suggested that somehow astronomers
 goofed, and that the Perseids won't be so stunning this year after all.
 It's true that two meteor scientists recently predicted that the Earth
 will plow through the densest stretch of the narrow rubble ribbon in
 1994. But even they admit that this year's storm should be spectacular.
 Much more on the Perseids is in the August issue of SKY & TELESCOPE. 
 

    -------------------------------------------------------

Info from Bob Stachnik at NASA HQ concerning the meteor shower:

   As suggested by the following, the peak year for Perseid meteor storm
activity MAY not be 1993, but 1994. 1993 is still predicted to be a year of
very high activity. It is clear that this still-hypothetical storm is not well
understood. The "storm" is generating an associated storm of predictions.

   Note that next week's predicted heavy meteor activity is due to material
ejected from Swift-Tuttle during its 1862 passage.

-Bob
_______________________________________________________________________________
Subject: RAS Perseids Release of August 1, 1993


The following press release was received electronically from the
Royal Astronomical Society and is forwarded without comment for 
your information.

 Steve Maran, AAS Press Officer


ROYAL ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY

PRESS NOTICE

Date: 1 August 1993   For immediate release
Ref. PN 93/5
Issued by: Dr Jacqueline Mitton, RAS Public Relations OfficerFAX & Tel.
Cambridge (0223) 355924 (UK), +44 233 355924 (international)
E-mail: JMITTON @uk.ac.ro-greenwich.srf
Even more Perseids in store for 1994

Astronomers are excitedly anticipating an exceptional display from the
Perseid meteor shower on the night of 11-12 August. But this may not be
the only opportunity to see spectacular Perseids. According to the very
latest calculations by Dr Zidian Wu and Professor Iwan Williams of Queen
Mary and Westfield College in London, the Earth will plough through
the thickest part of the dust cloud giving rise to the Perseids in 1994
rather than 1993.  Their results will be published in the Monthly Notices of
the Royal Astronomical Society later in the year.

A meteor stream in space is created by dust grains ejected from a parent 
comet - in the case of the Perseids, Comet Swift-Tuttle. This comet's most 
recent return to the Earth's vicinity was in 1992. It takes about 130 years to 
orbit the Sun and was last seen in 1862. Dust ejected at the 1862 return will 
still be in a clump near to the comet because it has not had time to spread 
out around the cometary orbit. Since the comet is now relatively close to 
Earth, we are encountering an increasing number of meteors. 

Wu and Williams have computed the actual motion through space of 
hundreds of typical dust particles ejected from Comet Swift-Tuttle at its 
1862 return. They have found that the Earth started to encounter the new 
dust during the mid 1980s. This ties in with increased numbers of meteors 
seen over the last few years, a few hours before the expected peak of the 
shower. But significantly, they predict that the maximum rate will be in 
1994, not 1993.

'This does not mean that you should not go out and look in 1993', Professor
Williams said. 'There will certainly be a spectacular display. But it does mean
that if you miss 1993, there is no need to give up. 1994 should have an even
higher rate'. The only disadvantage in 1994 will be more moonlight because the
Moon's phase will be approaching first quarter.
	With their calculations, Wu and Williams show that the Perseid 
meteoroids would not pass close enough to the Earth to create a meteor 
shower if it were not for the gravitational pull of the planets deflecting 
them from their original paths as they sweep round the Sun in their 
elongated elliptical orbits. For that reason the dust ejected at the 1992 
return will not produce visible meteors until the next return of the
comet in about 130 yearsU time.

The most intense part of the Perseid display is likely to be quite short - 
an hour or less - because the dust cloud responsible is quite compact and 
the Earth will travel through it quickly. Exactly when it will occur is 
difficult to predict but the best guesses are somewhere between  10. 00 p.m. 
on 11 August and 1.30 a.m. on 12 August, Universal Time. (Universal 
Time is equivalent to Greenwich Mean Time. On British Summer Time it 
will be 11.00 p.m. to 2.30 p.m.). This means that the shower is likely to be 
seen best from western Asia and Europe.


For general information, references and other contacts regarding the 
Perseid meteor shower, contact Jacqueline Mitton (Phone/FAX/E-mail as
 at head of press notice)

Ok Folks, Every once in a while I do say some goofy and offbeat things, but then agin, Im the jester that reminds us all to laugh...
But I cant laugh at this.
This guy refered to some people as Goons. 
Ok, So in some way somehow this can be taken as a racial slur.
Fine.
But I , being the semiintelligent, Walking on 2 feet human being did not see this as a racial slur, and I think anyone who has 1/2 a brain could read into it and see that it was not. I certianly didnt see it as a slur, and I think it took more thinking to
make it into one than it owuld have taken to just read it as what it was. 
Also, Its my personal feeling that most people on this list are slightly above using racial slurs anyway. If Im worng, go spank yourself with some wet pasta.

PC Belongs on your desk, not in your mindset.

Im not accusing anyone here at all, but I get a little tired of people who read things looking for the racial slur and making noise aobut it. Im NOT NOT NOT NOT accusing the poster who made the ovservation of doing this, but lets face it, it happens in 
silly world. Remember what happened to " Louie Louie ".
( The Song was played Every way imaginable to man and cat, and noone could find the supposed dirty message that was in it, as there was not one )

What can I say ? Being aware is GREAT! Looking out for things Is GREAT, 
But being hypersesnitive is nothing but a pain in the ass.

	Ad Nauseum,

% Anyway, just a little note... As for charging for water, and no going out, i'm
% affraid it's universal... Please let the good old days return...

I do my raves (here in Okla City) in clubs for the usual reasons, and
require the owner to provide access to water.  The first time, they sold it
anyway and I didn't find out until the next day.  Now I make 'em put it in
the contract.  If they gripe about cost of cups and the bar tender not
getting paid to fill 'em, I'll offer to buy the cups myself, so long as
people are allowed to take them in the bathroom.  Or hand out free cups at
the smart drink bar.  We also allow no-fee re-entry (we provide security
and control the door, so it's our choice, not the club's).

Can't these things be negotiated in SF?

David

country (England) :-(   Service industry, what's that?

  Niels> or whatever, we're seeing the increasing attitude on the part

(which shall remain nameless) and asked to listen to a record.  The
salesman refused, on the grounds that he hated "that techno shit".
When my friend tried to reason with him, saying that he'd buy the
record if it was the one he was looking for, the salesman explained
that they made enough money without him, so they really didn't need
his custom!  Some service industry....  (Fortunately this isn't the
norm...)

Besides having no ethics Laura (That was PRIVATE mail to YOU) you really
need to be informed:
Look, you wanted to cast your two cents.  Now you're caught up in it.  This
whole thing started because a few people decided to bag on a friend of
mines choice of space.  Next we have stupid lawsuits because someone took
it upon himself to go into a place inhospiible to his health.  I replied in
defense of my friends venue and character.  Which in my estimation was
assasinated.  I am done with this stupid tit-for-tat, esp with a few of you
who are overly sensisitive about the most inane things.  When I, note "I",
criticize a "space" (3rd & 24th), I get the wrath of the people on this
list who are personal friends with the people who thre that event.  This
does not bother me, but when many of you invoked my wrath because of the
same thing "I" am the "asshole".  I really could care less what you call me
or what you think about me, since ONLY a very few know me.  So what we have
here is a group of people with a religious bent.  Unknwon rules of conduct
that do not allow for the slightest disagreement/dissent.  Ways of thought
are carefully controlled and monitored to promote this perspective
throughout this list.  Oh yes, gripe about the evil promoter since he's
trying to fuck you.  Oh yes, gripe about the space that has age
prohibitions, because they are ashholes who care only about money.  All
that I have heard on this list is a bunch of whiney self-centered,
duplicitious people who have a definite poltical agenda.  It is no suprise
why people think what they do about SFR's...oh well.  I have managed to
talk to a few of you off-line, and have found you to be GREAT people with a
GREAT sense of humor about everything.  I have met Brian B. and even though
we have had OUR back-and-forth. I do admire his spirit, and willingness to
make a diff.  I have met Bob R. and have found him , in our brief
encounter, to be a nice guy.  I do not need to namedrop sice it serves no
purupose.  But I have found that those I have met are quite nice and good
people.  

I can say only one thing.  Personal attacks will get a reply.  Attack my
friends and I will jump out of the woodwork and defend them with vigor.  So
here is the solution honey, leave me alone and you won't have to deal with
me.  Leave my friends alone and you won't have to deal with me.  Transgress
these rules and incur my wrath, just as I have incurred many of the
people's here on the list.  So you and your buddies can keep your
sophomoric political agenda since it allows for no dissent.  I have no need
or want to deal with people who want only a one way communication of ideas.
 So I am ready to engage in discourse privately with those individuals with
the intellect,integrity, and humor required in any human communication.  So
make your hit list, but be sure that none of my friends are on it.  Bag a
promoter, but make sure he/she is not MY pal.  Do nothing about making
things right and gripe, cry, bitch, complain.  Yawwwn...nothing will change
unless you take it to the next level.  But keep bangin those hardheads
aainst that brick wall and you will eventually stop  since it feels good to
do so.

I am done, can we move on.  This has become inane, stupid, boring, and
childish.  Poke me with a fork, I'm done.

I would be very curious to know what the name of the politcal party is here
on the list?  Can I vote for it in the next election?  I already know the
agenda and am curious as to whether it will be on the next ballot?  Somehow
I doubt it since to do that requires action, not words.

Are we finished yet?  I know I am ;)

Make a difference, make a change.  Be apart of it or step back...

John

P.S.  SInce it is clear I will defend myself I am done for now with the
personal tit-for-tat.  Save it so that we may all save bandwidth.  You know
how damn wordy I am so why, why, WHY in god's name reply?  Talk about
masochism ;)

> You are misinformed.  I am defending my friends.  And I will determine what

And I guess you'll defend your friends if they are wrong too. But then
again I can fully expect that kind of "my country right or wrong" attitude
from a proud citizen of the new roman empire (your words, not mine).

> You know if others played by your
> rules we'd all be thinking right!  Just like Orwell, just like Hitler.

Actually, I'd like to think it was closer to Ralph Nader. Meanwhile, as far
as I can tell, you're just a little George Bush -- defending your greedy
buddies-in-business regardless of whether it's right or wrong.  Just
another scum-sucking plutocrat.

> As
> for the money, they ARE entitled to it IF you lay it in their palm.

And I'm entitled to a refund if the place is not up to standards of
lowest-common-denominator decency. And if they don't give it, I see no
reason why not to threaten with a lawsuit (as in John Draper's case), or
threaten to call the cops, fire dept, state-board-of-health (for the
smega-pit bathroom) or whatnot, or just bitch about it to all and sundry.
If they're assholes, I have no problem being an asshole right back. They
show me respect, then I'll give them respect. It's that simple.

Here's a short list of events where positive respect has been given in the
past: Groove Kitchen (only when not at 174 King St), The Gathering, Unity,
Come/Unity, Let Freedom Rave, Full Moon Massive, Together, Deep Faith, Your
Sister's House, Mother Earth Sound System, Connection, etc.

> You are misinformed.  The boycott will not be effective as new ranks will
> be there to replace you and your voice will be diminished.  

Effective to whom? Will it prevent a group of people from being abused by a
greedy promoter and a bad venue? If we watch out for each other and inform
each other of the good, the bad, and the ugly of the scene, then that's all
the effectiveness I need.

Will a boycott change anything? Well, lets say 5 people call me on Saturday
night to ask what's happening that evening. I tell them to avoid XXXXXX
since it would be a crowded gangster-laden attitude-hellhole (because of
the location, not because of the promoter).  So maybe 5 less people show
up. I&Others spread the word on the list and maybe 20 people won't show up,
and those twenty people will pass the word on to their 5 friends... Suddenly,
the promoter is getting something like 100 less people.  That's $1500 which
is somewhat significant. 

> rather you
> shoudltry to change things by at least talking to them and airing your
> greivances.  That's what the promoters meeting should've been all about. 

I'm not a promoter, my voice would not be heard nor heeded as I'm not
running on that glorious inside track that you've taken. Besides, I'm just
a consumer, not a promoter, so I have better things to do with my time.

Lets say that I'm an amateur restaurant reviewer. I go to a restaurant, I
get a bad meal, I slag the restaurant in my review. That's the way things
go. I don't go into the kitchen and show the cook how to cook, nor show the
waiter how to waiter. By the fact that I've paid them my hard earned money,
I expect them to do the job right. Otherwise, I would have stayed home and
cooked for myself.

In other words, I have a right to an opinion. Just as you have a right
to yours. The media in which our opinions are carried is democratic
enough that people can decide for themselves whether an opinion has merit.
Shouting matches and ad-hominem attacks are unecessary...

> You are misinformed.  The rave scene operates much more on a barter system
> than anything else.  Yes there is money exchanged, but there are also
> plenty of non-monetary favors (like "I'll lend you my projector if you give
> me 2 video tapes" or "get me and my 2 friends in free-of-charge [foc] and
> I'll loan you...").  So the capitalist model you constantly rail against
> hardly applies to the rave scene.  Same with clubs since there are many
> non-monetary favors exchanged, and deals made.  Now you are informed. 

Spoken like the true plutocrat that you are. Stop it with your insulting
"let em eat cake" attitude -- most of us aren't that chummy with the
promoters to be able to trade anything other than greenbacks. I don't even
know why you're trying to waste my time with such a pathetically weak
argument to defend whatever system is being used by the rave scene. The non-
underground rave scene is basically the same as the SF Club scene, and it
is run by greed and greed alone.  I will fight against that and slander
promoters/venues that are acting greedy by not providing the customer with
appropriate value for their money.

> You are correct.  And I as a promoter have every right to challenge
> anything I see as slanderous or unfair to any of my promoter friends, or dj
> friends, or helper friends.  Blood is way thicker than water or concept. 
> Threats are illogical, and payment is usually expensive. Check it.

And while you're defending your buddies in power, you throw in a couple of
personal insults for good measure. Such persuasive force of argument!

> You are misinformed.  They are doing you a favor.  Think of it.  If you
> weren't at a rave you'd be in the streets causing trouble, robbing, looting
> and other nonsense.  Keeping you locked up is the secret plan we all have. 
> And if you stay home our mission has been accomplished.  Remeber the
> Promoter's are always out to get you so watch your back, and your wallet,
> your water, your woman/man, your dancing shoes, and your state of mind.

Don't quit your day job to become a humorist, ok?

> You are misinformed.  The party goes on even if you stay home.  And the
> only person to lose out is the promoter.  He loses a person who is clueless
> as to what's what, he loses major negative energy that causes trouble at
> parties.

Yeah, but if enough of us stay home, the party will be relegated to the
gangster-types that have discovered raves (and 174 King St.). They can run
around scamming on underwear-girlz and pick fights all they want as long as
we're nowhere near.  Meanwhile we'll be off doing something better and more
interesting.

> He loses a griper who has done nothing to make a diff.  Oh well

Put up and shut up, right? You're sounding more and more like George Bush
(or is that Rush Limbaugh) every second. And what causes a rave
attendee to "make a difference?" -- sheepishly putting up with any
of the bullshit that gets thrown our way for our $15.00 entry fee? 
Being so whacked out on X that you can't judge whether you've been had?

If you're the standard by which I'm supposed to be clueful, then I'm very
happy to be clueless, thank you very much.

I went to progress last night and walked in 
while my friend was spinning(julius papp).
This place is pretty cool for being a club!
You walk in and there was a little room with
a movie projector with some strange stuff going
on. Then you walk thru that and there is the
main room witch is pretty big it had stairs
leading somewhere but it was blocked off. There
was the bar then the dance floor. The dj was
elevated in a half circle enclosure towards the back
of the main room over looking the danceing area and
bar. There was to slide projections on two big walls
and good lighting efx! The sound system was pretty
kicking but what do I know! The music was better than
any Deep Space encounter at Oasis!!! As you walk thru the
main room there was a little area behind the slide projections
with a couch right behind the screen and an elevated couch thing
with tall little round tables so's you can sit and sip! I like
this place just for the fact that it has places to sit ;).
There were only maybe 40 people there, but I left early do to
tiredness. By the way this place was 100% well ventilated! Not
alot of smoke to bother you people who get bothered easily. Plus
they have pitchers of water there with cups no charge. You get in
free from 9 to 10p.m.. Definitely something to support here in 
San Jose! I think I saw Vivian but I was not sure do to lights
going on and off, but if that was you HELLO!!!  ;)
Sorry about the spelling errors, nobodys perfect!

noah@cadence.com
"True friendship comes when silence between two
 people is comfortable".

Greetings!
After spending the last two hours sifting thru 275 + posts with more
arriving during my reading time. I feel like we may have lost something
here. What is the purpose of this list? Is it for these ongoing flame wars?
When I read these posts from all of you out there. I am touched by what
you people say. All of this negativity is a sheer downer, which is the
exact opposite of what I want. I want to be uplifted and get high off what
you have to say!!! There is no reason for violence to come between us...
   
     We here are not all wanting to be Captain Kirk's just waiting for the
chance to say. "FIRE!!!!"

So take a step back from your computer and think to yourself... 
Do I really want to go out and hurt other peoples feelings???

I know from all of these flames my feelings have been scorched.
Live Long and Prosper... (couldn't help it 8^)

XDZebra Review #35

        Addiction
        266 Delmar Ct.
        Salt Lake City, UT 84101-1817

When in Utah call the T A S T E hotline 801-461-3375.

Trying to find these releases?  Try Ear/Rational Music:
FAX 805/893-8553, Phone 805/564-4949, email angst%cs@hub.ucsb.edu

Back issues are available from me by mail or by ftp'ing to soda.berkeley.edu.
They're in the pub/sfraves/music directory.

BPMs provided courtesy of Eric Pederson's BPM calculator for the Sparc.

XDZebra Reviews may be reproduced without permission under one condition,
they remain intact and unchanged.  If you publish this in print, mail me a
copy via "Addiction".

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Review #35 Contents:
Bjork: Debut
System 7: Sinbad/Quest
Ultramarine: Kingdom
TC 1993: Harmony
Fierce Ruling Diva: Get Funky With Me
Ace The Space: 1 Gun - 2 Gun - 3 Gun - Roar!
Amorphous Androgynous: Tales of Ephidrina


Bjork: Debut
Elektra: 961468-2
1  109  04:11 Human Behavior
2  116  04:52 Crying
3   68  04:43 Venus As A Boy
4  124  03:21 There's More To Life Than This
5       04:34 Like Someone In Love
6  119  03:57 Big Time Sensuality
7  105  05:24 One Day
8  105  03:55 Aeroplane
9   87  04:55 Come To Me
10 120  04:59 Violently Happy
11      03:33 The Anchor Song

Comments: Bjork, otherwise known as the lead vocal for The Sugarcubes brings
out a quirky, dancy, fun solo album.  With strong backing production from
Nellee Hooper, this release has some serious thumpers with a few returns to
the 'cubes sound.  "Human Behavior" is the first single of the album.  It uses
these fab sounding kettle drums to give sort of a 60's "Walking Boots" air
about it.  "There's More To Life Than This" is produced to sound like it is
being done in a club, with Bjork singing to you at the table, then in the
bathrooms.  The backing is clubby, but the front is a definite message to the
club kids.  "Big Time Sensuality" is also on the housey side, but then we are
treated to an Orbalistic endeavor with a moving bass and gurgling baby
sounds.  Tracks like "Aeroplane" and "The Anchor Song" return to what we know
as the mixed pallette that Bjork normally sings.

Summary: 7/10.  Bjork's voice is fabulous and works well with a dancey track,
but her experimental ventures are a bit hard to swallow with casual listening.


System 7: Sinbad/Quest
Weird and Unconventional/Big Life: BFLD 8
1  130  03:51 Sinbad (Bandit Edit)
2  125  08:32 Quest (Moody Boys Interpretation)
3  130  05:53 Sinbad (7th Voyage of Sinbad)
4  125  06:44 Quest (Moon Mix)

Comments: "Sinbad" is my favorite track from the System 7 "777" album, and
this single is much nicer than the previous single, "7:7 Expansion".  The only
notable mix of "Sinbad" is the second "7th Voyage of Sinbad" which expands it
into a lighter, yet deeper version with analog overtures and watery samples,
but still retains the driving drum line.  "Quest" is a delicious new track
that glistens like bright moonlight itself.  The first "Moody Boys
Interpretation" is interesting, but not as stunning as the "Moon Mix" which is
really the best song on this single.

Summary: 9/10.  Nice remix of "Sinbad", but the real stunner is the final
version of "Quest".  System 7 is producing better ambient house than anyone
right now.


Ultramarine: Kingdom
Blanco Y Negro: NEG65CD
1  110  04:54 Kingdom
2  124  07:27 Goldcrest
3  110  07:15 Kingdom (Extended Mix)

Comments: A highly awaited new single from the distinct Ultramarine.  This
time with a medieval tinge that lifts its lyrics from an 1848 folk song.  The
pan flute fits into Ultramarine's light sound and gives "Kingdom", of all
things, a sort of Jethro Tull feel.  "Goldcrest" is an instrumental with weird
vocal samples stirred in.  The entire single uses the trademark Ultramarine
analog dive instrument, but is a definite progression for the band.

Summary: 7/10.  Good feel to "Kingdom" and a nice extension as well as a
decent bonus track.  However, it leaves me a little empty.  I'm sure the new
album will more than satisfy.


TC 1993: Harmony
VC Records/Union Recordings: UCRCD20
1  130  09:06 The Big Bump Symphony
2  130  04:55 The F.P.I Funky Mix
3  130  08:36 The Martian Mix
4  130  04:15 The Train Mix
5  130  08:19 The Blue Bullet Dub
6  130  04:18 The Harmony Mix

Comments: There are very few house releases that I groove on anymore, but TC
can always be counted on.  True to form, "Harmony" grooves hard with multiple
well-done remixes.  Although I didn't like it as much as "Funky Guitar" and
"Berry", this does make for some great dancing.  The remixes are all of a wide
variety, and aside from the final "Harmony Mix" stick well to the original
theme.  I just wish TC would put out more than one release a year.

Summary: 8/10.  If you like house, you'll love this.  If you don't but have an
affection for funky rhythms, check it out as well.


Fierce Ruling Diva: Get Funky With Me
The Medicine Label: 9 40828-2
1  133  03:47 Get Funky With Me (Get Funky Radio Mix)
2  130  05:31 Get Funky With Me (You Better Take This)
3  140  04:49 Get Funky With Me (House Music)
4  130  05:28 Get Funky With Me (Love Your Enemies)
5  165  05:09 Get Funky With Me (How Funky Eurotrash 165 BPM)
6  125  04:47 Get Funky With Me (Love Your Enemies Sound Factory Garage Mix)
7  135  05:05 Get Funky With Me (Gimme Your Body Seriously Club-Minded Mix)
8  140  07:11 Get Funky With Me (You Better Take This Synthetic Voodoo Mix)

Comments:  I originally received this on white label a few months back and I
really only liked the "Love Your Enemies" mix enough to play it.  Since then,
they've added a few new mixes that are fairly decent, but I still like both of
the "Love Your Enemies" mixes better than anything else.  The "Eurotrash"
remix is hard and fast, and is somewhat of a joke.  Juan Atkins contributed
the "Synthetic Voodoo Mix" and it is quite boring.  The original "Radio Mix"
is just that, FRD slathered up in radio form, bleagh, too bad.  The remaining
mixes, "You Better Take This", "House Music", and "Gimme Your Body" are a cut
above average, but not too far above average.

Summary: 5/10.  Peppy single for FRD, but by no means as good as their
previous releases.  Medicine is a subsidiary of Elektra, could this be FRD for
the unwashed masses?


Ace The Space: 1 Gun - 2 Gun - 3 Gun - Roar!
Dance Pool/Sony: DAN 659526 2
1  140  03:39 1 Gun - 2 Gun - 3 Gun - Roar!
2  144  03:54 Go Voodoo!
3  109  04:21 Your Special Attraction

Comments: I picked this up because of the Dance Ecstacy 2001 production, and
the fact that they mention Frankfurt Trax 4 on the label.  I haven't received
FFT4 yet, but I'm anxiously awaiting it, so I thought this would tide me
over.  Wrong.  The worst kind of hardcore, chipmunk techno with the Hoover
vacuum running in overdrive.  The sad part is, the use of a military march
chant is a good idea, it was just executed poorly.  "Go Voodoo!" is the same,
but this time Alvin raps.  "Your Special Attraction" holds a bit of merit in a
hip-hoppy Altern8 form, but really isn't worth the cost of this import.

Summary: 2/10.  I wish I could have found a Lenny Dee EP instead.


Amorphous Androgynous: Tales of Ephidrina
Astralwerks/Caroline: ASW 6101 0777 7 88238 2 7
1  129  07:22 Liquid Insects
2  121  04:17 Swab
3  115  04:39 Mountain Goat
4  120  05:38 In Mind
5  146  08:17 Ephidrena
6  140  07:20 Auto Pimp
7  116  04:04 Fat Cat
8  113  05:28 Pod Room

Comments: In the process of creating a new Future Sound of London record,
Dougans and Cockbain found that they had so much material that they decided to
put out this album under the "Amorphous Androgynous" name.  What is amazing
about this fact is that if this is the "leftovers" the next FSoL album will be
ungodly.  "Tales of Ephidrina" is damn fine music, not just for the pounding
danceability of "Swab" or the beauty of "Mountain Goat" but for the FSoL
innovation and originality is in strong form here.  Only one track sags, "Pod
Room", which begins to sound like a power-plant gone awry with its repeated
buzz line.  It eventually makes good with a sweeping orchestral sparkling
closure.  Astralwerks is a new division of Caroline and this is their first
release.  The production is stellar and far beyond the original Jumpin' and
Pumpin' mush.  Astralwerks has a bright future if they keep it up with this
quality.

Summary: 9/10.  Once again, D&C twist our ears, minds, and souls with
fantastic music of another form.  $14 for this music, a nicely printed booklet
with cool art, and clean production is a bargain beyond reason.

From sfraves-owner  Wed Aug 11 12:35:43 1993

Received: from well.sf.ca.us (well.sf.ca.us [192.132.30.2]) by nkosi.well.sf.ca.us (8.5/8.5) with SMTP id MAA21447; Wed, 11 Aug 1993 12:35:37 -0700

From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: What's So Funny About Peace, Love and Understanding?
Message-Id: <93Aug11.123516pdt.13956-2@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Wed, 11 Aug 1993 12:35:01 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I am sure that most everyone on sfraves is pretty distraught at the tone
of the postings for the last few days.  I'm not going to point any fingers
lest I gotta point one at myself, but let's just say that we're in a
spiraling loop of overheated rhetoric, ego and Serious Attitude.

There's really no need for it, as 10 seconds of serious consideration
shows. 

We've got a great group of people here and plenty of room for discussion
and even vociferous disagreement while maintaining respect.  How else
do we learn unless we're exposed to each other's views and experiences
which of necessity differ from our own?

I don't want to be didactic about this.  Online discussion is a fragile
environment and we've gotta promote the vibe here just as at any gathering.

Peace and respect aren't just slogans.  They mean *serious attention* to
one's relationships with others.  It's not about winning, it's about living.

We don't have to overlook our disagreements.  But what Carlos said to me
several weeks ago stands as a crucial point: "You've got to be *positive*!"
(You can just see him standing there with his arms outstretched making this
statement :)

I don't like the feeling of being preachy so I'm gonna cut this now.
It's up to each of us to steer a positive course.  

Peace out  . . .

Subject: Progress

Well, Progress down here in San Jose is a good weekly event with the usual
San Jose kickin' DJs:  Julius, Harry Who, and Rick Preston.  The San Jose
scene really has some great DJs (don't forget Spun) for a town that won't
let dancing go on after 2am.  There aren't as many choices as in SF, but 
the community here is tighter, I feel.  It is great to see the same faces
everywhere.

So check out:

Mondays - every other monday is Free Life at FX
Tuesdays -  every tuesday is Progress at Oz in the pavillion
Wednesdays - somethhing abovr  a record store (?)
Thursdays - every thurs. is Deep Space with Spun, Rick Preston, Harry, guests
Fridays -  FX again.

See ya there.
Zak

Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA06671; Wed, 11 Aug 93 13:47:27 PDT
Date: Wed, 11 Aug 93 13:47:27 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9308112047.AA06671@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: SFRaves social agenda
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


If there is a sociopolitical or philosophical culture on SFRaves it is
certainly unintentioned.  We are a pretty diverse bunch, but any group
of people will have some basic things in common, and repeated interactions
within the group will usually reinforce such things, resulting in a 
*somewhat* common outlook.  What follows are *my* subjective observations 
of what we seem to have in common on SFRaves which someone might percieve 
as contributing toward a sociopolitical "agenda" of sorts.  I do not at 
all suggest that anyone *should* adhere to any of it.  For that matter,
since I don't personally know most of the people on SFRaves, take this
as an overgeneralized guess about our shared backgrounds. 

1. Raving: The act of raving causes us to focus on music, dance,
a group vibe, altered states of consciousness, shared sensory
stimulation, and certain kinds of technology among other things.  
Many of these things typically take us out of our selves, i.e. we 
experience AND VALUE the loss of our egos to some extent.  Of course 
we still have egos, but most of us know how to transcend them for 
the sake of fostering a Oneness amongst us.  Many of us have learned
that what any one of us has to say is not necessarily more important
or *right* than some other point of view.  The world is an imperfect 
place, so often we tend to let things we disike slide and focus on what
brings us together, like music, dance, love, humor, etc.  

2. Living in the SF BAy Area: The history of SF (i.e. the psychedelic
60's) and the cultural diversity here has affected most of us who live 
here.  The large gay population here is especially important becuase it 
underscores an openmindedness toward alternative lifestyles.  From this 
comes the idea of mutual respect and the realization that it's OK to be 
different, unless what makes someone different is their intolerance toward 
others.  The Bay Area also tends to lean politically toward the left and 
seems to be more environmentally conscious than other parts of the country.

3. Network Access: People with experience being online understand that
this mode of communication requires a certain amount of etiquette in
order to work.  A lot can be lost in a mishmosh of hurried words.
Bandwidth is a shared and limited resource and rules are difficult
to create  and enforce without restricting everyone's freedom to 
express themselves, so there is a certain amount of care and self-policing 
that we tend to expect from each other.  On the net, mutual respect is
often measured by how well the basic elements of net etiquette are followed, 
but at the same time, we value the freedom of the anarchic spirit here, 
and so the inevitable occasional digressions and "abuses" are quickly
forgiven.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

Just would like to respond to John's post, hopefully this flaming
will settle down.

1) I don't think I ever said that you weren't entitled to you opinions,
   but rather that you should state them as such instead of acting as
   if they're the absolute truth.  Most people, I would gather, don't
   agree with your ideas about 21+ vs. under-21, nor are they quite so
   bothered about going to raves with mostly hets in them.

2) At various points in your message to me you implied (perhaps
   unintentionally) that I was racist and narrow-minded.  When I first
   wrote my post, I had a feeling you might take offense to some of
   the things I wrote, because they were the sort of things that I
   *know* from personal experience will trip some people's PC sensors.
   I was in fact merely trying to point out that ragging on white
   people is just as bad as ragging on black people, or ragging on
   any such class of people, Serbs and hillbillies included.

3) Many people perceive your attitude as "aggro" whether or not you
   intend it this way, so keep this in mind when you post.  I don't
   think anyone has any desire to censor you or prevent you from
   saying what you want, but some people (I in particular!) would
   prefer that you say it in a slightly nicer way.

Let's get past this, please ...

ben

From sfraves-owner  Wed Aug 11 18:47:57 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA07408; Wed, 11 Aug 93 18:47:57 PDT
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA07401; Wed, 11 Aug 93 18:47:54 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA14148; Wed, 11 Aug 93 18:48:35 -0700
Date: Wed, 11 Aug 93 18:48:35 -0700
Message-Id: <9308120148.AA14148@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Accentuate the POSITIVE ;)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

After all this discussion my mind was set ablaze with your 
many comments and ideas (oh yes, there were PLENTY amongst 
the flames of thought).

It is obvious that there must be a change.  All of us are 
tired of the same old club(s), and the same BS that goes 
along with it.  Tired of the disingenuine promoter who 
promises the world but delivers a grain of sand.  So with 
this in mind I began to think of how, as a collective, we as 
a group can make a change for the better.  Dig this:

1.  Start a local rag (magazine) that documents the many 
aspects of the scene.
    Don't just dismiss this as another URB (which is based 
in LA and has not a clue about what is happening here).  A 
mag that is small, free and objective/subjective can do alot 
to stimulate thought, discourse, and action.  It can also 
serve as a very powerful communications medium that helps 
people locate, and dive into the UG we create.  It should 
cover ALL aspects of the scene, from the gay/lesbian vibe to 
the present house culture.  It should act as a catalyst to 
bring the MANY houses together in unity to accomplish the 
one thing we all want to do, enjoy life (read killa party).  
This can also help new people (DJ's) get broken into the 
scene, creating more variety for the community.  It can also 
help to prop up the resurgence of UG's here in SF!  It can 
also act as a means to discover new talent in the area 
(musicians/DJ's making music/video/high tech [ala Synergy & 
Nitty Gritty]), as well as new movements that are related to 
house.  It can be funded by adverts from the local shops who 
have benefited greatly from our common house culture.

2. Support the local UG's and promote it's growth!  You want 
to send a message to promoters, club owners etc. Then 
support venues and locations that are not the conventional!  
Support the DJ's who spin at these places.  And more 
importantly GET INVOLVED!  Either by word of mouth promotion 
of such events, or doing one yourself!
There are sooo many things that have not been tried.  Why 
not a "New Moon" party.  Why not something really chill 
during Perseid tonight with just some chill ambient music 
while watching the "shooting stars", then later shutting it 
off for nature's perfect sound system.  How about a boat 
party on a Friday...man, so many possibilites for those who 
want to make a difference!  For those who want to make a 
change!

3.  I have harped about diversity and there are ways of 
accomplishing this.  Allowing different types of music to 
play at different times.  And the themes of such parties 
would change.  Why not some soul, garage, tribal, funk.  Why 
not some acid jazz, break beat, acid.  Why not some...you 
get the idea.  Mix it up, and you'll get a variety of 
people.  Keep shit the same and things stay the same.  
Different DJ's and not just the conventional lineup is great 
too (this is what we have done with Vortex and it works 
great).  Which brings me to my next subject...new talent.

4.  There is plenty of talent here in the bay area.  Lots of 
DJ's, and lots of people with ideas.  Everyone should have a 
chance if it adds to the overall vibe.  New DJ's have it the 
toughest since they are caught in a catch 22.  I say this, 
if you can match beats, and are into it, then you should be 
given a break.  This could occur at UG's where people are 
more open to new talent, and new talent has a chance to do 
what it needs to do to become better, PLAYING IN FRONT OF A 
LIVE AUDIENCE.  Not everything has to be UG, but if you're 
gonna be all inclusive regardless of age then this is one of 
the few possibilities.

5.  With all of this there should be several goals in the 
movement.  I have plenty of ideas as to what they should be 
but I have been told about my bandwidth so I'll only present 
one.  I think that the IDEA of a promoter making $$$ is not 
a bad idea, I think it is more how they do it.  I think the 
goal should be $10 parties if massive, and less if they 
occur during the week.  No party should be over $10, unless 
it is a special event (where I would think that $15 is 
adequate).   By forcing the price down all production costs 
go down.  DJ prices drop, equip. prices drop, and the venue 
price drops.   This is attainable and worthwhile.

6.  Get ACTIVE.  There is little that can be done without 
massive action.  If you are dissatisfied with the current 
laws then there is the power of the vote that can be wielded 
with great strength.  There are more 18-30 year olds in the 
city than other populations.  Therefore the politicians will 
take notice if you have first registered SF ravers, and have 
them sign a petition.  This double whammy will attract  not 
only the attention of the politicians (who YOU NEED in order 
to change current legislation), but of the media.  It would 
be nice to have a discussion on KQED about the scene, what 
it's about and the implications of the scene on society.  It 
could also bring to light the hypocrisy of current laws, 
thus facilitating the changes we all want to see.


Well that's just about it.  There is alot more that can be 
done, and I have provided at least some ideas for action.  I 
have already begun a few of the steps myself, and am moving 
forward with like minded individuals I have met a parties 
and here on the list  There are some things that I am not 
interested in pursuing at this time since my time is quite 
limited (although I find PLENTY of time to reply to the 
voluminous ruminations that occur here on the list ;) ) so I 
direct my energy where it will have the greatest 
impact/result (read I am doing 2-5!).  We each have a golden 
opportunity.  It is now up to the individual to either make 
an impact OR stand on the sidelines.  Active participation 
or do nothing.  The choice is always yours.


From the prophet on high, or rather
from the prophet who is high,
John

+                                  P.E.                                    +
+                    from the village of jsl@netcom.com                    +

From sfraves-owner  Wed Aug 11 21:52:09 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA08280; Wed, 11 Aug 93 21:52:09 PDT
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA08271; Wed, 11 Aug 93 21:52:04 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA29213; Wed, 11 Aug 93 21:52:45 -0700
Date: Wed, 11 Aug 93 21:52:45 -0700
Message-Id: <9308120452.AA29213@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Please read this. Thanks!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Well I have decided to use up a bit more bandwidth here.  I will keep it as
brief as possible. So if you can bear with me for a moment.

I was told a day ago that I should "ignore those people" and "you know how
they are", but I didn't and was glad to accpet the consequences of not
doing so. 

The reason...I saw someone post the umpteenth message about ripoff
promoter, and boycotting this or that.

Before that I posted a message about the "insiders guide" which offended
many even though a discliamer of humor was posted at the end, old news.

Before that it was 21+, 21--.  Whatever they were they were not BORING
discussions (this was not what I wanted, I wanted discourse, dialogue, and
action but that has YET to materialize).

I have been called out becuase of the "way" I say things, and "how" I come
off. My attitude needs constant adjusting, and I've been told "I'm not with
the 'vibe'".  Very few address the content since they have such a hard time
in the manner in which it is presented.  This I cannot help.

Throught all of this I have kept my sense of humor, and have tried to let
each of you know that even though I am a "promoter" (another inane
self-bestowed title) I like to bandy it about as well with people who, I
was told, are a group of fun beings with great ideas.  Well I am a bit
disappointed, but aren't we all.

And throughout all of this I have tried, in my own "annoying" and
"obnoxious" way to get you all invovled so that your many ideas could make
a difference in a scene that is in a serious state of transition.  Into
what?  Who knows, even I as a prophet can't tell that.  But all that seems
to have been said is "lawsuit", and "club hit-lists" all under the guise of
making things better for the, uh, "consumer" (which is YOU, the people who
make/break this scene).  Nope not one time has anyone said, "hey let's take
this to the promoters, to the DJ's, let's have a small public forum, let's
take it to the next level".  And the excuses have ranged from "all we are
are partiers, they won't listen" to "fuck the rules, fuck this, and fuck
that, fuck THEM".  I thought it was about UNITY.  I thought it was about
change.  Well those things come when you work very hard to ensure that the
idea is transformed from thought to action.  When it remains within this
realm of ether it becomes electronic-mastubatory fodder whose purpose is
wasted in the hand of internet mailers.  In each post I have always added a
bit of "yuck, yuck" humor.  I assumed that you all at one stage or another
were involved with the throwing of C2 or other parties that mostly SFR's go
to (I know you all attend many events, but c2 is most prominent in my mind
as a SFR event), and therefore got these tepid attempts at humor.  I
miscalculated.  In any event the one thing I have always stressed, when I
was not bagging like we all do at times, was that we all should take an
ACTIVE part in making this scene work. Become active an create the changes
you want to see.  Hit-lists, and bagging on this-and-that without action is
IMO useless.  And it takes so little effort to change things...at first. 
The larger part of which is organization, and getting things going, along
with changing peoples perception.  It can happen, all it needs is you and
your ideas!

Hey, I know I pissed many of you off, but you pissed me off.  Things
happen...it's part of humanity. The real diff is once we realize that, can
we move on?  And can we GROW from the experience?  This is the true test of
Homo Nova.

I have tried earnestly to get some action going with a few of you.  Getting
a petition for 18+ all nighters, but was BAGGED on becuase it did not
include 18--.  Starting UG's like Late Train (btw there will be one next
Monday, check Pepper at DDD on haight.  It's called "Late-Train - The
Caboose is Loose!", and are the funniest parties you can ever attend (if
you can.  They start around 1-3 and are very chaotic, that is until the
music starts :)> ), and doing your own thang (but as usual was bagged
becuase I would not give details since that would be premature). In any
case we are both (SFR collective sans a few) guilty of jumping the gun and
being (I gotta say it!) misinformed (ahhhhhh :), about each other (talk
about virtual).  In any case I hoped that some of you would take action to
change things, but I guess some things cannot be rushed or changed.

In any case I have decided (whilst driving on 280 s going to work in SJ
from SF eeech, and overlooking the scenery with hawks, buzzards, and
greenery) to stop posting anything here on SFR.  The reason, we just can't
seem to communicate.  We talk AT each other, and as a result get the worse
that each has to offer.  I do not like the "rave till grave" philosphy, or
"peace, love, & harmony" (sounds like the Return of the Archons [orig Start
Trek]) since there is very little peace, and very little harmony in our
world.  I also do not beleive in it wholly becuase this scene IMO (over the
past 2-3 years) has become so homogenoues that it, for me, has lost alot of
the magic and lustre it once had.  I do not see SFR promoting diversity or
change.  And I see the willingness of others to do little more than
complain (which IS their right!) about something they can HELP (man, it's
like seeing suffering, and saying "fuckin' homeless", "fuckin' this/that",
"bad neighborhood" without reaching out to help.  This is sick and banal.
Most of all NOT HUMAN!).  In a scene that depends upon the energy of others
putting in as well as giving back, this list to me at times seemed one
sided.  But as I said when we talk AT each other alot of nuances are lost. 
In any case I have been asked by many to leave (not by BB mind you). And I
see no need to be in a place that does not want me, or in a place where I
cannot make a difference in the positive. I am also tired of explaining
every word I say to people who are totally literate.  I do think that there
is a line of thought that runs through the list that I do not care for or
care to be a part of.  Hell, unity is great if we can unite in diversity of
culture/mind/deed, this does not seem to be the case here.

So with that I do hope that at some point many of you with very fine points
present your case to the promoters (they NEED it, esp now)/dj's/venues so
that the changes you want are enacted.  I do hope that change occurs and at
some time we may talk TO each other when we are ready (man, it's like SFR
is a being...I guess it is in a way huh?  comrpised of many parts...not
bad), and by that time we can work together to change the things we BOTH
dislike.  Until that time I'll just watch what happens on the list.  And
like the village I will subscribe to "A still toungue makes a happy life"
philosphy. My happiness begins now.

Peace.
John

P.S.  The things you think about when you drive!  BCNU :)

One other thing.  I do follow my own words.  I am hooking up with a couple
of people I've met here and making some nice and overdue changes...anything
is possible, even amongst newly made friends!

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
+         "War 33 & 1/3 not really live I'd rather do it at 45...."        +
+                                  P.E.                                    +
+                    from the village of jsl@netcom.com                    +
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

John S. Lee and everybody else, too:

I just came back from the most spirtually-charged               
dance-concert that I have participated in in a long                  
time--and it was a no-booze 16+ crowd at the Catalyst
in Sanity Cruise.  And suddenly I knew why I was on
sfraves and in sfraves with you-all.  I knew what
John S. Lee and Geoff White and Brian B. and all of
us are abot--for one together tight timeless moment,
crunched in space into the craziest little blue and
red and black box I could ever imagine.  And I thought
yes, imagine...that's what we're all about here,
Warriors and Magicians and LoversandKvetchers...it
may be fucken hard but it's the only thing we have.

And thenI knew why I was going to YSH this Thursday
night and why I'm glad I've never unsubscribed and why             
even with all our misunderstandings and disunderstandings
and I-hate-you-yes-I-understand-yous...why we're still
such a long way from wha we can imagine together!  What
I hate and fear and anger most about is all inside me just
as much as what I love and welcome and am most 
vulnerable about!  It's not me vs. you.  That game is
over.  It's not us vs. them.  That way leads only to death.

Thank you, John Draper and John S. Lee you are me and I
am thee.  Let's see what we can be!

World's second most out there raver,
Will

--

 Southbay SFR Lunch Reminder
 
 
 Just a quick reminder to let everyone know about
 today's SFR Lunch ...
 
 When: Thursday, Aug. 12th   
 Time: 12.00 noon
 Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto
 
 Directions:
 
 * From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
 
 * Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
   (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)
 
 * Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (past apartment complexes on right)
   
 * You will see the park on your right hand side. Park in the first
   carpark to your right.
 
 * We'll meet on the grassy knoll, under the trees behind the backstop.
 
 Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9308121630.AA12126@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Synergy's TV Show
Cc: tgrant@netcom.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


I tuned in to Viacom's Channel 51 at 6:00pm and was treated to
a 1/2 hr of really nice ambient visuals & music (mostly if not
all Eno).  The style of the patterns was very fluid; lava lamp
video overlayed with flowing digital landscapes, some fractal
images and some nice geometric kaleidoscope type patterns that
pulsated and were continuously treated with vivid washes of color.  
Very psychedelic and stimulating, yet totally soothing.  Great stuff; 
I taped the whole show for my own psychedelic library.

I only have 2 very minor nitpicks:  1. There were some occasional
sudden discontinuities in the color changes rather than the gradual
changes that characterized most of the 1/2 hour.  2. The music had
silence between songs where I would have preferred some overlap
in the mix.

Great Job Tony!  But then, I've always liked Synergy's stuff.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

ccat recently asked, after the latest flame wars, "What's the point?"

For what it's worth, i found jslee's signal ratio very high during the
overwhelming flury.  many here on the net were so concerned with his
perceived attitude that they threw the baby out with the bathwater,
missing some very perceptive insights into the scene.  and people forgot
that he was reacting not to someone's opinions, but threats of lawsuits
(frivilous, and ridiculous from someone who should know better....
peace and love, my ass) and boycotts.

but as far as what one reads or deletes, Internet might do well to adopt
a standard WELL caveat.  YMMV...your mileage may vary, everyone's
interpretation will likely be different.  YMMV.

At least there's a scene in which to experience growth pains.

best,

>Penelope's only lost money because it wasn't publicized in quite the right
>way.  Those of us who helped out & attended 'debugged' the event and I'm
>quite sure it will be much different next time.  The only thing missing
>at PW were the people and the vibe, everything else was righteously ready.


>That sucks!  When I talked to (I believe) Melissa she said that it would be
>a cooperative of sevral promoters for a good cause.  When we first talked I
>was doing my party and was concetrating on IT that evening.  All I can say
>is promotion, promotion, promotion.  All it needed was that, since all else
>was there.  I saw VERY few flyers handed out, and most of the word on the
>street had no mention of the party.  I will talk to whoever and see if I
>can be more active in the next venture.  Since I live 2 blocks from Haight
>and know some of the store owners and some other folks we can get really
>strong promotion from SF -> SJ.  I also know a few people in Sac...in any
>case I would like to contact whoever about PW and help out (if I can). 
>Leave me e-mail with the details. 

The problem is that the promoters of PW didn't really want that much 
publicity.  I didn't think that they wanted that many people there.  
At least not everyone of your GK, Basics, etc etc raver.  Not that there 
is anything wrong with them, but  a basic harmony with nature was 
trying to be achieved. They just didn't want anyone to drop there 
trash everywhere and not respect their Mother.  I agree there needed 
to be more people there, but I don't think leaving flyers everywhere 
would achieve the ultimate goal of these particular promoters. 
Not to put you down or anything John, because I know you have all 
good intentions in mind. However I think a more careful way of promoting 
this party would be better.  

This is my opinion and only my opinion.  I hope in my short paragraph 
I have not offended anyone. If so please tell me nicely I don't want 
to be flamed. :-0


vivianm

I am sorry but there are very few people on this earth that are not 
somewhat judgemental.


>Vivian, I am through explaining myself here on the list.  Either you like
>me or you don't.  I have nothing against you or anyone else here.  That is
>all I have to say about that.  Elucidations and calrification?  Im done
>with those as well. As for meeting me, whatever.  I like to meet people who
>are interesting and challenging to my mind, that is the ONLY criteria.  If
>they have integrity and  follow their words with actions I am interested in
>meeting them.  If not I have nothing to offer them as well, they have
>nothing to offer me.  Human beings are all about communication, exchange of
>ideas.  Often times we misunderstand one another.  This has caused wars,
>death, destrcution.  What has caused even MORE death and destrcution is the
>inaction of others.  This list is full of them, but why and how I ever
>thought otherwise is beyond me. Nuff said.
 
 
  As I have stated before, it wasn't the information you were conveying, it was the way it was being put forth.  And I do apologize for saying I would never want to meet you, that was mean of me. However as I said you did ruffle my feathers.  I do agree that everyone has gone overboard on this whole thing.  It is a good thing that everyone has differing opinions, but when we are just 
sitting around yelling at eachother nothing gets accomplished right?  
I think we should be working together not against eachother.  We 
are a more  mellow group as a whole. I have read the flames on other 
newsgroups and they are all downright rude.  I applaud everyone for 
the majority for not getting completely out of hand, and resorting 
to petty name calling.  I hope we will be able to get over this.

Hmmm...I don't have a lot of events for this weekend.  I don't really
have a solid handle on how LoveStock will be; it sounds like it'll be
in a cool location, but the crowd could be cool or could be more in
the Cyberfest direction.  I think if you go with friends, you can have
a good time.  Origin might be fun too - seems to be put on by the
Foundation people, for what that's worth...

Otherwise, you're left with the weeklies, but that's not so bad, since
there now seems to be at least a couple good choices every night (!) :)

Thursday, August 12th - free beach party at Bonny Doon
	DJs Shon  Alonzo  Darwyn  Matt Mau
	begins at 12am.  check 408.383.6125 thurs night to confirm.

        Homegrown Love Mission in association w/ Sharon, l.P. Productions,
        Black Sun Rising & Sudzy Blunt Music, and the SF Cultural Assoc.
        A community Festivahl in celebration of music, peace, life, love,
        unity, free spirit & mind.

        Buck Gary Christophe Noel Sam Raggamuffin Troy Dutch&Richie (UK)

                10 Bass T, Single Cell Orchestra, Inka Inka, Alaura of PTV
                Dub Tribe, and Sona Lacosta (UK)
        Camp and party all weekend on beautiful wooded campgrounds encircled
        by a gorgeous flowing river.
        Bring family, drums, tents, etc.  Be prepared and waste conscious.
        Global Issues Pow-Wow Saturday & Sunday Afternoon.

Here are some weeklies - whether or not they count as real "raves" is 
debatable, but they were advertised by fliers and the music could be
good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their 
appropriateness in being on the list, let me know....

Subject: A question for the DJs
Message-Id: <93Aug12.141841pdt.14182-2@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Thu, 12 Aug 1993 14:18:21 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


How do you all feel about digital audio and computers?

The reason I ask this is that I write programs that deal with digital audio
and MIDI and I want to write a program that would basically give the DJ the
same capabilities that you currently have with turntables and a mixer plus
the ability to add other things to the mix like live percussion, lighting
control, digital video control and all the other cool things you can do with
computers that are near impossible with out them.

What I'd like to know is this:  if such a system existed, would you consider
using it?  And if so, what features would you like to see in the program.
Also, if you think this idea sucks I'd like to know why.

This is not a marketing survey. This is just an idea I've been toying with
for a while.

I'm a musician who likes to use new and unusual performance techniques and
listening to a good DJ is everybit as rewarding as listening to a more
traditional performance.

Thanks for the help
-Jeff Moore

jmoore@well.sf.ca.us
