Subject: an early morning tale
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Thu, 12 Aug 93 15:10:12 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


A funny thing happened to me this morning.  I was being driven to the
train station so I could go to work at about 7:30 a.m. and I saw a bunch
of ravers standing outside some space down near there!  It is so funny...
I am so used to coming out of raves in the morning, feeling superior
to all the fools driving by who got up that early to commute to slavery,
and now for once I was on the other side!  I don't know what event it
was, but for a Wednesday night event to last all the way through to
the morning is pretty good...

gros bises, Jessica

Beyond the ultraworld of Jeffrey Moore:
> 
> 
> How do you all feel about digital audio and computers?

I work in audio/video/telecomm integration (multimedia/vr/audiotex/videotex),
so i use it all the time... You should post this to bpm, the internet DJ's
list... (bpm-request@andrew.cmu.edu to sub), it is probably more appropriate
there than here.

> The reason I ask this is that I write programs that deal with digital audio
> and MIDI and I want to write a program that would basically give the DJ the
> same capabilities that you currently have with turntables and a mixer plus
> the ability to add other things to the mix like live percussion, lighting
> control, digital video control and all the other cool things you can do with
> computers that are near impossible with out them.

A few radio stations use the Roland DJ-?? sampler. Personally i use 2 Gravis
Ultrasound and a Roland controller. I see it as a complement to a dual CD
player (or turntables for most djs), but i can make megamix easily with that,
live and without touching a mixer or turntable or cd (once i have all my samples
ready). I have not toyed with SMPTE time code for video control, nor used a
MIDI light controller, but these are all off the shelf components...

> What I'd like to know is this:  if such a system existed, would you consider
> using it?

Well, i dont see the difference from what i'm using (or could buy at the local
musician shop...)

  And if so, what features would you like to see in the program.
> Also, if you think this idea sucks I'd like to know why.

I dont think it's a bad idea, but maybe you could explain a bit... all that is
needed is already available... unless i misunderstood you!

> I'm a musician who likes to use new and unusual performance techniques and
> listening to a good DJ is everybit as rewarding as listening to a more
> traditional performance.

If you want to impress a lot of people, use a powerglove and "fake" scratching
with it and a sampler... pretty cool... I'm now working on the windows part,
because i want to integrate this with all the cool tools in windows (rave,
patch controller etc...).

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion
    '  _   _   _ 
 CISM (_) (_)  _) FM       Montreal , Canada       Email: CISM@ERE.UMontreal.CA
      (_)  / . _)             10000 Watts          Telephone no: (514) 343-7511

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

> How do you all feel about digital audio and computers?

Like I was sleeping in a bed of purring fuzzy kittens....

> The reason I ask this is that I write programs that deal with digital audio
> and MIDI and I want to write a program that would basically give the DJ the
> same capabilities that you currently have with turntables and a mixer plus
> the ability to add other things to the mix like live percussion, lighting
> control, digital video control and all the other cool things you can do with
> computers that are near impossible with out them.

I'll take one of these! Might even help work on it if the software is
free and it is written for a suitably open platform (e.g. unix).

I've been wanting to do this kind of stuff for a long time, and it now
seems like I might have the chance.

I will be getting an SGI Indy in the near future and will be working on
"multimedia" group-work (or play) environments on that platform. (Niels
finally decides to get deunemployed...). I would be glad to share
whatever bits of non-proprietary code I develop in return for the same
from you all.

For "play" I'm definitely going to need digital video/audio editing
that go beyond the basic stuff provided with the system... The sorts of
things that might be fun to experiment with, include the following
audio wet dreams: 

* applying functions to the colormap (of video or graphics) based on
the real-time spectrum of the incoming audio signals... Yer digimaniac
update of the 70's-something-been-hanging-out-at-radio-shack-too-much-
light-organ.

* beat-match assistant -- plots a crude map which helps visualize the
rhythmic structure of a pre-recorded digitized sample of music (as a 3D
surface with x,y a function of spectral analysis, z time). "Beat
matching" could occur by placing the visualization of the rhythmic
structures "on" top of each other, with 3D cues helping people align
the structures.

--------------------

Aside from that, you can also get a variety of mac or PC-based
hard-disk recording systems that may help do some of the digital
audio/video editing.

Has anybody heard about Digidesign's Session 8 -- it's an 8 channel
direct-to-disk, recording, mixing, DSP, and random access editing, with
a supposedly "full" (whatever that means) MIDI implementation. $3995.00
list (plus your PC w/ Windows 3.1), includes SCSI controller....

How good are the "low end" audio hardware and software for the PC?
(e.g. Microsoft's Windows Sound System, Sound Blaster 16ASP, Media 
Vision Pro Audio Spectrum 16). Any recommended random access editing
systems for such a platform?

Subject: More about computer DJs
Message-Id: <93Aug12.164107pdt.14204-1@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Thu, 12 Aug 1993 16:39:06 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


First a little about me and what I do.  Technically, I'm a programmer with
OSC.  We make Deck.  For those not familiar with us, Deck is the original
(and still the best :) 4 track digital audio workstation on the Mac.  I
write user interfaces among other things.  I'm also a musician interested in
alternative performance mediums including audience participation.

What I envision in this program is an open ended environment for controlling
and manipulating sound and other stuff (video, lights, coffee makers, etc).
The question is not whether it can be done, cause it can.  The question is,
what would it look like?  Since a lot of techno is basically sound that's
been looped, I've taken this as my starting point.  I envision an interface
that lets the user put together looped material in real time.  What medium
the sound is on is beside the point, though the first incarnation will most
likely be something that resembles the program Upbeat but will include
machine control and digital audio.  The technical side of all this has
already been written.  We have an audio engine that's more than capable to
do the task.

I want this program to be more than just a mixing and playback of someone
else's music (which is the current method of the DJ), but to be a full
performance environment with all the bells and whistles (including power
glove support).

You all sound interested, so I'm actually going to try to throw something
together that I can share.  What I need to know is what essential user
interface elements need to be in the program to make it useful and
productive.

-Jeff Moore

I've been toying with idea to create a mixxing juke box. The user would pick
the song they'd like to hear and the MJB would process the BPM of the song
picked (song header file) versus the song playing and mix them based upon a 
mixxing algorythm (what a great name for the thing). Does anyone have any ideas 
for the algothrthm to mix two digital signals. Let me know.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Aug 13 09:48:23 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17198; Fri, 13 Aug 93 09:48:23 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17191; Fri, 13 Aug 93 09:48:20 PDT
Received: by netcom3.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA28921; Fri, 13 Aug 93 09:49:04 -0700
Message-Id: <9308131649.AA28921@netcom3.netcom.com>
To: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: Re: More about computer DJs 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 13 Aug 93 09:17:08 PDT."
             <9308131617.AA25940@netcom3.netcom.com> 
Date: Fri, 13 Aug 93 09:49:03 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>I've been thinking bout Digital mixing for a while,  and yes!!  I think
>it's possible to do it.  I discussed this with Amit last evening,  who
>is a digital music and audio programmer,   and the idea intregues
>me greatly.
>
>While at YSH last night,  ai discussed it with a few other psople
>and while dancing,   I think I came up with an algorithm for
>doing it,   but it depends on sonstant "boom boom" to exist,
>but that can be used to lock a time base.

seems like a good way to do it is generate a sound-envelope function
(which should make the "boom boom" pretty prominent) and use a phase
locked loop to adjust the source speed to match up a source of known
BPM. PLL's tend to require a pretty clean signal, but one can "damp"
the output of the phase comparator s.t. it won't come out of lock as
easily. The downside to that being that it may take a long time to
acquire lock.... (Furthermore, PLL's make it easy to perform frequency
multiplication, perhaps useful for chipmunk breakbeat fans.)

However, don't most DJ's "beat match" off the high-hats? What happens
if the "boom boom" is actually BASS? In jazzy/funky domains, BASS tends
to SWING, which makes algorithmic beat matching difficult.

I personally still like the 3D visualization approach I mentioned in my
previous post better. For one, it will allow you do do interesting
things like putting the beat exactly 180 degrees out of phase for
interesting effect. It also provides easier correlation between how a
song sounds and the visualized "sound structures" which one aligns
using graphics ops.

==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==

> >I've been thinking bout Digital mixing for a while,  and yes!!  I think

[technical discussion deleted]

Whatever happenned to the digital opcode outputs that were gonna be
used on CD players?  I know a few CDs were released with some primitive
graphics synced to the music that took advantage of this, although
some kind of an adapter was needed.  Anyway, If MIDI timecode could
be recorded with CDs and transmitted this way, CDs could be synced
with sequencers, SMPTE (video), lights, theatre props, etc. without
much in the way of of new software/hardware development.  Leaves
vinyl out of the picture, though.

Has anybody heard about Digidesign's Session 8 -- it's an 8 channel
direct-to-disk, recording, mixing, DSP, and random access editing, with
a supposedly "full" (whatever that means) MIDI implementation. $3995.00
list (plus your PC w/ Windows 3.1), includes SCSI controller....

How good are the "low end" audio hardware and software for the PC?
(e.g. Microsoft's Windows Sound System, Sound Blaster 16ASP, Media
Vision Pro Audio Spectrum 16). Any recommended random access editing
systems for such a platform?

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ya, I've heard of it.  And dreamt of finding $3995.00 and buying it.

The "low end" stuff isn't really digital audio, per se.  I have the Sound
Blaster 16ASP and it's real fun to play with but there's not much you
can do with it in terms of making or contributing to music.  It has good
sound for games, it let's you spice up your environment by assigning sound
effects to system calls (porky pig saying bdi bdi bdi that's all folks when
I shut down windows), and currently I'm having lots of fun with the recorder
and editor by tweaking and looping samples, etc. until I get a "real"
sampler that I can control via midi.  It's good practice though, and I can
start planning and arranging music until I get a midi controler, sequencer,
and a sampler (I already have a keyboard and a couple of drum machines).

Oh, by the way.  There is a new direct-to-disk recorder/midi interface (I
think) that is about to or just came out.  It only has 2 channels digital
audio but it's only around $600.00.  It's called the TAP 10 and Roland
makes it.  Check it. ;-)

-Mark

WWWhhhhhhhhheeeeeewwwwwwwwwuuuuuugggggghhhhhhhh.........


I dunno how to spell it, but I think that's right. Anyway, it's supposed to
be a long, audible sigh of contentment, satisfaction, happiness in general,
and muscles that will definitely hurt later.

I couldn't believe it. I had the best time of my life. I know I said that
LAST week as well, but it WAS the best time.

The DJs were GREAT! I couldn't believe that every song spoke to me, call me
back from the boring, cold chill area and back into the
carbohydrate-sapping heat of the dance floor. Usually, there's at least one
set or so that I can't dance to, music that I don't particularly like...
Nope, not here.

I ran into a shitload of people again. Heya, Monikat, Susie, Louis, Amit.
(Special thanx to Susie for un-tensing Sean.) As before, met new ones
(*waves*) like Ben and Howard.

I missed Oz and that pissed me off. I looked around a bit, but I s'pose it
was doomed from the beginning. A guy in a green shirt... Hmm, that
certainly narrows it right down. *smirk*

heheheheh

A few of my friends were teasing me a bit about my conduct with a potted
plant. At the very beginning of the party, around ten or so, I was feeling
very nice and not altogether normal, which is fine. I started rubbing up
against the plant like a cat, just rubbing my face against the leaves and
touching the pot and stuff. I looked up and said to a friend "I can't
believe I'm standing here with my head in a plant." It seems a few people
noticed and remarked. Odd.

Anyway, what I said last week about YSH is ditto for this week. Kickass
location, lotsa room, and the same old YSH stuff, which is fine.

"I think I've found a new hobby." - Louis

hazrat Gregor Mosheh

623 Radcliffe Drive   Davis, CA  95616-1011
(916) 758-5589                  THIS ADDRESS EXPIRES AUG 31, 1993.

gmosheh@nyx.cs.du.edu
mosheh@cybernet.cse.fau.edu

PGP2.2 key available. Please request it and use it.

It occured to me last night (at a rave) why Christians are so against rave
and dance in general, despite it's blatant and frequent use as an adjunct
to worship: What is there that Heaven could offer in the future that isn't
here right now (at a rave)? All the temptations of Hell and glories of
Heaven could be nothing compared to the experience of Rave.

John Draper writes...
> 
> I've been thinking bout Digital mixing for a while,  and yes!!  I think
> it's possible to do it.  I discussed this with Amit last evening,  who
> is a digital music and audio programmer,   and the idea intregues
> me greatly.

Me too...  I've been thinking about an interface box for the Denon
(cause I don't want to design out a whole CD player too), that basically
serves as a database and alternate UI to the player.  For each CD/track
you will be able to store BPM, and break and cue points.  It's a pain
to find cue points on the Denon.  This device would let you store
your favorite cue points so when you want to mix in, it's all a matter of
finiding the cue point you want from the database (or by hand if you
want) and then auto-adjust the pitch of the incoming based on the
BPM of the incoming and outgoing CDs.  Fine tuning, etc. would still
be done by hand on the existing Denon UI.  For outgoing CDs the
interface could be used to locate an out-break, then setup a countdown timer 
that lets you know when the break is coming up so you can cue the
incoming source, either automatically (if it's a CD) or just as a reference.
Of course, in the deluxe model, the database would actually store
the actual audio of breaks so that you can preview whole mixes in
the phones while stuff is playing.  Eventually it would be nice if you
could store at least a set's worth of songs on a hard drive and forget
crating records and CDs along altogether.  The DJ would just come
with his hard drive.

> While at YSH last night,  ai discussed it with a few other psople
> and while dancing,   I think I came up with an algorithm for
> doing it,   but it depends on sonstant "boom boom" to exist,
> but that can be used to lock a time base.
> 
> Programmically,  it's certainly possible.

Since it's too much of a pain to determine the beats from analyzing
the signal, why not just tap in the beat like you would on a computer
BPM counter?  There would be a beat tap-in feature on my interface
as well.  You would use it to BPM your CDs for the database, and you
could use it on-the-fly to BPM CDs that aren't in your database, 
or to BPM records that are playing so you can mix them out with the
auto-mix feature.

Since all these features are decidedly unmacho, they would only be
a supplement to the existing Denon (or whoever) UI for doing mixing
by hand, of course!  It seems like a basic version of the interface
I describe could be done today.  There's plenty more gee-whiz stuff
that can be added in the future.
-- 
Eric Pederson                                        PacTel Corporation
eric@nit.pactel.com                                        510-210-8890

Beyond the ultraworld of Eric Pederson:
> 
> Me too...  I've been thinking about an interface box for the Denon
> (cause I don't want to design out a whole CD player too), that basically
> serves as a database and alternate UI to the player.  For each CD/track

Denon politely said "forget it" when i asked them for the specs of the mini din
interface a few months back...

> Eventually it would be nice if you
> could store at least a set's worth of songs on a hard drive and forget
> crating records and CDs along altogether.  The DJ would just come
> with his hard drive.

Tell me then why you would even need a DJ? A lot of remote stations that cant
afford staff are fully automated... you just need 1 person to do the playlists,
and the rest is full auto... Now if you do the same thing for beat on beat,
then all you need is somebody to program a playlist. Heck why even bother? You
can just buy mixed tapes! ... Seriously, it is a consideration...

> > Programmically,  it's certainly possible.
> 
> Since it's too much of a pain to determine the beats from analyzing
> the signal, why not just tap in the beat like you would on a computer
> BPM counter?

There is a german CD player with pitch that shows the bpm and can adjust the
second bpm to match. Then all you need to do is press play at approx the good
time (it is synced to the bpm clock). But if you want to do a good bpm
counter not just based on the volume, then you gotta use ffts (fast fourier
transforms), and for that you will surely need a DSP. You can get several cards
with DSP like the Turtle Beach Multisound (the SB16ASP cannot do ffts so it's
of no use) that you could program (it's a 56001 like in the NeXT and SGI).
There have been a few papers written on that subject... check at your cs
library... BTW, on a 486 you could do a few points fft, but the processing left
would be limited to just indicating the values, nothing else...

> Since all these features are decidedly unmacho, they would only be
> a supplement to the existing Denon (or whoever) UI for doing mixing
> by hand, of course!  It seems like a basic version of the interface
> I describe could be done today.  There's plenty more gee-whiz stuff
> that can be added in the future.

Check out in a DJ mag from about a year ago, they talk about the german cd
player... no database for cuepoints, but aided beat matching.

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion

Recently , Gregor posted this [ inspired by the last YSH ]: 
> It occured to me last night (at a rave) why Christians are so against rave
> and dance in general, despite it's blatant and frequent use as an adjunct
> to worship: What is there that Heaven could offer in the future that isn't
> here right now (at a rave)? All the temptations of Hell and glories of
> Heaven could be nothing compared to the experience of Rave.
> 
 In my opinion , one working definition of heaven is " A place where I
will feel better than I could possibly feel in my mortal life " 
[ That's just one of many ideas of a heaven ] . So , if the most intense
experience you have on earth is raves , then heaven will be like the
best ever rave you've been to , except much more so. Since you won't have
a mortal body anymore , this is possible without being physically or
psychicly fatal. You will truly be in "... thee infinite beat".

	  flyers would look like? :-)

caliban@soda.berkeley.edu sez:
        as far as looped techno goes, i have always envisioned
        a huge board covered with switches that turn the loops
        on and off... a board that people in the crowd could
        take turns switching.  truly interactice!  the switches
        would control the loops, or track numbers (in the case
        of master trax and other such sequencing software...)

yup that's right along the lines i was thinking.  At our last CD release
party (for Poke in the Ear II) we wired all sorts of triggering mechanisms
(piezo elements, motion detectors, light detectors, etc) to trigger all
sorts of stuff (sound, video, lights, etc).  This is I concept I'm going to
keep in the program.  So the DJ becomes more of a tour guide through the
mindscape...

ericlacy@hpcc102.corp.hp.com sez:
I've been toying with idea to create a mixxing juke box. The user would pick
the song they'd like to hear and the MJB would process the BPM of the song
picked (song header file) versus the song playing and mix them based upon a
mixxing algorythm (what a great name for the thing). Does anyone have any
ideas
for the algothrthm to mix two digital signals. Let me know.

The DSP engineer at OSC, who also wrote the EPS operating system among other
things, has a real time time compression algorithm  that sounds absolutely
incredible.  His code is currently owned by Dyaxis, but it is based on a
publicly available algorithm (I'm not sure where it's published, but I'll
ask if anyone cares).  It would of course be an integral part of my program.

Hmmmm. This frightens me a little bit.  One of the best qualities of a
good DJ is his/her ability to feel a crowd and work off their collective
energy.  I love watching a DJ start to mix in a song, think of something
better, go scrambling through the crate, slap it on just in the nick of
time-- the crowd roars-- energy surge.  I'd hate to go to a pre-programmed
rave.  Just my $0.02.

lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com sez:

Whatever happenned to the digital opcode outputs that were gonna be
used on CD players?  I know a few CDs were released with some primitive
graphics synced to the music that took advantage of this, although
some kind of an adapter was needed.  Anyway, If MIDI timecode could
be recorded with CDs and transmitted this way, CDs could be synced
with sequencers, SMPTE (video), lights, theatre props, etc. without
much in the way of of new software/hardware development.  Leaves
vinyl out of the picture, though.

syncing CDs is even easier than you thing.  Just use a CD-ROM drive that
supports direct cueing from the computer (just about all of them can do
that).  This is the basis of one of Macromedias presentation programs.  I
think it's Action! but I'm not sure

>   Hmmmm. This frightens me a little bit.  One of the best qualities of a
>   good DJ is his/her ability to feel a crowd and work off their collective
>   energy.  I love watching a DJ start to mix in a song, think of something
>   better, go scrambling through the crate, slap it on just in the nick of
>   time-- the crowd roars-- energy surge.  I'd hate to go to a pre-programmed
>   rave.  Just my $0.02.

    I don't see this as something that would replace the DJ, more as
    something that would allow the DJ to push the envelope still further.
    They could control more sounds at once, or handle more complicated
    rhythms.  It could and should permit more improvisation, not less.

beautiful a huge space with big river in the backyard so to speak. Saw
Alphie. Jeno, John Williams spin terrific sets on a crispy clean sound

way good fun. But there's not many people  (saw Amit) so mabey they'll
drp the price. the site is worth the drive for sure.

Glad to hear this went off.  I was at the map point (which strangely enough
was in the parking lot of Denny's in Santa Cruz) for about an hour between
12:30 and 1:30 and they had yet to find a site.  Apparently the original 
site was private property and had not been properly cleared with the land
owner.  The backup site (somewhere on the beach just north of Davenport --
possibly Greyhound Rock?) got busted as they were setting up.  (So much for
"100% Bust Free" :)

expected.  They also had a dozen or so cases of free bottled water :)

Received: by NeXT Mailer (1.87.1)
To: socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Subject: volunteers needed for MDMA research
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Reply-To: rnj%lila@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

this announcement is from the Summer 1993 MAPS Newsletter (see below for info  
about MAPS).  please feel free to redistribute - especially to anyone you  
know who might be willing to participate in this MDMA research in Los  
Angeles.  beyond the value of the scientific information the study will  
yield, there is another reason to volunteer:  having ample numbers of willing  
subjects will be a needed sign to other researchers and funding organizations  
(the "Powers") that psychedelic explorers are interested enough in the  
scientific truth about psychedelics to support research in this area. 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
              "Normal" Volunteers Needed for MDMA Research

         No spinal taps but, sadly, no MDMA either.  Subjects who
           volunteer for this study will be given preference to
          participate in subsequent studies in which MDMA may be
                              administered.

   Investigators at Harbor Hospital-UCLA Medical Center are interested in  
studying subjects with a history of past use of MDMA and/or LSD for possible  
evidence of MDMA neurotoxicity.  This study is a very important investigation  
of the possible risks of MDMA.  Data from this study will provide important  
evidence to compare to data from studies also being undertaken at Harbor  
Hospital-UCLA Medical Center in which small amounts of MDMA will be given to  
six medical professionals.

  This study is formally known as a "challenge test."  Subjects will be  
administered either the drug fenfluramine or placebo in a randomized  
double-blind procedure and their blood will be sampled for evidence of the  
functioning of their neuro-hormone system, principally serotonin.   
Psychiatric interviews will also be conducted.

   The challenge test takes between four to six hours and requires that  
subjects have a small needle inserted into an arm vein for about 4 hours.   
Small amounts of blood will be drawn intermittently throughout the challenge  
test.  Subjects will need to participate in two tests, separated by about two  
to four weeks.  Subjects must abstain from all drug use during the interim  
period.  Subjects may volunteer to participate on weekends or weekdays,  
whichever is more convenient.

   Three groups of volunteers are required with each group to consist of  
20-30 subjects.

   Group 1... people who have used MDMA at least 3-4 times.
   Group 2... people who have used LSD, but not MDMA.
   Group 3... people who have virtually no history of non-medical drug use
              other than alcohol or tobacco or caffeine.

   Anyone interested in possible participation in this research investigation  
of the long-term effects of MDMA should call Carla at (310) 222-1663.

   Volunteering for this study as an excellent way to help MDMA research.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 

MAPS is a non-profit, membership-based organization working to assist  
psychedelic researchers around the world design, obtain governmental  
approval, fund, conduct and report on psychedelic research in humans. [...]   
If you can even faintly imagine a cultural re-integration of the use of  
psychedelics and the states of mind they engender, please consider joining  
MAPS in supporting the expansion of scientific knowledge in this area.

	MAPS / 1801 Tippah Avenue / Charlotte, NC  28205
	704 358-9830 voice 704 358-1650 fax

	id AA22647; Sat, 14 Aug 93 18:10:29 -0700
From: zdross@ucdavis.edu
Date: Sat, 14 Aug 93 18:10:29 -0700
Message-Id: <9308150110.AA22647@othello.ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Lovestock/Festivahl
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

After much preparation (H) Mike and I headed off for this event with high
hopes.  We had been to the site before when we had gone to the most recent
Sharon, and had loved the place.  We got there at around 1:30, and asked the
guy at the entry gate how many people there were inside.  "About 600."

There were 40-50 people, tops.

So what did we do, now that we had paid the 30 bucks EACH to get in?  We 
walked around a little, checked out the stars, made friends in a circle of
trees, set up our tent, chilled a little.  We then realized that the 
evening would be lame, so we went to sleep in the hopes that maybe more
people would sho up by the time we awoke.

After trying to sleep with house music playing quite loud nearby, we awoke to
find FEWER cars arounf than before.  We were very pissed.  The promoters 
looked bummed.  As we were getting up, we heard some familiar sounding music,
sounded like Rick Preston, so we went over to check it out.  There was Rcik
finishing up his set at 9:30am.  Said hi, he looked tired, he wasn't 
EVEN gonna get paid with such a low turnout, so we bought him a mocha for
the ride home.  He's gonna be at ORIGIN tonight, and he is incredibly good,
so go check him out if you can.

We couldn't really bear the thought of hanging out in the heat, listening 
to 12 hours more music before tonight, so we cut our losses and left dor
home.  I don't expect that that many people will show up tonight, so
be wary if you plan to attend.  It's not as thoug we didn't have a good
time, but I wish we hadn't spent that much money to do it.

Maybe we will see some of y'all at Origin tonight.  Take care, everyone.

Zak

Report from LoveStock...

I'm back from a continious raving weekend,   danced from Friday evening
all the way until they shut off the sound system at around 10:30 on Sunday
Morning,   no sleep since then.   Late Sat evening,   I get reports that
some dickwad farmer called the pigs and forced the sound system down
Drats!!  I really wanted to hear Carlos with the sound
system intact....  I did meet and talk with him...   Great dude...

 (I treid to sleep during the quiet time,  but stayed awake to look at the
metior showers.    which was greatly enhanced by the electrical brain
enhancements).    At around 7 am,   the sound system went on again,
and I slowly made my way to the dance area for one final fling.

>It was like haveing them spinning just fer you
>way good fun. But there's not many people  (saw Amit) so mabey they'll
>drp the price. the site is worth the drive for sure.

Yea!!   It was totally bare,  few people showed up Friday evening,  but
having a DJ all to myself was also GREAT!!   Most of the time,  I was the
ONLY dude out there dancing.   WOW!! What gives??   Everyone wimp out Fri
nite?    (probably went to another rave I bet!).

The area was totally awsome.   It was right by the Stanaslaus (Scuse spelling)
river.    They had some lights mounted on the bank of the river,   shining
out over the low hanging fog.    It was the eeriest thing I ever saw,  and
definately enhanced my visual input.

All in All,  dipite the very small group of people that showed up,    it was
the best rave I've been to all summer (Squeaked by Penelape's web a scosh).

We just Gotta have more of these big all weekend long events.    Well,  at
least I can use one per weekend.  :-)  No tobacco smoke problems,  faschist
bouncers,   and plenty of chill out opportunities.   Hats off for Johnny Vegas
for putting this on.

Rave on dudz...

Cheers

From: dz5401a@palestrina.anderson-lab.american.edu (Douglas Zimmerman)
Message-Id: <9308160502.AA03103@palestrina.anderson-lab.american.edu>
Subject: A Trip to Mecca (a.k.a. San Fran)
To: ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu
Date: Mon, 16 Aug 93 1:02:55 EDT
Cc: dcraves@american.edu, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU,
        phengsom@sph.harvard.edu
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.2 PL0]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hey everyone.      

  Well it has been almost a week since i finished my pilgrimage to
the promise land. upon touching the holy soil of the sacred land
i realized at that moment what i had been searching for was
now there in front of my eyes. It was indeed San Francisco.

  I got the chance to check out the sf scene thanks to a free
ticket and the prodding of raving buddy susie kameny. 
  i was skeptical, but in the end sf surpassed all expectations.
  the first night was the FMR  which still blows my mind that
1500+ people by word of mouth found out about the event and made
it to the location. And after it was busted it was moved to the
berkeley marina where it continued till 5pm!!

  but the fmr was just a taste. On Thursday night was the club
Your Sisters House. some people dis the discussion before-hand,
but the talk about sex and drugs actually was educative and
fascinating for me; and it let you know a little bit more about
the people you were dancing with and who they are rather then just
any person. the musice was good there and a special treat was the 
person drumming along to the beat of the music. :)

  the most special event i went to was on friday night, the
gathering. it was amazing! the first location was at the marina,
and was great music+vibe were good, but it was then busted and
moved to another location. i helped move the sound system and 
people would just come up and start talking and everyone was on
the friendly tip. THe vibe there was incredible!! i really do not
think i have ever experienced anything similar. 
  most people were out there dancing and feeling the music and vibe.
compared to many east coast events ive been to it has been a LONG
time since anything comparable.
  just being able to check out the sf scene and seeing how well it
works and has evolved, and comparing it to siimilar scenes along
the east coast and its not hard to see why there are few events out
here and many in san francisco. the people have their shit together.
there is a really commited amount of people who go to these events.
heck its just incredible!

  not to mention san francisco and the surrounding area is amazing!
special thanks to cindy k. and brian b. for being such wonderful,
helpful and tolerant hosts and putting up with any imposition that
i caused. thanks to tafor being ggreat and making it and helping me
gget around the city.
  t was ggreat to finally meat people who i had only knew over
the computer: plui(pat) jerry(tarbaby), bryan(now i know who you
are),myklg, twitch, derek, leah, ccat, dana, and many other people.
  its great to actually get away from the computer and be with people
for real!
 
  and wow to the city of san francisco, its beautiful fogg, its
people,
its wonderful sights, beautiful view, amazing cafes, fine
record stores. and truly special scene that you are all lucky to have!

maybe i can join you out there next year :) !!

cindy and brian thank you for views, drives, clam chowder, neat
dancing locations and cable car rides!!!

sorry to people who received this letter three times. i apologize!

peace and love to all
doug )))))a b00mingg baSS for a l0ving race ((((( dz5401a@american.edu
check CT in 94.

>	I think it's the distancethat's the prblem, aswell. But what
>can we do about it? The reason theseplaces are so *wonderful* is
>BECAUSE they are far away from civilization, the lights of the city,

I think part of the problem is the *inane* tradition of not "revealing*
the location until a few hours before.  Thats' fine & ncessary for an underground
but when you're asking people to travel it's important to know if it's gonna
be 2 hrs away or 6.  And silly claims by promoters that, par exemple, 
a party in Livermore is "20 minutes from the Bay Bridge" also contriubte
to the credibility problem that IMHO is killing off at least the big end
of the rave biz ( yes, a mixed curse ).


Just my 2 pfennigs

EstelleKnabel

    I would have gone to Lovestock, but I had other commitments last weekend.
    I *did* go to Penelope's Web (much farther away), and I will go to the
    next one, whenever.

    The distance, itself, isn't the problem.  *Driving* the distance is.
    For something like Lovestock, they might have gotten a much better
    turnout if they had allocated some of the $30/head to a shuttle bus.

    Sell tickets, discounted, in advance, and perhaps include transportation
    in the price.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug 16 12:51:28 1993

Received: from srv.PacBell.COM (mother.srv.PacBell.COM) by ns.PacBell.COM (4.1/PacBell-06/08/93)
	id AA29510; Mon, 16 Aug 93 12:51:24 PDT
Received: from pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM by srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.0)
	id AA20115; Mon, 16 Aug 93 12:51:24 PDT
Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA12844; Mon, 16 Aug 93 12:51:23 PDT
Date: Mon, 16 Aug 93 12:51:23 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9308161951.AA12844@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: rpcaras@srv.PacBell.COM, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: LoveStock report
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

 
> I think part of the problem is the *inane* tradition of not "revealing*
> the location until a few hours before.  Thats' fine & ncessary for 
> an underground
> but when you're asking people to travel it's important to know if it's gonna
> be 2 hrs away or 6.  And silly claims by promoters that, par exemple, 
> a party in Livermore is "20 minutes from the Bay Bridge" also contriubte
> to the credibility problem that IMHO is killing off at least the big end
> of the rave biz ( yes, a mixed curse ).

Also, not disclosing the cost doesn't help much either.  I know of
one case in which some people arrived at LoveStock and were told that 
it was $30.  They turned around, walked away, and were beckoned back to 
be let in for $25.  Then there are the advertised "100% Bust Free" spaces 
that get busted, and of course, it takes more than a few weeks to
forget total fiascos like the last IMagiNation.

There was a time, not too long ago, that ravers were much more willing
to roll with the punches, 'cause there was this feeling that the promoters
were in it with us, and if things got fucked up, there was a sense that
at least the right intentions were there.  Free weekly GG Park raves
and $5 monthly ComeUnity parties helped foster this sense of a
nonexploitative community.   Whether or not promoters these days are in 
it *just* for the money is not the issue.  The issue is simply one of
perception.  Ravers are not a bunch of dumb sheep, and after feeling 
misled a few times they'll either start throwing smaller parties 
themselves, or just go with some friends to the vibe-diminished, 
but somewhat conveniant & dependable clubs that happen to play house 
music.  Either way, if promoters don't buy into the original "vibe"
that started raving, there really won't be much of a need for them.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

Received: by si.ucsc.edu (5.65/4.7) id AA12187; Mon, 16 Aug 93 16:46:13 -0700
Date: Mon, 16 Aug 93 16:46:13 -0700
Message-Id: <9308162346.AA12187@si.ucsc.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Harmony Part Three
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


This mail _should_ go through this time...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ok...shoot...my message didn't go through...oh well...see if I can remember this
Yeah...it finally happened, at twoish, we got to this beautiful meadow surrounded by a happy forest out in the middle of nowhere...
somewhere north of Santa Cruz...helped set up, and Carlos started 
spinning (Carlos IS GOD) at around 2:30+...and within two minutes,
everywone was dancing...I found the crowd mighty-o friendly, and all happy
smiles... I saw very little alcohol at all...and I had no problem trading
my happy lemon heads for some happy gummy bears or suckers...yum-yum...
...there was a good 150-200 
ravers the whole time...I found myself lacking in dance energy, so I kicked back
in the Ambience forest (Set up by...damn, can't remember...whoever they
were, they were fun
had a palm and a very acurate tarot card reading...came back, bounced
away to Alonzo a while (Alonzo is the shit<--that's good) and I don't know
who else...cops came at 6:30...
Overall, I had a great time...the crowd was very positive, the music was
bone stoping intense, the new-new location was beautiful, and the candy was
dandy...
Oh yeah...it was FREE, an not ten dollars like it said on the flyers...the DJ's decided not to charge after they found the final location...
Best thing was tho, it was small...and not comercial at all...low key raves
are the best...they make you feel rebelious once again...and you remember
what _underground_ means again...screw Cyberfest's...
But...anyways...rambleramble...
HAVE FUN AND MERRY XMAS!
--STefan
PS Thanks brians@unislc.slc.unisys.com for all your help...
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hey All,

Well, it's been a while since I had a weekend fun enough
to merit a report...

Checked out Cord. City on Friday night.  Hot, good
energy, good visuals, free water, 18+, & ok music.
Saturday, I was hi-jacked by some friends and ended
up at The Fridge.  Good music!

Weird thing about this weekend was that on both 
nights, I only ran into one person that I knew,
and recognized very few people.  Seems like there's
definitely a new wave. <** Had a conversation about 
this with a friend who said that although he had a 
great time at Cord. City, he's never going back 
because he wouldn't want to ruin it for them (newbies).
A very good point, I'd say. **>

So, Sunday, I spent the day hanging out...basically 
putting off sleep as long as possible, something that
I *always* hate myself for on Mondays.  :)

And tonight...Pepper or JazzUp?

Ravi

outdoor East Bay location Labor Day weekend.

events, chloroform them, hog-tie them and drag them kicking and twitching onto
our grassy dancefloor.

And later in the SAME article I said:
Renegade - Many have asked "How'd they have it there with all those ---s in
the ---d?"  Heard some good things about it, way to go!  Hopefully onto a
more original venue, but ya gotta start somewhere!

I did not know the name of the party but this passage at the end of my
article was near the end.  I should have mentioned the addr (3 & 24) so
that it was clear to you and other Bob.

I know that it is VERY difficult to find new spaces, ESP here in SF.  I
just don't like it when everyone thinks it's the latest and baddest when
others had blazed that trail before.  I admire ANYONE for pulling a one-off
in a parking lot, in a park, marina whatever.  It takes a special person to
throw a party even knowing the the cops are right around the corner. 
Whenever someone throws a renegade I am quite happy that they had the GUTS
to make a diff.  Thus the PROPS at the end!  Information is given.

Peace out :)
John

attend (a smaller party IMO), and we are always asked to do more.  So
although I don't like to hear that you didn't have a good time, and will

say read the bottom of that post, or if I say..., or maybe I should repeat

say: Check it.

>

>me off, as the members of sfraves HAVE thrown some really great parties.
>The first Connection is probably one of THE BEST events I've been to.

>go away.


You are misinformed.  Foolish person.  I throw parties for one reason and
one reason only.  I throw them for myself.  I, note "I", want to have a
good time at my party and since that takes precedence I take great care in
location, venue, and all apsects of production.  By ensuring that it meets
my and my partners satisfaction we are pleased.  Others throw parties for
all type of innocuous reasons.  And as a result they lose focus.  If you
try to please yourself, while keeping in mind that others will see your
handiwork, and look at what was done and say "would I pay $10-$15 to be
here?" and answer in the affirmative then you can't go wrong.  When the
formula is "hey this costs us this much therefore we have to charge xx" or
the focus becomes let's add $3000 of special efx so we cna sharge more, or
we gotta give the people waht they want oinstead of being TRUE to yourself
then you MAY make alot of money, but there will be no vibe.  I think, (as
well as the 500+), that the V has that vibe.  The proof in all this is that
although we have not made money, for the most part broken even, and will
continue to do more.  People have always asked us when the next one is. 
People have wanted to work with us since we put everything we have into a
party (not just money, but spirit), and it shows.  But oh well.  We have
also learned there are some you just can't please.  But such is life.  You
are now informed. Oh yeah, the one thing that is OLD and done with is the
competition aspect.  That shit has been gone, but like a Serb you keep
bringin up old ways.  There is new cooperation.  And I would nevert try to
"top" C2, since that is not a standard I choose to base anything on.  I try
to top myself and my own expectations.  This is far more difficult than
beating someone else down.  Try it, you'll be a much better person for it. 
Trust me for I am the prophet and "ultimate insider"!

Check that!

You are misinformed.  I have seen most of this attitude from a few SFR's,

least one time (if not more) in their life of thinking that their way is

>
>The jist of my argument is that If you're going to play in a free
>market, then people have the right to be informed of problems without
>fear of censorship/flames/whatever. The CUSTOMER NEEDS TO REMEMBER THAT
>THEY ARE ALWAYS RIGHT. The  promoter/venue/bouncers are there to serve,
>and in the process of doing that, if they make some money, then more
>power to them.
>

You are misinformed.  The rave scene operates much more on a barter system
than anything else.  Yes there is money exchanged, but there are also
plenty of non-monetary favors (like "I'll lend you my projector if you give
me 2 video tapes" or "get me and my 2 friends in free-of-charge [foc] and
I'll loan you...").  So the capitalist model you constantly rail against
hardly applies to the rave scene.  Same with clubs since there are many
non-monetary favors exchanged, and deals made.  Now you are informed. 
Check it.

>Some customers are sheep and will take whatever they get. However, the
>people on sfraves are not sheep. We're here to learn, build community,
>look out for each other, and inform each other.  So people should feel
>free to discuss bad venues, asshole promoters, and any of the scam

anything I see as slanderous or unfair to any of my promoter friends, or dj
friends, or helper friends.  Blood is way thicker than water or concept. 
Threats are illogical, and payment is usually expensive. Check it.

>

and other nonsense.  Keeping you locked up is the secret plan we all have.

parties.  He loses a griper who has done nothing to make a diff.  Oh well

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Digital Audio
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Has anybody heard about Digidesign's Session 8 -- it's an 8 channel
direct-to-disk, recording, mixing, DSP, and random access editing, with
a supposedly "full" (whatever that means) MIDI implementation. $3995.00
list (plus your PC w/ Windows 3.1), includes SCSI controller....

How good are the "low end" audio hardware and software for the PC?
(e.g. Microsoft's Windows Sound System, Sound Blaster 16ASP, Media
Vision Pro Audio Spectrum 16). Any recommended random access editing
systems for such a platform?

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ya, I've heard of it.  And dreamt of finding $3995.00 and buying it.

The "low end" stuff isn't really digital audio, per se.  I have the Sound
Blaster 16ASP and it's real fun to play with but there's not much you
can do with it in terms of making or contributing to music.  It has good
sound for games, it let's you spice up your environment by assigning sound
effects to system calls (porky pig saying bdi bdi bdi that's all folks when
I shut down windows, etc.), and currently I'm having lots of fun with the
recorder and editor by tweaking and looping samples, etc. until I get a "real"sampler that I can control via midi.  It's good practice though, and I can
start planning and arranging music until I get a midi controler, sequencer,
and a sampler (I already have a keyboard and a couple of drum machines).

Oh, by the way.  There is a new direct-to-disk recorder/midi interface (I
think) that is about to or just came out.  It only has 2 channels digital
audio but it's also only around $600.00.  It's called the TAP 10 and Roland
makes it.  Check it. ;-)

-Mark

> Ravi says:
> >  Seems like there's
> > definitely a new wave. <** Had a conversation about 
> > this with a friend who said that although he had a 
> > great time at Cord. City, he's never going back

Oops.  I think the point was that he didn't feel that
he had the optimism/enthusiasm/energy/*innocence* to
make a positive contribution to the party. 

The opinion I've heard most on the net is that the older
generation needs to show the younger generation what it's 
all about.  

Now, I'm starting to wonder why?  Isn't discovery and 
self-discovery the most beautiful part of it all?  How
can the scene change if the older generation (which I
believe is set in its ways and opinions) exerts its
influence (just by being at a party) and "steers" 
the experience of the younger ones?  In a way this
seems like a disservice to me.

Of course, I'm not going to stop going to parties--
maybe I'll try to go with the flow a bit more.

Clearer now?

Mark October 3rd, Sunday on your calenders.

We've just been approved to put on a party for members,
friends and family of SFRaves.  The permit will be for 
300-500 people, with amplified sound from 1-5 pm.  I was
able to talk the park officials into waiving the requirement
to provide portable toilets, so the total cost to us will
be $300 for the park permit plus $35 for the SFPD sound permit
plus whatever a generator costs.  Ethan (nrg) will be providing
the sound system for free.  This will be a free event by SFRaves
for ourselves and the community.  The following people have
already donated money:

Larry Ching, Arthur Chandler, Derek Chung, Ravi Gadhia,
Eric Pederson, Ti Fred, Tim Hyland, Bob Jesse for a total of
$180.

Send your contributions to:
Lee Fogel
2444 Van Ness Ave.  Apt. 2
San Francisco, Ca. 94109

I'll probably be going to Ananda in Friday if you want to give in person.  
Thanks to everyone for your support.  This is gonna be great!

Excerpted from:
>/*Written 10:35pm Aug 11, 1993 by mkontakt@gn.apc.org in igc:gn.ecotopia*/
>/* ---------- "Daily Ecotopian 1" ---------- */
>THE SAINT BARTHELEMY ECOTOPIAN
>(an irregular publication)


         TRAVELLERS

Everyone has heard of the
rise of facism and the far
right in Germany and France,
but for me the real danger
is in Britain. The conserva-
tive party are not publicly
facist, but their policies
in the past are nothing com-
pared to what they are now
trying to do. Their refusal
to join the social chapter
is well known (and is a good
example of their contempt
for their own people and the
rest of Europe). What is not
so well known is that their
treatment of political oppo-
sition and minorities in
Britain. A good example of
their undemocratic methods
is their treatment of the
travelling people and the
festival movement. Many peo-
ple have heard how the po-
lice attacked and destroyed
a convoy of travellers going
to Stonehenge in 1985. This
was not the only attack;
there were at least two
other major assaults on
groups of travellers at
about that time. The media
was instructed not to report
those. Since then, there
have been many such inci-
dents, including one violent
police attack on a Spiral
Tribe rave last year. The
conservative government are
now trying to pass laws to
make the gypsy and travel-
ling lifestyle illegal (this
is against the European De-
claration of Human Rights).
They are also trying to des-
troy the free festival move-
ment, to make squatting il-
legal, to prevent people
taking direct action against
fox hunting, and to make it
illegal to busk or beg for
money.
These new laws have a pur-
pose, to destroy the alter-
native movement of Britain.
I believe that if they are
allowed to do so, other Eu-
ropean governments will try
to do the same. I think it
is important that you are
informed of what is really
happening in Britain, and
that you take some action to
help prevent it. For exam-
ple, write to your EEC elec-
ted representative, and ask
them to exclude Britain from
the EEC.
For more information, write
to: Stonehenge Campaign, c/o
99 Torriano Avenue, London,
England. Send a self-addres-
sed envelope.

contributed by Richard


--

>   The opinion I've heard most on the net is that the older
>   generation needs to show the younger generation what it's 
>   all about.  

    Then some of us in the older generation have found all
    of this rather recently and are still figuring it out.

    I first experienced the Vibe at Grateful Dead concerts, and
    continue to do so every chance I get.  Other musicians (too few)
    work intentionally with it as well -- I am always on the lookout...

    Raves run at a much higher energy level and the music never stops
    and rarely slows down.
    Everyone is there to dance, very few will just sit and listen.
    I dance for hours and feel more alive/awake/energized when I leave
    than when I went in.

    Periodically, someone on rec.music.gdead posts something of the form
    "What are we going to do when the Dead can't tour anymore?"
    I know what I'm going to do (am already doing)...



    [It seems like almost everyone I talked to when I was at Penelope's Web
    is planning to see the Dead in Oregon this weekend.  Interesting.

    Those concerts are in the afternoon, by the way.
    Parking lots are open *all night*.  hmmmmmmmm...
    Camping OK.  Lots of extra tickets on the net.
    (I'll be taking the train up there a day early)


                            c u later
                                    &andy



    "Dance to all the little notes too".  (Frank Zappa)

------- Forwarded Message

From: "ZotMail-Mail and Records Services" <ZOTMAIL@uci.edu>
To: "All Campus Faculty and Staff":;@orion.oac.uci.edu
Subject: Precautionary Measures to Avoid Hantavirus Illness
Date: Tue, 17 Aug 93 10:42:52 -0700

 INFORMATIONAL BULLETIN
 PRECAUTIONARY MEASURES
 TO AVOID HANTAVIRUS ILLNESS

 We have recently been notified by the California Department of Health
 Services that precautionary measures should be taken to avoid exposure
 to the acute flu-like virus known as the hantavirus.  The disease is
 also known as the Four Corners Respiratory Disease or the Adult
 Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).  There have been two fatal cases
 in California.  One California case appeared to be acquired in the
 Mammoth Lakes (Mono County) area in July, 1993, while the other appeared
 to have been acquired in the Santa Barbara area in September, 1992.
 Thus far, per the Orange County Health Care Agency, there have not been
 any confirmed cases in Orange County and it is unlikely that urban areas
 will be affected.  However, basic precautions should be taken by
 vacationers or other individuals who travel to potentially affected
 wilderness areas.  Persons who may handle deer mice or other wild
 rodents or are exposed to their wilderness habitats could be at risk.

 This notice provides information for the prevention of hantavirus
 infection and establishes precautions for handling materials infected
 with the virus or working in an environment potentially infected with
 the virus.  The agent has been associated almost exclusively with
 deer mice(genus Peromyscus) but can potentially affect other rodents.
 The agent is transmissible via contact through the respiratory route
 with urine, feces, and dust from the rodents or their habitats. Human
 to human contact does not seem to occur.  The hantavirus causes an acute
 illness characterized in its most severe form by fever, headache, muscle
 aches, breathing difficulty, bleeding, kidney failure, and shock.  Since
 May of this year, it reportedly has claimed the lives of 16 persons
 nationwide, including the two cases in California.  The respective local
 health agencies and the state are conducting surveillance and control
 efforts.  The Mammoth Lakes area case involved a 27 year-old female UCSD
 wildlife biology graduate student and the Santa Barbara County case
 involved a 50-year old male ranch hand who trapped rodents.  Only these
 two isolated cases are known to have occurred in California, and there
 is no evidence of widespread disease activity.

 Simple precautions can reduce the risk of exposure to the hantavirus;

 1.  Avoid contact with deer mice and other wild rodents whether dead
 or alive.  Do not camp on, or otherwise disrupt, their burrows.  Avoid
 breathing dust from soil around rodent burrows, which is likely to
 contain dried rodent excreta.

 2.  Store food in secure containers so that rodents are not attracted
 to the food by its smell nor able to contaminate the food.

 3.  Rodents that carry bacteria and viruses that can infect humans may
 not appear ill themselves.  To be safe, never handle or try to pet any
 wild animal. If dead animals are observed, notify county health, park,
 or Forest Service officials, who will arrange safe collection.  On
 campus, notify Facilities Management at extension 5444.

 4.  Individuals who rent or own cabins in wilderness areas or occupy
 cabins on university business should take appropriate precautions.
 These include ventilating for thirty minutes by opening all doors and
 windows prior to occupancy.  Do not sleep directly on the ground or on
 cabin floors or occupy structures where there is evidence of heavy
 rodent infestations.  Rodent excreta should be cleaned up with caution.
 Do not perform any dry sweeping operations.  Prior to clean-up, the
 contaminated area and any dead animals should be soaked in a phenol
 disinfectant (e.g. Lysol) or a solution of 1 part household bleach to
 4 parts water.  Rubber gloves should be worn, and dead animals should be
 double-bagged in plastic for safe disposal.  Consult EH&S for more
 details on preventative measures.

 5.  As indicated earlier, there have not been any confirmed cases in
 Orange County, and urban areas are unlikely to be affected.  However,
 the campus is taking a conservative approach to illness prevention.
 In addition to issuing these guidelines, EH&S staff are contacting key
 campus administrators and other individuals who are being given special
 instructions regarding illness prevention as it relates to this virus.
 If you believe that your work or responsibilities could place you or
 your colleagues at risk, or you know of others who could be at risk,
 please contact EH&S.

 6.  On campus, buildings that have been unoccupied for some time, or
 are infrequently occupied, should be inspected by professional vector
 control personnel prior to occupancy.  This includes sheds and other
 structures that may have heavy rodent infestations.  Consult EH&S for
 further details.

 7.  Any campus research laboratory colonies of wild rodents should be
 screened for evidence of exposure to this agent.

 8.  Researchers or others who work with Peromyscus in wildlife settings,
 such as people who set traps, open burrows, or perform other activities
 that may expose them to aerosols of urine, feces, or contaminated dust
 should wear coveralls, gloves, and a fitted respirator with a HEPA
 filter.  They should wear eye protection, such as goggles or a face
 shield if the respirator does not cover their eyes.

     In addition, researchers and others who work with Peromyscus in
 wildlife settings and have experienced flu-like symptoms in the last
 two months should see a physician.  If the symptoms are confirmed by
 the physician to be associated with this virus, please also contact
 EH&S.  When applicable, the physician has access to a special treatment
 of intravenous ribavirin available through the California Department
 of Health (510)540-2566 or Center for Disease Control (404)639-3311.
 Physicians who suspect hantavirus infection are being asked by the
 California Department of Health to call these telephone numbers.

 For further information or if you have any questions contact John Chan
 or Rebecca Lally, EH&S, at extension 7101.

All Campus Faculty and Staff

- ------- End of Forwarded Message

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

speaking of new finds, maybe some of you would like to know about an album i  
recently stumbled across:  babel by D*NOTE.  it's a strange and delightful  
mix of house beats, hip hop, rap, rock, spoken voice samples and other  
sounds.  creative intros & interludes - classical, choral, swing.  decidedly  
jazzy in parts (could swear i heard some Kind of Blue riffs).  other parts  
have the clash and sonic layering style of Consolidated or the later Beastie  
Boys album.  way cool art, i think.

Well I went to Progress last night, and there were
more people there then last week. When I got there
Rick P. was doing a pretty good set, but towards the
end he played some really good grooves. Then came
Carlos whom I have not seen for awhile. I went over
and talked to him for awhile, he was in his usual
happy fully charged and ready to go mood! He said he
hasn't been in the area for awhile, but he was glad 
to be there last night. He played a most killer set!!!
My friend who has never heard him couldn't keep his
jaw from hitting the ground. Carlos was doing all
sorts of stuff with the mixer, tweeking knobs, scratching,
slowing down the record etc. I love watching him he's
such the performer. Anyway I left before Julius came
on do to work at 7am. It wasn't that bad of a crowd. It
seemed to have more people on the sidelines than dancing,
but hey I wasn't complaining, at one point I had the whole
floor to my self with Carlos spinning the killer music.
Oh ya! Yes, he did play salsa like usual and like usual
I loved it! 

-=good day=-


Noah Ruiz

From: winston@lurnix.com (Mark Guthrie)
>I used to have a theory about this that as key members died, and after an
>appropriate mourning period, they would be replaced and the member with
>the most seniority would become the key man and they Grateful Dead would
>go on for ever.  Jerry replaced Pig pen, Bobby will replace Jerry, etc.

A glimpse into the plastiscene ball reveals dead Dead key-members
(DDKM) pumped full of formaldehyde, propped up on stage, and turned
into MIDI-controlled-audio-animatronic-players-of-instruments
(MCAAPOI); controlled by a massive neural net which had been trained by
watching thousand of videos and DAT soundboards of concerts.

A new front-seating area would be added where audience members that had
paid dearly for tickets would be able to control DDKM's via MIDI-ball;
The results often are crazed hurky-jerky dance moves by the DDKM,
somehow strangely organic in a surrealist sort of way. Meanwhile,
band-members rush to keep up with their dead companion's motions and
notes. Overall, this will add a new sense of interactivity to the
concert experience!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From: "Mike Romo" <mike_romo@quickmail.apple.com>
Subject: Is the scene dying?
To: "Internet Address" <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

                      Subject:                              Time:  4:03 PM
  OFFICE MEMO         Is the scene dying?                   Date:  8/18/93
This "virtual community" works best when the members talk together and discuss
a topic as a group, instead of waging in odd flame wars and stuff like that. 
(Why do so many of you hate nitrus?  That stuff is just straight up fun, I
think.)

But my real point.  After last weekend's series of fiascoes, I come back to a
thought that I have pondered/"figured out" during the last couple of parties,
even the so-called "good ones" like Unity and Basics.  

Is the scene dying? 

Everyone probably agrees that last year was a lot better than this year, as far
as quality of parties goes and the crowd.  Most of you know me, I ove going to
these things.  I try to have a good time, and I try to be a positive experience
to everyone I meet.  But lately, things have just been plain SLOW.  The crowds
are more insular, and the parties lacking...something.  Of course, there are
exceptions, but they are few and far between.  The last just ripping time I had
was the last Vision and the Basics Finale.  Those parties went OFF.  I had a
proper time at Unity, but it was like the last Come/Unity party (IMHO), the
props were there, but the people just weren't into it as much.  Lasers are
cool, but nothing replaces a truly good vibe (remember that Channeling in the
Stone?  GOOD time!).

I will remark no further.  I merely want to start a thread so there can be some
really good positive discussion on what is going on, how people feel the scene
is progressing, and what can be done, if anything, to rejuvenate the house
scene in northern california.

I think Lee's efforts for the Park party are going to really pay off (check's
in the mail, good sir!), and I think there ARE some good exceptions to this
dreary downfall--FreeLife in San Jose has one of the best vibes and is
consistently one of the best parties around.  Period.

Okay.  Go off, friends.

Mike



From sfraves-owner  Wed Aug 18 16:52:36 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

	id AA08585; Wed, 18 Aug 93 19:52:30 EDT
Date: Wed, 18 Aug 93 19:52:30 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9308182352.AA08585@pilot.njin.net>
To: sameer@genesis.mcs.com (Sameer Parekh)
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Penelope's Web site description
In-Reply-To: <m0oSurl-000ZD4C@genesis.mcs.com>
References: <9308172251.AA00558@pilot.njin.net>
	<m0oSurl-000ZD4C@genesis.mcs.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

[Sameer asked me to type in a Penelope's Web site description for some
people he knows. I figured I might as well post it. -Sean]

The Penelope's Web site is as perfect a site as I have ever seen for a
rave.  It is a beautiful retreat set in wooded hills at about 2500
feet elevation.  It's about 20 minutes east from Willits, CA, about
10-15 miles down a mostly gravel road.

The site is about 400 (!!!) acres of forest with the occasional open
field.  There is privacy should one wish to wander off and be alone or
to be alone with someone.  There are no neighbors nearby, no highways,
and no airplanes overhead.  One hears and sees only the mother earth.
There will be great music, but if one wishes, silence is only a 15
minute walk away.

Running water is available at several places.  There is a shower, two
bathrooms, a kitchen, a beautiful deck made with homemade fired brick,
and a lawn with shade trees overhead.  A large vegetable and flower
garden provides food for the 4 residents.  Power is supplied by solar
cells and batteries.  Up on the hill there is a mud pit--a great way
to cool off on a hot day.

At the first Penelope's Web, the hosts were very friendly and
hospitable in the finest sense.  I was surprised when I wandered back
down in the morning to find hot coffee (!), whole-grain pancakes, and
an amazing shared-comraderie-friendliness awaiting.

The landowner, I am told, is a hippy type :) who wanted to get away
from it all a while back.  He's sympathetic to the cause, and is fully
informed as to what his land is being used for.  Two of the residents
there participated in the first Penelope's Web. As a matter of fact, I
have this fantastic picture of one of them in the mud-pit with the
rest of us.

I couldn't imagine a better site and better promoters.  It is
beautiful, isolated, has facilities, is perfect for camping, is as
bustproof as it ever gets, and it just *feels* good.

Given the chance, I think I'd live there.

Sean

========

Because of the incredible nature of the site, a few restrictions--as I
understand them--have to apply:

The event needs to be around 300 people.  More than, say, 500 would be
injurious to the site.  Therefore interesting arrangements for tickets
have to be made.

The woods are dry this time of year, and the fire hazard is very high.
We don't want a tragedy, so smoking is allowed only in the large
central gravelled area.

There is only parking on-site for about 10 cars and it's fragile at
that.  Plus, the road narrows long before it gets to the site.
Parking on-site just isn't feasible (perhaps this is a good thing).
Instead, people will be ferried there in buses.  Probably 20-seaters.

The death of raving! Details at 11!

Seriously, I wouldn't agree at all. I've been witness to a lot of
wonderful super-friendly vibes and some really wonderful events since
my arrival in CA this March.

The last couple of weekends, I admit, were a little slow. And we had
our share of fiascos. But that hasn't deterred lots of smaller
parties. And some of the bigger parties have went off well, too.

I think as long as there are people who want good events, and putting
on a good event isn't too expensive, that there will be good events.

Just have a little patience for the slow spots. And if someone wants
to do an event, help out! Contribute to the positive energy. That's
the best investment I think you could make. NRG's party was _really_
small, but a heck of a lot of fun for me. If he wants to do it again,
I'll be there! And I'll probably drag some more people along :).

Sean

Cc: sameer@genesis.mcs.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

I don't know how to say this, so I'm just going to say it.

I feel very much like a traitor, but I think I've been properly
supportive in enough situations that it's clear I don't "bug out"
lightly.

I haven't talked to Melissa, but I tried reaching her yesterday.  I do
need to talk to her still, so these comments are preliminary.

I feel like I need to post, though, because there's been a good bit of
discussion here about the event on the 28th at Willits (PW II?) and I
think it's important to talk about it.

Last I heard, Walter, the landowner, decided he needed $500 minimum or
$10 per person, whichever is greater, for us to use the land.  Melissa
agreed to this.  I think it's outrageous, given that we haven't thrown
a successful event up there yet.

As a "rave consumer" I would have a hard time getting excited about an
event where I would need to drive 3 hours one way and pay $30 (the
estimated charge per person according to Melissa's last message on my
answering machine Sunday).

Now, I'm sure that there are those who went to the first event who
would be willing -- camping is like $8 a night at state grounds, and
this includes food and tunes and the site is gorgeous and all that --
but I'm just generally against $30 events.

I'm also a little bit tweaked by the fact that we need some SERIOUS
promotion --- even underground promotion takes time and effort.  With
the green light from Walter only on last Sunday, there was less than
two weeks to the event, with lots of details still to be ironed out.

I could see this happening, even at $30 if need be (if that can be
justified), but only if we put this together well in advance.  I think
we'd need a really strong DJ lineup with lots of participation from
everyone.  I think we'd need a really good sound system.  I think we'd
need to rethink our approach to the van shuttles.  I think we'd want
to / need to sell advance tickets.

Maybe I'm just being a fuddy-duddy, but I think this event needs more
time to develop and happen properly... and if Melissa wants to go
ahead with this event, that's fine, and I support her 100% and hope
she does well with it and I hope that everyone who missed the first
event goes.  But I'm not going to be involved, and I will be
contacting Melissa and trying to get her to reschedule this in
September or hold off until the spring, when we can have one with
enough lead time to make it really viable.

Email about PW in general should still go to the list, but if you have
personal comments to me, please send them to me and off of the list.
Thanks.

Bob

 the weekly SFR Lunch ...
 
 When: Thursday, Aug. 19th   
 Time: 12.00 noon

 Directions:
 
 * From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
 
 * Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
   (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

vivianm@src.dec.com writes:
> The problem is that the promoters of PW didn't really want that much
> publicity.

This is a really important point.  The promoter, Melissa, was very
concerned about the land on which it was held.  She much preferred
a too small turnout with really good people than a much too large one
with people who might not have had the right respect in mind for the
property.  She was very worried before the party about the number
of people who might show up.

It would probably be wise to refrain from dropping fliers "from
SF -> SJ" without checking with her first.  Instead, tell everyone
you know who are good people about the event and about the incredible
site.  Convince them that this may be one of the most beautiful
locations for a rave they may ever see....

I'll try to get more info on what in terms of other promotion
she feels comfortable with.

Drugs will kill any scene.....In febuaray of this year - Moby paid a visit to  
Chicago and said to a local promoter "Come the end of august, your scene will be  
dead, its killing itself with drugs"  and he was right - completely right - In  
Chicago the rave scene is dead - drugs (expessially N2O) have killed  
it...fourtunatley something new is arising here - what it is...I can't say yet -  
and where it will go I can't say either - but it revolves around disco, house, and  
the dark - no lights just energy in complete blackness....I've only been to one  
party like this - you walk in the door and you can't see.....just music.....but you  
can feel the people dancing - all embracing with their hearts the folks imediatley  
near them.....no drugs....

Nitrous kills things - if you have 200 at a party and the tank arives and 75 people  
do ballons and wander around like zombies the party is OVER - the vibe is lost for  
ever right their ---- one peice of advice for all of you in SF don't let N2o  
destroy your scene......kill it before it kills you

--Kurt

.... to sfraves.stanford.edu, also known as techno.stanford.edu.  It's
not really sfraves-centric, it has the archives from neraves and sfraves,
so the directory name has been changed to /pub/raves to reflect that.
*EVERYTHING* is there, and if it's not and you have it, stick it in
/pub/incoming and lemme know and I'll add it.  There are hundreds of files
there, from rave flyer jpegs to notable posts made to mailing lists and
alt.rave, to music reviews from everyone and their mom, to jpg's of 
ravers around the world and more.  Enjoy :)

	Brian

p.s. - ftp and sun's just weren't meant to be! *sigh*

  How many people on here have the DMX (Digital Music Express)
service?   I finally moved to an area that offers it.   There
is a channel that specializes in Techno House, trance,  but
very little generic disco.   For instance,   last night,  the
following set was played (And fairly well mixed - Sometimes :-)

Song title		Artist/Musician		Album title
----------		---------------		-----------

Dance your ass off	RTZ Belgium		Rave Dawn
Can you feel it		CLS			This is strictly rythm
Domything		Sub-Urban Soul		Declaration of..
Bass			Madd People		Madd People
Let the Beat Control	Eddy S.			Rave-ology


Anyway!!  This is whats offered on OUR dance channel on DMX.   
I am not familiar with any of the titles of Techno House stuff,
nor do I actually care,   but DMX offers this other neat thing..

You can punch in "View",  and all the song info displays on the
remote control...  Title,  Artist,  Composer,  Album,  Weeks on
chart,  Position last week,  and position this week.  Through
this,   I was able to write down some of this stuff so others can
get an idea of what it offers.

I'll see some of you folks this Thursday at YSH....My body feels
like it's ready to be moved again....

PS:  I would like to me on the TIX list for the rave up at Willits
whenever it happens...

See Ya!!
CC
