	id AA02314; Thu, 19 Aug 93 09:29:28 PDT
Date: Thu, 19 Aug 93 09:29:28 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9308191629.AA02314@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, mike_romo@quickmail.apple.com
Subject: Re: Is the scene dying?
Cc: jlf3@attmail.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Our Friend Mike asks:  
> Is the scene dying?

No.  It seems to be evolving and churning a bit.  The more dependable raves 
like Groove Kitchen, Basics, FMM, etc. are pretty much mainstream affairs.  
A lot of people who would normally go to clubs are going to these now.  
This summer, there's been a big push for these multi-day megaparties or 
camping trip/spiritual retreats that seem to be flopping (more or less)
for a variety for reasons.  Tiny Renegade raves are becoming more frequent, 
but so far only exist at the intimate sub-critical mass level of energy.  

But despite not always fitting into some of our more idealized vision of 
the "perfect" rave,  lot's of people seem to be having fun at all of
them.  

I still think there are maybe some good alternatives out there.  
Non-namebrand parties, like Harmony, perhaps Ananda and Fluid, the 
attempted Xochipilli, etc. with lesser known DJs are the ones that might 
continue to attract people who respond less to hype and are more interested 
in giving energy and spirit at a party where each individual can have an 
impact and share in a sense of special togetherness referred to as the 
"vibe".

But let's face it, for many of us, raving isn't so new anymore.  Staying up
all night, driving hours and spending lots of $ for something we've done
many times before may not be worth the risk of a possible letdown.  So 
many of us have become pickier and less willing to take risks.  It'd
be a shame if such people stop going out alltogether, because I think
that with a little foresight, like-minded groups of people will find
the parties that suit their needs.  

The "scene" will continue to evolve, with or without us.  But for those
of us who have gotten a lot out of raving, it would be self-defeating if
we didn't throw our enery into *some* aspect of the scene, whether it's
attending smaller (and growing) renegade parties, or showing up at the 
commercial raves after 4am.  We still have plenty of choices to explore.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________





 
> 
> Everyone probably agrees that last year was a lot better than this year, as far
> as quality of parties goes and the crowd.  Most of you know me, I ove going to
> these things.  I try to have a good time, and I try to be a positive experience
> to everyone I meet.  But lately, things have just been plain SLOW.  The crowds
> are more insular, and the parties lacking...something.  Of course, there are
> exceptions, but they are few and far between.  The last just ripping time I had
> was the last Vision and the Basics Finale.  Those parties went OFF.  I had a
> proper time at Unity, but it was like the last Come/Unity party (IMHO), the
> props were there, but the people just weren't into it as much.  Lasers are
> cool, but nothing replaces a truly good vibe (remember that Channeling in the
> Stone?  GOOD time!).
> 
> I will remark no further.  I merely want to start a thread so there can be some
> really good positive discussion on what is going on, how people feel the scene
> is progressing, and what can be done, if anything, to rejuvenate the house
> scene in northern california.
> 
> I think Lee's efforts for the Park party are going to really pay off (check's
> in the mail, good sir!), and I think there ARE some good exceptions to this
> dreary downfall--FreeLife in San Jose has one of the best vibes and is
> consistently one of the best parties around.  Period.
> 
> Okay.  Go off, friends.
> 
> Mike

Mike Romo ponders:
(Why do so many of you hate nitrus?  That stuff is just straight up fun, I
think.)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
One of my faves too, but the reason people have a problem with it and I tend to
agree is that it detracts from the vibe when there are groups of people huddled
around doing balloons.  Kinda anti-social.  If you were to approach one of these
groups or even an individual with a baloon to socialize with, they'd look at you
like you were trying to mooch some nitrous and act generaly suspicious of you.
Then when your kind of anoyed about this, you keep hearing shhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhht
to remind you of the presense of the drug that's causing this behaviour.  Then when
you look over to see the source of the noise you see a non-raver who is just there
to make money off of everybody by selling way over priced balloons.  Anyway, the point
is that it's not the drug but the behaviour that surrounds it.

-Mark

people like to dance to house music, I think this fundamental reality has
established itself.  When I look towards this scene I look towards the music,
and house music is becomming, let's face it, de regeur in most club venues,
which I think is a good thing.  I had a fre
iendly to wonderful time when I first
got involved in this scene and I have no regrets and I'm not going out trying
to relive those experiences - they're gone, and for me, outside of seeing good
friends, they're not so novel.  I mean I love the music but my body put the
brakes on, seeing the sun come up, sure its cool and beautiful, but frankly
when I'm going over 101, it out and out sucks.  Let the scene change, if the
old ingredients don't work, why the hell are we expected to go out and fuel
because this whole thing was originally done for us?
If the scene doesn't want to constantly evolve and change itself, pardon
me on this - like David Bowie, it will grow tired for those who really found
a  whole lot of heart and belief in this.

>	The ANON SALON, the South of Market location, has become
>	famous for gatherings that the San Francisco Chronicle described
>	as " the sort of party that you remember years later!".  YLEM is
>	honored to be invited to host one of these events.  Nancy Frank

>	following program of interactive art and multimedia:
>
>	BURNING MAN:
>		Each year a group of artists, paganists and full-moon
>		crazies build a giant 4-story tall wooden sculpture of
>		a man.  They then burn it with great fanfare in the 
>		Black Rock Desert during Labor Day weekend.  Find out
>		why, see videos and slides of last year's event, and
>		register for this year's Burning Man.

>		interactive installation using sound, video and computer
>		graphics.

>		best of painting and photography.
>

>		Contemporary paintings of the Age of Technology.
>
>	LARRY SHAW:  Vintage computer graphics from the 70's. 
>
>	ED SEVERINGHAUS:  The BodySynth.
>		A stand-alone MIDI that functions as a system for 
>		transforming movements, gestures, and other muscle
>		efforts into sounds and effects.  These sound are
>		translated into dance by CHRIS VAN RAALTE.  Between
>		performances you can strap on the BodySynth and 
>		discover your hidden cybertalents.

Anyone else interested in checking this out?

From sfraves-owner  Thu Aug 19 14:02:54 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA09830; Thu, 19 Aug 93 14:02:54 PDT
Received: from nkosi.well.sf.ca.us by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA09823; Thu, 19 Aug 93 14:02:47 PDT
Received: from well.sf.ca.us (well.sf.ca.us [192.132.30.2]) by nkosi.well.sf.ca.us (8.5/8.5) with SMTP id OAA08577; Thu, 19 Aug 1993 14:02:46 -0700
Received: by well.sf.ca.us id <14087-1>; Thu, 19 Aug 1993 14:02:07 -0700
From: Jeffrey Moore <jmoore@well.sf.ca.us>
To: PGRASSI@scuacc.scu.edu, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Is the scene dying?
Message-Id: <93Aug19.140207pdt.14087-1@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Thu, 19 Aug 1993 14:02:02 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Well if you think it is, I think you need to start a new "scene".  Find
something bigger, better, stranger and share it with people.  The completely
dark party sounds interesting, but I think that interactive parties with
more integration of the audience into what is happening in the music and in
the visuals are the real future.  We put on a party like this at our last CD
release and it went off pretty well.  The general feeling of the crowd was
that they had a great time and had all sorts of neat toys to play with.

-Jefff

From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
Subject: This Week's SF Rave Guide!
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFRaves)
Date: Thu, 19 Aug 93 14:17:41 PDT

OK, this weekend features a few low-key events which have a lot of
potential, and a big event which could be cool too...Ananda and All
Gods Children both look like interesting semi-undergrounds and Culture
is for those of you who want to support new talent.

Get Down/Wicked is almost a who's who of local DJs - so everyone should
find something they like there.  I've heard it is supposed to be at
the Richmond Civic Center, so it's pretty close and bust-free.

The weekly list is still pretty healthy, so everyone should have 
something to do all week...and looking ahead, there are plenty of
opportunities for all of you to keep the scene alive!  :)


*****************************************************************************

Here are some weeklies - whether or not they count as real "raves" is 
debatable, but they were advertised by flyers and the music could be
good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their appropriateness 
in being on the list, let me know.  Also let me know when any of them end...

	id AA10150; Thu, 19 Aug 93 14:44:01 PDT

	id AA10141; Thu, 19 Aug 93 14:43:58 PDT

	id AA11612; Thu, 19 Aug 93 17:44:11 -0400
Received: from andy.tiedye.wco.ftp.com by wco.ftp.com (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA20664; Thu, 19 Aug 93 14:37:24 PDT
Date: Thu, 19 Aug 93 14:37:24 PDT
Message-Id: <9308192137.AA20664@wco.ftp.com>
To: PGRASSI@scuacc.scu.edu
Subject: Re: Is the scene dying?
From: andy@wco.ftp.com  (Andy Nourse)
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Repository: wco.ftp.com
Originating-Client: tiedye.wco.ftp.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>   people like to dance to house music,

    I like to dance to just about anything, if it's fast and wierd enough.
    If it's just on the edge of being impossible to dance to, that's best of all.

>   I think this fundamental reality has established itself.
>   When I look towards this scene I look towards the music,
>   and house music is becomming, let's face it, de regeur in most club venues,

    Possibly this scene has outgrown clubs, or at least parts of it have.
    (Not so much in terms of size, but in terms of what we can do there)

>   I love the music but my body put the brakes on,

    That's the strangest part of this.  My body seems to be telling me
    that dancing is fine and lots of dancing is better.  (One must sleep
    some time, though).

>   seeing the sun come up, sure its cool and beautiful...
>   when I'm going over 101, it out and out sucks.  Let the scene change...

    The scene will change, but getting home will still be a challenge.
    Of course, if we do it in the woods, we might not be going home
    over 101.

>   If the scene doesn't want to constantly evolve and change itself...

    I hope that house music continues to be a collage of many different kinds
    of music, though the mix may (and must) change.  The report from Chicago
    suggested that there it was all disco.  I couldn't listen to that for
    very long (or all-any-one-thing for very long, for that matter).

A FOAF tells me that house.techno.phuture music sounds and feels really
great with NO2, but you have to approach it with a conscious decision
not to let 'nitrous greed' rule the experience.  This FOAF tells me that
if one finds it in oneself to share a balloon that it's almost like moving

space . . . a very rewarding experience, or so I've heard . . .

Ya, I do this all the time ;-).  At home though.  Put some computer on acid
jam, or space music, or Enya or something trippy and it's hella-fun.  You
get so out there somtimes that you start to come down and remember that you
are actualy an inteligence.  Then you remember that you have a body.  Then
you remember your identity.  Then you remember where you are.  Then you
remember what you just did.  Then you do it again.

>>   If the scene doesn't want to constantly evolve and change itself...

>    I hope that house music continues to be a collage of many different kinds
>    of music, though the mix may (and must) change.  The report from Chicago
>    suggested that there it was all disco.  I couldn't listen to that for
>    very long (or all-any-one-thing for very long, for that matter).


	Its not all disco yet.....its a mixture of disco, house, and trance - 

     however, disco is now what hardcore was a year ago....a year ago everyone
     had a huge grin on their face during the hardcore sets - now everyone has
     their huge grin during the disco sets - the two forms of music evoke the 

     same reaction.....disco has a deep groove to it though, and soul - 

     something that hardcore (IMHO) lacks......House/disco/trance evokes deep
     rooted emotions and thats something that a dying scene needs - is emotion..
     

--Kurt

Well if you think it is, I think you need to start a new "scene".  Find
something bigger, better, stranger and share it with people.  The completely
dark party sounds interesting, but I think that interactive parties with
more integration of the audience into what is happening in the music and in
the visuals are the real future.  We put on a party like this at our last CD
release and it went off pretty well.  The general feeling of the crowd was
that they had a great time and had all sorts of neat toys to play with.

-Jefff


Sorry About two posts.....What it all boils down to is this...the party is what 

the people make of it....If they think they will have a shitty time then,
it will be - essentially you get from a party what you put into it....and
I think for alot of us, we expect things now - instead of throwing our hearts
into a party we want to walk into a vibe - not create it - because we know 

what it is, where in the past we did't and that allowed us to add to it because
we wrapped our selves in creating it - not just using it...or something.....

--Kurt

I agree.  I think that this scene has many, many more miles left in it
before it becomes another "statistic".  Yes, there are the more commercial
ventures, but for the most part the people who go to these events
(commercial/ug/weekly/whatnot) are still into it.  And as long as THAT
remians constant (people being into it) it will thrive in one way or
another.

Last year, up until this summer was the GRAND experiment.  Many people
(myslef included), made a consious decision to keep the party to a bare
minimum.  For instance, black light/strobe/visuals.  But some people took
this to the extreme (one black light/one strobe/paintings or slides <that
we've all seen at least 100 times>), and then charged $15 for such a show. 
What once was novel, now became a ripoff (at least IMHO).  Well, rest
assured, the scene does not allow for anyone to stagnate, at least for
long!  Witness this past year if you need proof positive.  

As for vibe, hell, there is as much there as there was in the beginning. 
The difference is the type of vibe.  The smiles are for the most part (I
know, I know, YSH not included :), gone except for the very few, but that
does not mean that people don't like it when they go out.  I think that
people are just more into themselves right now, more than anything....and
when it gets a little colder, things will warm up again.  I also believe
that availablilty of drugs has alot to do with it.  Speed is fucking
rampant, yet E is definitely on the decline (not in terms of want, but in
terms of usage).  I think that as people go towards more organics (like
shrooms) thing will be a bit better.  But I still say that as soon as E
gets back to last years pricing ($10-$20) people will get "normal".  Not
that drugs fuel the scene, but in many way they do (contradiction, no?).

Went to boogie buffet this weekend (twice, by no choice of my own since I
love to be with my kid in the morning when he's rarin' to go!)....I spent
my usual $20 on drinks & left.  Came BACK at 2:30 (had to give a projector,
2 dj's, and Sharon a ride to SJ), and MAN that place was PUMPED.  Now you
talk about smiling MF's!  These people were sweating (it was warm in there)
and fucking going off like there was no tomorrow!  Very cool, and the , uh,
smile factor was high.  Hell, when you're 21+, no party is suiting your
taste, you tend to make the best of it.  But the boogie is still worth most
10-7 a.m. events for sheer banality!
(I have kidded P that it is the home of the exotic dancer revue - this past
weeks dancers were not to be found <except for banana girl>, but keep your
eyes peeled, cuz' they will be back!;)

As for this weekend....ugh!  I will probably go to get down, get ugly since
Markie is gonna spin!  And I havent heard Jeno in a while so I'm lookin
forward to it (for those reasons only, mind you)!  Should be OK since I'll
be tripping, and I like the Richmond space.  Plenty of spaces to hide, and
get high, get ugly.  This weekend will be cracker jack catch-up time.

Late...

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
+         "War 33 & 1/3 not really live I'd rather do it at 45...."        +
+                                  P.E.                                    +
+                    from the village of jsl@netcom.com                    +
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

So how was Your Sisters House?  I didn't go when I heard the advice to
dress warmly (I pretty much guessed where it would be, and a glance
outside didn't look too promising at the time).  I broke my promise
to myself (again) of never missing one. :-(

Had a great time playing old ported apple ][ games on my Mac until 1 am
or so though :-)

(Might and Magic is kinda cool with the Earthbeat comp playing as
background music.  OK I know.  I'm a geek. :-)

-H-

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, howardb@enlil.premenos.sf.ca.us
Subject: YSH?
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Yep, you pretty much guessed the site, which is one of my favorites. Vacant
weedy land by the SF Bay with views of sinister half-used industrial buildings,
and no residents for 100s of yards in any direction.  This time the party was
on a concreate pad which I guess was the floor of a now-demolished building.
Pretty friendly group of people (100 increasing to 200 by the time I left),
 a dozen or so sfraveulars that I know of, not
that I yam one.  The sound system, tho, was too quiet and seemed to get quieter
over time.  I got there a bit past 12, and the first dj (Chrstine ?)was pretty amateurish, choosing songs kind of haphazardly.
and doing bad yet lingering mixes.  The second dj ( Darcy? : Shoban was schedule to be 3rd ) started playing some pretty decent hard trance, I got my nocturnal
aerobics in and left about 2:30.   The 45 minutes of music I heard made up
for the earlier technical flaws and left me feeling pretty satisfied.  I much
prefer outdoors anymore, and the cyberpunk landscape was the shit.


AstroBoy

Tips for party planners:
	Remember, the critical mass for a dinner party can be 2 or even fewer.

In article <9308201950.AA01177@zeus.srv.PacBell.COM> you write:
|Yep, you pretty much guessed the site, which is one of my favorites. Vacant
|weedy land by the SF Bay with views of sinister half-used industrial buildings,
|and no residents for 100s of yards in any direction.  This time the party was
|on a concreate pad which I guess was the floor of a now-demolished building.
|Pretty friendly group of people (100 increasing to 200 by the time I left),

I think the location just rocked even tho' the cold was a bit annoying --
it was down a block or so from the previous spot, and the entrance was
through a hole torn in a metal fence.  The street we parked on (if you
could call it a street) had huge piles of freeway dividers and crane
sections and stuff in it, and once you went through the fence you had
to walk for (the equivalent of) two blocks or so through barren, open, 
weedy, gravelly terrain to a concrete space in the middle of the open air,
no buildings *period* for quite a ways around.  To top it off, right as
we got there, there was AC/DC blasting super-loud from a nearby building!
:-) Compared to that noise, there was essentially no evidence of a rave
going on, just a few people hanging out by the hole in the fence.

ben

Cc: <PLUI@iossvr.gm.hac.com>, uunet!thunder.lakeheadu.ca!Lui@uunet.UU.NET,
        uunet!thunder.lakeheadu.ca!Patrick@uunet.UU.NET
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

If you realy want to make "real" music (not computer game music) don't by the
Sound Blaster.  I have one and music is not realy it's intended purpose.  For
about the same price investigate the Roland SCC1, any computer-music store
will probably tell you the same thing.  It's a midi controller that you use
with sequencing software (another $75-$300) to control midi devices and it's
built-in synth has 128 or so voices AND 6 drum sets, including the 808 set.
Also check out the $600 or so Roland TAP 10, which has 2 channels digital
audio.  Or wait, supposedly cheaper and neater things are comming out for the
PC, to make it close to equal with the MAC for music making, but we'll see.

-Mark

In-Reply-To: <9308202332.AA07185@cassy.lurnix.com> from "Mark Guthrie" at Aug 20, 93 04:31:59 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 3077      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Beyond the ultraworld of Mark Guthrie:
> 
> I have one and music is not realy it's intended purpose.  For
> about the same price investigate the Roland SCC1, any computer-music store
> will probably tell you the same thing.

I fail to see the point, Mark. You tell him not to buy a sb16asp+waveblaster
which has an EMU general midi chipset (in the optional waveblaster) cause
music is not the purpose, and then you say go buy an SCC-1, which is almost
the same thing! (a rom wavetable synth)

> It's a midi controller that you use
> with sequencing software (another $75-$300) to control midi devices and it's
> built-in synth has 128 or so voices AND 6 drum sets, including the 808 set.

In his case he wants to make rap music. You dont have any interesting booms and
scratches on the SCC. Also you cannot put new samples or breakbeats on it.
You also cannot use the SCC for techno, trance, hardcore, house, dance,
disco, acid or whatever in these genre cause the included instruments are
General Midi, so you only have for lead synths: square, sawtooth, calliope,
chiff, charang, voice, fifths and bass+lead. For that, you need a sampler
synth card. See below.

> Also check out the $600 or so Roland TAP 10, which has 2 channels digital
> audio.

I would suggest a Gravis Ultrasound with 1Mb, the 16 bit recording daughter-
board and an effect processor. The base Gravis comes with 256Kb RAM and for
about 25$ more you can get it to 1Mb, briging cost to 125+25=150$. The 16 bit
recording board is < 150$. So you still have 300$ to reach the TAP10 and with
that you can buy a great fx processor. It also *includes* Midisoft recording
session for windows and Powerchords for windows (great for techno and rap).

The GUS has 32 pannable channels playable simultaneously of digital wavetable
from a RAM storage plus can play back digital audio from PC memory or hard
disk. It has >85dB SNR, and a frequency response pretty close to flat. It has
much better bass than the SB16. It gives me great flexibility along with my
analog synths and i have 40 Mb of instruments sampled with pro gear that i use
with that, including samples of TR303, TR808, TR909, some analogs, breakbeats
(RunDMC, Rob Base etc...) and also have real instruments, like great piano and
guitars etc... It also supports GM.

> Or wait, supposedly cheaper and neater things are comming out for the
> PC, to make it close to equal with the MAC for music making, but we'll see.

Well, on the MAC you have multi track recorders, but on the IBM too... but
for MIDI sample based music, i cant think of another product short of a
sampler keyboard (the GUS uses the same chip as in the Ensoniq EPS-16+) that
can be used for this purpose, except the GUS.

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion

From sfraves-owner  Sat Aug 21 16:40:35 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA21929; Sat, 21 Aug 93 16:40:35 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA21922; Sat, 21 Aug 93 16:40:32 PDT
Received: from vms.macc.wisc.edu by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA14722; Sat, 21 Aug 93 16:40:45 -0700
Received: from VMSmail by vms.macc.wisc.edu; Sat, 21 Aug 93 18:38 CDT
Message-Id: <23082118385472@vms.macc.wisc.edu>
Date: Sat, 21 Aug 93 18:38 CDT
From: JOSEPH P. BAGDONAS <YUSEF@macc.wisc.edu>
Subject: re:is the scene dying?
To: SFRAVES@soda.berkeley.edu
X-Vms-To: IN%"sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu",YUSEF
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

	The music is stagnating, for one. The releases this year, while
enjoyable, haven't been as innovative as years past, like last year when the
last new style (progressive) of house/techno appeared. Secondly, illegal raves
don't seem to stand much of a chance agaunst the cops these days. The police
have clearly mastered the "MO" (modus operandi, for you non-techies) of rave
promoters. That's why I'm at home tonight, typing this message, instead of
travelling to Cincinnati for Portal, which was supposed to be the first Net
"all-night, electronic music dance w/o alcohol" in the Midwest (2nd in the
nation after Connection?). Four of the last four raves in Cincy have been
busted, which contributed to Portal's cancellation. Lastly, the raves are
still mostly stuck at the level of mere spectacles, like Roman Bacchanalia,
over and over. Since everyone knows about raves, attending one says less and
less about the participants (i.i. you don't need a high UQ, underground
quotient :), to rave).
 
	"All night dancing to electronic music w/o alcohol" (in a friendly
environment and with stimulating aesthetics, I might add) will hopefully and
probably continue in some form though. I just hope that people (maybe WE, on
the Net) can take a small part of the whole scene to a higher level. For
example, it would be great if we could hold a half-day conference on
networking, ... the whole computer underground, followed by "all-night dancing
to electronic music w/o alcohol" that's friendly/stimulating, etc.
 
	To let you know where I'm coming from, the best event I've attended
was thrown by the Black Student Union here on the Univ.of Wis.-Madison campus
in '87. The music, IMHO, wasn't as good as today's finest house, it was basic
and early acid Chicago-style, direct from the windy city. But the event was
amazing for the following reasons: 1. the event was thrown by the BSU, so
attending the event meant that most participants probably supported the
organization-thus a shared perspective/cause; 2. the cost was affordable
(<$10); 3. the venue was completely legal, secure; 4. participants could leave
and return at will (and chat in the QUIET lobby); 5. there was a diverse mix
of people, not just white ravers dressed in the same rave fashions.
 
	Until more of these conditions are met by upcoming raves, I am
curtailing my raving to zero, saving my $$ for YSH and SFRaves gatherings for
when I'm back in SF. Thanks for reading. Please feel free to criticize/give
feedback.
"Create dangerously." "Friendship is the basis of liberation."-A.Camus
									Yusef

From sfraves-owner  Sun Aug 22 15:55:51 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA27630; Sun, 22 Aug 93 15:55:51 PDT
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA27623; Sun, 22 Aug 93 15:55:39 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA12534; Sun, 22 Aug 93 15:56:24 -0700
Date: Sun, 22 Aug 93 15:56:24 -0700
Message-Id: <9308222256.AA12534@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: get down, get stoopid, get ugly...
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Well get down, get stoopid, get ugly met all of my wildest expectations,
and then some...

The music was by far the ONE to "get down" to!  The sound system in the
main room was quite good, and they did an excellent job of filling that
space up with hella sound.  I was there for the end of Spuns set and
listened primarily  to Josh, who , played a great hard-morning set.  Fuck
the torpedoes, full speed ahead!

But that's when I began to notice the floor was slowly beginning to fill up
again (Spun did CLEAR that floor pretty well), and I noticed that the
stoopid factor had begun to rise in direct proportion to the number of
people returning to the dance floor.  The crowd was a bit young for my
tastes, too eager (the guys esp.) to take off the shirts.  Reminded me of a
high school dance, without the "high" ;)  Nitrous factor was RAMPANT, since
I saw very little E inspired motion, I resigned myself to watching people
get realllly stoopid to the point of passing out, lots of stoopid
tweakers...but this was only the beginning.  Once again, it met ALL my
expectations.

The place was arranged to maximize the sound dispersion.  You all know the
Richmond Center.  In the two hallways they had two seperate sound systems. 
In the foyer, or the usual entrance, they had the Wicked show stoppers. 
And the Main room was the big hall.  I thought that putting the DJ's in a
space (the halls) where there is hella traffick, killed any energy they
might have built up!  The Wicked posse was doing their damdest playing some
of the best music I'd heard them play in a long time....that's when get
ugly got started. Ok, get this, some dude @ 6:30 a.m JUMPS UP ON THE
TURNTABLES AND STARTS SWINGING AT THOMAS!!! :( :( :(  It took the whole
Wicked posse to subdue this asshole and expel him from the hall.  They had
to lock the doors to prevent his sorry ass from coming back in.  @ 7:00
a.m. the party ended.  As I left I saw 6 cop cars, and 5 cops holding some
guy down.  The guy was yelling "I own the world! I am the Earth, I love the
ground!  I am the ground!"  and I quote further "NO!,NO!,NO! I am the
ground, you cannot harm me!  I won the world!  I am the Earth!...."  As I
looked onto this haphazard stoopidity incarnate, he spewed forth gobs, and
gobs of spit, from his mouth, and nose.  Suffice it to say it took about 5
of Richmonds multi-ethnic 285lb gorilla-types to subdue our beloved
asshole.  Come to find out, yes, it is the same guy who was "ejected"
earlier.  They had to use hella clubs to get him down, and they were
waiting for the ambulance to arrive.  It was obvious this asshole, like
sooo many others, forgot NOT to mix his drugs!  He was sooo fucking high, I
doubt it was LSD, probably dust.  Yes indeed, this party EXCEEDED all my
expectations! Could that be the end of Richmond events....only the city
council of Richmond will know...

All in all, an ok (note little "o") party.  Lots of first timers who forgot
what they came there for in the first place.  Lots of 21--, so it should
have satisfied all those folks who never get to go anywhere due to some
stupid curfew, cab laws, whatever. The people, although young (and I doooo
mean young) were friendly enough, not much 'tude.  They were all earnestly
trying to have a good time.  The ulglyness of it all still haunts me (and I
was/am on major psychotropics). So much so I am changing my signature to
reflect how in tune I am with my surroundings;)  I wish assholes did not
show up to events.  I also wish they could control their drug intake.  I
also wish N20 would disappear along with speed since I think that both of
those are MAJOR scenekillers.

Of course I did go to boogie afterwards, caught a cab home, and am
promising myself "if(scene > 500) { void StayHome(void);  }"  Keep America
Beautiful, tweakers stay home!

Until another celestial event...
John 

P.S.  To show my kind and giving spirit, I will be having a small benefit
for the afformentioned tweaker (sometimes tweeker).  Because as they cart
his ugly ass to the asylum, I don't ever want him to think that he's been
forgotten.  The money will go towards a fund for the new non-profit
"Tweekers Anonymous".  The posterchild of which has already been chosen by
the Richmond PD with an Assist from the boys of Wicked! ;)

Man, sometimes you have no choice but to laugh!!!

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
+"I own the world! I am the Earth, I love the ground!  I am the           
+      + ground!"..."NO!,NO!,NO! I am the ground, you cannot harm me!  I
won the  +
+ world!  I am the Earth!...." - the unknown tweeker                      
+                                             +                    from the
village of jsl@netcom.com                    +
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++


From sfraves-owner  Sun Aug 22 17:43:50 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA28214; Sun, 22 Aug 93 17:43:50 PDT
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA28207; Sun, 22 Aug 93 17:43:38 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA18553; Sun, 22 Aug 93 17:44:24 -0700
Date: Sun, 22 Aug 93 17:44:24 -0700
Message-Id: <9308230044.AA18553@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: T.A. (Tweekers Anonymous)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Tweekers Anonymous was founded on August 22,1993 in response to a growing
crisis within our beloved community, that of the unloved, and unwanted
tweeker.  You've seen 'em...they have said things like , and I quote "I own
the world! I am the Earth, I love the ground!  I am the ground!"  and I
quote further "NO!,NO!,NO! I am the ground, you cannot harm me!  I won the
world!  I am the Earth!...." while being held down by 5 policemen.  You can
also identify a tweeker by recurrent incursions with ANY PD, Tweeker
Anonymous member Rodney King to be exact (you DO remember him, his famous
words being "ouch, ow, umph!").  Tweekers can also be idenfied by , uh,
certain characterisics, like having COMPLETE conversations with themselves
whilst walking around a, uh, "rave".  Or sitting in a corner, head in hands
, shaking as though they are trying to dislodge a demon wedged deep within
the crevices of their gulliver (ClockSpeak for head).  Another sure sign of
a tweeker is outdated, overused, ameba-gear worn as if it was created
yesterday.  But be sure the person (hereto referred to as Tweeker) who is
sporting this "retro-rave" look has washed the clothes enough times as to
make the patterns undiscernable.

Tweekers have many unsual characteristics.  Did you know that:
- Tweekers can jump from the ground onto awaiting turntables quicker than
you can say "Tweeker".  Don't try this at home, wait for the next rave and
see how difficult this task can be!
- Tweekers are the essence of multi-tasking.  Asking and answering many of
thier own questions.
- Tweekers, in the true pioneer tradition, go where no person even THINKS
of going.
- Tweekers push all limits when it comes to drug use.  Too little is too
much and, too much is never enough.
- Tweekers are their own shamen, priests, gurus, whatever.  They are
experts at exorcizing their demons upon anyone within an arms, oops, fists
reach!
- Tweekers make great hood ornaments!

It is because of these interesting characteristics that the Tweeker may
suffer isolation in one form or another.  That is where Tweekers Anonymous
comes in, as a friend to all Tweekers and Friends of Tweekers.  The many
services this non-profit provides are:
- Police escorts FROM parties.
- Free Amubulatory services.
- Free straightjackets.
- Free muzzles (in case your Tweeker decides he's Hannibal Lechter or even
worse Jeff Dahmer).
- Free Legal Counseling (beleive me, where the Tweeker goes he'll need
plenty legal assistance).
- Free auto detailing (one of the many uses for a Tweeker once he's been
cured is the honorable job of car detailing.  Nothing intricate mind you,
just vacuming).
- Free Hood Mounting (another good use for the cured tweeker is that of a
Hood Ornament. Makes great dinner conversation).

That's just about all Tweekers Anonymous can do. Usually if you've
identifed someone as a Tweeker it's too late for any preventative measures,
so Tweekers Anonymous is the "automatic backup", to a system that cared a
bit too little, and a bit too late.

Give today!  The Tweeker you save could be your own! (huh?, what, oh yeah,
I get it...okay...huh?  wait...I...own...the...world?..., yeah...huh?) 
John


++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

+      + ground!"..."NO!,NO!,NO! I am the ground, you cannot harm me!  I
won the  +
+ world!  I am the Earth!...." - the unknown tweeker                      
+                                             +                    from the
village of jsl@netcom.com                    +
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++


From sfraves-owner  Sun Aug 22 17:59:59 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA28293; Sun, 22 Aug 93 17:59:59 PDT
Received: from net.bio.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA28286; Sun, 22 Aug 93 17:59:46 PDT
Received: by net.bio.net (5.65/IG-2.0) 
	id AA12540; Sun, 22 Aug 93 17:59:41 -0700
Date: Sun, 22 Aug 93 17:59:41 -0700
From: red@net.bio.net (Ben Wing)
Message-Id: <9308230059.AA12540@net.bio.net>
To: jsl@netcom.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: get down, get stoopid, get ugly...
Newsgroups: 
In-Reply-To: <9308222256.AA12534@netcom.netcom.com>
Organization: Straight On Till Morning
Cc: 
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

[John writes a good summary of Get Down etc.]

I was struck by how ... well ... *mainstream* the crowd was, and
suburban, at least in terms of how they dressed.  Esp. in line ...
I was noticing how much I stood out wearing my silly ravish clothing
(baggy overalls, skull cap, etc.).  The craziest thing was this guy
in front of me and my sister in line, who (after eavesdropping on us
talking for awhile) said, "you guys are really interesting ...  you're
like intellectual Grateful Dead types" (?!).  I had this distinct
feeling that he and most of the others there, gawking over the huge
multicolor multipage "Massive Culture" flyers being handed out, were
not in the scene, but had just picked up the flyers and were there
because it seemed like the place to be, kinda like you might see an
ad in the Chronicle for an event that was going on on Halloween or
something and say, "Oh I have to go to that." I guess I should have
known this, but I kept making comparisons to Y.S.H. and noticing how
completely different it all felt.

I also went to Boogie Buffet afterwards -- I've never been there before.
I was struck by how different *that* was, different from either Get
Down or YSH.  I understand now what John means when he talks about
21+ events and Boogie Buffet and such, although I'm not sure I really
like the scene there so much.  It felt very jaded and urban there ...
it really felt like a scene out of a 30's movie, with lots of people
just lounging around acting cool and hip and not really talking to
each other.  A scene that really sticks in my mind is of this girl
Iessa (?), a "Peachy Puff" concessionaire-type that I've seen around
at a number of YSH's, just sitting there at a table by herself looking
forlorn.  Usually at YSH she would be walking around chatting with
people here and there.  (I was also annoyed that the only breakfast
they would serve was pancakes and fruit, but if you knew the manager
you could get eggs, toast, sausage, etc.  This seemed especially
strange seeing as you had to buy breakfast anyway.)

Ben

ps Reading back over this message it sounds awfully negative ...
sorry, it's not meant to be so negative ...  more reflectful than
anything else.

From sfraves-owner  Sun Aug 22 19:13:29 1993

Man, mainstream is too kind.  I think the operative word here Ben is clueless.
Speaking of the Chronicle.  A reporter, digit it, a REPORTER was in Boggie.
 She tried to talk to me and get the dope on what the whole *thing* was
about.  She asked me for my name, of course I don't have one for her.  She
then started asking Jan Cooley (who spun a really GREAT morning set, get it
girl!) questions.  It's not like I don't like reporters.  I just don't like
'em.

>
>I also went to Boogie Buffet afterwards -- I've never been there before.
>I was struck by how different *that* was, different from either Get
>Down or YSH.  I understand now what John means when he talks about
>21+ events and Boogie Buffet and such, although I'm not sure I really
>like the scene there so much.

Many people feel the same way as you Ben.  Myself Included.  It vasilates
though.  Sometimes it's really good, other times it's really ugly.

>It felt very jaded and urban there ...
>it really felt like a scene out of a 30's movie, with lots of people
>just lounging around acting cool and hip and not really talking to
>each other.  A scene that really sticks in my mind is of this girl
>Iessa (?), a "Peachy Puff" concessionaire-type that I've seen around
>at a number of YSH's, just sitting there at a table by herself looking
>forlorn.  Usually at YSH she would be walking around chatting with
>people here and there.  (I was also annoyed that the only breakfast
>they would serve was pancakes and fruit, but if you knew the manager
>you could get eggs, toast, sausage, etc.  This seemed especially
>strange seeing as you had to buy breakfast anyway.)

I don't know what the fucks up with that shit!  P is coming over later on. 
I'll ask him about it(the breakfast stuff).  I noticed it last week as
well, but didn't know what was up with that.  The cook was VERY defensive. 
I told him to mellow out, then he asked me to leave the kitchen.  Oh well,
the hired help these days.  Hey, if they're gonna give folks eggs and
sausies then it oughta bee for everyone, not just whoever knows the
promoter.  Now it very well could be people bring in their suasies and
eggie-wegs, but I doubt it. As for the cool versus uncool...the "cool"
people are sooo fucked up (read High) that if it weren't for those beanbags
they'd be in sad shape.  The uncool people are the ones who ,could not get
high in the first place, AND could not secure a beanbag :)  The only people
who are into that cool shit are the strippers, and fashion fatales.  Who
cares about them anyway...most of the people who are there are quite
friendly...it's more of a speakeasy than anything else...

>
>Ben
>
>ps Reading back over this message it sounds awfully negative ...
>sorry, it's not meant to be so negative ...  more reflectful than
>anything else.


Your opinions negative? Hell no!  Your observations are just that.  No need
to put a +/- slant to it.  Hell, sometimes there's good events, sometimes
bad.  Even though Get Down, Get Stoopid, Get Ugly was not my kind of party,
I had a good time.  Got off my face, danced a little, and was very, very
happy I didn't pay to get in.  Most of the people there TRIED to get into
it, and maybe next time they will have a better handle as to what's what. 
The tweeker that I saw will provide many hours of entertainment in the days
to come. And if you can get even a laugh out of a scene then IMHO it ain't
all that bad.  Considering the sloppy summer we've had, a few good laughs
go a long, long way! :)

Later & Peace...
John


P.S.  I read in SPIN about that Massive Culture thang.  To me it's complete
rubbish.  I will not attend that event, comps or no!  Just one more reason
to keep things UG.  BTW, a friend of mine (who does Late Train) talked
very, very, highly about YSH.  I will be at the next one!

Oh yeah, please don't forget to give as much as you can to Tweekers
Anonymous.  A tweeker you know is counting on you! ;)

From sfraves-owner  Sun Aug 22 22:48:27 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA00132; Sun, 22 Aug 93 22:48:27 PDT
Received: from gandalf.rutgers.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA00116; Sun, 22 Aug 93 22:48:06 PDT
Received: by gandalf.rutgers.edu (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA22148; Mon, 23 Aug 93 01:48:01 EDT
Date: Mon, 23 Aug 93 1:48:00 EDT
From: Monica Tauriello <monicat@gandalf.rutgers.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: get down and ugly
Message-Id: <CMM-RU.1.3.746084880.monicat@gandalf.rutgers.edu>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

well, i think ben's right on the mark in his description of this event - the
crowd was VERY mainstream - i felt like i waz at a NJ high school dance! :(
...very few pockets of vibe, altho' i did see a few people dancing their asses
off as if the musick had possessed them, which was nice..... too much of a
markie mark look-alike factor for me there, tho' - i mean, i have no problem
with people taking their shirtz off when they're hot from dancing (i do it),
but it seemed like a lot of posturing to me....

i waz also disappointed in the way the space was set up - didn't like the djs
in the hall - some of the fabbest acid was being played in the hall by the
chill room but it was hard to get into with people passing thru, bumping,
etc....

so this was an experiment for me, in a way - my first west coast large rave...
well, i thought it was definitely better than any large east coast event i'd
been to, but i still don't think i'll be doing another $20 thang for a long
long time, if ever again... the place felt ot me like a bunch of middle class
kids with little sense who blew $20 plus whatever else for chemicalz and
trashed a civic center with pretty-colored, stepped on flyers and lollipop
sticks.... to me, IMHO, that's not what raving's about - to me raving's about
Doing It Yourself/Yourselves, not buying a concert ticket; it's about putting
your cigarette butts in your pocket to throw away later; it's about coming
together to share and dance in, ideally, taken/squatted spaces, or empty
warehouses that you transform into TAZs....a civic center with police roaming
around is the opposite of a TAZ for me - i don't want the state in my face
when the 303 takes over my body....

and $20?!?! i guess i'm still a bit shocked at the prices out here.... i waz
just reading today in charles perry's history of Haight Ashbury how the
diggers actually picketed an event where they thought the promoters were
charging too much ($3.50!).. i'm not going to go that far, but i guess from
now on i'll be boycotting these large things unless maybe it's some kind of
benefit...anyway, i feel like a groundhog scurrying back underground now after
glimpsing at the state of corporate capitalist america.....

wow.... i feel really negative.... i really didn't have an utterly bad time
.... really enjoyed the chill-out room, tho i thought it coulda used a dream
machine....but i guess overall i just feel like an idiot for having gone...:( 


monicat

>being beaten up by police might have had on him whilst he was

Yes, I did stop and think about him.  I thought, "this asshole, who JUMPED
onto turntables, and started swinging at Dj's is getting that karma
returned to his ass, WHOLESALE!".  Compassion?  Yeah...I wanted the cops to
restrain this fuck, and get him the hell outta there before MORE people got
hurt.  My compassion lies with the people who had to witness some dude go
off becuase he could not handle his drugs.  My compassion goes out to the
people who paid $20 for an event that was interrupted by violence caused by
some unknown cracker-jack tweek.  My compassion goes out to everyone who
was even thinking about doing an event @ the Richmond, but now may have to
contend with further vibe-reducing qualities assoc with that space (have
you begun to think HOW the cops may prevent these types of incidents from
happening?  Like more stringent searches :( !!! ).  That Tweeker, IMHO, is
waking up this moment wondering "Hmmm...how did I get these bruises?  I
remember jumping...then I remember the earth...but I can't figure out why
I'm in a straightjacket in this padded room?".  People like this are
ANOTHER reason parties are getting harder to throw.  They (people who don't
like raves), now have another prime example as to why these parties are no
good.  They will not see our beloved Tweeker as an aberration, they will
see him as a prime example, that is usually the way these things work to
kill a scene.  They will also notice the nitrous cannisters thrown
everywhere...yep, compassion...me thinks you should examine the impact
incidents of this type have upon the whole, not just at the individual
level Roy.

If you really feel strongly about this issue I would hope that you give
money to T.A. (Tweekers Anonymous).  Because compassion for the tweeker is
what they are all about...

Later & Peace...
John

Larry & Roy et. al.,

Club use WAS restrained.  And was quite measured.  They did what they could
to get that dude DOWN.  You see, after he rushed Thomas, and the boys from
Wicked threw his butt out (btw he was FIGHTING all the time), he CHARGED
the door (glass doors folks).  That's when they tried to lock it, and
presumably thats when the cops came (they ARE right across the street). 
This guy was REALLY angry/high and was going to do someone damage (he
already tagged a DJ, fought the boys from Wicked, and now he had to deal
with the authorities). Terrible combo.  He was/is a hazard to the people
around him, so I have NO sympathy whatsoever for his plight.  I am tired of
people not being responsible with their intake of drugs.  If you are NOT
sure of what they will do to you then simply don't take them.  But don't
ingest them and expect everyone to "understand" that you've gone overboard
and caused harm to others.  I understand people having really bad trips,
but this was the worse case yet I've seen.  The other alarming thing is
that this seems to happen all to often at parties of late.  Some goofball
decides that the DJ is the devil or some other supernatural hokus-pokus and
decides perform ritual excorsisms on the spot.  Not healthy at all.

This is another reason why I strongly believe (esp. these days) in some
sort of security being present.

At a rock show (which is where that tweeker thought he was at) they would
have thrown him out, after beating the shit out of him to teach him a
lesson (or so they would think).  So he got MUCH better treatment from cops
than he would have from a rock show security team.  It also helped that the
cops were doing their job in from of many people, so they made sure to take
a completely measured response to this lunatic.  I was VERY happy to see
the cops for once.

All in all I hope he recovers and thinks about his actions.  I hope he
thinks before he takes drugs, and I hope he puts more thought into why he
does them in the first place.  I hope this Tweeker, if he decides to go out
again, is a bit more caring of those around him and tries not to disturb
that which others have tried so hard to build.

Me?  Hell,  NO MORE MASSIVES!!!!

BCNU,
John

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <9308231629.AA07046@netcom3.netcom.com>

Monica says:

>i waz also disappointed in the way the space was set up - didn't like the djs
>in the hall - some of the fabbest acid was being played in the hall by the
>chill room but it was hard to get into with people passing thru, bumping,
>etc....

Yea!!  That was most unfortunate,   because when Carlos started spinning
in the hallway,  it was practically impossible to pass through the hall
because of all his worshipers and fans.  WOW!!  He sure had them hopping.
Why didn't they put Carlos in the main hallway??

Later on,  one of Carlos' partners came up to me and said "I like your
dance style"  WOW!!  But I never danced until just recently...   But I like
doing my OWN THANG!! and getting creative,  and letting the music dictate
my movements.

Just curious how old the "Tweeker" bozo was that jumped on the turn-tables
and what drugs he was on.

>i have no problem
>with people taking their shirtz off when they're hot from dancing (i do it),
>but it seemed like a lot of posturing to me....

WELL!  I have to admit,  until they started upening up the doors in the main
entrance way,  that was the ONLY way to cool off.    I learned early on,  to
either bring an extra shirt,  or not wear it when dancing.    Nothing I hate
worse than that is to be wearing a wet tee-shirt when it's over.   

All in All,  Wicked was totally awsome,  and I had a GREAT time,  and a chance
to dance to some DJ's I never had an opportumity to before.

For those that expected me at Boogie Buffet,  we got there,  but my friends
girl friend lost her ID,  and they raised the cover charge to $5 instead of
the usual $4,  which meant that one of us couldn't get in,  so we collectivly
decided to bag it.    Soory about not showing up to those that were expecting
us.

I eventually went home,   had so much energy left that I wound up hiking in
the woods for 4 - 5 hours afterwords to chill down.

Till Penalepe's Web...

Cheers
JD

and one will be far away.  The one near the city will be lame, and the
faraway one will be a lot of fun.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug 23 12:54:32 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA03773; Mon, 23 Aug 93 12:54:32 PDT
Received: from gatekeeper.oracle.com (gatekeeper.us.oracle.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

	id AA15273; Mon, 23 Aug 93 12:55:46 PDT
Message-Id: <9308231955.AA15273@slamdance.us.oracle.com>
From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Mission Rock Warning
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFRaves)
Date: Mon, 23 Aug 93 12:55:45 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


On Friday, when my friend and I were leaving Mission Rock, we were
robbed in the parking lot by at least two men who claimed they
had guns.

It happened at about 3am, before the club had closed.  My friend
and I had gotten into my car and were about to leave when the 
thieves opened the car doors and asked if we had any money, then
said we had better give them our money or we would be shot.  They
took our wallets and told us to go away, so we drove off and went to
the police station.   (both of us were OK, just a little rattled)

We had been parked about 10-15 cars north of the building, on the
same side of the road as the club.  While walking to my car, we
saw a bunch of people around a couple of cars which were parked
in the road (blocking in some parked cars) and blasting music;
I would guess that our attackers came from that 'gang', but I'm
not sure.  Anyway, when I went back to Mission Rock the next
afternoon to look for the wallets, I talked to the bartender and
he said that they have been having problems with a group of
people who park out in the lot late on Friday and Saturday
nights and cause trouble; also someone else told me they tried
to enter the club one night, and they've tried to start fights.

So the bartender's advice was to park on the south side of the
building, preferably where it's lit.  I don't want to discourage
people from going, 'cause the music was great, and many other 
venues are probably just as dangerous, but be careful there and
anywhere else you go; San Francisco is becoming a more dangerous
place and some caution is always worthwhile.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 o derek chung  o  oracle graphics  o  dhchung@us.oracle.com  o 415.506.6195 o
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From: brycer@netcom.com (Bryce Ryan)
Message-Id: <9308232149.AA09510@netcom2.netcom.com>
Subject: Weekend Event Reviews
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Date: Mon, 23 Aug 93 14:49:10 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Your humble reporter experienced the following this past weekend in SF:

On Friday night, I checked out Corduroy City for a couple of hours.  I
arrived just after 1AM, and the place was going off, and kept going off
the entire time I was there.  I listened to two DJs.  I didn't catch the
first DJ's name, but she played a fine house set.  The second DJ, who, I'm
told, was John Williams, played acid house, progressed into acid, and
moved into Chicago & Progressive house. The visuals were outstanding--they
had a video projector with lots of great graphics going through interesting
transformations.  The place was packed, the sound system was an 8' high
6 speaker stacks, the smile factor was high, and the price was reasonable
US$7.

I then wandered out to the Ananda location, since it was advertised as
a late starter.  True to my form, I arrived just as the sound system
got going.  The location was outstanding, providing free visuals, lots
of cool air (I found I had overdressed for the occasion, which is rare
for me for outdoor night events).  It seemed to take the DJs about 30-45
minutes to settle down, but once we all settled down, things seemed to
flow much better.  The SFR posse was in full effect.  I also finally
got to hear the much talked about Goa Gil in person.  The smile factor
seemed fairly high.  The event was marred mostly when a woman friend 
was harassed by some guys...yuck! 

Saturday, I visited with some friends, thought about going to Get Wicked,
circumstances changed, and I went to All God's Children.  Unfortunately,
the event never really went off for me.  Also, the space was busted at
about 4-4:30.  Major bummer, since the space has been a friendly home
to some fine events.  The smile factor was fairly low, the dance factor
for most people was high, all in all, a so-so event.

Sunday, I visited the newly formed (I guess) Ambient Night, downstairs
at Spike's.  Oops. Big mistake.  The place is a [very] small cavern
tucked under Spike's on 8th Street in SF.  Half the room seems to be
taken up with the bar (*yawn*), cover is $2, half the room is in 
near darkness.  The sound people were using lighters to see their
equipment.  The visuals were boring. There were sporadic attempts
at digeridoo playing. The sound was mostly not ambient.  We were
subjected to a version of "The Girl from Ipanema" mixed with ocean
sounds at one point.  I like the song...just not in a supposedly
"ambient" context.  My advice: save your money, save your time.  This
one is not yet ready for prime time.
-- 
Bryce Ryan -- Specializing in AMBIANCE -- brycer@netcom.com
"The revolution will not be televised, 
 but the proceedings will be available online."  Art McGee

From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug 23 16:22:38 1993

Received: from nkosi.well.sf.ca.us by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA00698; Mon, 23 Aug 93 16:21:58 PDT
Received: from well.sf.ca.us (well.sf.ca.us [192.132.30.2]) by nkosi.well.sf.ca.us (8.6.beta.4/8.5) with SMTP id QAA04198; Mon, 23 Aug 1993 16:21:48 -0700
Received: by well.sf.ca.us id <14257-1>; Mon, 23 Aug 1993 16:21:04 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
To: jsl@netcom.com, roy@harlequin.co.uk
Subject: Re: get down, get stoopid, get ugly...
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Message-Id: <93Aug23.162104pdt.14257-1@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Mon, 23 Aug 1993 16:21:03 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

John, think again.  Your haste to mete out justice without necessarily
having all the facts may be emotionally satisfying, but does it really
deal with the situation as you saw it?  For example, suppose somebody
like that was dosed without his knowledge.  It could happen -- I've seen
it.  Suppose somebody then freaked and started acting out whatever
happened to be at the surface of their consciousness at that moment --
latent hostility, whatever.  It could happen -- I've seen it.  And
suppose then that the local gendarmerie or security bozos or whatever
started beating the shit out of the guy because they had no training
in how to deal with problems of violence except with counter-violence?
It could happen.  And I've seen it.

Jumping to conclusions is the wrong thing to do.  If you're in a situation
where you have to deal with something like this, of course you have to
react.  I am glad when the security people at parties respond to these
things, but I get upset when I see the usual brute-force approach when
they haven't tried anything else, mostly because they've never had the
appropriate training -- much of which really gets down to following the
Golden Rule, and distracting the subject's attention so they can get
out of their stress-loop and start acting a little more rationally.
Of course, there are situations where this won't work.  Of course.
And sometimes you just have to tackle someone to deal with their
problems.  But why *start* there, especially when the inappropriate
use of force can cause the problem to escalate out of control?

If someone is tweaking on acid, that's one thing; if they're flying on
crystal or ice that's another; if they're simply dumber-than-fuck drunk
that's yet another.  The symptoms may seem fairly similar -- aggressive,
loud, even violent behavior.  The wrong diagnosis or worse, no diagnosis
can cause a lot of damage and wreck the vibe for everyone, as this
incident did for you . . . 

A few months ago BrianB was collecting ideas to bring up at the Monday
planning meetings, and I wrote a long thing about improving the security/
safety/door situation.  What you witnessed is exactly the kind of
situation I was concerned about.  

These kinds of disruptions are undesirable and nobody likes them.  But
before drawing any conclusions about who "they" are who are having all
these problems and disrupting parties and other events, and about what
should be done to "them", and what groups "they" supposedly represent,
let's think a bit about why this stuff happens at all, and the best way
to respond.  Seems to me that acknowledging the human qualities we all
share is a good place to start.  We all have The Beast Inside, and with
some folks it seems like that's the only thing there . . . but I've found
that except for the truly psychotic (who are thankfully very rare), you
can always find some common ground to deal with someone.  

Is the self-satisfaction of the bystander at rough justice being carried
out worth the risk that someone's life will be ruined or even lost?

Received: by netcom3.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA08789; Mon, 23 Aug 93 13:41:50 -0700
Message-Id: <9308232041.AA08789@netcom3.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: weekend in revue
Date: Mon, 23 Aug 93 13:41:49 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>


(1) Friday: Someone posted about "time warp" on friday night. Lacking
better things to do, and given the fact that the other friday night choice
(Mission Rock) was vetoed on the grounds of "bad vibe" by my S.O., and
given the fact that Ananda kept on delaying the starting time of their
event; we decided to check "time warp" out. (note that the plan was just to
do a few hours of dancercise, as opposed to going for an all-night massive
rave extravaganza).

| Subject: Time Warp tonight ...
| Sez it's a promotional event for a new location for San Francisco's undergroud
| scene. Four live acts "Alphabet Soup, Last to Serve, Universal Joint, High
| Gain", DJ's Thomas, Skinny Ribs, Daemon, Pause, Pete, Leanne, and Jestr.
| Live music starts at 9:00pm. 415-469-6976. Hyde and Sutter?!
| Flyer states it's Invite Only Please.

So we "crash" the party, pay our $10.00/person, and walk in. The place is
very interesting -- looks like an old hotel lobby and dining area. Plush in
a dated kind of way. Upstairs there was a large stage/hall with live
hip-hop acts, plus DJ'd hip-hop music; downstairs they had some pool
tables, a chill out room, and a small room with DJ'd dance music. We got
there around midnight or so, which means that the best live acts had
already played.  So we spent most of our time in the small dance room. Good
vibe, friendly people running the event, free water, etc. One DJ hauled out
alot of old rare-groove dance numbers that were fun to funk to;
unfortunately, she didn't really know how to mix; later, a different DJ
pulled out the techno groove and got the (small) crowd pumping. Didn't
recognize any of the DJ's I saw....

Even though there were a few of gangsta-looking hip-hoppers upstairs,
positive respect was given and taken by all involved.  The upstairs area
was low-vibe by rave standards, but pretty good by hip-hop standards,
especially given the fact that it is oh-so fashionable to front a
hard/mean/sullen/angry pose in the hip hop milieu; also, the music upstairs
was a bit too slow to dance too. Music to bounce yer car to, but not your
body. So we spent most of our time dancing in the downstairs area.

I asked the people in charge whether there would be more events like this
and they said "call the number". It probably won't be a weekly.

- --------------------

(2) Saturday: blew off "Get Down Get Stupid Get Wicked" so's I could
hang out w/ my bro-in-law and sister visiting from NYC, and gather
up the appropriate sleep for....

- --------------------

(3) Sunday morning: Boogie Buffet 10:30AM-2:30PM. Well, this just wasn't as
massive as the one I attended two weeks ago (the
post-wicked-at-174-king-st-boogie-buffet). The idea was to show my sister
(a musician/composer visiting from NYC) what the scene in SF was like
without keeping her up all night in uncomfortable, sweaty, ugly,
rave-venues, filled with frothing-at-the-mouth-cuz-i-took-too-much-speed-
shirtless-male-hunter-gatherers.

Well, S.O., sister, and I had fun, but the DJing in the "sunlight" room was
nowhere near as good as it had been the previous time. I was hoping for the
massive epic dubwise rare groove disco extravaganza that I had witnessed
the previous time, but it just didn't quite materialize.  (Perhaps there
was something in the water the previous time :-)).  Overall, however,
it was fun for the whole family.

In the sunlight room, the female DJ (Jan Cooley, perhaps) that was on
earlier just didn't turn my crank -- a bit too discoey in a boring sort of
way. Later a different DJ came on (who was that?) and improved things
somewhat.  Particularly missing was the fine mixing that I had seen in
previous times.  Instead, there were plenty of times when the music
stopped, then another record was slammed in. Perhaps I was just being
overcritical and oversensitive because I was "showing off" the scene to my
sister, and was hoping that the scene, the DJing, and the music come off as
epic and overwhelming. Also, the sound system in the "daylight" room was
just a tad too loud (verging on distortion) in the midrange, while the bass
was not as earth-shaking.

Meanwhile, Spun was in the "dark" room spinning up a jungular tribal rhythm
storm. A good amount of time was spent there because the music was real
real nice.

Saw a handful of sfravers there, met a few new faces too....

In either case we're all going back there next sunday, and hopefully,
we'll even manage to get my sister's husband to emerge from the recording
studio and have some fun with us.

Re: the prev. conversations about breakfast and entrance price at Boogie
Buffet. $5.00 entry fee -- no complaints out of me -- a very good value for
the money. The $2.00 pancake and fruit breakfast -- also a good value, and
I don't need no steenking eggs and sausages! It was just enough food/sugar
to get me dancing. Nice new feature: espresso/cappucino! Yum yum. Caffeine
rules! Security -- present, pleasant, helpful, friendly. Overall, a very
well-done event.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

------- End of Forwarded Message

Date: Mon, 23 Aug 1993 18:32:29 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL22]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 631       
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

If anyone is in the mood for an out of town adventure Groove Kitchen
will be doing a special out of town show this Saturday the 28th in
Portland, Oregon.  It about an eight (!) hour drive for all you folks
in the Bay.  DJs are to be Jon Williams, Spun, Harry Who, and Brad
Vachal (a local DJ, loacl being Portland :-)).  Visuals will be
handled by the able team of Synergy and Pure.

The info number for all you people down south is (415)267-3932.  And
if you happen to make it up the number in Portland is (503)796-4696.

Come check out our scene, I've enjoyed watching (and helping) it grow
since I got up here from LA.
--
matts

furniture arrivals, so a break in its alias database caused some email
sent to sfraves to be bounced back user unknown.  Sorry about this - 
here's a post from neils that got bounced and never made it.

} Return-Path: <mayer@netcom.com>
} Received: by netcom3.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
} 	id AA08789; Mon, 23 Aug 93 13:41:50 -0700
} Message-Id: <9308232041.AA08789@netcom3.netcom.com>
} To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
} Subject: weekend in revue
} Date: Mon, 23 Aug 93 13:41:49 -0700
} From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
} 
} 
} (1) Friday: Someone posted about "time warp" on friday night. Lacking
} better things to do, and given the fact that the other friday night choice
} (Mission Rock) was vetoed on the grounds of "bad vibe" by my S.O., and
} given the fact that Ananda kept on delaying the starting time of their
} event; we decided to check "time warp" out. (note that the plan was just to
} do a few hours of dancercise, as opposed to going for an all-night massive
} rave extravaganza).
} 
} | Subject: Time Warp tonight ...
} | Sez it's a promotional event for a new location for San Francisco's undergroud
} | scene. Four live acts "Alphabet Soup, Last to Serve, Universal Joint, High
} | Gain", DJ's Thomas, Skinny Ribs, Daemon, Pause, Pete, Leanne, and Jestr.
} | Live music starts at 9:00pm. 415-469-6976. Hyde and Sutter?!
} | Flyer states it's Invite Only Please.
} 
} So we "crash" the party, pay our $10.00/person, and walk in. The place is
} very interesting -- looks like an old hotel lobby and dining area. Plush in
} a dated kind of way. Upstairs there was a large stage/hall with live
} hip-hop acts, plus DJ'd hip-hop music; downstairs they had some pool
} tables, a chill out room, and a small room with DJ'd dance music. We got
} there around midnight or so, which means that the best live acts had
} already played.  So we spent most of our time in the small dance room. Good
} vibe, friendly people running the event, free water, etc. One DJ hauled out
} alot of old rare-groove dance numbers that were fun to funk to;
} unfortunately, she didn't really know how to mix; later, a different DJ
} pulled out the techno groove and got the (small) crowd pumping. Didn't
} recognize any of the DJ's I saw....
} 
} Even though there were a few of gangsta-looking hip-hoppers upstairs,
} positive respect was given and taken by all involved.  The upstairs area
} was low-vibe by rave standards, but pretty good by hip-hop standards,
} especially given the fact that it is oh-so fashionable to front a
} hard/mean/sullen/angry pose in the hip hop milieu; also, the music upstairs
} was a bit too slow to dance too. Music to bounce yer car to, but not your
} body. So we spent most of our time dancing in the downstairs area.
} 
} I asked the people in charge whether there would be more events like this
} and they said "call the number". It probably won't be a weekly.
} 
} - --------------------
} 
} (2) Saturday: blew off "Get Down Get Stupid Get Wicked" so's I could
} hang out w/ my bro-in-law and sister visiting from NYC, and gather
} up the appropriate sleep for....
} 
} - --------------------
} 
} (3) Sunday morning: Boogie Buffet 10:30AM-2:30PM. Well, this just wasn't as
} massive as the one I attended two weeks ago (the
} post-wicked-at-174-king-st-boogie-buffet). The idea was to show my sister
} (a musician/composer visiting from NYC) what the scene in SF was like
} without keeping her up all night in uncomfortable, sweaty, ugly,
} rave-venues, filled with frothing-at-the-mouth-cuz-i-took-too-much-speed-
} shirtless-male-hunter-gatherers.
} 
} Well, S.O., sister, and I had fun, but the DJing in the "sunlight" room was
} nowhere near as good as it had been the previous time. I was hoping for the
} massive epic dubwise rare groove disco extravaganza that I had witnessed
} the previous time, but it just didn't quite materialize.  (Perhaps there
} was something in the water the previous time :-)).  Overall, however,
} it was fun for the whole family.
} 
} In the sunlight room, the female DJ (Jan Cooley, perhaps) that was on
} earlier just didn't turn my crank -- a bit too discoey in a boring sort of
} way. Later a different DJ came on (who was that?) and improved things
} somewhat.  Particularly missing was the fine mixing that I had seen in
} previous times.  Instead, there were plenty of times when the music
} stopped, then another record was slammed in. Perhaps I was just being
} overcritical and oversensitive because I was "showing off" the scene to my
} sister, and was hoping that the scene, the DJing, and the music come off as
} epic and overwhelming. Also, the sound system in the "daylight" room was
} just a tad too loud (verging on distortion) in the midrange, while the bass
} was not as earth-shaking.
} 
} Meanwhile, Spun was in the "dark" room spinning up a jungular tribal rhythm
} storm. A good amount of time was spent there because the music was real
} real nice.
} 
} Saw a handful of sfravers there, met a few new faces too....
} 
} In either case we're all going back there next sunday, and hopefully,
} we'll even manage to get my sister's husband to emerge from the recording
} studio and have some fun with us.
} 
} Re: the prev. conversations about breakfast and entrance price at Boogie
} Buffet. $5.00 entry fee -- no complaints out of me -- a very good value for
} the money. The $2.00 pancake and fruit breakfast -- also a good value, and
} I don't need no steenking eggs and sausages! It was just enough food/sugar
} to get me dancing. Nice new feature: espresso/cappucino! Yum yum. Caffeine
} rules! Security -- present, pleasant, helpful, friendly. Overall, a very
} well-done event.
} 
} =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
} ==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
} =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
} 
} ------- End of Forwarded Message
} 
} 


From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug 23 18:51:43 1993

	id AA01445; Mon, 23 Aug 93 18:51:43 PDT
