	id AA01438; Mon, 23 Aug 93 18:51:41 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA12609; Mon, 23 Aug 93 18:52:26 -0700
Date: Mon, 23 Aug 93 18:52:26 -0700
Message-Id: <9308240152.AA12609@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: More ugliness...& then let's move on!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

(dont worry, this is NOT a flame war...just conversation...patience)

>John, think again.  Your haste to mete out justice without necessarily
>having all the facts may be emotionally satisfying, but does it really
>deal with the situation as you saw it?  For example, suppose somebody
>like that was dosed without his knowledge.  It could happen -- I've seen
>it.  Suppose somebody then freaked and started acting out whatever
>happened to be at the surface of their consciousness at that moment --
>latent hostility, whatever.  It could happen -- I've seen it.  And
>suppose then that the local gendarmerie or security bozos or whatever
>started beating the shit out of the guy because they had no training
>in how to deal with problems of violence except with counter-violence?
>It could happen.  And I've seen it.

In the first place I do not know whether or not he ingested willfully or
no.  I DO know that he jumped on turntables and took a swing, and hit a dj.
 His reasons?  Who knows...I can't speak for his motives, I can only adress
his actions which is exactly what I've done.  That DOSING-FOR-FUN stuff has
been done before.  But the way in WHICH he was acting made it seem as
though he was suffering from soem form of delusional dimentia.  Now if he
had been dosed with very strong LSD, I doubt he would gain SUPER HUMAN
strength.  Your space and time becomes highly distorted under LSD
delusions.  Rare is the case (that I know of, and I've read much from the
AHF about this so...) of somone becoming very violent from LSD. 
Delusional? Yes...many might see demons and RUN for cover.  This guy was
out for blood...that was quite evident.  He could have been on dust or
speed. which in this scene is quite probable.  If it took 5 cops to
restrain his butt (and it did), and he continued fighting it leads me to
belive he was on some type of amped up mode.  He was frothing at the mouth.
 Yes that can happen with LSD, but it also happens with dust.  As for who
did what...this is not my concern...since I may not ever know the answer to
that question I concern myself with the immediate...was he endangering
himself AND others?:YES. If left alone would he harm others?:YES.  Did he
have to be removed?:YES.

As for your second point you create a scenario:
> And
>suppose then that the local gendarmerie or security bozos or whatever
>started beating the shit out of the guy because they had no training
>in how to deal with problems of violence except with counter-violence?
>It could happen.  And I've seen it.

This is a moot point since it did not happen.  Roy asked how he would have
been handled by the "rock & roll" security types found at rock concerts.  I
said, and rightfully so, that he received better treatment than he would at
rock shows.  Anyone who has been tossed on their ass by one of those rock
show sec. forces knows what I am talking about.  But since nobody beat the
shit out of him, and since he was removed by force, first by Wicked then by
the cops, I am satisfied (esp since nobody else was hurt by this fool).  If
I, would a, should a, could a, does not apply.  So I dare not conjecture
about this.

>
>Jumping to conclusions is the wrong thing to do.  If you're in a situation
>where you have to deal with something like this, of course you have to
>react.  I am glad when the security people at parties respond to these
>things, but I get upset when I see the usual brute-force approach when
>they haven't tried anything else, mostly because they've never had the
>appropriate training

Fred, were you there?  This guy was hitting Thomas, what do you want to do
sit him down over a nice cup of tea and reason with him.  Is that after
he's caused damage or not?  We simply don't agree with each other.  He was
tossed out.  Locked out.  The authorities restrained him.  And IMO they
were justified in the removal of this tweeker.  All else is legalese and
has NOTHING to do with justice being served.  He was a threat to others.
Who else has to be punched before he is removed?

[...]
>A few months ago BrianB was collecting ideas to bring up at the Monday
>planning meetings, and I wrote a long thing about improving the security/
>safety/door situation.  What you witnessed is exactly the kind of
>situation I was concerned about.  
>
>These kinds of disruptions are undesirable and nobody likes them.  But
>before drawing any conclusions about who "they" are who are having all
>these problems and disrupting parties and other events, and about what
>should be done to "them", and what groups "they" supposedly represent,
>let's think a bit about why this stuff happens at all, and the best way
>to respond.[...] you
>can always find some common ground to deal with someone. 

I agree.  But I do make some distinctions.  "They" are people who come to a
party just to cause trouble.  "They & them" are those who are not careful
as to how they act around others.  "They" are those who intentionally ruin
a vibe for everyone.  "They" are those who don't know how to take drugs. 
And as far as I am concerned, "they" have no business at ANY party. "They"
are the vibekillers, the scenekillers.  And "they" can stay home.

Fred, the other thing you must remeber is that in order to find common
ground people have to first agree to do so.  If they do not, one side has
one agenda while the other has a different one.  It takes two to do the do,
otherwise you end up talking to yourself.
  

>Is the self-satisfaction of the bystander at rough justice being carried
>out worth the risk that someone's life will be ruined or even lost?

Self-satisfaction at rough justice?  Well, YES (since there was no rough
justice, just a rough removal ;).  I was QUITE satisfied that they removed
him from the premesis.  I was quite satisfied that Thomas was OK.  I was
quite satisfied that the boys from Wicked removed him without trying to
hurt him.  I was quite satisfied that the cops removed him so that he would
be no further threat to others.  The only thing that was runied was a good
time for the people.  He will pay the bail, and get out.  If he has a prior
and is on probation then rough.  His life is far from over, unless he wants
it to be.  Yes, I was quite satisfied Fred.

To cap it off...I am NOT a legalist.  I am interested not in revenge, but
in justice.  This society has become quite interested in the splitting of
hairs when it comes to this.  If someone is a threat, they must be removed,
once it has been proven that they are a threat.  If someone punches a
anybody at a party, if someone does not respect the rights of others to
enjoy themselves, if someone wants to harass people, then IMO they cannot
be reasoned with.  They must be ejected, and we can talk OUTSIDE the event
if necessary.  Anything else, in these situations puts everyone at risk,
and is not fair to the society as a whole.  Sometimes, and note, SOMETIMES,
the need of the many outweigh the needs of a few or the one.  This dude was
the one, and he needed to be locked up.

No more TWEEKERS,
Peace...
John

Ahem, as a veteran of the SF -> Seattle route, and as a person who
just drove to Eugene this weekend, 8 hours is wrong.  I'd estimate a
minimum of 10 hours.  Eugene one way from SF proper is 520 miles, and
Portland is 105 miles farther from Eugene... so that's 625 miles, and
you've got Mt Shasta, Siskiyou (sp?) Summit and four smaller passes in
Oregon.  With traffic, it took me 11 hours to drive up to Eugene, and
without traffic, it took 8 hours to return.  And I drive fast, though
maybe not as fast as this poster :-)

Bob

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Clio's and the YSH DJ's need your help.
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Sometime during the weekend, Clio's, a coffee shop on Lower Haight in
SF, was broken into and their two tables, mixer, amp, and speakers
were stolen.

Clio is asking for anyone's help in finding a new set of all the above
pieces of equipment for sale at a reasonable price.  Clio's is the
unofficial practice headquarters and meeting place, and indeed the
only place available to several of YSH's women for practice in
spinning; Clio makes her tables available to newer DJ's, especially
women, and lets some of them store equipment and records there.

Maybe those of us who support the ideas (and the fun) behind YSH
can help her replace the stolen equipment!  If you can or have a lead
on something, please respond by calling her directly at 252-7912
or e-mail me here:

nineball@remarque.berkeley.edu


From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug 23 22:24:24 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA02769; Mon, 23 Aug 93 22:24:24 PDT
Received: from remarque.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

From: nineball@remarque.berkeley.edu (9ball)
Message-Id: <9308240524.AA27350@remarque.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Penelope's Web update....
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Just spoke to the promoter, Melissa, whom many of you all know, of
the Penelope's Web party that happened up in the mountains near
Willits, CA.

The latest is that the second Penelope's Web has been postponed
3 or 4 weeks from this weekend when it was originally going to happen.

One main issue here has been the projected cost, considering the
additional fees for the site up in Willits.  She is determined
to keep the cost down, still doesn't have a firm figure, but
she has found one relatively painless way to cut costs.

It turns out that one of the major costs was the rental of the
shuttle vans (to keep the cars off of the land) and the gas
expenses involved in running the van constantly the 13 or
so miles between the map point and the site.  Instead, she
will have people at the map pt asking people to wait up to
1/2 hour for the next trip when enough people have arrived.
No problem....

I'll try to keep the list posted of all updates she passes on!
Meanwhile you can get info and/or get on the mailing list by
calling the VM number at 765-7671.

-BC

PS. She has a full DJ lineup, but is calling for any women DJ's
who would like to spin for their first or n'th time.  If you
want to make yer break this might be the chance!

From sfraves-owner  Tue Aug 24 09:31:11 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA05192; Tue, 24 Aug 93 09:31:11 PDT
Received: from pilot.njin.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA05185; Tue, 24 Aug 93 09:31:08 PDT
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA29377; Tue, 24 Aug 93 12:31:06 EDT
Date: Tue, 24 Aug 93 12:31:06 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9308241631.AA29377@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Get Down Get Down Get Down and Wicked
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Well at Get Down/Wicked, I had just about the best time I've ever had
at a rave. Why?

After being to a lot of small events, I was ready for a big thousands
of people multimedia blowout event. And this was. The crowd was a bit
weird, not that ravey really, but I found plenty of people to share a
good vibe with.

The sound system was done *right*. At the Come/Unity and Unity events
I went to in Richmond, the speaker placement was awful. The walls
resonated out of time with the music, and interference from speakers
across the room dulled the sound and made it confusing. At gdgdgdw,
the sound wasn't quite as loud but very clear and enjoyable to listen
to.

There were five (count them) DJ's going all night. One in each lower
hallway, one in the main room, one in the back room by the stairs, and
one in the ambient room + dubtribe. If the music wasn't getting it,
just walk 75 feet :).

The real story of the night was Carlos! You have to imagine a the
regular Carlos vibe, and then imagine a hall packed with crazy dancing
people, and a huge crowd-DJ synergy. I was grinning so hard I nearly
broke my face :). I have never in my 25-30 odd events experienced such
an incredible vibe. Hats off to Carlos, who can totally go off on
scratching/tweaking the mixing board, and it sounds *good*.

Bad news: They confiscated my water. To return the favor, at the pay
point, I berated the promoter for a good solid three minutes,
explaining how that wasn't in the spirit or rave, how it was
irresponsible, etc. etc. and how neither me or my friends will attend
another event by them if they insist on these tactics. I think he
actually listened.

So all in all, a somewhat weird unravey crowd (they can't all be), but
some really good vibes available if you looked. A _Fantastic_ ambient
room. And of course, really great sfraver friends.

I don't want all events to be like this. But I want *some* events to
be like this because I like it once in a while.

See you Thursday,

Sean

Subject: Re: a review  (by Astroboy)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


>Thankfully, the real world is still utterly clueless:
>witness the following record review from Stereo Review::
    (Astroboy, a Tuesday morning greeting) 

Well Astroboy, three things are evident from your remarks:
    1) you regard yourself as outside the real world.
    2) you think you have a clue
    3) you want the world to remain in this perceived state

The first two reek of narcissism, ego, and pretension, but 
the third observation is the most destructive for it 
violently contradicts the rave vision. The truth is that for 
the spirit of rave (of which peace and unity are only two of 
the many dimensions) to gather the power needed to begin 
transforming the ugly features of this world, we must not 
place ourselves on a raised plateau over the "cluelss" real 
world as you have childishly done, but to work together and 
within it because we are part of this real world.  Raving is 
not about gathering togehter to praise one another and 
comment contemptiously on those who differ, but to create 
and nuture a spirit of understanding, tolerance and joy, and 
then share this spirit unselfishly with everybody.  
Self-centered people such as yourself thwart these efforts.  
My recommendation is to keep your diseased spirit away from 
the scene until you tap into some love and harmony within 
your being, then return to continue the process of healing 
(individual and communal healing) and become a positive 
force at the raves and in the world you share.

Mark Norman

	(in the PacBell both #5176)

	be providing (among other things) ISDN connectivity
	into the Internet (or 112 kbs right into your bedroom!)

	With that much bandwidth, you can easily run X11, transfer
	a 5 Mbyte gif in about 5 minutes (the whole sfraves archives),
	or listen to internet talk radio.  We will be offering the
	service to most of the Bay Area (you must be able to get ISDN
	or switch 56 service) for around ($100 -$150) a month
	(not including ISDN charges which should run you about $50 per
	month) but where else can you get that 8 times the bandwidth
	of a 14.4kbs modem for so little?

	Oh don't worry we have plenty of bandwidth, this is coming to
	you through a T1 at 1.5 Mbits sec.

I'm not disputing your description of the facts, John, or the necessity
of physically restraining someone who is clearly out of control.  But
there are good ways to do that, and hard ways.  Trouble is, the good
ways take training and common sense, and it's all to easy to succumb to
the feeling that someone got what they 'deserved' without knowing all
the facts.  Again, my caution is based on my guiding principle from the
GD scene -- believe half of what you see and none of what you hear
(at least in the sense of automatic belief).  

The bigger question for me in this incident is to what extent it represents
a change in the nature of the scene, or at least one part of it.

From sfraves-owner  Wed Aug 25 07:27:12 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA04592; Wed, 25 Aug 93 07:27:12 PDT
Received: from holly.harlequin.co.uk by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA04583; Wed, 25 Aug 93 07:26:58 PDT
Received: from piaget.harlequin.co.uk by holly.harlequin.co.uk; Wed, 25 Aug 1993 15:25:59 +0100
Received: from wundt.harlequin.co.uk by piaget.harlequin.co.uk; Wed, 25 Aug 93 15:25:51 BST
From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Wed, 25 Aug 93 15:25:49 BST
Message-Id: <20118.9308251425@wundt.harlequin.co.uk>
To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: Bob Ramstad's message of Tue, 24 Aug 93 18:25:05 PDT <9308250125.AA00679@groovy.us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: PGP
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>>>>> On Tue, 24 Aug 93 18:25:05 PDT, Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com> said:


  Bob> FYI, I managed to get PGP up and running here locally.  Feel free to
  Bob> use my key below... and if anyone out there wants to start working
  Bob> with me to verify and certify keys of people on this list, that would
  Bob> be cool.  I'd love to see this get used more... at least for practice,
  Bob> if nothing else.

Well, after composing my reply to this message, i realized that it's
really rather long, so i thought an executive sumarry would be in
order:

Hmmm... i'd like to say that you shouldn't trust a key that you;ve got
from the net (unless, of course, it's certified by someone you trust.)
You should generally exchange keys in person, on floppy disk, or
verify them over the phone using an MD5.... see the PGP manual for
more details...  there's also a nifty way of exchanging keys by
business card, provided you have email access (see below)

Security is hard work... but if you're going to do it at all, you have
to do it properly...

So, if you're interested, read on...

---------

Well, here's my original reply....

Check out the facility to produice an MD5 of your key.  You can put
this on a business card, along with your email address, and then you
can give people you meet your card.  They email you for you key, and
check the MD5 against the one on the card...

it's equivalent to printing your key on your card, except that it's
shorter.

Oh, and make sure you keep an exact copy of the key that you did the
MD5 of... 'cos if you add new signatures to your key, its MD5 will
change.  This ins't a problem, as long as you keep the one you used to
generate the MD5, since you can send this to people, and then, once
they're satisfied with it, you can send them an up-to-date key and PGP
will merge the signatures into their keyring.


I should also point out that if you're doing this properly, you
shouldn't ever trust a key that you see on a mailing list.  Someone
could have tampered with it so they can impersonate Bob.  Imagine that
there's a system manager at Oracle who doesn';t like the idea of Bob
receiving mail he can't spy on.  (Please, this is just fictional, i
wouldn't for one moment suggest that Oracle would really do this.)

So what this sysman does is he creates his own PGP key, and
substitutes this for the one in Bob's mail.  Whenever anyone sends Bob
mail, they'll inadvertently encrypt it using the sysman's key instead
of Bob's key.  The system manager has set up a demon to recognize pgp
messages, decode them, and print them out.  But here's the clever
bit... his demon then encrypts the message with Bob's real key (which
the sysman got from bob's mail), and passes it on....  so Bob doesn't
know that anything is wrong.

Provided that all Bob's PGP messages and keys go through the Oracle
mail system, the sysman could maintain this indefinitely, and no-one
would be able to tell...

What's more, the sysman could pose as Bob, by signing fake messages
using his own key... since as far as the rest of the world is
concerned, this *is* Bob's key.....

There are three obvious ways in which the sysman's game might be
discovered, even if the sysman makes no mistakes.... the first is, if
Bob manages to give someone his *real* key to someone, eg on a floppy,
and someone becomes suspicoous, either because they can;t veroify
bob's signatures (the sysman has substituited his own) or because he
ends up with 2 different ekys for bob on his keyring.

The second possibility is if someone gives Bob a PGP-encrypted file on
a floppy (encrypted, of course, with the sysman's key) and Bob will
find he's unable to read it, which might make him suppicious (though
of course the file could simply have been corrupted).  

The third possibility is that Bob signs something (a key, a messsage)
and gives it to someone on a floppy.  Now, to the outside world, the
signature won't verify....

But you can see that it might take quite a while for one of these
scenarios to happen, and for you to become convinced that this has
really happened to you... (your first reaction would be the file is
corrupted, right... i mean no one is *really* going to be spying on
you...)

Ok... second problem... if you're running on a unix machine, you;'ve
got problems that other processes might be spying on what you're
doing... this is a problem with any multitasking machine....  you
*have* to trust anyone who can get root access to your machine, since
they can monitor *anything* that goes on.  So they don;t need to do
anything clever with keys... they can just monitor your PGP session,
and keep copies of the plaintext.  In practice, security is less than
perfect on most multi-user machines, so you have to trust everyone who
has access to the machine...

Ok, solution: you need to run on single-tasking machine, eg a DOS
machine, unless you trust everyone who uses the unix machine.

Even so, if you keep your copy of PGP on your hard disk, you don't
know that it hasn't been tampered with (eg to keep a copy of the
messages, or to substitute someone elses key for yours) so you need to
carry your own copy of the DOS PGP on floppy.  Of course, someone
could have tampered with the DOS on this machine, too... put a virus
on it, or somehow tweaked it so that it notices when you try to run
PGP...  This is no problem, though... just make sure your PGP disk is
a bootable DOS disk (ie do a format /s), then copy PGP onto it and
write protect the floppy....  Never run PGP except when you;ve booted
from this floppy....

Hmm.... what am i saying here....?  Secuirty is hard work... but if
you want to practice playing with secure mail, you may as well do it
properly.  I mean, if no one's out to get you, then you don't need PGP
in the first place... and if *they* really are out to get you, then
you *need* to do it properly....

Besides, it gives you the satisfaction of knowing that you *really
are* sending messages that the NSA, with all their resources *really
can't read*.

(Well, actually, if they really want the information, they'll just
kidnap you, and torture you, and get you to divulge your pass phrase,
but if they do that, then they must want your data real bad...)


	Cosmic

	id AA22350; Wed, 25 Aug 93 08:56:01 PDT

At  3:25 PM 8/25/93 +0100, Roy Badami wrote:
>Besides, it gives you the satisfaction of knowing that you *really
>are* sending messages that the NSA, with all their resources *really
>can't read*.

Well, you never can tell... PGP uses IDEA, which *seems* 'unbreakable'
(which means that it would take so long to crack it that the info owuld
probably be worthless at that point), but the NSA really shouldn't be
underestimated on this... and they neither confirm or deny that the can
crack anything... but I would trust IDEA before I would trust DES. As far
as if they can break it... that can have less to do with the algorithm used
and more to do with the passphrase. Doesn't matter if you use something you
know for a fact is unbreakable (which cannot happen anyway), if someone can
guess your passphrase, they can read your message with ease. Which brings
me to something Roy left out of his otherwise pretty complete post-
password security. Your private key should be not only kept secure, but has
to be hard to guess, too. What this means depends on who you ask, but the
generally paranoid will pick one with at least 12 letters of both upper and
lower case, matbe with some non-letters (Like $$%!#@+~) in them, that is
not found in or derivable from and dictionary. This of course makes it not
only hard to guess, but hard to remember... But as roy said, security is
not easy. For more info, I'd say look in alt.pgp or sci.crypt. the
sci.crypt faq is a really helpful set of documents. Why this discussion is
going on in the rave mailing list, I have no idea... Not that I am helping
any.

jamie
jamiel@sybase.com


From sfraves-owner  Wed Aug 25 09:06:58 1993

Message-Id: <22062.9308251607@wundt.harlequin.co.uk>
To: jamiel@sybase.com
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: Jamie Lawrence's message of Wed, 25 Aug 1993 08:57:58 -0800 <9308251556.AA22350@ralph.sybgate.sybase.com>
Subject: Re: PGP
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



Hmmm... the passphrase is important, but i was also assuming that
you'dd attempot to keep your secret keyring physically secure....
rather than relying on the pasphrase.... 

In PGP, the passphrase is only an issue if someone else has access to
your secret keyring... think of it as a second line of defense in case
your secret key floppy should be lost or stolen.... but don't rely on
it....  if you lose a copy of your secret keyring, then, if you're a
cautious type, you'll issue a key compromize certificate even if
there's no evidence that your passphrase has been compromized....


as for DES vs IDEA... personally i doubt that there's any NSA trapdoor
in DES, and IDEA is a little too new for my liking.  That said, DES is
getting rather small... exhaustive search of 2^56 keys is looking more
and more plausible....  so it's swings and roundabouts....


	roy

Subject: PGP
In-Reply-To: <9308250125.AA00679@groovy.us.oracle.com>
References: <9308250125.AA00679@groovy.us.oracle.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

One of the things I did was to get my PGP key fingerprint, print out a
bezillion copies in a tiny 6 point font, cut them apart, and put some
in my wallet. Then I can hand it to other PGP user's in person. If
anyone wants mine, just ask. I usually have some of them on me
somewhere.

One thing to keep in mind when you certify someone's key is what you
think the chances are that their key will be compromised. These are
probably small in any case, but if they are using PGP offline, say on
a PC, things are much more secure.

I strongly advise everyone to read the PGP documents to fully
understand how to get the most from it.  Properly used, I'd say (and
I'm a cryptology geek) it's reasonably secure from any--including
government-- eavesdropping when used with 1024 bit keys. So far there
have been no weaknesses found in IDEA or RSA, requiring a cracking
effort of searching a 128 bit keyspace or bugging your apartment (more
likely, and much cheaper).

Sean

Has anyone tried sending sound bites of their favorite trance-style
  habbadasherie over the net? You can uuencode small snippets of sound
  (10 secs or so) at a low rate in one of several sound file formats
  nowadaze, and others can actually figger out for themselves what they
  like (would be a great supplement to album reviews!)

Most workstations can play back that stuff; I can play Sun/Next as well as
  SGI sound files, and newer PC's can do it too!  Some of the files would
  be big, but probably not much over 100k (c'mon, some of your more rabid
  typists crank out that kind of volume on a good day anywaze!)

How about (oh, mr behlen???) a repository of sound bites somewhere over on
  the raves machine site?  

Just trying to catch up . . .

Hello Everyone!

Well I'm finally back on the east coast... All I have to say about my trip
is that it was really good.  I did and saw things to many to mention..
well I decided to compile a list of things that I will remember for a while
instead of writing a story .. so here goes:

1. Going to a Rave Called Ananda and hearing CJ Bolland on the decks..
   it was an excellent rave at candlestick park that had music which
   just blew my head away.

2. Going to Your Sister's House straight from the airport and meeting a 
   bunch of friendly sf ravers.  Also hearing tara's set which featured
   some DJAX..

3. walking to every record store in town and getting some amazing records
   ..although I did score some german hard trance the best records were
   the domestics ..especially exist dance.

4. spending 5 hours in the exploritorium with criag, brian and miles.

5. Staying with cindy and having Jeno (the Cat) attack me at 6 oclock 
   in the morning..

6. watching Mystery Science Theatre 3000 at brian's place.. that was
   fun... :)

7. Driving up highway 1 and seeing Bonnie Doon.

that's all I can think of right now.. there was a lot more of course.
San Francisco is a great town. the people are friendly and the scene
seems really together.  Most importantly I would like to thank brian,
cindy and susie for letting me stay at their place and showing me around
town.  Also Bryce and Tamara who were great rave companions (remember 
lyons heheh).  I met a tremendous number of people.. A lot more than
I expected..Hopefully I will return very soon.. thanks to all of making
this a great trip...

take care,
oz

At  5:07 PM 8/25/93 +0100, Roy Badami wrote:
>Hmmm... the passphrase is important, but i was also assuming that
>you'dd attempot to keep your secret keyring physically secure....
>rather than relying on the pasphrase.... 
>
>In PGP, the passphrase is only an issue if someone else has access to
>your secret keyring... think of it as a second line of defense in case
>your secret key floppy should be lost or stolen.... but don't rely on
>it....  if you lose a copy of your secret keyring, then, if you're a
>cautious type, you'll issue a key compromize certificate even if
>there's no evidence that your passphrase has been compromized....

My main point was that the passphrase should not be discounted- even if you
keep your keyring on a floppy, it could be compromised on some systems, and
if you are mugged for it...with a hard-to-crack password at least your old
messages are secure.

>
>as for DES vs IDEA... personally i doubt that there's any NSA trapdoor
>in DES, and IDEA is a little too new for my liking.  That said, DES is

DES wa limited to a 56 bit key at the NSA's request... this makes me
wonder. I doubt that there is any true back door, but that limit makes me
think it is practical for them to break it, if they think it is worth it.

IDEA is new, but looks thoeretically very solid. Of course it is impossible
to say, but you take your chances with anything.

>getting rather small... exhaustive search of 2^56 keys is looking more
>and more plausible....  so it's swings and roundabouts....
>

As an example of how small, I saw a post on sci.crypt about a new program
(I think running on a Cray- limited access but there are enough of these
around for this to be significant) can run a brute-force passphrase search
on DES for all 6-letter passwords in about an hour, and all lowercase 6
letter passwords in bust under a minute. That is my point about passwords-
if you use a 14 or 18 character password that has no real words in it and
extra non-letter characters, it is, as you say, a second line of defence,
but a very improtant one.

jamie

Visuals at Progress last night were definitely above average.  Although 
nothing super technical (just a bunch of slide projectors, film loops,
overheads, etc.), it was very creatively done.  I usually get bored quick
with most visuals (of course I've yet to see the Aurgasm alchemy that
everyone seems to like so much :), but these were in a constant state of
metamorphosis.

I talked with the creator a bit, and he was quite open and friendly.  Last
year he did a Gathering and a Sharon, this year he's been doing a bunch of
smaller parties and of course he's at Progress every Tuesday.  He's
interested in more work so I offered to post his business card to the net.
I hope nobody minds.  


    orbital therapy
    multi-image light shows

Checked out Progress in San Jose last night with Johnny T.  It sure was nice
to get my beat fix without having to drive over an hour to the city to do it!
Got there about 11:00, but most people didn't show up 'til after 12:00.  

Rick Preston spun a pretty hot set, followed by (I think) Julius.  Have to 
say that I liked Preston better.  His set was pretty consistent and more my
flavor -- there were a couple of dance floor dropouts during Julius' set.  

It was on the small side, maybe 75 people, with maybe a third of that on the
dance floor max, but a good crowd for a week night and plenty enough for
the size of the space.  The smile factor was about a 2, but there was little
if no attitude and although people seemed to have beamed in without their 
Luv Phasors, there wasn't a *bad* vibe.  It was just a personal decision
whether or not to have a good time, and I did!

The sound was really clean and never got too loud.  The fog machine got a
little noxious at times, along with the cig smoke, but wasn't a constant
threat.  The visuals were definitely above average ++, more on that in
another post.  Oh yeah, and free water! :)

Overall, a good time for only $3 and a Tuesday night, which for me usually
involves domestic trivialities such as laundry and dishes.  :P  Looking 
forward to checking out Free Life next Monday...

At 12:29 PM 8/25/93 -0700, Gregor Mosheh, Administrator wrote:
>Hey, why not talk about PGP on SFR? Better than flame wars and much more
>appropriate for the scene and the "clientele" (if that's the right word
>here). I'm glad the thread has at least gotten interesting. Flame wars
>aren't my kind of fare. Of course, PGP isn't everyone's idea of stimulating
>convo, but everyone who uses e-mail should use PGP also, I think.
>

Sounds good then. I actually don't use it. I have had no 'need' for it thus
far, and if I did, I would probably use something like RIPEM/Mac (Yup, I'm
a mac head) for communication. Not quite as ubiquitous, and I think it will
become more of a standard, in only because companies won't be afraid to use
it because of legal issues. Face it- the companies drive this thing, and I
think that PGP will be dropped  by most people within a few years.
Commercial interests will build software with integrated public-key crypto,
it will be completely transparent, and that will be the end of PGP. (Plus,
macPGP's interface is lousy :)). Triple DES, while possibly not secure from
NSA, is fine for me (If the NSA cares enough about the tripe I talk about,
I _AM_ worried about this country. I understand the matter of principals in
this, but I have chosen other battles. Anyway, that is my non-technical
assessment of PGP.

jamie

From: edward.levitch@sfwmd.gov (Ed Levitch)

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Dave Scruton says:
> 
> Has anyone tried sending sound bites of their favorite trance-style
>   habbadasherie over the net? You can uuencode small snippets of sound

On 'sfraves.stanford.edu' there exists a directory called
'/pub/raves/song-samples' that contains song samples of 30 seconds or less
and have a size of 250k bytes or less.

To upload, place the sample file in '/pub/incoming'.

I have placed a uploaded a few Sun Sparc '.au' samples that are about
30 seconds long.  If you want to listen to the samples and don't have
something that will play this type of sample, you can convert it
to you favorite sound format using a conversion tool that I have
uploaded called 'sox'.

'sox' is public domain and will convert between must common sound
file formats on UNIX platforms.  Currently, the raw (no header),
IRCAM Sound Files .SF, Sound Blaster .VOC, SPARC .AU (w/header),
Mac HCOM, PC/DOS  .SOU, Sndtool,  and  Sounder, NeXT .SND,
Windows 3.1 RIFF/WAV, and Amiga/SGI AIFF and 8SVX formats are supported.

Listen and enjoy...

	Ed

From sfraves-owner  Wed Aug 25 15:25:47 1993

	id AA18702; Wed, 25 Aug 93 18:25:35 EDT
Date: Wed, 25 Aug 93 18:25:35 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9308252225.AA18702@pilot.njin.net>
To: jamiel@sybase.com (Jamie Lawrence)
Cc: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: PGP
In-Reply-To: <9308251816.AA01258@ralph.sybgate.sybase.com>
References: <9308251816.AA01258@ralph.sybgate.sybase.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Jamie Lawrence writes:
 > DES wa limited to a 56 bit key at the NSA's request... this makes me
 > wonder. I doubt that there is any true back door, but that limit makes me
 > think it is practical for them to break it, if they think it is worth it.

A lot of people are suspicious about this because all of the DES
design criteria are classified. This is reasonable from the NSA point
of view even if DES is secure since good design criteria is something
one would like to keep out of enemy hands.

Is DES secure? Expert cryptologists think so. They don't believe
shortening the keyspace to 56 bits weakened DES. Now they believe that
DES--even when used with 64 bit keys--has only 56 bits worth of
strength. They believe that the NSA shortened it to 56 bits to reduce
processing time.

Despite being extensively analyzed in hundreds of published papers by
the best cryptologists in the public world, DES' only shown weakness
to date is to a chosen plaintext attack, which reduced the keyspace
search by two bits. This doesn't affect it's practical security in the
real world where chosen plaintext is rarely available. More likely
they'd just bug your apartment.

DES's biggest weakness is probably its 56 bit keyspace which will
eventually fall to faster and faster computers.

Nonetheless, I like IDEA better because its design criteria is public
(and thus available for attack) and because of its inherent 128 bit
keyspace. DES isn't bad, according to big gun cryptologists, but
IDEA--as long as it resists attack--is better.

Sean

ObNonRaveyMandatorySFRPostContent:
The other day I was riding home on the freeway near Walnut Creek and
noticed what can only be called a "CHiPS" ticket quota machine.  There
were 6 CHP cruisers at the side of the road with their officers
walking the shoulder, pointing at drivers and waving them over.  What
they were ticketing most people for is unclear, since the traffic was
5 mph. bumper to bumper.  Anyway, this fat govt. goon points at me and
jerks his thumb in a smooth practiced motion towards the shoulder.  I
made sure to ride about 25 extra yards, making the pig walk up to my
bike (I was certain I had not broken any law-ha ha).  Haas walks up
and takes my licence, while I am noticing that these jokers are
keeping no fewer than 4 cars pulled over at any one time (during rush
hour!).  So Johnny Law sez: (in a Capt. Kirk type voice) "Are you,
are you wearing prescription sunglasses?"

"Shit.  Shit.  Shit.  Shit!"  A voice in my head says.  Although I
have 20/20-20/40 L/R vision, I was wearing my glasses when I took my
California drivers test.  So I get this ticket for driving w/o
my glasses.

I asked the officer why he pulled me over in the first place, and he
sorta beat around the bush.  Dickhead.

I'm going to court over this one.  Wish me luck!

-Howard "Fuck da police" Berkey

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


I'm not familliar with the precisise details of the PEM key
certification heirarchy, but the problem is, it requires you to
*trust* the certification authorities.

It's a really neat system, and it automates a lot of stuff, but it
means you have to trust the government.

Also, RSA won't allow anyone to take RSAREF (the cryptographic library
used by RIPEM) out of the US, because of export licence issues...
PGP, on the otherhand, is legal everywhere *except* the US (because of
US patents held by PKP).  Strange world, eh?

there's another cool song along these lines, not by F242, but someone else,
a group w/ only 1 well known song but the cut is called "Bushwacked",
and contains cut up samples of Bush speaking. They re-arrange what he
said in various speeches so that it says what he really meant all along,
quite brilliant, I'll try to remember who did it.  If you like the songs
mentioned in these posts, you'd probably be at least slightly amused by
"Bushwacked", music wasn't half-bad either.

i always find it kinda annoying when they do trippy "bad vibes" type
shit like spiders or other quasi-frightening type images; the industrial
types used to love this shit, and I got enough of it way back when.  it's
not a big thing, it's typically a "male" thing, (macho, etc.), and not
really "dangerous", but I don't see the value in it, and while I'll be
damned if anyone will bum my trip w/ *anything*, I could see less stalwart
souls being shaken by scary stuff under certain conditions...I just
shine it on, it's just those silly boys again...

  Southbay SFR Lunch Reminder
  
   
 Just a quick reminder to let everyone know about
 the weekly SFR Lunch ...
  
 When: Thursday, Aug. 26th   
 Time: 12.00 noon
 Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto
  
 Directions:
  
 * From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  
 * Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
   (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)
  
 * Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (past apartment complexes on right)
   
 * You will see the park on your right hand side. Park in the first
   carpark to your right.

At  6:25 PM 8/25/93 -0400, Sean Casey wrote:
>Jamie Lawrence writes:
> > DES wa limited to a 56 bit key at the NSA's request... this makes me
> > wonder. I doubt that there is any true back door, but that limit makes me
> > think it is practical for them to break it, if they think it is worth it.
>
>A lot of people are suspicious about this because all of the DES
>design criteria are classified. This is reasonable from the NSA point
>of view even if DES is secure since good design criteria is something
>one would like to keep out of enemy hands.

True, from the NSA point of view. But regardless of whether or not this is
the reason, it still brings up security through obscurity.

>Is DES secure? Expert cryptologists think so. They don't believe
                ^^^^^^                         ^^^^^
These words should probably have the word 'most' in front of them.
There are those who have thier doubts. (don't have refs on hand- sorry)


>shortening the keyspace to 56 bits weakened DES. Now they believe that
>DES--even when used with 64 bit keys--has only 56 bits worth of
>strength. They believe that the NSA shortened it to 56 bits to reduce

Where did this come from? that is interesting.

>processing time.

Color me paranoid, but I have my doubts. I think in the PGP documentation
there is a discussion of what we don't know about IBM and NSA's
interactions there, and PGP's author's doubts about it (DES).

>Despite being extensively analyzed in hundreds of published papers by
>the best cryptologists in the public world, DES' only shown weakness
>to date is to a chosen plaintext attack, which reduced the keyspace
>search by two bits. This doesn't affect it's practical security in the
>real world where chosen plaintext is rarely available. More likely
>they'd just bug your apartment.

True, but there is still no proof that DES _is_ secure, either.

>DES's biggest weakness is probably its 56 bit keyspace which will
>eventually fall to faster and faster computers.

Yep, and what adds to that is that is (as far as complex algorithms go) can
be implemented in pretty fast ways. Definitely double edged.

>Nonetheless, I like IDEA better because its design criteria is public
>(and thus available for attack) and because of its inherent 128 bit
>keyspace. DES isn't bad, according to big gun cryptologists, but
>IDEA--as long as it resists attack--is better.

I agree. The keyspace is the deciding factor for me as well.  BTW, where is
a good source for the design criteria? I would like to look at it.

>Sean

jamie

At 10:50 AM 8/26/93 +0100, Roy Badami wrote:
>I'm not familliar with the precisise details of the PEM key
>certification heirarchy, but the problem is, it requires you to
>*trust* the certification authorities.

Yep. I think that this is what is going to make it a standard. Flaws, true,
but a well structured hierarchy creates standards (and heinous monsters).

>It's a really neat system, and it automates a lot of stuff, but it
>means you have to trust the government.

Menas you have to trust a cirtification heirarchy. This means the
governement how, but there are other heirarchies emerging. The RPIEM Mac
decumentation has email addresses for a couple experimental servers. There
are a couple of weaknesses in it, and nonheirarchical distribution patterns
like PGP's privides the possibility for more checks on a possible forgery
through the fact that different people will probably have different keys
and can crosscheck, belonging to a couple different heirarchies using PEM
provides a similar service. Also, PEM heirarchies make forgeries harder in
the first place (thoeretically; the problem is that right now ( could
register in your name, assuming you haven't already. Don't know how that
will be solved. Identity proofing... hm.)

>Also, RSA won't allow anyone to take RSAREF (the cryptographic library
>used by RIPEM) out of the US, because of export licence issues...
>PGP, on the otherhand, is legal everywhere *except* the US (because of

True, but you know that legal issues have stopped its 'exporting' as much
as they have stopped PGP's use here... And I do think that commercial
interests will force export licence issues to loosen soon enough for it to
take on. This is idle seculation, but one has to bet on something...

>US patents held by PKP).  Strange world, eh?

You said it. Twisted...

jamie

Message-Id: <25728.9308261716@wundt.harlequin.co.uk>
To: jamiel@sybase.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: Jamie Lawrence's message of Thu, 26 Aug 1993 10:09:00 -0800 <9308261707.AA22668@ralph.sybgate.sybase.com>
Subject: Re: Jamie's Post
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


  Jamie> (thoeretically; the problem is that right now ( could
  Jamie> register in your name, assuming you haven't already. Don't
  Jamie> know how that will be solved. Identity proofing... hm.)

No problem.  The PEM standards require each registering autority to
issue a statement as to what checks they make on the identity of the
applicant before issuing a key.  That means that any user who
retrieves a key from an authority can make his own decision as to
whether or not the level of security provided by the authority is
adequate.  (This assumes, of course, that the authority itself, is
trustworthy...)

  Jamie> True, but you know that legal issues have stopped its 'exporting' as much
  Jamie> as they have stopped PGP's use here... And I do think that commercial
  Jamie> interests will force export licence issues to loosen soon enough for it to
  Jamie> take on. This is idle seculation, but one has to bet on something...

Actually, there'd be no problem with someone outside the US
implementing an RSA library that is compatible with RSAREF.  I believe
RIPEM itself (without RSAREF) can be exported....


	Cosmic

insecticide. Rave long and hard. It worked for me!

>While were asking about artists of 'sampling' songs,
>does anybody know the name of the group who did a
>parity of U2's "I still haven't found what I'm looking for"
>with samples of Casey Casem bitching at his producer ?

The group is called Negetiveland; I've heard the cut that that your talking
about, it's all these "off the air" production outtakes of Kasem obscenely debasing
various tired pop music song formats.  Quite a turnaround for someone you
usually hear brightly promoting the latest pop megarelease!

Incidently, Negetiveland got into a bit of trouble sampling U2, as well as
reproducing Kasem's tirades -- resulted in all sorts of legal difficulties which
they go into great detail about on their liner notes.  It's a pretty in-depth
discussion of copyright law, sampling, etc. actually...

-jon2p

        "Carl A. Wescott" <eyethink@cis.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Re: Atomic Rooster 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Thu, 26 Aug 93 13:08:42 PDT."
             <9308262008.AA12120@cassy.lurnix.com> 
Date: Thu, 26 Aug 93 16:07:46 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


There was a small soundsystem set up in the back of a pickup yestereday
before and after the shoreline shows. Hung out there after-show and got
in my 1/2hr of ravercise for the day. At most 10-15 people dancing,
more standing around and watching from "afar"... I asked and they said
they weren't assoc'd with atomic rooster. One of the guys assoc'd w/
the event handed me a "burning man" flyer, and another handed me
something w/ the TAZ # (SOLS-666 or whatever) on it -- so perhaps this
group is associated w/ TAZ?

I kinda promised myself i wouldn't waste my money on another Dead show,
but when some amazinglyclose tickets became available at face-value, I
went for it.

The show was pleasant enough at first... but... perhaps it's just that
I wasn't dosed, but the show really started grating on me near the end
(bad musicianship, total inability to sing, combined w/ overloud
distortion coming from what seemed to be a blown speaker stack). So
despite the fact that it was "socially" interesting, visually
stimulating, and a fun party, the music began to bore/grate on me near
the end.

In that respect, coming out and hearing non-rock-and-roll
non-sub-120-bpm house/techno/rave music in the parking lot was a
blessing. A nice way to cap off the evening.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

No, just that my mother-in-law doesn't have net access.  Janie
can be reached at jlf3@attmail.com.

ObRave: Insects, reptiles, and all biological organisms certainly 
belong within the realm of raver consciousness.  The forces in
society that have trained us to consider these creatures as 
repulsive are the same forces that have taught us to rape the
environment and practice bigotry towards fellow humans.  For me,
raving is a celebration of all life.  Rhythms exist in every
aspect of nature and I look forward to seeing Gregg's electron
scanning microscope photos at future raves.

	id AA21281; Thu, 26 Aug 93 14:06:25 PDT
Message-Id: <9308262106.AA21281@slamdance.us.oracle.com>
From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
Subject: This Week's SF Rave Guide!
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFRaves)
Date: Thu, 26 Aug 93 14:06:24 PDT
Cc: sfraves-calendar@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFR Calendar)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



I didn't get much new for this weekend 'cause SOMEONE STOLE MY WALLET
w/my driver's license, and I couldn't go out much this week.  Thanks
to Philip and Jessica and others for contributing a few flyers, though.

Tonight, at Your Sisters' House, ne-raves' and sfraves' own Laura will
be spinning, maybe early, so don't miss it!  I don't know what
the deal w/Xanadu is, the phone message doesn't say anything about the
SF event.  Funky Tekno Tribe will be big - the Galleria is a kinda 
interesting place, but this isn't quite an underground.  Planet Drum has
a good lineup, I think it'll be in the South Bay.

I've heard good things about Corduroy City (plus it includes Synergy
visuals) and the Fridge, so maybe it's a good week to check those out.
Mission Rock is fun, but be careful if you go - there have been several
acts of violence outside recently.

If I get more flyers at YSH tonight, I'll post an addendum.

Here are some weeklies - whether or not they count as real "raves" is 
debatable, but they were advertised by flyers and the music could be
good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their appropriateness 
in being on the list, let me know.  Also let me know when any of them end...

Subject: Bad Car Night At YSH
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Bad Car Night At YSH 
 or
How to spend $20+ at YSH

 I got to Your Sister's House at 11:15AM . I parted in a side street 
alongside a whole bunch of other cars - unfortunetly , we all didn't
notice the "No Parking 12midnight to 2AM sign." When I got to my truck
at 12:30AM , a $20 ticket was on all our windshields. 

 Another SFRaver had an even worst auto problem - getting into a fender
bender right next at the corner ! Niels was OK , although his left
rear fender has a 2" deep , plate sized dent.

 Auto abuse aside, YSH was great! I had at least two sublime moments
tonight - once while dancing to Jan Cooley's mixing, and the other 
listening to the drummers in the basement. 

 Nice to see some familiar SFRavers , and the folks from "back east"
as well. I was the guy in the grey shirt with the red crab on my back.
I left at 4AM - all danced out , even though the music was still
playing!

 No work today - so off to bed I go ....

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

--

>  Another SFRaver had an even worst auto problem - getting into a fender

> rear fender has a 2" deep , plate sized dent.

Geez!  Yesterday must have been Bad Transpo Karma Day or something...
Still mad from my B.S. ticket the other day, I got in a pretty bad
motorcycle accident on 680 yesterday.  (I'm OK... the bike and I
parted ways quite nicely.  The bike, however, it damn near destroyed
:-(  )

The worst thing was, I was about to get off the freeway and could
actually see my cubicle from where I bit it.   My boss saw it all, he
thought I was dead.  I was pretty lucky.

I considered going to YSH anyway but I was too sore.  Stayed home and
went on an alcohol and tylenol binge and read E-Mail. :-)

I'll be limping to interop today... Hopefully I'll run into (no pun
intended) Geoff & co. 

C'ya!

-H-

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: San Jose is still getting brighter.
Date: Fri, 27 Aug 93 09:07:58 -0700
From: vivianm@src.dec.com
X-Mts: smtp
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Oasis is Downtown San Jose was totally going off last night. It was 
the best I have ever seen it. 
The DJ line up was fantastic. Not necessarily in this order:  Marky 
Mark, Spun, Jeno, Garth.  There was so much energy it was like being 
at an event.  The last song, they turned on the lights, and everyone 
was still going.  It was the best crowd too.  I think a lot of people 
came down from the city.  
After the club closed there was a party in a wherehouse in Santa 
Clara, that was going off almost as much as Oasis. We finally left 
at about 4 am, and there were people still arriving.  (Amazingly 
enough I am here at work writing this).  Anyway, i just wanted to 
pass this info along to anyone who doesn't necessarily want to make 
the long drive to San Franciso on a Thursday night.  




vivianm

"A really hot time!"
          - Anonymous raver

"The place was really cookin'..."
          - Entertainment Tonight

"I felt right at home!"
          - Louis Cypher


Well as we kind of suspected all along, Laura came into town and
blasted some poor SF raver's bodies into total neuralmuscular overload
with that fast East Coast style. Everybody *loved* it. Wow, Laura.

This week's YSH was held in a small not-very-well-ventilated venue
which concentrated those raver-generated BTUs into an amazingly Amazon
jungle-like environment.

The usual YSH wonderful positive vibes and great crowd contributed to
the usual good time. If you haven't been there, go!

Sean

YES!,

     I must agree with Vivianm.  Last night at the 'O' was one of the most
pumped nights there in a while.  Major smile factor and this was everyone not
just a few people.  Only two DJs played Markie Mark and Garth.  They played
with a vengance.  I haven't had that much fun or danced that much at a party in
ages.  The Vibe was flowin'.  Mini rave on a Thursday night is what it was. 
Peace to all who participated and those who didn't!

Today's vocabulary lesson, courtesy of Prof Drukman:

  RAVIN n  1) the act or practice of being a predator 2) something seized or
           devoured as a prey

           'The sight of lions feasting upon their bloody *ravin* in the game
           preserve quickly banished any Bambi-ish notions of wildlife that
           we may have harbored.'


/j/

From sfraves-owner  Fri Aug 27 11:03:05 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

Subject: YSH last night...
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Fri, 27 Aug 93 11:02:54 PDT
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

the first thing that comes to my mind about last night is....

wow.

this was my third YSH, and by far the best one for me...

firstly, i just want to say that the discussion group is a really great
idea - at least people were talking, interacting, communicating, and 
enjoying the exchange of ideas & opinions.


and the music...amazing

Laura came on at 11, and to say her set blew me away is an
understatement. *INCREDIBLE* 
fast, yet trancy, & amazingly powerful - i just let myself get lost in
the music...the rhythm was pounding into me & i was loving it.

and to my pleasant surprise, after the DJ after her suddenly left, she
came on again. 

I haven't danced so hard, so long, or enjoyed myself so much in a very long
time...

her music made me feel really happy inside, full of energy, and it moved me
until i had sweat pouring in my eyes and my feet and muscles were completely
sore, but i had a huge grin on my face the entire time...8-)

and the DJ after Laura's second set kept me going until about 3:30 - 
i danced to oblivion 8-)

and the people were wonderful - evrywhere i looked, & met someone's eyes,
they would smile back, & that made me feel really really good.

hellos to everyone there...it was nice seeing both old and new faces 8-)

minor gripe- the dance floor got too overcrowded, and really hot as a result,
but then, i like to take up a lot of room when i dance 8-)

it's events like this that remind me what first attracted me to raving...

and i'm still wearing a grin, despite an 8am physics lecture this morning-
and people stared at me wondering how in hell i could be so happy this early
in the morning...8-)


-jo

>that sounds like NegativLand (sp?), a little prank they had
>industry giants (MONSTERS?!?!?) U2 and their record co. (Virgin?
>or was it Island?  any U2 fans out there?) suing them over.  I
>think Casey might have sued (or tried to sue) them as well.

Negativland released the "U2 NEGATIVLAND" single and got sued because
of the COVER ART - not the song.  Basically, it has "U2" in huge
letters (over a U2 spy plane) and "Negativland" in much smaller
letters.  Island Records (not U2, not Casey Kasem) sued SST and
Negativland over it.  They settled out of court - Negativland
basically just rolled over and played dead because they are a tiny
band and couldn't afford the kind of high priced entertainment lawyer
that Island could.  (Island retained the guy who represents Madonna
for this case, incidentally.)  Negativland were ordered to destroy all
unsold copies, the master tapes, glass masters & stamper molds...

After all this, SST Records sued Negativland because they wanted
Negativland to pay all the legal fees, which isn't in their contract,
btw.  I don't know what happened with that suit.

>Good show by NL, IMHO...

They don't think so.

The whole regrettable story can be read in U2's magazine/CD "The
Letter U and the Numeral Two".

BTW, Negativland have a new album out called "FREE" (which is public
domain, btw!).  It was subsidized by donations from fans.  You should
buy it because they need the money.

Jon Drukman                                      jdrukman%dlsun87@us.oracle.com
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Always note the sequencer - this will never let us down.

My friend John had never been to a Grateful Dead show or a r*** so
last night I double-newbied him :)  We arrived at YSH around 1:30
to find it hot, packed and sort of not happening very much.  He
was wiped and took off around 2, right around the time things began
picking up.  It was at the Railway Spine Gallery on Howard, a nice
but not very ventilated space.  We had a visit from the local
gendarmes around 3 am but things continued until about 4.  Jan Cooley
gamely played on through the heat and occasional inadvertent jostling
of the DJ table and scratchy vinyl and all that.  Got quite good for
about half an hour but the place was really too small and traffic too
constant through the dancing area down the middle to get a seriou
gruve going.  

I missed Laura's set unfortunately but did say hi to her, Brian, Derek,
Larry, Sean, Geoff and some other folks.  A good sweaty time sez I,
a nice contrast to the GD scene where I love the music but for some
reason feel pretty wiped when I leave.  After YSH and a good shower
I felt great, tho!

Not sure where I'll be this weekend.  One more Grateful Dead show and
Phish tomorrow at the Greek in the conventional mode, maybe Funky Tekno
Tribe or even Bulletproof in the expanded mode ;-)

You can start out by getting Hardfloor's album "TB Resuscitation" (an import),

My friend and I were sitin around last night and we came to the realization
that we (humans) are at an all-out, no-rules, hardcore war against bugs.
We take over the land that they exist on, exterminate them, squish them, use
chemical warfare on them (including using planes and helicopters, make 
comercials showing robot/human cyborgs ala robo cop killing them (negative
publicity media campaign), drive around in trucks with huge plastic spiders
on the door or monopoly-man-looking-guy-with-hammer about to smash bugs as
symbols of the war, etc.  We went on for a half an hour thinking up examples
such as these and tripping on the way we think of them as the invaders, always
trying to get into our shit when from their "viewpoint" we come and plop all
our shit in their way and then kill them when they get into it.

As for visuals, I think it would be cool to see other facets of nature such
as plants and rocks.

-Mark

hey all,

--------------------
You can start out by getting Hardfloor's album "TB Resuscitation" (an import)
--------------------

anybody interested in some discussion of records?  i've heard alot of
stuff but often have trouble finding it/figuring out what it was, etc.

on the other hand my 12" addiction has recently branched out from
"strictly hard core rap" to include house and related stuff (techno,
etc.).  one of *my* problems is, that while i have "good ears", I
don't know the sub-genres very well (for ex., breakbeat to me implies
old school rap/hip hop like Treacherous 3, Funky-Four, Sugar Hill,
T-Ski Valley, Bambata (sp?), etc., which is NOT what i suspect is
being referred to when discussions on this list refer to breakbeat).

on the lighter side, i have recently acquired some groovy new 12" house
records that y'all might be interested in...so anybody interested?

i'll start off by mentioning a couple that i can remember (they're
at home, so i'll have to bring in a list of 'em) that i really liked,
maybe if some informed sould out there recognizes 'em, they'll let me know
the proper terms for discussion, and what classification is practical
(i.e. prog, trance, hcore, etc.)

Verde Sative: The Positive Cult EP

this is (i suspect) progressive house, has 4 mixes, kinda "jazzy" in 
feel, and I like it alot.  It is not very techno-y, not to many gated
a-a-a-a-a-a-ah type keyboards, vocals etc, kinda has some cool percussion,
medium tempo (for house) and i suspect wopuld fit into houseier styles at
events here.  i've heard stuff like this at groove kitchen.

Jeek!:  Ragga

This is great, has REALLY cool mixes that build in energy very well, great
percussion, normal intruments (non synth, non-techno), and has both house
and dancehall mixes...

i'll post a better review next week....later!

*

I've often wondered if my impression of what people are talking about when
they refer to styles of house/techno is close to others'.  Here's what _I'd_
call certain sets from the Come/Unity tapes...
Spun: Funky trance
Jeno: Deep trance
I don't hear any of what I'd call straight up hardcore or acid there.

Anyway, if anyone knows any better, or especially has some track IDs from
those sets, I'd be grateful.  Some of the stuff on Spun's set especially
really tweeks my head.  Most of the stuff I remember enjoying at Deep Space
and other places made it in there, and the rest made it into Jeno and Garth's
set (thy both played a bit of that "breakbeat with sine-wave bass and a
really distorted set of organ/guitar hits over it").  The only exception
is a bit of insane breakbeat, sounding basically like several slightly
different sampled measures of someone whacking out a (well-recorded)
godlike funky 4, mostly naked but with an occasional figure that sounds
like four descending crunchy guitar chords or, hell, I don't know, but I
*NEVER* can figure out what this is because all few times I've heard it
I'm dancing like a demon and don't get to look over the DJ table until 
a few tracks later when I've cooled down.

It's frustrating not knowing anything about the music you like.  I guess
the answer is "go to more raves", but I'd still like to pick up what I
can.

Any other naming conventions for stuff on the C/U or Connection II tape
sets?  Tx // g

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

 Hello Folks!

 For any SFSFRavers out there ( San Francisco Ravers who are also into
Science Fiction ) , you might be interested in the one-page write-up
on ConFrancisco in the latest issue ( Aug. 23rd ) of MicroTimes. 
A more detailed , but much harder to read , daily schedule is available
via anonymous ftp from gandalf.rutgers.edu , in the pub.sfl directory -
get the "ConFrancisco.Program" file. It's the tentative daily schedule,
subject to last minute changes.

 ConFrancisco is the 1993 edition of WorldCon , the annual world science
fiction and fantasy convention. It's being held in San Francisco during
the Labor Day weekend , starting Thursday afternoon.

 I've managed to get a meeting approved for the convention - it's
presently titled "Non-Rave" - it's a chance for people who are science
fiction/fantasy fans who are also ravers to get together and exchange 
experiences , and maybe music!

 I could still use some slides and videotapes , if anyone's got 'em.
I have and FMR videotape and a Connection I ( Bonny Doon ) videotape.

 If you're going - hope to see you there!

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

--

I received some interesting mail from "jsl@netcom.com"
recently that I thought you should all see, so I'm
forwarding it.  

Some context: after jsl's post about "Tweekers Anonymous", I
sent him a short message, which as I remember it was
something like:

"Being your usual mature, sensitive self I see.  I thought
you'd promised to pack it in?  Maybe you should think about
forming Flamers Anonymous."

He sent me a long note, which I unfortunately don't have.
It included all of his usual catch phrases.  Told me I was
"mistaken", stated I was obviously a tweeker, told me to
"consider myself checked!", and in passing asked me to not
send him any mail.

I thought he was just trying to piss me off, so I sent him a
two liner acting bored.  He quotes it below, repeating his
request that I not write to him, and I sent a note agreeing
not to write to him (probably I shouldn't have, but I have a
fairly dumb sense of humor.)

The exchanges below seem interesting to me in a number a
ways.  He gets very legalistic, accusing me of "harrassing"
him, makes dire threats of reporting me to the authorities,
and so on.  He claims to have asked me not to write to him
"several" times, when it was really twice.  (His last
two pieces of mail came on top of each other, I didn't reply
in between.)

Personally, I've been convinced that jsl deserves to be
taken seriously, and I'd recommend thinking twice before
associating with him in any way.  I keep wondering if he's
something like a "wolf in ravers clothing", so here I am
crying "wolf"...  but mostly I think you should just read
the following and make your own conclusions.

Sorry if it seems like I'm just bringing a flame war to the
net, but I did think you all might want to know about this. 

(By the way, if anyone has reservations about posting
"private" email to the net, I'd be glad to discuss that via
email.  Briefly, I believe someone who sends you mail is
trusting you to use your discretion, but you aren't sworn to
secrecy about it.) 

Date: Wed, 25 Aug 93 07:01:22 -0700

Look,  I have asked you not to send me mail.  Please respect my wishes, as
I have really no use in conversing with you.  I am serious.  Please refrain
from sending me mail, and  I will do likewise.

Thanks,
John

Date: Thu, 26 Aug 93 07:19:52 -0700
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
To: doom@banneker.Stanford.EDU
Subject: The next level....


Mr. Brenner,

I have asked you several times to stop sending me e-mail, yet you continue to think that my request is some form of joke.  Well sir, rest assured it is not.  Harassment on any computer network, especially if it originated from a school can get ugly.
I do not want to write a letter campaignto your sys admin, or your dean letting him know of such abuses (since I have saved each communique between us) since I believe all it would accomplish is the silencing of you.  I do not want that to happen at all.
What I would like is total non-communication between us.  Why?  Look you don't respect me.  I could care less that you disagree with the many things I say, but respect of the individual is another matter.
Once Again I ask that you refrain from leaving me mail.  If you do not I can call you and discuss this matter further.  Meet you face to face to discuss this matter futher, or call/write/talk to your Dean and make him aware of my concerns.

A non-reply will mean that you have complied with my wishes, and I can leave it at that.  ANy other form of communication between us will be considered a breach of my request and I will take action to ensure I am no longer harassed by you electronically.

Consider this a final warning.

Thank you,
John S. Lee

From sfraves-owner  Sun Aug 29 20:36:46 1993

	id AA12064; Sun, 29 Aug 93 23:35:17 EDT
Date: Sun, 29 Aug 93 23:35:17 EDT
From: abbe@bronze.lcs.mit.edu (John C. Abbe aka Rademir)
Message-Id: <9308300335.AA12064@bronze.lcs.mit.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Drug laws and FIJA
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hmm..
Are any of you aware of FIJA, the Fully Informed Jury Association/Amendment?

The historical duty of juuries includes judging the law itself, both
in general and as to whether they judge that it should apply in the
given case. This duty has never ben legally revoked (it's hard to
imagine that happening...), but knowledg of it has all but disappeared
and judges have been allowed to instruct juries that that is *not* 
within their power.

So...many people have recently taken this up to publicize it, one method
being to hand out leaflets outside of courthouses around the time that
propspective jury members show up.

I have more info if anyone's interested. I could bring it to a YSH
(unfortunately not this week's).Do your friends have a trial date
yet, Geoff?

--John

Umm, I hate to tell you all this, but what I played was *HARDLY* hardcore.
What I play we consider to be on the harder side of trance, and I had most
of it pitched down by about -3 to -4 for you all.

	"Meltdown" - Radiation [Direct Drive, USA]
	"Debugged" - SDL [Labworks, Germany]

From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug 30 07:46:09 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA03534; Mon, 30 Aug 93 07:46:09 PDT
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA03527; Mon, 30 Aug 93 07:46:07 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA29028; Mon, 30 Aug 93 07:46:18 -0700
Date: Mon, 30 Aug 93 07:46:18 -0700
Message-Id: <9308301446.AA29028@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Funky Technotribe....
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

A big party.  The sound was not the best.  It was held in the Galleria,
lots of people who were 21-- (this was an all ages event...no id required).
 At 3:00 a.m. they turned off the music to enforce the cabaret license laws
"...will everyone clear the building...one you have left we will let you
back in..."..."the crowd yelled "...how old!?!?"...someone over the
loudspeaker said "21...".  Lots of boos. Phil Smart did play a great boomin
set,  I left @ 5:00.  The breakup ruined a building vibe.  Things at
parties that are getting a bit annoying:

- people have now decided that "hoofing" is a spectator sport (you know,
where those guys, primarily from sj, form a big circle and do the fancy
footworks).  They take up larger, and larger portions of the dance floor
making the space difficult to dance in.  I don't mind the dancing at all,
it's the spectators that see it as their duty to make the big ring
(sometimes 6 people deep), to watch the spectacle.

- rude, rude pushing people.  gone are the days when you'd get pushed or
stepped on and someone would say excuse me.

Overall it was an OK party.  Hope they don't get it shut down next time.

------------------

Boat Party Beach Blanket Bingo,

This is one of the few good things on the scene. That boat was going off
from the time it set sail, until it docked.  Markie fucked it up! :),
moonpup did the do downstairs (great disco set btw :), Felix did the do
after markie...I dunno who came on before markie, but he was playing some
good hip-hop.

By the time the Starship Stoopid came to dock there were nothing left but
victims :).  Many had passed out...most were STILL going off after the
music stopped....that was one giggin' party!.  Now these fools are getting
ready for the full moon tonight...the madness in SF never ceases!

----------

Ugliness to come:  Basics, Wicked, et. al. Too much juice....

                 from the village of jsl@netcom.com

In-Reply-To: John C. Abbe aka Rademir's message of Sun, 29 Aug 93 23:35:17 EDT <9308300335.AA12064@bronze.lcs.mit.edu>
Subject: Drug laws and FIJA
Reply-To: jdrukman%dlsun87@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>Are any of you aware of FIJA, the Fully Informed Jury Association/Amendment?

yes, i am.

>The historical duty of juuries includes judging the law itself, both
>in general and as to whether they judge that it should apply in the
>given case. This duty has never ben legally revoked (it's hard to
>imagine that happening...)

possibly because it's guaranteed in the constitution.

>but knowledg of it has all but disappeared and judges have been
>allowed to instruct juries that that is *not* within their power.

and any lawyer that attempts to even *mention* it gets slapped with
"contempt of court."  they passed *that* into law.  (they couldn't
revoke the law that was really irking them, so they made it illegal to
talk about it!  lovely country we live in.)

this law was originally written up during Vietnam when too many juries
acquitted draft dodgers because the people on the jury didn't agree
with the war.

it is *definitely* legal for a jury to vote its conscience, not just
the law!  tell everyone you know.  if you ever have jury duty, tell
your fellow prospective jurors...

Jon Drukman                                      jdrukman%dlsun87@us.oracle.com

Always note the sequencer - this will never let us down.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Aug 30 09:14:33 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA03890; Mon, 30 Aug 93 09:14:33 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA03881; Mon, 30 Aug 93 09:14:30 PDT
Received: by netcom3.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA07111; Mon, 30 Aug 93 09:14:46 -0700
Date: Mon, 30 Aug 93 09:14:46 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <9308301614.AA07111@netcom3.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Funkey techno report
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

  Pigs!  Pigs and more pigs!!  is the word at this rave.   We got there
about midnight which I introduced a friend to raving for the first time.

  Sometime around 2 am,   the pigs closed the place down,  and kicked
everyone out because for some reason the promoters had failed to screen
out 21- folks.   So,  everyone left the Galleria and was grouped outside,
which in my opinion was a BAD IDEA,  as it left a bad head trip on most
folks.   For the most part,   they took it in stride,   but eventually
everyone was allowed back in,  and the music started up again.

  Towards the end,  the DJ was really hopping,  and the sets were very 
long,   and it was the point where the dancing sorta seperated the men
from the boys.    

  Another PIG incident took place on the dancing stage where this older
black guy was really dancing wonderfully,  when two cops can in and
forcefully pulled him from the dance floor.    Has anyone gotten any word
as to why they picked on this dude??    He wasn't doing anything,   they
just went up and took him away.

  After Boogie Buffet,   towards the later part of the afternnon,   we mosied
down to the beach rave at the end of Sloat,  where I got in yet another hours
worth of dancing where once again the pigs came and shut it down.    They said
that NO amplified music was allowed on the beach.

  So,  it appears that more and more faschism insanity is happening in this
country,  which explains my most of my hip friends are moving to Amsterdam.

  As far as this no-amplified music is concerned,  I have a way to get around
that,  and we did this in Peoples park in the early 80's.    We used a good
quality
sterio FM transmitter,   and plugged in the sound source,  and everyone brought
boom boxes.    So,  as a standby,   if we get busted again,  we could remove
the
amplifiers,  and plug in the transmitter.   Then people with good quality car
sound systems can crank up their sub-whoofers,   and everyone bring their
boom-boxes and we can boogie.

  As far as obtaining transmitters are concerned,  there is this dude in
Berkeley
who started a workshop on how to build one.    His name is Steve Dunnifer,  who
you all will read about soon in nect issue of Mondo-2000.    He holds a
workshop
on how to build a small 5 watt transmitter (Don't know about it's sound
quality),
every two weeks in Berkeley.    The info number is (510) 464-3041 and you can
leave a message if anyone is interested in building several of these.   The
cost
is minimal (Less than $50 to build),  and will make it possible to get around
the "No amplification" rules (because thay haven't outlawed radios yet).

  I will be contacting Carlos soon and will gice this idea to him,  and if
anyone
else knows the other DJ's Pse pass this info on to them.   So lets stop this
faschism and rave on...

Cheers
CC
