grigsby sez:

>I've often wondered if my impression of what people are talking about when
>they refer to styles of house/techno is close to others'.  Here's what _I'd_
>call certain sets from the Come/Unity tapes...
>Spun: Funky trance
>Jeno: Deep trance
>I don't hear any of what I'd call straight up hardcore or acid there.

spun is really on the hip-hop/funk/miami bass tip.  that track with
the really low bass note and the voice going "ignition" is a total
miami bass thing.  jeno tends to go for jazzier but still funky stuff.
descriptions are pretty useless.

>(thy both played a bit of that "breakbeat with sine-wave bass and a
>really distorted set of organ/guitar hits over it").

that's "chile of the bass generation" by mental cube (otherwise known
as The Future Sound Of London).

for whomever to go in the circle.  It doesn't bother me as much when 
there is plenty of room to dance, but when we are all crammed like 
sardines while the circle is hamming it up with their fancy dance 
steps, I get annoyed.  


Just my opinion.

Date: Mon, 30 Aug 93 09:47:09 PDT
From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Drug laws
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Attorney General Janet Reno was considering a few weeks ago sending
out a letter from her office to all the Appeals Court judges informing
them that it was the intent of the AG office to have mandatory
sentencing guidelines repealed entirely.  Cooler heads prevailed,
though.  Her staff is preparing a suggested reformation for unveiling
September 15th.  She was quoted in the Chronicle as saying that she
doesn't believe that a first time drug offender should go to jail at
all, and she also thinks that even a second time offender should get
off with minimal punishment provided that both crimes involved mere
posession.  She seems to agree with many judges and lawyers that minor
drug cases with mandatory jail time are filling the jails and putting
violent criminals (robbery, rape) out on the street sooner.

This combined with the reduction in LSD penalties (carrier no longer
factors into weight) starting November 1st (?? I believe ??) seems to
indicate a shift in policy in Washington... but I guess we'll see when
this finishes playing out.

Bob

>  As far as this no-amplified music is concerned,  I have a way to get around
>that,  and we did this in Peoples park in the early 80's.    We used a good
>quality
>sterio FM transmitter,   and plugged in the sound source,  and everyone brought
>boom boxes.    So,  as a standby,   if we get busted again,  we could remove
>the
>amplifiers,  and plug in the transmitter.   Then people with good quality car
>sound systems can crank up their sub-whoofers,   and everyone bring their
>boom-boxes and we can boogie.
>
>  As far as obtaining transmitters are concerned,  there is this dude in
>Berkeley
>who started a workshop on how to build one.    His name is Steve Dunnifer,  who
>you all will read about soon in nect issue of Mondo-2000.    He holds a
>workshop
>on how to build a small 5 watt transmitter (Don't know about it's sound
>quality),
>every two weeks in Berkeley.    The info number is (510) 464-3041 and you can
>leave a message if anyone is interested in building several of these.   The
>cost
>is minimal (Less than $50 to build),  and will make it possible to get around
>the "No amplification" rules (because thay haven't outlawed radios yet).
>
>  I will be contacting Carlos soon and will gice this idea to him,  and if
>anyone
>else knows the other DJ's Pse pass this info on to them.   So lets stop this
>faschism and rave on...
>
>Cheers
>CC
>

What I don't understand about mandatroy sentencing and the law is:  Why do
people stick around for these sentences?  If I was looking at hard time, i.e.,
5, 10, or 20 years of my young life, as in you get out and you've missed your
20s, I would leave and wait for statute of limitations to run out.  Or at least
I think I would.  What is the reason that I must be overlooking why people
don't do this?  Why stick around and let assholes put you in jail like that?

By the way, if we all know these people, is there any reason not to mention
who they are?  I mean, they've already been busted, right?  And it's not 
exactly gossuping, seems important to know who we should be supporting.

chief, and assembly members. I'm tired of seeing my money wasted while
this country slides further and further. Maybe if I explain how their
campaign contributions and votes depend on reform they'll listen with
a few brain cells. Maybe. But somebody's got to start doing something
about it.

From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Message-Id: <9308301913.AA11880@slack>
Subject: Hoofing and Hip Hop
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SF Raves)
Date: Mon, 30 Aug 1993 13:13:00 -0600 (MDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL22]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1979      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

This last Friday, we did a commercial hip-hop dance in still yet another
attempt to pay off our Meat Beat debt.  We didn't use the TASTE name at all,
just my contacts and production skills.  After the pie was divided between the
clothing shop we were working with, the radio station, and the piss-poor DJs I
was somehow convinced into hiring by the clothing shop, we ended up with $1000
to bring our debt down to $500.  So I guess it was worth it, but in other
senses, it wasn't.  Why?

1. Four fights.  We stopped the event after the last one at midnight.

2. Attitude, attitude, attitude.  It really sucked to see all these kids just
standing around.  Of course, the music wasn't great because I was selling
colas most of the night instead of pumping the sound system ;-).  But the
"hoofing" thingy was in full force.  Kids even rushed the stage at one point.
I would estimate that most of the night, only about 10 people out of 700 were
dancing at one time.

3. The biggest sound system we've ever rented and I didn't get an entire
minute to play with it.  I put on Strange Cargo for 30 seconds after the event
was over, before the cops *WE HIRED* told me to shut it off.

4. Drive by shooting while we were cleaning up.  A couple of kids in the
parking lot got hit in the legs.  This was the largest bummer of all.  What
amazed me was to see the ambulance arriving at the scene, with the *LIGHTS
OFF* and the cops *LEAVING* as soon as the shooting happened.

There were about three kids that came up to the concession booth saying how
they just wanted to dance and were disappointed at the crowd.  We told them
they were attending the wrong events :-), then we took down their addresses.

I'm looking forward to seeing everyone at Fluid Groove on the 5th.  Mike
Perkowitz and Mary stayed at my house that night on their way across the
country.  Looks like a genuine net.gathering is going to happen.

I'm also really psyched for Garth and Carlos with Taste on the 25th 8^)!!

Hey, I have no great love of the police, but try to remember that while there
are some macho, power-hungry, small pricked cops out there, most of them are
just honest guys and women trying to do their jobs. It's political pressures
that determine where the emphasis of law-enforcement lies, I'm sure the 
individual police officers have very little to do with deciding who they're
going to bust on a particular night.

Blame the system, not the poeple who make a living by enforcing it. And please
remember that in their hearts, alot of them believe that they're doing a good
positive thing by busting a rave and taking all of those innocent minors away
from an evil drug-infested environment.

Also, let's take a moment to consider that the promoters surely knew that they
were violating the SF curfew law, and knew that there was a good chance they
would get busted. They took $20 from each of those under-21 folks knowing full
well what might happen. Then, when the inevitable happened, the cops got the 
blame.

Now, as a disclaimer for that previous paragraph, I should state that I have
no idea what the promoters were actually thinking. Maybe they actually thought
they would get away with breaking curfew.

						Pete

From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
To: winston@lurnix.com

Subject: mandatory sentencing
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


actually, i have a friend who was looking at going to court on LSD
charges about 7 years ago.  she moved here after going on tour
following the Dead for a while and started using a fake name.

starting a new identity is the easy part.  the hard part is cutting
all ties to the previous life --- if they "really" want to nail you,
something as simple as a phone call or a post card can land you in a
lot of hot water.

the statute of limitations for LSD is 7 years.  she went back home for
good about 3 months ago.

a good story: after she moved here, she went home to see her sister
get married.  sure enough, the DEA showed up at the wedding looking
for her, and she had to sneak out of the back and hide until they
left.  just one minor drawback to all this.  much better to get stupid
mandatory sentencing laws repealed.

Bob

  doom> (By the way, if anyone has reservations about posting
  doom> "private" email to the net, I'd be glad to discuss that via
  doom> email.  Briefly, I believe someone who sends you mail is
  doom> trusting you to use your discretion, but you aren't sworn to
  doom> secrecy about it.) 

Well, that *might* be a reasonable position to take, but unfortunately
the net is a complex society which has evolved it's own set of rules
and customs...  know as "netiquette".

I'm afraid that whatever you think is or isn't reasonable, it is a
*fact* that within this electronic society posting private e-mail
without the senders consent is considered by many to be inapproriate
and rude.  In netspeak, it's a beach of netiquette.

There doesn't need to be any good reason for this fact.... societies
often have customs that are seemingly arbitrary, and you are of course
free to chalenge them.... but the society is unlikely to accept you if
you refuse to play by its rules...

That was my detatched view... now my opinion.... i think the status
quo (ie not posting private email without the senders consent) is a
Good Thing.  I think that personal attacks on individuals in a public
forum are a Bad Thing (again, some would regard this as a breach of
netiquette, though this one's more open to debate...)

This isn't intended as a flame, i really don't mean to offend anyone.
Just by $0.02 worth, as you americans like to say...

	roy

>     One rather visible thing we can do is to start setting up voter
>     registration tables at raves.  This will plant the idea in the
>     minds of the city government officials that we vote too.  It also
>     implies a level of civic responsibility and all that, making it
>     harder for them to paint us as a bunch of troublemakers.
>     It might also require them to be a bit more careful if they bust
>     us, lest they violate some election law.

We did this once and it is EZ.  Go to the local voter registration office and
just tell them that you are doing an event and you'd like to register people
for the vote.  They'll give you several free books of forms and you just have
people fill them out as they come in the door.  This was right before the last
election and a LOT of people were grateful to have the opportunity.  If you
put it in front of their faces, they're more likely to sign up than if you
pester them with ads.

        Reading the past couple day's rave mail, I think the voting idea is
one of the most brilliant things discussed (other than Laura's YSH playlist
of course). Some friends of mine have their own theatre group and whenever
they have a show, afterwards in the lobby of the theatre they set up voter
registration. The key is to put this option right in front of people, so
they act on it spur of the moment, and lo and behold, they're registered to
vote. Doesn't necessarily mean anything will change, but the more voting
ravers, the better!!!!! Peace

Date: Tue, 31 Aug 93 10:26:16 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <9308311726.AA22213@netcom3.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Radio transmitters and such
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


>    One rather visible thing we can do is to start setting up voter
>    registration tables at raves.  This will plant the idea in the
>    minds of the city government officials that we vote too.

I agree that we should set up voter registration booth or something,   but
now we need some volunteers to do it.    Any takers?   I think that we
can make a difference if enough people get off their guff and write to 
their local politician with their concerns,  things might actually happen.

The Cypherpunks through cooperation of the EFF,  CPSR are certainly making 
a difference in this Clipper chip privacy issues by letting these bozos know
their concerns.   But we have to get enough people to do this.  

Eventually,  our representitives will get on-line and things might be easier
for us to reach them.

>  John> is minimal (Less than $50 to build),  and will make it possible to get
d
>  John> the "No amplification" rules (because thay haven't outlawed radios
yet).

>I was under the impression that 5 watts is way above the point at
>which you need a licence...?

Well!!  It certainly is possible to run a lot lower power and still reach out
to a wide area (up to 1000 ft) with as little as 50 milliwatts.   But it is
highly unlikeley that the signal if kept reasonably contained with proper
antenna placement would generate radio interference complaints.   The FCC
doesn't have the resources to drive all over creation busting little 5 watt
transmitter operators.   They usually act on complaints.    But outide raves
are usually held in more remote areas and if the antenna is placed low and
towards the center of the coverage area,   low power will still send out a
strong enough signal to operate a boom box or car FM radio very well at over
1000 feet.   So I know of few dance areas THAT large.

We used to do this at Peoples park in the early 80's,   and we covered the
area with as little as 100 milliwatts,  and we were able to recive the signal
fairly well at the Berkeley campus.   Although there were houses nearby,  we
kept the antenna close to the ground,   but within line of sight to the radios
that were recieving it.    It worked out very well,  we had no complaints and
I personally went over to a friends house next to Peoples park and checked
their
TV and there was no interference.    Simple responsible things like this can
eliminate possibilities of complaints.   The Xmitter was also fairly clean,
but don't know about Steve's design.    I personally met Steve a month ago and
looked at his design,  it was fairly straight forward,   and I think with
proper
shielding and construction,  interference won't be a problem.

As an Ex-ham radio nerd,  I have built many transmitters in my time,  and know
the pitfalls and gotchas.    Steve's workshop is pretty good and covers a lot
of these issues.   and I recommend that if anyone wants to try this to attend
one
of them.

JD

>   Has anybody seen this before ?

    Not at a rave,
    but Frank Zappa did it at his concerts starting in the '80s.

>                           Does anybody have an idea about what
>   percentage of voting age ravers actually are registered ?

    It might be interesting for a rave to offer a $1 discount to anyone
    who can show they are registered to vote somewhere and see how
    many takers you get.  That will be a lower figure, of course,
    since many registered voters can't find their voter registration
    card (you don't need it to vote, though it is the easiest-to-get
    proof of citizenship that is acceptable for international travel,
    and it's free, unlike a passport or certified copy of a birth
    certificate).

    A voter registration drive can register voters living in any county
    in California.  I live in San Mateo County, and registered as a
    San Mateo County voter, but I actually signed up in San Francisco
    at a voter registration drive here.

>I'm a bit shocked by all this talk of voter registration.  Are you
>telling me that the onus is on the individual to apply to be allowed
>to vote, rather than on the state to ensure that everyone can vote?
>Are you saying that there are a substatial number of people who are
>*unable* to vote in elections....?
>
>Some democracy....

What I'm saying is, people have the right to vote, but to be able to vote
you must register to do so. Now, a lot of people don't take the initiative
to register, so when election day comes, they must pass on voting since
they aren't registered. Voters registration makes sense at raves, because
large groups of people can be registered without each of them making a trip
to City Hall to register. Roy, let's face the facts. A lot of Americans
simply do not exercise their right to vote. This is pathetic, I agree. But
if people are signing up to do so at raves, or other places where large
groups of people congregate, maybe they'll feel an obligation to do their
part and PARTICIPATE in the next election.
I agree, some Democracy.
                                                    Adam Rybaczuk
                                               Northwestern University
                                               Language Laboratories
                        (99.97% inert materials, .03% active ingredients)

Subject: More stuff on FM and other things

In relation to transmitting on FM...

>If this is true, then it might be worthwhile
>trying to operate within the law...

I'm not familiar with CURRENT law,  but under part 15 rules,  they state that
it's legal to transmit for only a distance of 50 feet (Which really means
about 20 milliwatts or less).   But I doubt if it matters to push the distance
to 1000 feet if...   

  a) transmissions last through duration of rave and not all the time
  b) it won't interfere with existing services.
  c) and nobody makes a big stink about it.
  d) and we be discreet about it.

FCC doesn't have the resources to pick up such low power transmissions,  and
even if they did pick it up,   they would have to get an "Agent" out there
to catch the bootlegger in action.    Knowing that raves can happen ANYTIME,
mostly on weekends and late at night,  it is highly unlikeley they would act.

I know this from talking to our local agent at the last CFP (Computers
Freedom and Privacy conference) where I met one of them and asked him this
very question.   He was fairly straight forward and was open with his
information.   The FCC is mostly concerned with higher power transmissions
that might interefere with Aircraft,  military and other services.

Most home brew transmitters are "dirty" and will transmit on many frequencys
unless a proper filter is used.   Construction of such can be trickey,  and
not always straight forward.   

>Unfortunately, Steve's kits seem to be nonexistant except for the flagship 5
>watt model.  Someone here ordered a $5 filter last month and still nothing has
>shown up yet.  Another person on the net has dumped $70 on an order and hasn't
>seen anything at all.  Do any Berkeley people know anything about this?

I don't know,   but I can contact Steve and ask him what the status is when
I get the chance.    I have his home number and will try and find out
if you like.

>    It might be interesting for a rave to offer a $1 discount to anyone
>    who can show they are registered to vote somewhere and see how
>    many takers you get. 

WOW!!  Incredable idea,   Hmmm!   How would I show that I regestered.  I
suppose I could contact the registrar of voters and find out,   but we have
to convince the rave promoters to allow the discount.   Do you think they
would go for it?

JD

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


>What I'm saying is, people have the right to vote, but to be able to vote you
>must register to do so. Now, a lot of people don't take the initiative to
>register, so when election day comes, they must pass on voting since they
>aren't registered.

In the UK the government conducts a census every two years or so to
compile the electoral roll.  Every home in the UK is sent a
questionaire on which they have to list all people over 16 who are
living there on a particular date.  It's a criminal offense to fail to
respond to the questionare, and they make it pretty hard to forget...
they keep sending you reminders and duplicate questionaires.....

Of course, some people *deliberately* avoid returning the forms, or
leave themselves off the forms, because they want to effectively be
"unpersons" to try and avoid paying taxes....  It's pretty futile,
though, because if you ever have a job or claim any kind of state
benefit then the state will find out your name and address anyway....

	Cosmic

The real UK has it's problems too, though....

  Mark> In answer to your question, there are many people who don't
  Mark> register to vote on time or at all, then when election day
  Mark> comes they can't and don't vote.  Trouble is, these tend to be
  Mark> the kinds of people who would offset the votes of right-wing,
  Mark> facist, religious zealot, republicans (or any como thereof).

I guess the important question is, would these people vote if the
system didn't require them to register in advance?  We have a problem
with voter apathy too, but i don't think it's quite as bad as yours.
I don't have any figures to hand, though.  Our system requires less
effort on the part of the voter though....

A couple of people mentioned to me in e-mail that there are plans for
the DMV to register voters.  This still doesn't seem ideal to me,
since it will still exclude people who don't drive or own a car, which
will still but a skew on the results.....  But i guess it'll be
interesting to see whether more people vote as a result of it....


	roy

It's Official: All Permits Have Been Obtained for Marx Meadows, Sunday, 
October 3rd.  I didn't have to lie at all and managed to avoid the R-word 
as well.  But it was close.  Navigating the beauracratic maze at the Hall 
of Justice yesterday, I found myself in the company of a police sargeant 
who after looking over the application asked me "What's SFR?".  I started 
babbling about how we're a group of people who use computers over a network 
to communicate...blah, blah, blah...which is why I couldn't put down an 
address for the 'organization' blah, blah...  His eyes started to glaze over 
and he mumbled "Oh, I was just wondering what SFR stood for." But at this 
point he had lost interest and was eager to be rid of me, so I never had to 
answer his question.

The current DJ Lineup is: Lee An, Markie Mark, Jon Drukman, all SFRavers.  

I'll post the list of $ contributors later in the week, so that those 
who haven't given can be suitably humiliated.  I've received about $250 
so far, about $150 short of break-even.  Any extra $ will probably go 
towards fruit & stuff to be shared.  If there's a lot of extra $, then 
I'll put it towards another event!

We are only permitted for amplified sound from 1-5pm, but I'm gonna try 
to start early and end a little late if I can.  The party *may* continue at 
another location, but this is not yet certain.  The only thing that
can really stop us is the weather.  I'll be establishing a phone # shortly.

If anyone wants to bring voter registration stuff into the fray, that
would be great.  We're not allowed to be selling or soliciting stuff, and 
we're responsible for cleaning up after ourselves and removing garbage from
the premises.  I'll be bringing plenty of garbage bags.

- lee fogel - Promoter of Truth, Justice, and the American Rave

From: abbe@bronze.lcs.mit.edu (John C. Abbe aka Rademir)
Message-Id: <9308312308.AA18060@bronze.lcs.mit.edu>
To: jdrukman%dlsun87@us.oracle.com, roy@harlequin.co.uk,
        sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Drug laws and FIJA
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

roy@harlequin.co.uk said:
>so you're saying that it is the *constituational duty* of the jury to
>judge whether the law is appropriate to the case, and yet it is
>*illegal* to inform a jury of their legal duties...?
 
Close :-). It's legal to inform the jury of their duties, but it is also
legal for the judge to essentially lie by telling them that their *only*
duty is to judge the case on the basis of the facts. It's also legal for
the judge to put anyone who tries to tell the jury of their duty to
judge the law as well in contempt of court. That's why if we want to
get to whoever-it-was's friends' jury, we would have to pamphlet
outside the courthouse.

The precedent was set for this duty in England, in fact, in a case
involving William Penn and freedom of speech. The jury refused to convict
him under an extremely restrictive speech law, and they were thrown in
jail, fined, etc. The case was appealed up to the highest court in the
land and they ruled that the jury had the right to rule however they
wishd, even against the law. Note that this does not strike down the
law, like when the Supreme Court rules a law unconstitutional. It only
lifts it for this particular case.

As long as we're registering voters, how about putting some FIJA flyers
out? I have several dozen..  }:-)

peace,
--John

From: white@sleepy.ctstateu.edu (Harry White)
Message-Id: <9309010016.AA10315@sleepy.ctstateu.edu>
To: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re:  Radio transmitters and such
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hi SFRavers...
I just finished building the FreeRadioBerkeley kit (after 3 weeks of
hacking on it and dealing with problems in the instructions, a couple
of missing parts, etc. It works GREAT, with a solid 5 watt output (had it
up to 12 watts for a few seconds but turned it down to save the power 
transistor and prevent a conflagration at the homestead :) and virtually
NO drift. I'd advise the folks waiting for kits to bug Stephen via email
at stephenpd@aol.com, bearing in mind that this is the GENESIS of
a nationwide micro-radio movement, and I'm sure that he is overwhelmed
(by kit production AND legal issues dealing with his defense against the
ludicrous $20,000 FCC fine). I am working on gathering my notes/mail 
regarding my construction problems/solutions into a doc, and will 
upload it to the FTP site shortly.
As far as converting the FRB kit to stereo, I heard that it can be done
by disabling the audio pre-emphasis circuit on the FRB kit and running
a stereo generator (like the Panaxis SG kit) into the FRB audio input.
I'm getting ready to tackle that one shortly.
FRB probably jumped the gun a bit with the kit offers, but that's what
happens when you get hyperactive hyperintellectual electrical engineers
at the forefront of a movement... You can always go the FM-10 route,
and buy a low-output Ramsey Electronics FM stereo kit and then build all
of the FM-10 pirate toys to boost the output.
Peace
harry
white@sleepy.ctstateu.edu

Subject: xmitters vs voting?
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFRaveMail)
Date: Wed, 1 Sep 93 0:59:15 CDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I missed the beginning of this thread about fm transmitters--what do they
have to do with voter registration?  

The subject line caught my attention, though.  I just today ordered a
Ramsey FM10 kit, to broadcast our next rave to the neighborhood...and
beyond...  The kit only puts out a few milliwatts, but mods to increase
output to 1 watt appear fairly straightforward.  I'd heard about 
Stephen's kit, but too impatient to wait :-)

I like the idea of the $1 discount to registered voters, though as a
promoter who lost money on the last two raves, it's a scary concept.  

To those of you who have avoided voter registration in order to avoid jury
duty:  when you vote in a jury, your views, your opinion, and your beliefs,
can mean the difference between some poor shmuck getting railroaded, or
getting justice.  When you vote in a jury, you lay yourself on the line for
what you believe in.  Do you know that the outcome of cases to test new 
laws have major influence in how those laws are applied in the future?  
In an election voting booth, you can only say what your opinion is, yes 
or no, and diluted by millions of others.  In the jury room, you can say 
what your opinion is, why you feel that way, and help influence the out-
come of something that might change a person's, a family's, even a
community's life forever.  The society you work to influence is the society
you live in.  Jury duty is a *privilege* to be cherished, not a chore to be
avoided.

<OFF SOAPBOX>

*whew*

We now return you to your regularly scheduled discussions.

David

From: John Turpin <turpin@apple.com>
Message-Id: <9309010800.AA24050@apple.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Orbital - Back to the basics!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU





What follows is a little bit if music history and music composition
dialog, so if you aren't interested, don't care, or already
familiar with Steve Reich, you may want to delete now.

I just picked up the new Orbital CD this weekend and WoW!
I think the most interesting songs on the CD are the first
and last songs - 'Time becomes' and 'Input out'.

These two songs utilize a fundamental electronic music concept
called phasing, in which two looped samples are played simultaneously
and one of the samples is either slightly shorter or slightly 
pitched down causing the two samples then to slowly get 'out
of phase' and then slowly work there way back 'into phase', as
the faster loop catches up again with the slower one.

This very simple composition technique can produce surprisingly
complex sequences as the two samples journey around each other
in time and space (if in stereo).

Steve Reich is probably considered the father of phasing. He 
recorded the first ever phasing composition back in 1965 here
in San Francisco called 'It's Gonna Rain', and shortly followed
by the ever popular 'Come Out' in 1966.

Excerpt from CD booklet about 'Come Out':

"Composed in 1966, it was originally part of a benefit presented
at Town Hall in New York City for the re-trial, with lawyers of 
their own choosing, of the six boys arrested for murder during the
Harlem riots of 1964. The voice is that of Daniel Hamm, now aquitted
and then 19, decribing a beating he took in Harlem's 28th precinct
station. The police were about to take the boys out to be "cleaned
up" and were only taking those that were visibly bleeding. Since Hamm
had no actual open bleeding he proceeded to squeeze open a bruise on
his leg so that he would be taken to the hospital. Sample follows -

"I had to like open the bruise up and let some of the bruise blood
come out to show them." With "come out to show them" the actual
sample that is looped and phased.

Two other phasing projects he worked on "Piano Phase" and "Clapping
Music" are performance pieces that are actually performed by
live musicians. "Piano Phase" is two piano players playing the same
monophonic piano pattern as one stays put, and the other slowly changes
the tempo creating the phasing effect. "Clapping Music" is two musicians
clapping a rythmic pattern and one of the patterns is missing a single
beat. This creats a totally different phasing effect.

All of these pieces are incredibly interesting and as shown by
Orbital, way ahead of their time. They can be heard on the highly
recommended CD by Steve Reich called "Early Works".

It is really cool to see some of the Techno musicians picking up
on some interesting alternative forms of composition. I can't 
wait to hear a techno 'Markov Process' song. Hmmm. Maybe a good
project to work on...

In my Electronic Music class in school, we were given a phasing
assigment. I looped a sample from the Art Of Noise - "Hey! Can
I Say Something - Woop Woooo". I think I still have this laying
around somewhere if anyone else out there is interested in 
alternative music composition.

Well, thats it for Music Comp 101 tonight. See ya

johnny t

Beyond the ultraworld of John Turpin:
> 
> I just picked up the new Orbital CD this weekend and WoW!
> I think the most interesting songs on the CD are the first
> and last songs - 'Time becomes' and 'Input out'.
> 
> These two songs utilize a fundamental electronic music concept
> called phasing, in which two looped samples are played simultaneously
> and one of the samples is either slightly shorter or slightly 

Actually, some people call this effect phasing but it is a flanger effect.
Phasing is when you play one source and the second source is the same, with
the second beeing out of phase with the first, but both playing at the same
speed. Usually done with an fx box or a computer. Flanging on the other hand,
is two sources (same) that start playing a little out of phase and as time
passes the difference of phase will grow, then shrink, then grow, etc...

> It is really cool to see some of the Techno musicians picking up

(It's only time they do what Techno DJs have been doing for a while)

> on some interesting alternative forms of composition. I can't 
> wait to hear a techno 'Markov Process' song. Hmmm. Maybe a good
> project to work on...

This effect is as old as reel to reel. I even have a technical note from
Viking on flanging with 2 reel to reel. "Then, by slightly touching the
second flange, you will obtain a variation..." blah blah blah. It is why it
has been called flanging, because of the flange. Oh and the technical note is
from 1959. And since then, it has been used a lot by DJs. As for Markov process
well, you never know! So much has been done (from interactive music, to FSK
modulations, to brownian movements, to pink noise etc...).

> In my Electronic Music class in school, we were given a phasing
> assigment. I looped a sample from the Art Of Noise - "Hey! Can
> I Say Something - Woop Woooo".

One can easily achieve flanging with either 2 reel to reel or 2 turntables.
It is also present on most fx box worth mentioning. On any decent computer,
you have software to do it.

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion

I remember those Reich pieces, as I had to "study" them (NOT a problem)

direct samples from the early era of electronic music.  The musique

I can't recall called something like "bebe cola"  that uses that (title)
phrase in a whole bunch of ways that could be added as a chant/chorus
type thing on a house jam.  now that  you mentioned it, that whole era
 is ripe for sample fodder.  What studio are you working in?

Subject: Re: xmitters vs voting?
In-Reply-To: <9309010559.AA12787@okcforum.osrhe.edu>

Ooooo it appears I have said something not PC.

I believe that everyone should do what they believe is right. My
political agendas aren't yours. Some people believe that military
service should be a civilian obligation. Some believe that voting is a
civilian obligation. Some believe that jury duty is a civilian
obligation. Some people believe that serving a deity is a civilian
obligation. 

I don't necessarily believe or disbelieve any of these things. I have
definite opinions, and I act upon them because my conscience demands
it.

I don't recall telling anyone on this list what I think they should
do. Unless you understand my political agenda _in_depth_ and have
explored thoroughly my personal reasons for doing so, I'd appreciate
it if you didn't tell me what you think I should do. You're making me
feel as if you're trying to convert me to some religion.

A nice, friendly, in-person conversation on the matter would be much
more enlightening. My views are not fixed in stone, and they can
respond to persuasion. But they won't respond to "You should do this."
or "Everyone should do this." I'm constantly surrounded by that kind
of stuff every day. It's actually quite a bit of static for one life.

Sean

From: John Turpin <turpin@apple.com>

Subject: Re: Orbital - Back to the basics!
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU




From the huge ever growing pulsating brain of Francois Dion:

> Actually, some people call this effect phasing but it is a flanger effect.
> Phasing is when you play one source and the second source is the same, with
> the second beeing out of phase with the first, but both playing at the same
> speed. Usually done with an fx box or a computer. Flanging on the other hand,
> is two sources (same) that start playing a little out of phase and as time
> passes the difference of phase will grow, then shrink, then grow, etc...


Yes and No! The flange can be thought of as phasing, but the flange is more
of an effect or sound process and phasing can be thought of more as a
compositional process or tool. Generally, the flange represents very small
amounts of phase difference in which the two sources being played do not
differ by more than several milliseconds. To get the flanging effect that
DJ's use, one source remains constant while the other source is sped up
and the slowed down centering around the constant source, never letting
the two become completely out of phase. Just enough so that you here
this "flanging" effect.

> This effect is as old as reel to reel. I even have a technical note from
> Viking on flanging with 2 reel to reel. "Then, by slightly touching the
> second flange, you will obtain a variation..." blah blah blah. It is why it
> has been called flanging, because of the flange. Oh and the technical note is
> from 1959.

Have you heard the Reich pieces? I doubt if anyone would categorize these
as flanging techniques. Sure flanging has been around for a very long
time, but the Reich pieces are important because they were the first 
pieces to use phasing as the sole fundamental compositional technique.

The point I was trying to make is that it is nice to see modern pop composers,
using some of the techniques pioneered by the founding fathers of electronic 
music.

> One can easily achieve flanging with either 2 reel to reel or 2 turntables.
> It is also present on most fx box worth mentioning. On any decent computer,
> you have software to do it.
 
The techniques used by Reich were  accomlished using tape loops.
Both loops are from the same source, but one loop has a slightly shorter
endpoint, therefore the pitches of the samples do not have to be changed.
A computer could do this easily, but the flange on most effects boxes that
I have seen, could not accomplish this effect at all.

And dont forget that humans can phase too. (Hey, how about this for a pickup
line - "Would you like to uh phase with me" :)  )

The song "Piano Phase" is two piano performers who start off playing the same
melody and then one of them changes the tempo until the two melodies are
completely out of phase. This is very difficult to do. It is a natural human
tendancy to avoid phasing and play along with the other performer.

Well, it is time for me to 'phase' out -

See ya on the back side of the moon -


johnny t

>Wouldn't it be wierd if everyone wore walkmans and the D.J's pumped
>out the sound over the airwaves (heh, an air-rave) to a bunch of
>ravers dancing to only the sound they could here.  That would sure

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Burning Man is on
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


...for this weekend, and the big sound system for rave t00nz _will_ be there.
I'm sure people have heard about it, but for those that haven't: it's in
the Black Rock desert north of Gerlach, NV.  Lots of people, dust, dancing,
madness, and the Man which was about 2.5 stories tall last year and should
be even bigger this year if preparations are any indication.  I recommend
it for an experience broader than "drive, dance, drive".  Anyone else from
the area going?  I've got my ride, but it's far enough away that carpooling
is essential for those who might want to go.  Friday through Monday morning,
suggested donation is $40 to cover insurance, BLM fees, the Man, etc.

I don't have a contact #: I know one was posted earlier.  I'll be there 
with drums, water, food, friends, and RaveLite (a Radio Shack super-hi-
intensity LED powered by AAA batteries -- runs forever and is as bright as
a small flashlight, not to mention being a kool red color).  Moon will
be nearly full, desert will be vast, time will be suspended.  See you there.

// g

i like the idea of registering people to vote at raves, but our registering
isn't really going to maean a thing for us as ravers unless we organize as
ravers to protect our parties by holding our elected officials accountable -
after all - how do we know their positions on rave-busting? it's not exactly
on the evening news... people have suggested that we write, but i think
unless this is an organized effort it won't go very far... we need to choose
our targets, finding out who can do what for us and demand it....
i would also be interested in having mandatory minimum petitions, or better
yet, letter-pwriting tables, set up at eveents... i can do this at ysh if
someone sends me the info..... i'm also wondering if it's feasible to have
some kind of protest about this - outside the courtroom? i think it's
important for thsoe of us who are willing to be open about our support for
psychedelics (if not about our use ) to do so, or at least be open about our
stand against mand. mins..... i'm really pissed off right now cuz i'm feeling
like the dea just came in and grabbed someone from our community and HOW ARE
WEFIGHTING BACK/RESISTING AS A COMMUNITY? are we? or are we just going to
gossip about this and say, "that sux.." i have lots of experience doing
political organizing and if otherz are interested, i'd like to plan
something...i'm new here, tho, so i really do need help, being unfamiliar
with san francisco....
pleaz email me or call 621-4703 if you're interested - maybe we could set up
a kind of raverz response group whenever we're busted or something.... (BTW,
it's probably better to call me cuz i'm only logged in occassionally, since
my computer is busted :( )

ALSO, i have an idea: is it possible to have a political demonstration/rave?
like, we could get permits to have a demo demang our right to dance and
freely assemble, and of course at a demo you need a sound system, and we
could have a few speakers bt mostly have musick... it doesn't have to be
huge, it could be a lot of fun, w could be putting some pressure on, (like,
if you don't let us have our parties we're going to continue with these demos
- and hell, if they ignore us, well, it's still a good party:) ).....

has this ever been tried? what do people think? obvioussly , the event would
be heeavily policed and thus have to be drug free (or at least visibly drug
free), so we'd have to let people know this...anyway, at least we'd have a
good party and demonstrate our opp. to man mins. or whatever we want..

spewing,
monicat

Your right Monica, If the DEA thinks that they can just start busting people
without some noise being made, then they will bust more people.
I'm not talking about hindering them from doing their job in any way, but
It is our duty to protect people in our community from rediculous entrappment
and set ups.  If anyone knows the situation that just went down, it is a case in
point on how arbitrary this whole mess with enforcement of drug laws really is.
It is obviously more about curtailing certain forms of social behavior then 
about protecting people.

Look at all the shit over the gunman at 101 California.  When there is some
crazy  shooting and killing people, the cops take there own good time getting
there, but I bet if someone called and told them that some kids were having
a Rave in the lobby they would call out the riot squad, (like they did at
Pulgas water temple).  I've been in the habit lately of asking cops when
they come to places like YSH whether they have more important things to do
like chasing muggers and rapest then hassleing a bunch of people dancing in a
dirty warehouse.

> pleaz email me or call 621-4703 if you're interested - maybe we could set up
> a kind of raverz response group whenever we're busted or something.... (BTW,
> it's probably better to call me cuz i'm only logged in occassionally, since
> my computer is busted :( )

Good idea.
It is high time that people strt to question the drug laws, specifically
the laws around mandatory sentencing for LSD and other psychedelics.

It is INSANE that a person can get more time for selling a someone a sheet
of acid, then shooting someone in an armed robbery.

From: Lee An <lee@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: Orbital - Back to the basics!
To: Francois Dion <dionf@ere.umontreal.ca>
Cc: John Turpin <turpin@apple.com>, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <9309011539.AA05481@brise.ERE.UMontreal.CA>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.05.9309011928.A12807-b100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



On Wed, 1 Sep 1993, Francois Dion wrote:

> Beyond the ultraworld of John Turpin:
> > These two songs utilize a fundamental electronic music concept
> > called phasing, in which two looped samples are played simultaneously
> > and one of the samples is either slightly shorter or slightly 
> 
> Actually, some people call this effect phasing but it is a flanger effect.
> Phasing is when you play one source and the second source is the same, with
> the second beeing out of phase with the first, but both playing at the same
> speed. Usually done with an fx box or a computer. Flanging on the other hand,
> is two sources (same) that start playing a little out of phase and as time
> passes the difference of phase will grow, then shrink, then grow, etc...
> 
> > It is really cool to see some of the Techno musicians picking up
> 
> (It's only time they do what Techno DJs have been doing for a while)

This is an old DJ trick, quite often overdone. All you have to do, as
Francois has described above, is take two copies of the same record and
match them up. At that point, you can either run the copy together with
the master out of phase, or flange it with the pitch control. Both create
interesting effects.

Lee

today's SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Thursday, 
Time: 12.00 noon
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Park in the first
  carpark to your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  2 02:30:36 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA21627; Thu, 2 Sep 93 02:30:36 PDT
Received: from nkosi.well.sf.ca.us by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA21619; Thu, 2 Sep 93 02:30:28 PDT
Received: from well.sf.ca.us (well.sf.ca.us [192.132.30.2]) by nkosi.well.sf.ca.us (8.6.beta.4/8.5) with SMTP id CAA22991; Thu, 2 Sep 1993 02:30:02 -0700
Received: by well.sf.ca.us id <14286-3>; Thu, 2 Sep 1993 02:29:23 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Long weekend report
Message-Id: <93Sep2.022923pdt.14286-3@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Thu, 2 Sep 1993 02:29:20 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

This starts Thursday with Your Sisters House and goes through today's
Blue Moon Rave . . .

I took my old friend and former housemate John to his *first* Grateful
Dead show and r*** on Thursday night.  He got off pretty well on both,
though he only stayed at YSH for about half an hour.  I thought this
YSH was much less congenial than the TAZ one I attended a couple weeks
ago, and I missed Laura's sets, but did catch Jan Cooley
for her long turn.  It was a struggle, with a narrow gallery space,
various interruptions and the inability of the crowd to really get a
consistent vibe going.  Plus it was Sweatbox City . . . but I had
a good time anyway.

Friday night I crashed at Bob Ramstad's after the last of the three
Dead shows at Shoreline.  We then made our way over to the Greek Theatre
and got in the front of the line for the Phish show -- it was great to be
back in my 'home' venue for the GD on a fine evening.  We did the post-
show prandial thang at North Beach Pizza, after which I took a brief nap,
then rallied to head over to Funky Techno Tribe at the Design Center.

I arrived around 3:15, just in time to find that a couple of cops had
gone in to sweep out the under-21 crew inside.  This led to a rather
amazing hour of confusion.  First the under-21s were herded out, and
they proceeded to set up shop on the sidewalk and in the street, basically
hanging, dancing to tunes from a car stereo and waiting to see what would
happen next.  What happened next was that lots of other people also came
out and were then instructed to come back in through the 'security' line.

While this was going on in generally disorganized fashion, quite a few
people slipped through the 'out' door back inside.  Ultimately it seemed
like most anyone who really wanted to get in did so eventually.

I was impressed with the Design Center space -- a large four-story high
atrium.  Shredder sound and a consistently high-quality DJ list helped
insure that things weren't a total loss for the evening.  By about 5:30
Phil Smart had things really moving, and then Tony took over for another
superb set.  Mr. B. Positive himself, Carlos, and many others of us took
to the floor with abandon as the daybreak started to manifest itself
through the skylights.  The one rather distracting aspect was the number
of people who basically just hung around doing nothing much of anything.
Unlike jslee, I would say that some under-21 and some over-21 types were
involved here.  Just what the heck are people doing going out until 6 am
to stand around and look bored while the rest of us get down with the
sound on the floor or at least go around and have a conversation or two?
I sure don't know but it puts a bit of a damper on the levels . . .

Tony shut down around 7:15, so I headed over to Boogie Buffet.  A slow
start that morning, by the time I left at 10 it was still rather sparse.
But I had an interesting conversation with Rick Webb, the manager, who
turned out to be old friends with a guy I met at the Dead shows (who was
also in town for the Interop network trade show) and was bemusedly taking
in the r*** scene.  Rick has some interest in getting things going on a
tribal tip, which is where I personally think the next wave of excitement
is going to be.

After a quick nap, I tried to glom onto the monthly Bulletproof boat party.
On Friday I'd hoofed it over to BPM to buy a ticket at Bulletproof's
upstairs
counter, only to discover they've pulled out and only have the Haight St.
store now.  Rick Webb had clued me in to a before/during/after party
alongside
the boat trip at Cal's (2001 Union at Buchanan), basically a college
bar which has been taken over as a sort of cool r*** hangout the last couple
of Sundays.  I wasn't able to get a ticket to the sold-out boat trip but
did drop in on the before and after party scene for a while.  This is a
promising space for the usually barren Sunday evening slot . . .

I was in Sacramento on Monday and Tuesday to do some work.  When I arrived
back in SF last night, I was faced with a quandary.  Didn't want to miss
yet another FMR, but I had a plane to catch at 8:00 this morning.  Nor did
I have a ride to the FMR, wherever it might be.  A series of inquiries
soon revealed that the rumored Bonnie Doon location was in fact the
destination.  I called the Together line and found that Simon, Garth and
Neon Leon (?!) were the listed DJs -- which meant that it had to be the
jumping-off point for the FMR.  With nothing to lose, I headed down and
met up with Lee Fogel's brother and another friend.  After checking the
Together scene briefly (in the basement of Big Heart City), we took off
for parts coastal . . .

Arrived at around 3 am to find Route 1 lined with dozens of cars and the
sound system on the beach just firing up.  I had not been to any beach
event yet that actually went off, and with the perfect weather I figured
things would go off in a big way, seeing as how this was at the faled
Bonnie Doon site.  As it turned out, the experience was less than optimal
for the first few hours.  In spite of the superb location and weather,
the crowd seemed to be mostly locals who were more interested in yammering
constantly with each other than getting into the music and surroundings.
In addition, the Nitrous Factor was off the scale.  In a relatively small
crowd I counted at least five separate tanks going at one point.  One or
two might have been OK, but this level of activity definitely put a damper
on things.

In addition, Markie was spinning some of his weirdest stuff and the crowd
was just not getting off on it.  Given my perhaps over-inflated expectations
this was a great disappointment, because it's hard to imagine a nicer
location.  When Jeno started up, however, things seemed to improve as the
hang-out crowd dissipated and the in-the-groove posse started to do its
thing.  It's also likely that my lack of sleep over the last couple of
days colored my reaction.  In any event, Jeno and Garth both provided
consistently solid, relaxed grooves that were conducive to dancing,
sedate toe-tapping and wandering around the site.  Around 9 I found myself
barefoot with my pants legs hitched up, strolling through the surf to the
sublime "Walking on Sunshine" remix . . . a great moment!  Garth
finally shut down around 11:30 and we slowly moved on out and back to the
City.  I was dropped off at BPM and ran into Cin and Mike on a record-
shopping expedition -- and that's it for the diary here!

It's pretty apparent that the scene in SF has hit a kind of plateau for
the time being.  The burst of energy that followed Malachy's accident
seems to have run its course.  I see a lot more non-participative attendance
at events, the DJs are getting a little complacent in their selections, and
in general things seem to be sort of in the doldrums.  But under the surface
I can also see some potentially good new directions.  YSH represents the
emergence of a new kind of non-commercially oriented but nonetheless regular
party, while the trance/tribal scene has yet to emerge in the way I suspect
it will.  The club scene is actually fairly healthy -- a good many of the
weeklies like Boogie Buffet, Together and Mission Rock are sustaining a nice
presence in the scene.  

As for me, the signs are pretty apparent that it's time to 'go home' and see
what kind of good stuff I can help stir up in the Northwest.  The recent
efforts by the Groove Kitchen crew to do some events in Eugene and Portland
bodes well for more of a true West Coast scene than isolated units.  

At the same time, the pressures and dangers apparent from the greed factor,
the growing popularity of nitrous on a petty retail level, resistance from
the authorities on permit and curfew matters, an influx of newcomers with
little clue or inclination about how to take advantage of and add to the
scene, are all worrisome reminders of the supertransient nature of the
scene.  It's a fragile flower . . .

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  2 07:11:00 1993

Proposed schedule for the big labor day weekend:

11pm Thursday - Party at Your Sisters' House
4am Friday - go home and sleep
9am Friday - go to work
7pm Friday - get home, eat, take a nap :)
midnight Friday - wake up, start checking for location of MESS
2am Saturday - head over to MESS
8am Saturday - go home and sleep
4pm Saturday - free time, run errands
midnight Saturday - head over to Basics
8am Sunday - breakfast at Boogie Buffet
2pm Sunday - go home and sleep again or check out Elmo's thing in GG Park.
midnight Sunday - Fluid Groove!  Check out your favorite net.djs
8am Monday - sleep
4pm Monday - wake up, discuss the past, present and future of the 
	American labor movement with your friends, and the role
	of labor unions in a capitalistic society.
11pm Monday - chill out at Jazid Up.
9am Tuesday - back to work :(

        People who want to send money, cards and other goodwill 
	thoughts to Malachy can make checks payable to the:

                1388 Haight st #117
                San Francisco CA. 94112

debatable, but they were advertised by flyers and the music could be
good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their appropriateness 
in being on the list, let me know.  Also let me know when any of them end...

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  2 12:48:36 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA24295; Thu, 2 Sep 93 12:48:36 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA24287; Thu, 2 Sep 93 12:48:33 PDT
Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA03737; Thu, 2 Sep 93 12:48:24 -0700
Message-Id: <9309021948.AA03737@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Thu, 2 Sep 1993 12:48:19 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu
Subject: WC / EC
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hello again,

After sleeping for pretty much 30 hours, I've recovered from Tuesday's
Full Moon Rave out here in San Francisco.  

Anyway, I came out here thinking that things would be vastly different 
at West Coast raves from East Coast ones.  Postings from other visiting 
ne-ravers served to further strengthen this preconception.  Well, now that
I've been to an actual event, I must say that there *basically* is no 
difference between a good party here and a good party back home.

The FMR was held on a beautiful beach along a secluded stretch of coastline.
The beach area was ringed by cliffs, and the sand was soft and the water
blue and cold.  We don't have *quite* the same geography back home, but
various parties held in forests and on mountainsides at home were each
gorgeous in their own unique ways, too.

The music started promptly at 3.00 am (and I understand that this was sort of 
an exeception to what usually happens at the FMR's . . . often the music
doesn't get going 'till closer to 4), and there were a lot of people there.
Where we'd usually have 50-300 people at a party in the East, they had more
like 300-500 people.  Still, if you looked at the ratio of people dancing to
those just laying in the sand, it was pretty much the same fraction of people
dancing in SF as there are at good parties in New York (like the B2B parties).

The people were no more or no less friendly than I've experienced in New
York, and the vibe was quite similar too.  Sure, the party went on till
way after 10.00 am -- but if you figure we start at 11pm back east and they
start at 3am in SF, you get about the same number of music-hours in either
way.  Furthermore, a lot of people arrived at the FMR site around sunrise,
so there was an influx of new well-rested peole to keep things going, whereas
that sort of thing doesn't happen back East.

Although the music was rather different -- varying flavors of low-bpm'ed 
housey stuff -- the crowd responded in the same ways to their local favorites
as we do to ours back east.  I personally didn't dance much, about 15 minutes
to some very white-noisy/mindfucky/acid stuff spun by Markie Mark, and then
a bit more after sunrise, but a lot of other people got a lot of enjoyment
out of what was played.

I need to have my body and brain tweaked a lot by harder tunes before I can
get to the point where I can enjoy house music (the non-vocal/non-piano
break variety) . . . around sunrise Brian and I climbed to the headlands
overlooking the beach and stood on the point where the sun would first
break.  As the sun came over the rim of cliffs, I felt warm and happy and
picked up on the house groove and danced a bit on the edge of the cliffs in
the warm sun (I'd been FREEZING all night).

We left a few hours later, around 10 am.  I was completely exhausted from
being so cold all night and walking around in the shifting sands.  It was
nice and all, but I really did miss the energy and drive of my favorite
types of music.  To each their own . . . the important things were that
the party went off well and that people seemed happy.

Laura

Date: 	Thu, 2 Sep 1993 13:54:45 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I absolutely agree with Mike about Markie's set -- it was great, but I tend
to be in the "weirder the better" crowd as far as this music goes, and
Markie has an absolutely unique record collection and approach to spinning
so I really get off when he goes into orbit.

My definition of 'tribal' may differ somewhat from Mike's.  Since I don't
know much about artists and titles I can't name the names I'd specify as
onna tribal tip, but I've been hearing more and more of it on tapes lately
(maybe that's not the best way to gauge the currency of the scene, of
course).  Nonetheless, I have ulterior motives here, because I think
tribal will go over big-time in the Northwest if anything really gets
moving up here.

One other thing I'm seeing more of in the tribal tradition, and this is
a good trend in the scene, is people bringing drums and providing a
live counter-component to the records.  I've seen this at Boogie Buffet,
YSH and elsewhere, and it works quite well to feather the edges of the
relentlessly perfect beats we hear from the records.

DIRECTIONS:
	From SF and South Bay...
	Take 80 to University Ave. exit
	Make a RIGHT at the 1st stoplight onto 6th St.
	Take 6th to Dwight and turn RIGHT
	Take Dwight to its dead-end at the railroad tracks
	(try to park discreetly a few blocks from the dead-end - 
		there will be people there to direct you)
	Cross the railroad tracks and follow the paved path to 
		your LEFT (South) a hundred yards or so,
		and perk up your ears.

	From Berkeley...
	Take University Ave. going west towards 80
	Turn LEFT at 6th St.
	Follow the directions above

If you forget/lose/misunderstand these directions, remember to 
call Scottie at (510) 549-6253.  His answering machine will 
always have the most current location and directions (call this #
if party gets busted and moved)

house, Le Chateau, 2545 Hillegass Ave., so you wanna chow and 
relax to some mellow tunes after the party, feel free to bring
some food along (or just yourselves) to our house (that's a 
Berkeley address, BTW).

> Markie was spinning some of his weirdest stuff and the crowd
> was just not getting off on it.
I think Markie did a terrific job.  Some of the stuff he played was insanely
weird yet worked very well.  (That track with the motorcycle sound effects
was mindblowing, imho.)  His set did get a bit housy for me towards the end,
but it appeared to me that the crowd was very receptive to it.  (Dancing on
sand is very difficult, though, which is why the dancing never *looks* very
energetic when parties are thrown at Bonnie Dune.)

> In any event, Jeno and Garth both provided
> consistently solid, relaxed grooves that were conducive to dancing,
> sedate toe-tapping and wandering around the site.
Agreed, but I was really looking forward to hearing one of Jeno's relentless
acid sets rather than the toetapping house stuff.  Oh well, maybe next month.

> YSH represents the
> emergence of a new kind of non-commercially oriented but nonetheless regular
> party, while the trance/tribal scene has yet to emerge in the way I suspect
> it will.
The trance/tribal scene peaked in the summer of '92.  (Listen to the Vision 
tapes.)  I'm not sure if anyone even *makes* tribal anymore.  I think the
musical future (as Jon Drukman predicted a few weeks ago) will be a move
towards the style that Markie was playing at the FMR (the Freaky Chakra record
being a perfect example of this style).

	id AA25864; Thu, 2 Sep 93 16:06:45 PDT
Date: Thu, 2 Sep 93 16:06:45 PDT
From: rpcaras@srv.PacBell.COM (Bob Carasik)
Message-Id: <9309022306.AA25864@zeus.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Deep in the Heart of Texas (rave rvw)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



I spent last weekend in Austin TX visiting some old and new friends.
Immediately following a final exam, I red-eyed it to texas and went to
a play called Snake Eyes, a sci-fi parable based on a Bruce Sterling
story about what becomes of people who have been given direct brain
implants that enable them to control fighter planes, the process is
called the Extended Human Interface Training System, pronounced
"E-hits".  Lots of cool computer graphics as the victim / trainees
grapple with the "snake" - the foraces let loose by the biological
implant, which ultimately reveals to them, not the evil interventions
of a computer, but the ultimate challenge, their own nature free of
restraint.  Way fun.  

Then off to the countryside for the Radiance party; the first outdoor
production by folks who have been doing club & warhouse raves in
Austin over the past year or so.  The site was truly godlike: 20 acres
at the end of a 2 mile dirt road which was off a little farm road 8
miles off the two-lane blacktop.  They had a 220-volt outlet and a
bathroom and shower a couple hundred yards back up the road.  Not much
shade, but some trees along the river for a camping area, a largish
swimming hole, free of unexpected rocks, and a big field with the
dance area & dj stage at one side.  The "stage" had a big dropcloth
with the "Blammo" muplitple slide-show projected on it from behind.
People parked along one side of the field ( note: no shuttle van
needed ).  And they had the worlds freshest, newly dug, smell-free
outhouses not too far away, and water available at all times.  An
ambient sound system was promised for the swimming area; while we were
waiting for the main sound system, they put on a variety of music,
from ragamuffin to Glenn Branca-type noiz.  A major high point came in
the late afternoon when they put on some 70s funk and a dozen of us
started backstrokin' in the swimming hole.  "Give Up the Funk" never
sounded so good as it did in greeenish-brown water with little fishies
nibbling at our flesh.

People were trickling in towards evening.  The dj's started up around
9:30 or so, with not much dancing until about 11.  I floated around,
danced a while, talked to the smart-drink and face-painting vendors,
joined the drum circle for a bit.  About 12:30 I went off with a few
folks to do "door" duty for a while. The "door" was a few folding
chairs by the side of the dirt road, 1/2 mile up from the campsite.
There was nobody much arriving at this point, as peak attendance ( 130
) had been reached.  Just an opportunity to hang out under the
undulating bejeweled clouds and a winking almost-full moon, feeling
like the luckiest people in the world.  Saw a few shooting stars.  All
too soon, it was time to go back and rejoin the party.  Which was in
full swing, with a couple solid hours of hard trance, moving into
minimal mechanical acid sounds spun by Herb.  After getting warm from
dancing, the only thing to do was jump back in the ambient swimming
hole, then back to the dance area, and so on.  There wasn't really a
"critical mass" crowd feeling until the final set, but the high level
of eye contact, smiles, and gesture-mirroring made for the sweetest
vibe I've felt in ages.  The final set, by Seville, went from about 7
to 8:30 or so, with high points including ( original version ) "We Are
Family" and "Music Express".  People were dragged back up from their
tents for this part; lots of arm waving and shrieking.  After the
music ended, people hung around packing, cleaning up, and swimming,
until 2pm or so.

It really can get this good, and I hope Penelope's Web can do it.
People primarly came through personal networks more than through
promotion, which amounted to extensive flyering.  The type of event
filtered out the devoidovibe element pretty effectively.  Two
heavy-metal guys left early because they "didn't like the gays in the
river" ( Several people covered in mud, some of whom were woemn,
actually ).  But other than that nothing even remotely unvibeful.
Some alcohol was in evidence, but no alcohol-behavior problems.  Or
N20 for that matter.  The site had been used for pagan festivals
before; one rumor held that the tribe of motorcyclists was coming from
Houston in a couple weeks to practiced Sumerian magic and eat
acid-laced beef.  Texas is too much sometimes.

AstroBoy

Subject:  Long weekend report
Reply-To: jdrukman%dlsun87@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

fred heutte says:

>One other thing I'm seeing more of in the tribal tradition, and this is
>a good trend in the scene, is people bringing drums and providing a
>live counter-component to the records.  I've seen this at Boogie Buffet,
>YSH and elsewhere, and it works quite well to feather the edges of the
>relentlessly perfect beats we hear from the records.

sorry, but i have to dissent here.  after spending hours in the studio
working on beats to get them into that perfect groove, it drives me
nuts to hear some lowly HUMAN sitting there with a drum going off in
his own personal time signature.  i like that "relentless
perfection"... we strive for it all the time, in the studio.  jeno
told my roommate that he really loved the timbale section in "trip
harder" because it sounded like a live person, but i thought it was a
failure on my part because i played it rather sloppily and we didn't
correct all the strikes afterwards.  it still bothers me in places.

Jon Drukman                                      jdrukman%dlsun87@us.oracle.com
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Always note the sequencer - this will never let us down.
